site_title: Smartphone wave boosts Q3 earnings at Unisem
summary: Malaysian chipmaker Unisem posted a 150% year-on-year rise in third-quarter earnings to RM27.1 million, driven by the global smartphone wave and a turnaround in the electronics industry. The firm's restructuring efforts, including cost cuts and product shifts, have contributed to its turnaround. Unisem's stock rose 0.6% to RM1.69 apiece, with analysts predicting a "buy" rating and target price of RM2.00 each.

site_title: Global family businesses open US outposts
summary: At least a dozen global family offices have opened US outposts or made direct investments in US corporations, attracted by the country's economic growth and low-interest-rate environment. These family offices, managing $4 trillion in assets globally, are seeking diversification and unique investment opportunities, particularly in venture capital and private equity. They are often looking for deals in industries such as technology, automotive, and luxury, with some seeking to manufacture yield in a low-interest-rate environment. The US is seen as a "big bright spot" in the world economy, with growth accelerating in the third quarter to its strongest six months in over a decade.

site_title: A platform for Malaysians to network
summary: The Malaysian Association of Singapore (MASIS) was officially launched on October 31, 2014, to foster camaraderie among the over half a million Malaysians living in Singapore. The association aims to provide a platform for networking through various activities, including business and student events, and family outings. Malaysian High Commissioner Husni Zai Yaacob and MASIS president Abraham Vergis attended the launch, with the association's goal of promoting Malaysia-Singapore bilateral relations and helping Malaysians settle in Singapore. MASIS is a non-political organization open to students and people of Malaysian origin.

site_title: Business confidence on the wane
summary: Business confidence in Singapore has waned across both services and manufacturing sectors, according to government surveys. While optimistic firms outnumber negative ones, the magnitude of positive sentiment has decreased, with a 7% positive net weighted balance in the services sector and 1% in the manufacturing sector. The transport engineering sector is the most optimistic, while the electronics and precision engineering clusters project worsening business conditions. The services sector's real estate industry is particularly negative due to the ABSD and TDSR, while retail, accommodation, and food and beverage industries are more optimistic ahead of the holiday season.

site_title: Herbalife to pay US$15m to settle class action lawsuit
summary: Herbalife agreed to pay $15 million to settle a class action lawsuit claiming the company operates a pyramid scheme. The settlement includes $15 million in cash and up to $2.5 million for product returns. Herbalife must also make changes to its business model for three years. The company denies wrongdoing and says the settlement was necessary to avoid prolonged litigation. As part of the agreement, Herbalife will also clarify its membership agreement and define its distributors.

site_title: Pop-up culinary stars
summary: Nordic culinary stars Mads Refslund and Nathan Outlaw will be cooking at the 4XFOUR pop-up dining event. Refslund, co-founder of Noma and champion of New Nordic cuisine, uses foraging to create his dishes, drawing inspiration from nature. He is known for his prize-winning MR restaurant in Copenhagen. Outlaw, a British chef, is celebrated for his seafood expertise. The event will feature their unique culinary styles.

site_title: Russia to resume gas supplies to Ukraine
summary: Russia and Ukraine have signed a deal to resume gas supplies to Ukraine over the winter in exchange for payments funded by Western creditors. The agreement, worth $4.6 billion, includes Ukraine paying $3.1 billion in debt to Russia's Gazprom by the end of the year and $1.5 billion for new gas until March. The deal eases concerns of a "gas war" disrupting winter energy supplies to EU states, with European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso stating that there is now "no reason for people in Europe to stay cold this winter."

site_title: Heady winners
summary: The Peak's fifth edition of the G Top 100 Wines features 100 curated wines from almost 300 entries from 12 countries. The list was selected after blind-tasting sessions by a panel of 13 wine specialists, with Marchesi Di Barolo's "Cannubi" DOCG 2008 as Red Wine of the Year, Van Volxem's "Alte Reben" Riesling 2012 as White Wine of the Year, and Shaw Vineyard Estate's Premium Botrytis Semillon 2008 as Sweet Wine of the Year. The list aims to provide a definitive and authoritative go-to list for wine enthusiasts, solidifying The Peak Selections' reputation as a luxury title.

site_title: Savvy spinoffs
summary: Restaurant owners are expanding their brands with upscale offshoots and avatars, offering unique dining experiences while maintaining quality ingredients and affordability. Examples include Saveur's upscale spinoff, Saveur Art, with French cuisine at reasonable prices, and Selfish Gene Cafe's dessert extension, Selfish Gene Patisserie, which combines Asian and French techniques. GRUB Noodle Bar, a spinoff of GRUB bistro, offers healthier late-night options with natural ingredients. The Gourmet Food Co, a dried seafood wholesaler, has launched a modern purveyor concept with a showroom for restaurant owners and chefs. Hashida Sushi's second outlet, Hashida Garo, will feature traditional Japanese confectionery, a Japanese sake bar, and an interactive art gallery.

images.alt_text: 'We are going to push Selfish Gene Cafe Patisserie as one concept. I want the dessert extension to be integrated with what we already have at our Cafe.' - Chef owner Gene Mok (above) of Selfish Gene Cafe which sprouts its Patisserie on the second floor

HIGH-END OUTING: For Saveur Art, a swankier version of French hawker stall Saveur, owners Joshua Khoo and Dylan Ong will plate up a high-end affair with French fine-dining dishes such as Mangalica Pork.

HIGH-END OUTING: For Saveur Art, a swankier version of French hawker stall Saveur, owners Joshua Khoo and Dylan Ong will plate up a high-end affair with French fine-dining dishes such as Mangalica Pork (above).

PATISSERIE EXTENSION: The second floor patisserie of Sefish Gene Cafe will offer a melding of Asian sensibilities with French techniques such as a twist on Nonya pineapple tarts, with an ensemble of French biscuit, pastry cream, and spiced, roasted pineapples.

HEALTHIER HELPINGS: Guilt-free late-night dining that is now possible with hearty fare from GRUB Noodle Bar, a spinoff of GRUB burger bistro at Bishan Park. The quartet behind the enterprise are (from far left) Dexter Tai, Amanda Phan, Kelvin Lim and Mervyn Phan. The eatery features seafood appetisers that can be paired with German craft beers as well as assam laksa and live tiger prawns.

The eatery features seafood appetisers that can be paired with German craft beers as well as assam laksa (above) and live tiger prawns.

EXPERIMENTAL JAUNTS: Kenjiro Hashida's two passions will come together when he opens his second outlet, Hashida Garo, at the Mandarin Gallery, which will offer wagashi, or traditional Japanese confectionery made of mochi, azuki bean paste and fruit, and often served with tea. Some of the sweet sensations include macarons in flavours such as sakura and yuzu.

Some of the sweet sensations include macarons in flavours such as sakura (above) and yuzu.

site_title: More temporary HDB flats for waiting couples
summary: Singapore is increasing the supply of HDB flats under the Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme (PPHS) by 800 units, bringing the total to 1,950. Couples can now co-rent the units to reduce rental expenses. This change is particularly useful for those renting four-room or five-room PPHS flats with extra space. The scheme provides temporary housing for first-timer married couples with children under 16, as well as married couples awaiting HDB completion or those without children. The increase aims to address the shortage of affordable housing options.

site_title: Barclays takes huge charge for forex probes
summary: British bank Barclays has set aside £500 million (S$1 billion) due to probes into allegations of rigging foreign-exchange market prices. This charge cut into the bank's quarterly profits. Barclays has announced the provision in relation to ongoing investigations into foreign exchange with regulatory authorities.

site_title: HK protests lay minefield for business
summary: Hong Kong's democracy debate has created a challenging environment for businesses, with many opting for silence to avoid straining relations with Beijing or alienating customers and employees. Despite some high-profile employees expressing opinions, companies are generally cautious, with HSBC and JPMorgan distancing themselves from views deemed critical of the protests. Tycoons like Li Ka-shing and Jack Ma have called for restraint, emphasizing the importance of maintaining good relations with Beijing. The delicate balance between free speech and corporate interests has led to a self-censoring approach, with companies weighing the risks of speaking out before making a statement.

site_title: US regulator demands documents on faulty air bags from Takata
summary: US auto safety regulators have ordered Takata Corp to provide documents and answer questions under oath about its potentially defective air bags in millions of US vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has been investigating the issue since June, and critics say the company and regulator have not moved fast enough. Takata has agreed to cooperate fully, but safety advocates claim the delay is inexcusable, and a federal judge is set to hear a case on whether the company should turn over internal documents to consumers' lawyers.

site_title: A natural defence against cancer
summary: A natural supplement, Pomi-T, has shown effectiveness in slowing down the growth of prostate cancer cells through its polyphenol ingredients. The supplement, containing pomegranate, curcumin, green tea, and broccoli, was tested in a double-blind randomized clinical trial involving 203 men with abnormal cell growth. Results showed a 63.8% lower median increase in PSA levels in the Pomi-T group compared to the placebo group. The study's findings have paved the way for more clinical trials on whole food supplements, which have traditionally been limited by funding.

site_title: Gamuda wins right to oversee Klang Valley MRT Line 2
summary: Gamuda Bhd has won the right to oversee the Klang Valley MRT Line 2 project in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. This is part of the conglomerate's dominant role in the country's largest infrastructure development, alongside its partner MMC Corporation. Gamuda is already a key player in the Line 1 project, scheduled to be operational in 2017.

site_title: Walmart to offer more discounted items as price war hots up
summary: Walmart plans to expand its discounted product offerings and broaden its price-matching scheme to include online rivals, amid an escalating price war in the US retail industry. The move comes as competition is expected to be as tough as in 2013, when earnings slumped across the industry. This is the latest sign of a price war that has already seen Walmart's profits drop in the holiday quarter last year, with the company posting six straight quarters of flat or declining same-store sales.

site_title: China's manufacturing growth slows in October: govt
summary: China's manufacturing growth slowed to 50.8 in October, according to the government, marking the weakest pace in five years. This is lower than the 51.1 recorded in September and the preliminary 50.4 figure in a private survey. The slowdown is attributed to a decline in the property sector, which is weighing on overall growth. China's economy expanded 7.3% in the third quarter, below the 7.5% target for the year. The slowdown raises pressure on policymakers to address the economic concerns.

site_title: Heart scans and cancer risk
summary: A recent American Heart Association (AHA) statement emphasizes the importance of minimizing radiation exposure during heart imaging procedures. Experts recommend choosing non-invasive tests with the lowest radiation dose, such as MRI scans, over CT scans and nuclear scans. For those requiring CT scans, selecting a low-radiation dose protocol and undergoing the procedure with an experienced operator can reduce risks. The AHA also advises considering patient preferences and individualizing the decision to use imaging, with the goal of achieving definitive results and minimizing radiation exposure.

site_title: George Yeo joins Wilmar board
summary: George Yeo, Singapore's former foreign minister, has been appointed as a non-independent, non-executive director of Wilmar International, a Singapore-based agribusiness group, effective November 1. Yeo, 60, has experience in both public and private sectors, including roles at Kerry Group and AIA Group. The appointment was made by Wilmar's Nominating Committee and approved by the board.

site_title: Nikkei leaps as BOJ springs a surprise
summary: The Bank of Japan's Policy Board voted 5-4 to launch a major new round of monetary easing, sending the yen to its lowest level since 2008 and Tokyo stocks soaring to a seven-year high.

site_title: Keppel FELS bags US$240m jackup rig contract
summary: Keppel FELS, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, secured a US$240 million contract for a KFELS Super B Class jackup rig from BOT Lease, a company affiliated with The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ. The rig, named Hakuryu 15, is scheduled for completion in 2016 and will be operated by Japan Drilling Co Ltd. The contract is the second KFELS Super B Class rig for JDC, demonstrating trust and confidence in Keppel O&M's proprietary solutions.

site_title: Home loans in focus at banks' Q3 results
summary: Singapore's banking groups report no systemic stress in their mortgage loans despite increased bad mortgage loans at UOB. OCBC and DBS Group Holdings see growth in home loans for next year. UOB's bad mortgage loans rose this quarter, but banks assure investors that there is no systemic risk. Stocks of all three local banking groups rose on Friday.

site_title: Sept bank loans stall on construction dip
summary: Singapore's bank lending declined in September, with a 1.2% increase in total loans to S$605 billion, despite a growth spurt in August. The decline in building loans, the third contraction this year, was attributed to the construction sector's restructuring.

site_title: UIC Q3 earnings rise 37% to S$59.7m
summary: UIC reported a 37% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$59.69 million, driven by a 17% rise in revenue to S$178.38 million. This was boosted by a near doubling in joint venture profits to S$9 million and increased interest in Singapore Land to 99.5%.

site_title: BT bags two awards for financial journalism
summary: BT's Michelle Quah and Lee Meixian won top awards for financial journalism from the Securities Investors Association Singapore, with Quah named Financial Journalist of the Year and Lee Most Promising Journalist of the Year. The Straits Times' Goh Eng Yeow also received a Best Commentary Award. The awards recognize companies for their corporate governance standards and transparency approaches, with DBS Group and Keppel Corporation among the winners. The awards honor journalists' integrity and commitment to good journalism.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market, amid US-EU tariff tensions. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and a similar operating loss compared to H1. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector issues. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Samsung unveils two new mid-tier handsets, driving up share prices
summary: Samsung unveiled two new mid-tier handsets, the Galaxy A3 and A5, featuring fully metal bodies and thinnest smartphones to date. The devices are comparable to the Galaxy S5 in size but have lesser screen resolution quality. The move aims to reclaim Samsung's title as the top brand in the world's biggest smartphone market, following a quarterly operating profit slump and market share losses to Chinese rivals. The Galaxy A3 and A5 will be sold in China in November, with other "select markets" to follow, as Samsung prepares to deliver a riposte to low-priced Chinese competitors.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: OCBC's Q3-14 earnings fell 9% due to lower gains, while its annualized EPS declined 11%. The bank's acquisition of OCBC Wing Hang added 5% to earnings. Parkway Life Reit's DPU and revenues rose 8.5-8.6%, driven by acquisitions in Japan. Indofood Agri Resources' core net profit was in line with expectations, but its earnings forecasts remain unchanged due to a potential boost in Q4-14.

site_title: China's shadow banking sector expands
summary: China's shadow banking sector expanded rapidly in 2013, ranking third largest globally under a new definition, with assets estimated to be around $3 trillion, according to the Financial Stability Board. However, analysts believe the sector's risks are not yet threatening the overall financial system. The Chinese government is weighing new rules to regulate the industry, which has been criticized for its speculative activities and potential impact on the real economy.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P surge into record territory after Japan stimulus
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 surged into record territory in opening trade on Friday, October 31, 2014, after the Bank of Japan's surprise stimulus move lifted global equity markets. The Dow Jones reached 17,348.48, up 153.06 points (0.89%), while the S&P 500 rose 19.08 (0.96%) to 2,013.73, and the Nasdaq Composite Index was up 65.97 (1.44%) to 4,632.11.

site_title: Myanmar Brewery stake: arbitrators rule against F&N
summary: An arbitration tribunal in Singapore has ruled in favor of Myanma Economic Holdings Limited (MEHL) in its dispute with Fraser and Neave Ltd (F&N) over a stake in Myanmar Brewery Limited. The arbitrators affirmed MEHL's rights under a joint venture agreement to buy F&N's stake in the brewery. This decision upholds MEHL's claim to purchase F&N's 51% stake in Myanmar Brewery, a significant move in the country's brewing industry.

site_title: It's the season of scandals in Japan
summary: Japan is experiencing a season of scandals, with two female cabinet ministers resigning over misuse of funds, and allegations of further impropriety surfacing. The scandals have been linked to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet reshuffle, which included more women in key positions, angering male backbench members. Opposition parties have capitalized on the scandals, damaging Abe's popularity, which had been high despite concerns over his policies. The media has intensified its coverage, fueling public cynicism about politicians' antics, a concern for a country that prides itself on being a mature democracy.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. The US stock market opened lower amid fresh tariff threats from President Trump.

site_title: No development charges for 3 former KTM sites in S'pore
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have resolved a land development charge dispute over three former KTM sites, clearing the way for joint mega property projects worth $11 billion. The Permanent Court of Arbitration ruled that M+S Pte Ltd, a joint venture company, does not have to pay development charges for the sites in Tanjong Pagar, Kranji, and Woodlands. The decision allows for the full implementation of the 2011 Points of Agreement, paving the way for closer collaboration between the two countries on transport connectivity, trade, and investment.

site_title: Fancy some chocolate in the raw?
summary: Raw chocolate maker Frederic Marr is showcasing his product at Paris's Salon du Chocolat, touting it as a "super food" due to its lower heat treatment of cocoa beans. Proponents claim this process preserves the health benefits of chocolate. Marr describes raw chocolate as similar to sashimi, inviting customers to try it.

images.alt_text: COOL BEANS: Mr Marr trying to tempt customers into getting a taste of his raw chocolate at the Salon du Chocolat in Paris.

site_title: Bank of Japan expands monetary easing plan as economy slows
summary: The Bank of Japan expanded its monetary easing plan by up to 20 trillion yen (US$182 billion) to 80 trillion yen annually, aiming to revive growth amid a slowing economy. The move sent the yen plummeting and stocks soaring, as the economy contracted 7.1% in the second quarter. The decision follows the Federal Reserve's end of stimulus and contrasts with the US economy's 3.5% annualized growth in July-September. The BoJ acknowledged the sales tax hike's impact on inflation and aims to maintain momentum despite risks of a delayed deflationary mindset.

site_title: Branson shocked as Virgin spaceship crash kills pilot
summary: Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo crashed on a test flight in California, killing a pilot and scattering debris across the desert. The accident has raised questions about the program's future. Virgin Group founder Richard Branson expressed shock but vowed to continue pushing forward with commercial space flight. Branson acknowledged that setbacks are a natural part of the development process and emphasized the need for perseverance. The incident is a significant setback for Virgin Galactic's ambitious plans to offer space tourism to the public.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui buys 50b yen of healthcare assets
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp has agreed to buy 50 billion yen (S$586 million) of healthcare assets, including Senri Chuo Hospital in Osaka and senior homes in cities like Tokyo, from Orion Partners. This purchase is part of the bank's plan to list a real estate investment trust. Demand for senior housing in Japan, with over a quarter of its population expected to be over 65 by the end of 2014, is driving the investment.

site_title: Redundancies up in Q3, employment growth rates hold steady: MOM
summary: The number of workers made redundant in Singapore rose to 3,400 in the third quarter of 2014, mainly due to business restructuring, with 1,900 in the services sector and 1,300 in manufacturing. Despite the increase, unemployment remained low at 1.9%, with 52,600 residents and 46,700 citizens unemployed. Total employment grew 27,100, with services generating the majority of employment gains. The tight labor market is expected to continue, with employers needing to remain vigilant to keep productivity high and secure talent.

site_title: Danone buys 25% of China infant milk firm
summary: Danone SA has acquired a 25% stake in China's Yashili International for $550 million, gaining entry into the infant milk formula market in China. The deal is part of Danone's efforts to regain market share in China after losing ground last year due to high prices, bribery, and food safety concerns. Yashili specializes in infant milk formula products, and the acquisition is expected to boost Danone's presence in the Chinese market, which is estimated to double in size to $31 billion by 2017.

site_title: Fragrance Group's Q3 net profit rises 6.7%
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 6.7% increase in Q3 net profit to S$24.3 million, driven by the absence of non-controlling interests in the prior period. Earnings per share rose to 0.4 Singapore cent from 0.3 Singapore cent last year. The company attributed the increase to the completion of the Parc Rosewood project.

site_title: Crossover charisma
summary: The Mercedes-Benz GLA45 AMG 4Matic is a compact SUV that offers a perfect balance of performance, luxury, and practicality. Powered by a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 360hp and 450Nm of torque, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in under 5 seconds. The 4Matic all-wheel-drive system and 7-speed DCT transmission provide excellent grip and refinement. The GLA45 features a sporty design, luxurious interior, and features like Artico synthetic leather and red accents. With a starting price of $289,888, it's a desirable performance luxury choice.

site_title: Plug & play ahead for SMEs in chemical sector
summary: Singapore's JTC Chemicals Hub @ Tuas View is set to open in 2016, offering plug-and-play solutions for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the chemical sector. The $67 million development features safety-compliant features, shared facilities, and a strategic location near major industrial estates. By clustering companies in one development, SMEs can save up to 50% on land costs and reduce setup time. The hub is expected to cater to the chemical sector, which accounts for one-third of Singapore's manufacturing output.

images.alt_text: S$67 MILLION PROJECT: Situated on a 1.6 hectare site and consisting of 14 modular units of 1,200 square metres each, the hub will bring chemical companies closer to their customers

site_title: STI rallies 1.2% on upbeat US GDP, Japan stimulus
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rallied 1.2% to 3,274.25 on Friday, boosted by the US GDP's strong third-quarter growth and the Bank of Japan's expansion of its monetary stimulus plan. The Nikkei 225 surged 4.8% to a seven-year high, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and China's Shanghai Composite also rose. However, analysts note that key risks include slowing growth in China and the eurozone, as well as oil price volatility.

site_title: China completes first mission to moon and back
summary: China successfully completed its first mission to the moon and back, with an unmanned probe re-entering and landing safely in northern China's Inner Mongolia region. The probe took incredible pictures of the Earth and moon before traveling at 11.2km per second before re-entering the atmosphere. The mission tested technology for China's Chang'e-5 lunar probe, set to launch in 2017. The achievement marks a significant step forward for China's ambitious space program, demonstrating its growing technical expertise and global stature.

images.alt_text: China completed its first return mission to the moon early Saturday with the successful re-entry and landing of an unmanned probe, state media reported, in the latest step forward for Beijing's ambitious space programme.

site_title: US regulators fine Ferrari US$3.5m for not filing reports
summary: US regulators fined Ferrari $3.5 million for failing to file required safety reports over a three-year period, despite being required to do so since 2011. Ferrari admitted to violating the law and failing to report three fatal incidents. The fine comes as Fiat Chrysler Automobiles announced plans to spin off Ferrari as part of a five-year expansion project.

site_title: Tokyo Disney Resort to undergo US$4.5b expansion
summary: Tokyo Disney Resort is set to undergo a $4.5 billion expansion, including doubling the size of Fantasyland and creating a new themed port at DisneySea Park. The 10-year plan aims to alleviate customer dissatisfaction and attract more users, following the park's full capacity. The expansion will feature special viewing areas, enhanced restaurants and shops, and a 500 billion yen investment. This move comes as Disney undertakes similar projects globally, including a new resort in Shanghai and renovations in Paris. The expansion is expected to boost visitor numbers and improve customer satisfaction.

site_title: First lawsuit over MH370 filed in Malaysia
summary: A Malaysian family has filed the first lawsuit over the disappearance of MH370, a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board. The lawsuit, filed by the family of Jee Jing Hang, claims negligence by Malaysia Airlines and government agencies. The family is seeking damages for breach of contract and negligence. The lawsuit comes as Malaysia Airlines faces financial struggles and criticism over its response to the disappearance. The chances of success for the lawsuit are unclear due to the lack of evidence and international law, which typically requires the airline to prove it was not to blame.

site_title: Estonian man faces cyber scam charges in US
summary: An Estonian man, Vladimir Tsastsin, 34, faces US cyber scam charges for allegedly hijacking online traffic and swindling advertisers out of $14 million. He was extradited to a federal court in New York to face charges of computer intrusion, wire fraud, and money laundering. Tsastsin and accomplices infected over 4 million computers with malicious software, rerouting internet users to websites where advertisers paid for fake visits. The scheme, known as "click hijacking," earned the group at least $14 million between 2007 and 2011.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,855.15, up 12.37 points on Friday, with 2.75 billion lots valued at RM2.40 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 663-248.

site_title: Minimal space, maximum impact
summary: Kian Liew, head of global interior design management, transformed a 1,163 square foot two-bedroom apartment into a visually interesting and functional space despite its small size. Liew, who owns the apartment, utilized careful planning and renovation to create a cozy home that suits his needs, including a compact kitchen, expanded dining area, and a balcony that doubles as a secondary dining area. The apartment features a muted palette, Asian art, and black-and-white photographs, making it his favorite place to relax.

site_title: The myth of pay for performance
summary: The concept of "pay for performance" is misleading as performance is hard to measure objectively and is influenced by external factors. Employers often tie compensation to financial results, which can be misleading, and employees may not see a direct link between pay and performance. Instead, companies should evaluate individual performance based on competencies, attitude, behaviors, and corporate values, and provide feedback and training to improve. Linking compensation to market value of the individual is a more sensible approach, and companies should focus on other important factors such as benefits, status, security, opportunities, and culture.

site_title: Philippine pension fund may divest artworks
summary: The Philippines' largest state pension fund, Government Service Insurance System (GSIS), is considering selling artworks worth around $20 billion, including pieces by Juan Luna and Fernando Amorsolo, to shore up returns and raise its equity investments. The fund aims to meet its annual returns target of at least 8.5% to meet its obligations to 1.4 million workers. GSIS president Robert Vergara plans to divest the art collection, which is valued at around $1.7 million for the most valuable piece, to invest in high-yielding assets and boost its equity portfolio to 20%.

site_title: Jakarta workers seek 33% rise in minimum pay
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's government is negotiating a new minimum wage for Jakarta, with workers seeking a 33% increase to combat rising fuel and food costs. However, the country's main employer group argues that such a hike would lead to job cuts, citing unaffordable labor costs. The government must balance pro-business policies with promises to help the nation's poor, with the outcome having significant economic implications for the country and its manufacturing sector.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine and PSA take top Asian awards
summary: Sembcorp Marine and PSA received top Asian awards at the Lloyd's List Asia Awards 2014. Sembcorp Marine's Sembmarine Integrated Yard won Best Shipyard of the Year for its commitment to safety, while PSA was selected as Port Operator of the Year for its innovative approach to productivity and endurance. China Export Import Bank was chosen as Newsmaker of the Year for its role in revitalizing the Chinese shipbuilding sector.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index gaining 39.94 points to 3,274.25, driven by 352 gainers and 100 losers. 1.73 billion shares valued at S$1.49 billion were traded.

site_title: HSBC board member's 'slave' slur slammed
summary: HSBC board member Laura Cha sparked outrage after likening Hong Kong protesters' demands for democracy to the emancipation of slaves, saying they can "wait for a while" for free elections. Thousands signed an online petition denouncing her comments, with many calling for an apology. The remarks come amid growing tensions between Hong Kong's pro-democracy activists and the government, with Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying recently criticizing free elections as unacceptable. The controversy is the latest to drag HSBC into Hong Kong politics, following earlier moves to pull advertisements from pro-democracy publications.

site_title: Tencent teams up with IBM to offer business software over the cloud
summary: Tencent Holdings has partnered with IBM to offer business software over the cloud, targeting small and medium enterprises in the healthcare and "smart city" industries. This move marks a departure for Tencent, which is best known for its consumer Internet industry. The partnership aims to provide Tencent's cloud unit with industry expertise and enterprise reach, competing with Alibaba Group Holding's nascent cloud efforts.

site_title: MPs raise questions on SMEs, economy, Ebola
summary: Singapore MPs have filed 72 questions for next week's Parliament sitting, covering topics such as the government's plans for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the impact of the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The questions also touch on the 2013 Labour Force Survey report, which revealed a relatively high unemployment rate for degree holders below 30. Additionally, MPs will discuss Singapore's labour productivity growth rates and the government's response to the Ebola outbreak, including a potential travel ban on affected nations.

site_title: S'pore market value falls for third month
summary: The Singapore stock market fell for the third consecutive month, with a 0.4% decline in October, marking the lowest aggregate market capitalization since March. The decline was widespread, with 430 companies losing value and 230 gaining, but smaller companies took a disproportionate hit. Key sectors, including oil and gas, consumer goods, and real estate, were negatively impacted. Financials and Reits, however, remained resilient, with the finance sector's market cap rising 1.2% and Reits gaining 1.7%. Analysts expect the market to remain rangebound for the rest of the year, with some potential for recovery in the holiday months.

site_title: Business optimism wanes for Singapore's manufacturing sector: EDB survey
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has become less optimistic, with 8% of over 400 polled manufacturers expecting better business conditions from October to March next year, down from 6% in the previous survey. A net weighted balance of 1% indicates a decline in overall sentiment. The transport engineering and biomedical manufacturing sectors are the most optimistic, while the electronics and precision engineering clusters project worsening business conditions due to seasonal softness in orders, particularly in semiconductor-related equipment.

site_title: Geopolitical crisis impact 'not long term'
summary: A geopolitical crisis typically has a short-term impact on markets, failing to alter underlying trends. Historically, markets have recovered quickly, and investors are better off buying on dips or staying put. Key indicators of an escalating crisis include superpower involvement and globally desirable commodities like oil. However, rare events like widespread biological or nuclear use can have a lasting impact. In contrast, financial crises, such as the 2008 global financial crisis, can have a deeper and more lasting impact on markets.

images.alt_text: MR MOORE: Recovery from a financial crisis is always longer than a political one. Investors do badly when they don't distinguish one crisis from another.

site_title: DBS interested in buying RBS's Coutts: CEO
summary: DBS Group Holdings is interested in buying Coutts International, the non-UK private banking business of Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS). DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expressed confidence in acquiring another business following the successful integration of Societe Generale Private Banking Asia. RBS plans to exit its international private banking business, with Coutts' operating profit decreasing by 9% in Q3 due to higher restructuring costs. The sale is expected to be handled by Goldman Sachs and may occur by the end of the year.

site_title: Chinese home prices fall again in October: survey
summary: China's home prices dropped 0.4% on average in October, marking a sixth consecutive month of decline, according to a private survey. This marks the first fall in 22 months on an annual basis. The government has implemented measures to boost the housing market, including cutting mortgage rates and down payments. Despite this, property developers remain focused on reducing inventories, and the cooling real estate market continues to impact various industries, with demand slowing and banks becoming more cautious about lending.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries opens 2nd cogen plant and technology and innovation centre
summary: Sembcorp Industries has opened its second cogeneration plant and technology and innovation centre in Singapore. The S$635 million gas-fired facility has a capacity of 400 megawatts of power and 200 tonnes per hour of process steam, increasing Sembcorp's combined power generating capacity by 50%. The new centre houses laboratories and research facilities to develop innovative processes and test emerging technologies, enabling Sembcorp to efficiently manage its international energy and water operations from Singapore.

site_title: World stocks rally after Japanese stimulus
summary: Global stocks surged on Friday after the Bank of Japan's surprise increase to its stimulus operations, boosting markets from Asia to the Americas. The BoJ added up to $182 billion to its asset-buying scheme, bringing it to 80 trillion yen annually. This move countered a slowdown in the Japanese economy and delivered a boost to equities, with the Nikkei index rising 4.8% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a new high of 17,390.52. The dollar also strengthened against other major currencies.

site_title: SMRT's Q2 profit jumps 75.5% to S$25.3m
summary: SMRT Corp reported a 75.5% surge in Q2 net profit to S$25.3 million, driven by improved performance in train and bus operations, as well as higher profitability from taxi, rental, and advertising businesses. Revenue increased 6.0% to S$314.0 million. The company also raised its interim dividend to 1.5 Singapore cents, up from 1.0 cent last year. Net profit for the first half climbed 54.9% to S$47.6 million, with shares closing 2.5 cents higher at S$1.49.

site_title: Taiwan's economy expands 3.78% in third quarter
summary: Taiwan's economy expanded 3.78% in the third quarter, beating forecasts, driven by corporate investment in electronics, machinery, and metals. This represents the best performance since 2012, with full-year growth estimated at 3.41%. Domestic capital spending rose 7.89% on-year, while private consumption grew 2.43%. The country's food industry was impacted by a "gutter oil" scandal, which led to a lower-than-expected growth rate.

site_title: Higher revenue, takeover of Singapore Land help lift UIC's Q3 net profit to S$59.7m
summary: United Industrial Corporation (UIC) has posted a 37% year-on-year increase in third-quarter net profit to S$59.69 million, driven by higher revenue and a near doubling in share of profit from joint ventures. The company's interest in Singapore Land has also contributed to the improved bottomline, with UIC increasing its stake to 99.5%. For the first nine months, net earnings rose 26% to S$274.87 million, and earnings per share increased to 4.3 Singapore cents.

site_title: Juncker's EU Commission takes office
summary: Jean-Claude Juncker's European Commission took office on October 31, 2014, with a goal of making the EU's executive arm less bureaucratic and more political. Juncker, the former Luxembourg prime minister, has delegated key powers to vice-president Frans Timmermans, who will oversee six "supercommissioners." The Commission faces significant challenges, including a stalling economy, skepticism from European voters, and major crises such as the Ukraine conflict and US trade negotiations. Juncker aims to kickstart a €300 billion investment plan to boost the EU economy and ease tensions within the bloc.

site_title: India's April-Sept infrastructure output grows at 4.0% year-on-year
summary: India's annual infrastructure output grew 4% between April and September, according to government data. The sector accounts for 37.9% of India's industrial output. No further information is available from the provided article.

site_title: Next 50 years will present new tourism challenges
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for Singapore to continually improve the quality of its tourism experience and value to attract visitors, as the country faces new challenges in the next 50 years. The tourism industry must grow by investing in capabilities, skills, and income levels for Singaporeans, and employers and workers must play a role in this effort. The government will provide incentives to support employers and workers, and the Singapore Tourism Board will encourage industry partners to upgrade and work alongside it.

images.alt_text: MR LEE: Also spoke of the need to continually refresh our tourism offerings and deepen the engagement with Singaporeans

site_title: Daimler to buy 25% stake in Italy's MV Agusta
summary: Daimler has agreed to buy a 25% stake in Italian motorcycle manufacturer MV Agusta as part of a long-term cooperation deal. The German car maker will purchase the stake via its AMG performance cars unit and take a seat on the board of directors. Financial terms were not disclosed. This move marks Daimler's entry into the motorcycle market, expanding its presence in the performance cars segment.

site_title: SMRT's Q2 profit up 75.5% at S$25.3m
summary: SMRT Corp's net profit surged 75.5% to S$25.3 million in Q2, driven by improved performance in train and bus operations and higher profitability from its taxi, rental, and advertising businesses. Revenue rose 6.0% to S$314.0 million, with operating profit increasing 66.5% to S$33.3 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents, up from 1.0 cent in the previous period. Despite a challenging fare business environment, SMRT shares closed 2.5 cents higher at S$1.49 on Friday.

images.alt_text: SMRT Corp's net profit spiked up 75.5 per cent to S$25.3 million for the second quarter ended Sept 30 on improved performance in its train and bus operations, as well as higher profitability from its taxi, rental and advertising businesses.

site_title: Japan's vast public pension fund says to double stock investment
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) is doubling its stock investment to 50% of its $1.26 trillion portfolio, aiming for higher returns to cope with a rapidly aging population. The fund's president, Takahiro Mitani, said the shift is designed to generate long-term returns with minimal risk. The new portfolio will allocate 35% to low-yielding domestic bonds and 15% to foreign bonds, with the remaining 50% in domestic and foreign shares. The move is seen as a response to Japan's struggling economy and shrinking workforce, with the fund's assets equivalent to a quarter of the country's economy.

site_title: China's central bank data implies up to US$82 bln in short-term injections in September
summary: China's central bank may have issued up to $81.81 billion in short-term loan facilities in September to prop up investment without over-liquifying the economy. The injections, with tenors of three months, were received by major commercial banks such as Bank of China and China Construction Bank. The move is seen as part of the central bank's efforts to keep lending rates low and prevent strains on the cooling economy, amidst a backlog of IPOs and seasonal factors.

site_title: Eurozone inflation slightly higher in October
summary: Inflation in the 18 countries sharing the euro edged up slightly in October, with consumer prices rising 0.4% and core inflation remaining stable at 0.8%. This suggests that price deflation can be avoided, giving policy makers hope. The European Central Bank is committed to an expansionary policy and may hold off on further measures, considering the better-than-forecast economic sentiment figures. Unemployment in the eurozone remained unchanged at 11.5% in September.

site_title: German retail sales post biggest drop for 7 years: official data
summary: German retail sales dropped 3.2% in September, the largest monthly decline in over 7 years, according to official data. This follows a 2.3% increase in 12-month sales and a 1.3% rise from January to September compared to 2013. The data suggests the German economy, traditionally a growth engine for Europe, is stalling, potentially pulling the eurozone back into recession.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia CEO says to step down around year-end
summary: Garuda Indonesia's CEO, Emirsyah Satar, will step down within months, citing current regulations preventing a CEO from serving more than two five-year terms. He will focus on Citilink's growth before leaving, aiming to improve frequencies and network coverage. Garuda aims to contain operating costs, despite posting a first-half loss. The airline has confirmed an order for 50 Boeing 737 Max aircraft and has no plans to buy additional widebody planes. Satar expects competition to spur consolidation among airlines in Indonesia, potentially leading to just three or four strong carriers.

site_title: US consumer spending weakest in eight months, savings jump
summary: US consumer spending declined 0.2% in September, the first drop in eight months, as demand for goods tumbled and services barely rose. Adjusted for inflation, spending fell 0.2%, the first drop since April. Savings jumped to $732.2 billion, the highest level since December 2012, as income growth outpaced consumption. The slowdown in consumer spending may be temporary due to lower gasoline prices and expected wage growth, but it could add to expectations of slower growth in the final three months of the year.

site_title: India's April-Sept fiscal deficit nears 83% of full-year target: govt
summary: India's fiscal deficit for April-September reached 82.6% of its full-year target, totaling 4.39 trillion rupees (US$71.5 billion). This is an increase from 76% during the same period last year. The government's net tax receipts were 3.23 trillion rupees (US$52.60 billion) in the first half of the fiscal year. The high deficit poses a challenge to the government's financial management.

site_title: Janet Yellen walks into a bar...
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen walks into a bar and jokes about the end of QE2 in 2011, comparing it to the Queen getting a fright. The article then shifts to a series of unrelated news stories, including a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, a decline in US weekly jobless claims, and China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Layoffs up in Q3, employment growth rates hold steady: MOM (Amended)
summary: The number of redundancies in Singapore rose to 3,400 in the third quarter of 2014, a sign of ongoing business restructuring. Employment growth was 27,100, lower than the previous quarter and a year ago. Unemployment rates dipped slightly to 1.9% in September. Total employment reached 3,577,000, a 3.6% increase from last year.

site_title: Asia stocks surge, yen dives on US data, Bank of Japan move
summary: Asian markets surged, with the Nikkei reaching a seven-year high, after Japan's Bank of Japan expanded its monetary easing scheme. The yen dove to 111 yen per dollar, while the US released forecast-busting economic growth data. Asian stocks rose 4.83% on the Nikkei, with the US dollar near a 30-year high against the yen. The Bank of Japan's move aims to boost the economy and avoid recession.

site_title: Sony reports narrower Q2 loss than estimated on strong PlayStation 4 sales
summary: Sony reported a narrower Q2 operating loss of 85.6 billion yen ($771 million) than estimated, driven by strong PlayStation 4 sales, which reduced the impact of a sluggish smartphone division. The company maintained its full-year net loss forecast at 230 billion yen. Shares rose 0.8% after the announcement, contrasting a 4.8% gain in the Nikkei benchmark index.

images.alt_text: Japan's Sony reported a second-quarter operating loss on Friday that was narrower than analysts had estimated, as blockbuster sales of its PlayStation 4 games console reduced the impact of a sluggish smartphone division.

site_title: Construction firms find formal qualifications for workers a stumbling block
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has announced that construction firms must have at least 10% of their Work Permit holders qualified as Higher Skilled (R1) workers by 2017. This will be phased in over two years, with firms required to upgrade 5% of their workers by 2015 and another 5% by 2016. Firms that fail to meet the targets will face hiring curbs. The move aims to increase productivity in the construction sector, but raises concerns about the cost and feasibility of upgrading workers, particularly those with language barriers.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: DBS' not seeing stress in Singapore mortgages, says its CEO
summary: DBS Group Holdings, a Singaporean bank, reported no stress in its mortgage book, with non-performing loans (NPLs) for housing standing at $110 million as of September 30. CEO Piyush Gupta attributed this to the quality of the bank's portfolio, which includes more owner-occupiers and HDB home loans. In contrast, UOB and OCBC Bank reported higher NPLs tied to high-end mortgages. DBS expects Singapore mortgages to grow $3.7 billion to $3.8 billion for the full year 2014, with total group housing loans reaching $51.8 billion in Q3.

site_title: Obama slams Republicans over minimum wage as vote looms
summary: US President Barack Obama criticized Republicans for blocking minimum wage increases ahead of the midterm elections, which could redraw the US political map. Obama argued that 28 million Americans would benefit from a $10.10 minimum wage, and that low-wage workers are mostly women. Despite his low popularity, Obama plans to make appearances on the campaign trail, backing Democratic candidates in key states. His approval ratings have hovered around 40%, a critically low level for a sitting president.

site_title: Sept consumer spending in first drop in 8 months
summary: US consumer spending declined 0.2% in September, the first drop in 8 months, due to a decline in demand for goods and a slight increase in demand for services. However, wages in the third quarter rose 0.8%, the largest increase in 6 years, suggesting a temporary slowdown. Consumer sentiment also rose to its highest level in 7 years, with expectations of a rebound in spending growth in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: HAPPY HOLIDAYS: With pump prices at a four-year low and better wage growth, consumer spending is likely to rebound in the end-year holiday period.

site_title: Panasonic raises profit outlook as restructuring kicks in
summary: Panasonic raised its full-year operating profit outlook by 13% to 350 billion yen, driven by restructuring and cost-cutting measures. The company returned to a net cash positive position for the first time in five years, with a 15% rise in July-September operating profit to 94.7 billion yen. Panasonic's auto business saw a 31% increase in operating profit, with plans to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in Tesla's new battery factory in the US. The company's restructuring efforts have eliminated unprofitable product lines in smartphones, plasma TVs, and semiconductor chips.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up 0.89% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.89% in opening exchanges on Friday, driven by data showing the US economy grew faster than expected in the third quarter. The Hang Seng Index increased 211.65 points to 23,913.69.

site_title: US third-quarter wage gains largest since 2008
summary: US labour costs rose 0.7% in the third quarter, the largest gain since 2008, according to the Employment Cost Index. Wages and salaries increased 0.8% in the period, the largest since the second quarter of 2008. This uptick in wage growth is a sign that a long-awaited pick-up in wage growth is underway, according to Federal Reserve officials. The 12-month increase in labour costs was 2.2%, the largest since the second quarter of 2011, and wages and salaries rose 2.1% in the period.

site_title: Singapore's services sector less sanguine about next half year: DoS survey
summary: Singapore's services sector is less optimistic about the next six months, with 18% of firms expecting improved business conditions and 11% anticipating slower business. The net weighted balance, a measure of business sentiment, is at 7%, lower than the previous edition. All industries except real estate are optimistic about business conditions until March 2015. The negative sentiment in the real estate industry is attributed to government measures, including the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty and Total Debt Servicing Ratio.

images.alt_text: Firms in Singapore's services sector are less upbeat about their short-term business prospects than they were a quarter ago.

site_title: BOJ unexpectedly eases monetary policy further
summary: The Bank of Japan unexpectedly eased monetary policy in a 5-4 vote, increasing the pace of base money expansion to 80 trillion yen (US$726 billion) per year. The BOJ also increased government debt purchases by 30 trillion yen, extended JGB holdings to 10 years, and tripled its purchases of exchange-traded funds and Japan real estate investment trusts. The decision was made due to concerns over a decline in oil prices and deflation, aiming to boost consumer prices and shift sentiment. The move is seen as a further easing of monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher, Mengniu up after Danone deal
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.3% to close at 23,998.06, driven by strength in the Chinese market and increased risk appetite following US growth data. This marked the market's largest monthly gain since July, with the Hang Seng Index up 3.0% for the week and 4% for October.

site_title: Update: Court rules development charges not payable for 3 former Malayan Railway plots of land in Singapore
summary: A Singaporean court has ruled that development charges on three former Malayan Railway sites in Singapore will not be payable to M+S Pte Ltd. The decision was made by the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, following a 20-year dispute between Singapore and Malaysia over the 1990 Points of Agreement (POA) to relocate a railway station. The ruling allows Singapore to move forward with joint development projects with Malaysia, including transport connectivity and trade and investment. Both countries have agreed to abide by the decision and work together to strengthen bilateral cooperation.

site_title: Asset sale not on cards for Bakrie Group: sources
summary: Bakrie Group, an Indonesian conglomerate, plans to negotiate with creditors to restructure part of its $8 billion debt instead of selling major assets. The company, which has missed debt payments several times, aims to restructure its debt through a long-term plan, despite risking frustrated creditors. Foreign creditors may not be able to enforce judgments in Indonesia, making it more likely for Bakrie to work out its debt problems independently. The company's coal business has been hit by low coal prices, but its leaders believe they can ride through the challenge and make a strong comeback.

site_title: EU bid to limit card fees set to win full backing
summary: The European Union is set to back plans to cap interchange fees on debit and credit card transactions, aiming to reduce charges imposed on retailers. The fees, collectively agreed upon by banks and card providers, have been targeted for over a decade due to their anti-competitive nature. The EU's executive arm proposes a comprehensive regulation to curb the fees, focusing on consumer cards. American Express, the largest credit card issuer, may not be fully affected, but would have to comply with fee caps when working with other companies.

site_title: NOL posts Q3 net loss of US$23m
summary: NOL Group reported a Q3 2014 net loss of US$23 million, marking its fourth straight loss, due to a decline in its container shipping business. Revenue remained unchanged at US$2.06 billion, while APL's container shipping business saw a 2% year-on-year drop. However, the group's cost-efficiency efforts resulted in a 31% reduction in core Ebit loss to US$59 million, and US$290 million in cost savings. NOL's supply chain management business, APL Logistics, reported an 8% year-on-year revenue increase.

site_title: Foreign access to China's card clearing market next August: report
summary: Chinese regulators plan to allow foreign firms access to the yuan-denominated credit card clearing business starting in August 2015, breaking a state-owned monopoly. The move, announced by the State Council, aims to open up a market worth over $1 trillion a year. Foreign companies such as Visa Inc and Mastercard may benefit from the change, which follows criticism from the World Trade Organisation in 2012. The People's Bank of China has yet to comment on the date.

site_title: Flamboyant finesse
summary: Italian fashion is experiencing a quiet renaissance, with brands expanding overseas and showcasing their heritage of craftsmanship and quality. After decades of being associated with extravagant designs, Italian fashion is now emphasizing elegance and refinement. New brands, such as Giudi and Boggi Milano, are offering affordable luxury and real-world chic, while established labels like Roberto Cavalli and Brunello Cucinelli continue to uphold high standards of quality and craftsmanship. The 60 Years of Made In Italy exhibition at Scotts Square showcases the evolution of Italian fashion, highlighting its dedication to using rare and exclusive materials and innovative techniques.

site_title: Can they finally QE-it?
summary: The US Federal Reserve may consider quantitative easing (QE) to boost the economy, which has been sluggish. This comes after the US economy showed signs of slowing down. The Reserve has been closely monitoring the economy and is considering various measures to stimulate growth. If QE is implemented, it could provide liquidity to the market and stimulate economic activity. However, the Reserve has not made any official announcement on QE yet.

site_title: Sembcorp partners EMA in S$10m fund to commercialise energy research
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered the Energy Market Authority to fund S$10 million for the commercialization of new energy technology. The initiative aims to identify areas where research and development can benefit from collaboration with technology providers and researchers. Successful applicants will work with Sembcorp to develop their applications in an industrial setting. The partnership was announced at the opening of Sembcorp Technology and Innovation Centre on Jurong Island, which also includes a cogeneration plant with a generating capacity of 400 megawatts.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is partnering the Energy Market Authority to put up S$10 million to fund the commercialisation of new energy technology.

site_title: Govt to expand supply of temporary housing for newly weds
summary: Singapore's government plans to increase the supply of temporary housing for newlyweds under the Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme (PPHS) by 800 flats, bringing the total to 1,950 units. Couples will also be allowed to co-rent units to reduce rental expenses. The PPHS provides affordable temporary housing for first-time married couples with children or those awaiting the completion of their HDB flats. This expansion aims to support couples with growing families and reduce their financial burden.

images.alt_text: The supply of HDB flats under the Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme (PPHS) will be bumped up by 800 flats, in addition to the current supply of 1,150 such flats.

site_title: Samsung Electronics shares rally on earnings, shareholder returns hopes
summary: Samsung Electronics shares surged 4.2% on the second consecutive day, driven by hopes of a fourth-quarter rebound and potential share buy-back program. The company's third-quarter operating profit fell 60.1%, but strong demand for TVs and memory chips is expected to boost sales. Market players anticipate a share buy-back to boost stock prices, although Samsung has not confirmed plans.

site_title: Japan consumer inflation slows to 3.0% on-year in September: govt
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation slowed to 3.0% year-on-year in September, down from 3.1% in August, according to official data. The decrease is attributed to the easing of inflation growth, which slowed from 3.3% in July and June. The rate is half of the Bank of Japan's 2.0% inflation target for next year. The slowdown is largely due to the impact of a sales tax increase from 5.0% to 8.0% in April.

site_title: US probing Standard Chartered over Dubai banking: sources
summary: US authorities are investigating London-based Standard Chartered Plc over potential US sanctions violations related to its banking for Iranian-controlled entities in Dubai. The probe is based on evidence from a separate investigation of BNP Paribas, which pleaded guilty to sanctions-busting charges and paid $8.9 billion in penalties. Standard Chartered is under pressure to revive the bank and cut costs after a 31% slump in its share price this year, and the investigation may lead to another fine or extension of deferred prosecution agreements.

site_title: Japan Sept jobless rate rises to 3.6%: govt
summary: Japan's jobless rate rose to 3.6% in September, the highest since June 1992, as the jobs-to-applicants ratio declined for the first time in over three years. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate increased, while the number of new job offers rose 0.5% from the previous month. This suggests the labour market is losing momentum, with economists' median forecast pointing to a reading of 3.6%.

site_title: Japanese life insurers see further, slower shift to foreign bonds
summary: Japanese life insurers plan to buy more foreign bonds in the next six months due to low domestic bond yields, which have fallen to 0.460% due to the Bank of Japan's monetary easing programme. Despite this, the pace of buying is expected to slow, and most purchases will be made with currency hedges. Japanese insurers collectively manage over $1.65 trillion in assets and have increased foreign bond purchases in the first half of the year, but will likely continue to shift their investments due to low domestic yields.

site_title: Bank not seeing stress in Singapore mortgages: Gupta
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the bank is not seeing stress in its Singapore mortgage book, with non-performing loans (NPLs) for housing at S$110 million as of September 30. This is unchanged from June 30 but down from S$119 million a year ago. Gupta attributed this to the bank's portfolio quality, citing a larger proportion of owner-occupiers and HDB home loans. He also expects Singapore mortgages to grow S$3.7 billion to S$3.8 billion for the 2014 full year, up from earlier estimates of S$2 billion to S$2.5 billion.

site_title: The end of QE...again?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is ending its third round of quantitative easing (QE) and concluding its asset purchase programme. This move may reduce the likelihood of a fourth round of easing, but the economy's progress is being closely monitored. The decision comes as the Fed faces the zero lower bound problem, limiting its ability to set short-term interest rates. The end of QE3 may indicate a stronger US economy, but the possibility of future easing cannot be ruled out, given the risk of a financial catastrophe.

site_title: Samsung seeks China turnaround, unveils mid-tier handsets with premium feel
summary: Samsung Electronics unveiled two mid-tier handsets, the Galaxy A3 and A5, with premium designs and metal bodies, aiming to regain its title as the world's top smartphone brand. The devices will be sold in China in November and in select markets, with lesser screen resolution quality compared to top-of-the-line Galaxy S5. The move follows a quarterly operating profit slump and market share losses to Chinese rivals, with Samsung likely accepting lower margins to preserve market share and growth volume.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics unveiled two new mid-tier handsets with a premium design as it prepared to deliver a riposte to its low-priced Chinese rivals and reclaim its title as the top brand in the world's biggest smartphone market.

site_title: Hisaka's shareholders to place out 13m shares to raise public float
summary: Hisaka Holdings announced a placement agreement to raise its public float by issuing 13,375,636 consolidated shares at 82.5 cents. The move aims to increase the company's shares held by the public to at least 25% of its issued share capital. CIMB Securities is the placement agent, and the Singapore Exchange has given Hisaka a month to complete the compliance placement. The Offer Information Statement was lodged with the authority on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 8.96 points to 3,243.27. Volume was 112.4 million shares worth S$278.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 34. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, as traders seem to brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: DBS' Q3 net profit up 17%
summary: DBS Group reported a 17% increase in its third-quarter net profit to S$1 billion, up from S$862 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Android co-founder Andy Rubin to leave Google
summary: Andy Rubin, co-founder of Android, is leaving Google to start a company supporting startups in technology-hardware products. Rubin previously headed Google's robotics effort and built Android into a free, open-source software platform used by major handset manufacturers. He will be replaced by James Kuffner, a research scientist at Google. Rubin's departure follows Sundar Pichai's takeover of the Android division last year, which brought mobile software, applications, and Chrome browser under one roof. Rubin's new company will focus on supporting startups in technology-hardware products.

site_title: Building a community
summary: Singapore's Business Excellence (BE) initiative has celebrated its 20th anniversary, thanks to the support of passionate practitioners and assessors. Introduced in 1994 by Cham Tao Soon and Freddy Soon, the initiative has grown into a robust management system and process recognition framework. The SQA Governing Council and Management Committee oversee the awards, comprising the SQA with Special Commendation, Singapore Innovation Award, and People Excellence Award. Assessors from certified organizations volunteer to conduct organizational diagnostics, providing insight to help organizations strengthen their management practices. The BE initiative has also established international networks, aligning with global excellence models and fostering collaboration among countries.

site_title: Asia shares rally after US growth figures
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday after the US released forecast-busting economic growth data, boosting concerns about the global outlook. The US economy grew at an annualized 3.5% in July-September, stronger than expected, and led to a rally in Japanese stocks, with Tokyo climbing 1.73%. The US dollar edged back towards 110 yen, while US stocks surged, with the Dow adding 1.30%. The data also sparked speculation about an earlier interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, which could impact global markets.

site_title: EU, Russia, Ukraine seal breakthrough gas accord
summary: Russia has agreed to resume gas deliveries to war-torn Ukraine through the winter, with the EU-brokered deal signed in Brussels. The three-year agreement, worth billions of dollars, will ensure supplies until the end of March, with Ukraine paying $3.1 billion by the end of the year to settle outstanding bills. The deal aims to ease the crisis over Ukraine, but the EU and Russia have yet to make progress on the wider conflict.

site_title: Stocks to watch: banks, Tuan Sing and Starhill Reit likely in focus
summary: Investors are focusing on banks, developers, and Reits reporting quarterly results. DBS Group reported a 17% increase in net profit to S$1.01 billion, while OCBC and UOB saw their profits rise 62% and 18.7%, respectively. However, UOB and OCBC were affected by declining Singapore home prices. Property developer Tuan Sing Holdings' net profit tripled to S$17.53 million, and Starhill Global Reit's distribution per unit increased 5% to 1.27 Singapore cents.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.02% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.02% on Friday, defying poor Japanese economic data, as the dollar strengthened against the yen following robust US economic growth data. The Nikkei 225 index increased 158.94 points to 15,817.14. Investors also welcomed news that Japan's national pension fund would double its domestic stock holdings. The dollar jumped to 109.32 yen, up from 109.08 yen, and fueled speculation of an earlier interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Hiring business drives LinkedIn's revenue beat
summary: LinkedIn Corp reported better-than-expected quarterly profit and revenue as its hiring business drove growth, with revenue from Talent Solutions rising 45% to 61% of total revenue. Strong growth in the hiring business and international expansion in China are seen as key drivers for the company's future growth. Despite forecasting current-quarter results below expectations, LinkedIn's shares rebounded after a brief selloff, trading up 3% at $209.12. The company reported a net loss of $4.3 million and earned 52 cents per share, excluding items.

site_title: Court rules development charges for 3 former Malayan Railway land in Singapore not payable
summary: A court ruling in The Hague has determined that development charges for three former Malayan Railway sites in Singapore will not be payable to M+S Pte Ltd, a joint venture company with 60% stake by Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional and 40% by Singapore's Temasek Holdings. The decision was made if M+S had developed the lands according to proposed land uses set out in the Points of Agreement.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore flat in September: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore remained flat in September, with total domestic banking unit loans unchanged at S$605 billion, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Consumer loans rose 0.5% to S$234 billion, driven by higher housing loans and credit card debt, while business loans declined.

site_title: Osim unveils ambitious expansion plans for TWG Tea
summary: OSIM International has unveiled expansion plans for TWG Tea, aiming to open 7 outlets by the end of 2014 and 15-20 in 2015. The company plans to open new locations in Phnom Penh, Abu Dhabi, Shanghai, and Guangzhou. Osim expects to open an outlet in Beijing in the first half of 2015 and two more in Bangkok by year's end. The company also plans to launch its flagship massage chairs and smaller products in 2015, with costs estimated at S$1 million per store.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation is planning to list a data centre real estate investment trust on the Singapore Exchange mainboard. Jaya Holdings reported a net loss of S$43,000 in its first quarter, with no revenue generated. The Hour Glass bought a Sydney property for A$32.8 million. Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit increased by 8.9% to 2.90 Singapore cents in its third quarter.

site_title: UK consumer morale edges down as economic outlook clouds -GfK
summary: British consumer morale edged down in October to -2, its lowest level since February, as households lost faith in the economy's prospects over the next 12 months. This marks the second consecutive month of decline, with the index falling from -1 in September. The decline is attributed to a weakening economic outlook, which has slowed Britain's rapid economic recovery in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: British consumer morale edged down for a second month in October as households showed less faith in the outlook for the economy, a survey by researchers GfK showed on Friday.

site_title: Percentage of Fed Board women economists tracks US average
summary: The Federal Reserve has reported that around a third of its economists are women, a figure in line with the national average. This comes as Fed Chair Janet Yellen aims to improve diversity efforts, citing the field of economics still having a long way to go. Yellen emphasized the need for progress in recruiting and promoting women and minorities into the institution. The findings are part of a broader push to increase diversity in the profession.

images.alt_text: Around a third of the economists at the Federal Reserve's Washington headquarters are women, a figure in line with women's representation in the profession nationally, according to a Reuters analysis of Fed employee data.

site_title: 20 Years of superior performance
summary: Over 1,000 local organisations have improved their performance against international benchmarks through the Business Excellence initiative, a framework that promotes continuous improvement and sustainable quality growth. A study by the National University of Singapore Business School found that organisations certified to the framework experienced an average profit growth of 14.1% between 2008 and 2012, double that of their industry peers. The initiative has been instrumental in helping small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) establish structured management practices, resulting in improved customer satisfaction and reduced employee turnover.

site_title: Canadian PM Harper unveils family tax breaks ahead of election
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper has unveiled C$26.76 billion in family tax cuts and benefits over six years, starting this year, ahead of the country's election in October. The measures include C$3.07 billion in cuts and benefits for the current fiscal year and a C$2,000 cap on the "income-splitting" tax break, which allows parents to transfer C$50,000 of income to a lower-earning spouse. The plan is projected to cost C$4.62 billion in 2015/16 and could limit opposition parties' room for maneuver in the upcoming election campaign.

site_title: World Bank to cut net 250 jobs
summary: World Bank President Jim Yong Kim announced a net 250 job cuts, the first major reductions under his reorganization plans. The cuts will be made in the Institutional, Governance and Administrative units, with around 70 unstaffed positions also eliminated. The reductions are aimed at better aligning staffing with the bank's strategy, offset by adding 250-300 jobs in the operations center in Chennai, India. The move is part of Kim's efforts to transform the bank's operations and focus on eliminating poverty.

site_title: A channel for excellence
summary: UOB Group Channels, the retail network of Singapore's largest bank, has achieved business excellence through technology investments and people development. The bank has introduced innovations such as teller assist units, paperless account opening, and seated queues, resulting in a 36% growth in retail revenue over the last five years. UOB has also received several awards, including the Singapore Quality Award 2014 and being named the Best Retail Bank in Singapore and Asia-Pacific. The bank's efforts focus on delivering a superior customer experience through training and technology, with a goal of transforming the branch banking experience.

site_title: US: Wall St up on GDP, earnings; fund year-end lifts winners
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by strong quarterly economic growth and upbeat earnings reports, including Visa. Healthcare and utilities sectors led gains, despite the Federal Reserve's statement that the economy is strengthening. Analysts attribute the sector's performance to mutual funds' year-end purchases of top-performing stocks.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose on Thursday, boosted by a strong reading on quarterly economic growth and by another round of upbeat earnings reports including Visa, which accounted for nearly 140 points in the Dow industrials.

site_title: Asia-focused ANZ reports record profit of US$6.5b
summary: ANZ, one of Australia's four major banks, reported a record annual net profit of US$6.5 billion, up 15% from last year, driven by its Asia-focused growth strategy. Cash profit increased 10% to US$6.3 billion. The bank's international business in Asia Pacific, Europe, and America accounted for 24% of group revenues, with cash profit from Asia rising 25% and revenue growing 10% over the past five years. Despite a slowing macro environment, ANZ aimed to achieve 25-30% of earnings from outside Australia and New Zealand by 2017.

site_title: A lesson in customer service
summary: ACS (Independent) school in Singapore has successfully adapted the Business Excellence framework to serve its students, winning the Singapore Quality Award twice.
