site_title: Hot stock: OSIM continues to get battered, down 5%
summary: OSIM International's share price fell 5% to S$1.835, down 10 cents, after reporting a 28% drop in net profit to S$16.4 million for its third quarter. Analysts CIMB Research and Macquarie Group downgraded OSIM to "Hold" and "Underperform" respectively, citing weak profits and a lower target price of S$2.37 and S$1.90. Despite being a free cash flow business, CIMB expects profits to remain weak before improving.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won fall on Fed outlook; Samsung Elec rallies
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.11% to 1,958.93 points on Thursday, amid a hawkish tone from the US Federal Reserve. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) initially dropped 0.9% before recovering due to Samsung Electronics' 4.5% rally. The South Korean won declined 0.6% to 1,055.5 to the dollar, as the dollar rallied on the Fed's economic outlook.

site_title: Microsoft launches wearable fitness device for US$199
summary: Microsoft launched the "Microsoft Band" wearable fitness device for $199, marking its entry into the wearable technology market. The wrist-worn device monitors pulse rate, calorie burn, and sleep quality, and is available in limited US quantities. The device is accompanied by a health app called Microsoft Health, which collects data from the fitness band and works on iPhones, Android smartphones, and Windows Phones. The launch comes ahead of Apple's Apple Watch, priced at $349, and follows Microsoft's health app launch in September 2014.

site_title: OCBC says impact of housing loan drop to come in H2 of 2015
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien stated that the impact of a 40% drop in Singapore housing loans will be visible in the bank's second-half 2015 results. This decrease in housing loans, compared to the same period two years ago, is attributed to the sharp drop in housing loans. OCBC reported a 62% rise in third-quarter net profit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened marginally higher on October 30, 2014, after the US Federal Reserve ended its easy money policy and reaffirmed interest rates at record lows for next year. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 21.87 points to 23,841.74.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise, NZ stocks hit record high on upbeat outlook
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, driven by financials and consumer stocks, despite the US Federal Reserve's expected end of its stimulus programme. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a seven-week high, with Coca-Cola Amatil shares rising to a two-month peak. The mining sector was weaker due to under pressure commodities prices. New Zealand shares also hit a record high, with the NZX-50 index up 0.2%, supported by positive company earnings and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's interest rate decision.

site_title: China's Baidu says mobile investment a priority as Q3 revenue falls short
summary: China's Baidu Inc reported a 52% increase in third-quarter revenue, but fell short of expectations. The company's mobile investment remains a priority as mobile traffic surpassed PC traffic for the first time, accounting for 36% of total sales. Baidu forecast a 45.4-49.6% rise in revenue for the current quarter and plans to invest in mobile search product refinement and new products, including Baidu Connect. Despite a 1.6% decline in US-listed shares, executives took a long-term view, emphasizing the importance of mobile investments.

site_title: SGX issues 'trade with caution' on United Envirotech
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a "trade with caution" on United Envirotech Ltd following a 13.5% surge in its share price between October 28 and October 29. The company stated it was unaware of the reasons behind the trading activity. SGX advised shareholders and investors to exercise caution when dealing in the securities.

site_title: China market regulator says Shanghai-Hong Kong connect in 'final stage': state media
summary: China's Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect scheme is nearing completion, according to a senior official at the China Securities Regulatory Commission. The scheme, which aims to liberalize China's capital markets, was initially expected to launch on Monday but has been delayed. The launch is seen as a milestone in China's efforts to increase market openness. Key issues, including taxation, remain unclear.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.36 points to 1851.87. Trading volume reached 17 million lots worth RM7.6 million, with 80 gainers and 51 losers.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank launches first USD sukuk mutual fund
summary: Malaysia's Maybank Asset Management has launched its first USD sukuk mutual fund, investing partly in Islamic bonds from Gulf countries. This is a rare move for Malaysian funds, as demand for dollar-denominated sukuk has grown despite an abundant supply of local ringgit-denominated sukuk. The fund will initially be available to Malaysian investors, with plans to distribute it overseas. This launch comes as sukuk funds continue to expand, with 36 funds in Malaysia holding $1.9 billion in assets, and Malaysia adjusts its tax structure to favor other types of sukuk.

images.alt_text: The asset management arm of Malaysia's Malayan Banking Bhd, the country's largest lender, has launched its first US dollar-denominated mutual fund that invests in Islamic bonds.

site_title: NOL looking for buyers for APL Logistics arm: Bloomberg
summary: NEPTUNE Orient Lines (NOL) is seeking buyers for its APL Logistics unit, with potential buyers including CJ Korea Express, which has expressed interest in growing its business outside Korea. The sale is expected to fetch at least US$1 billion. NOL has reported a net loss of US$151.68 million in the first half, and the shipping group is forecast to post a fourth straight annual loss due to slowing economic growth and excess capacity. The company has sent sale documents to potential buyers and is asking for first-round bids by the end of November.

site_title: Hot stock: Yongnam shares surge 20% on news of contract win
summary: Yongnam Holdings shares surged 20% in morning trading after winning a $1.4 billion contract to build Myanmar's second international airport. The company, along with two other consortium partners, will design, construct, operate, and maintain the airport under a 30-year public-private partnership agreement. The stock jumped 4 cents to 24.3 cents per share, with 24.3 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Lorenzo signs term sheet for S$100m funding, acquires rights to Gene ID in Asia
summary: Lorenzo International has signed non-binding term sheets with JE Capital for S$100 million in funding and Genetik Inc to acquire Asia-wide rights to Gene ID, a Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments- certified molecular laboratory specializing in DNA sequencing. Gene ID provides services for cancer diagnostics and treatment customization. The terms of the definitive agreement will be discussed.

site_title: Samsung Elec Q3 operating profit down 60.1% on year
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 60.1% decline in third-quarter operating profit to 4.1 trillion won (US$3.90 billion), the lowest in over three years, due to shrinking earnings from its mobile division. The mobile division's profit dropped to 1.75 trillion won from 6.70 trillion won a year earlier. This marks the weakest performance since the second quarter of 2011.

site_title: Bank of England chief economist wants global coordination on financial risks
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andrew Haldane advocates for global coordination on financial risks to prevent future crises. He suggests synchronizing policies on bank lending and other issues, and tracking global fund flows in real-time. Haldane proposes further measures, including international macroprudential policy coordination, to tackle asset managers and global markets. This approach is seen as more practical than coordinating national monetary policies, which could help mitigate the risk of financial instability.

site_title: South Korea Sept factory output edges up but misses forecasts
summary: South Korea's industrial output rose 0.1% in September from the previous month, missing market forecasts and falling short of recovering a 3.9% drop in August. The annual increase was 1.9%, compared to a 2.8% drop in August. Service-sector output also rose 0.1% in September, following a 0.3% gain in August. The data contradicts market expectations of a 1.9% gain in September.

site_title: Apple in talks to sell iPhone in Iran: report
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks to sell the iPhone in Iran if sanctions are eased, according to the Wall Street Journal. If successful, Apple would join other companies, including Boeing, in entering the large but inaccessible market. The talks involve discussing partnerships with Iranian distributors to sell Apple products at "premium resellers" without opening any Apple-branded stores. The US decision to lift rules on consumer communications technologies in Iran may have paved the way for Apple's potential entry into the market.

site_title: OCBC Q3 net profit up 62%, beats estimates
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest lender, reported a 62% rise in quarterly net profit to $1.23 billion, beating estimates. The profit growth was driven by strong loan growth, higher margins, and a one-off gain from a China-related acquisition. Excluding the one-off gain, the net profit was slightly below the forecast of $845 million.

site_title: Blumont now holds 30% deemed stake in Toronto-listed Powertech Uranium Corp
summary: BLUMONT Group has acquired a 30% beneficial interest in Toronto-listed Powertech Uranium Corp after a share restructuring. Powertech completed a 10-for-one consolidation and a private placement for CAD$5 million. Blumont, through Powerlite Ventures, initially held 49.46 million shares in Azarga Resources, which held 45% of Powertech's issued share capital. Following the restructuring, Blumont beneficially owns 18 million shares in Powertech, representing 30% of the issued and outstanding shares.

site_title: Nintendo to develop "quality of life" device to track sleep, fatigue: CEO
summary: Nintendo plans to develop a "quality of life" device to track sleep and fatigue, in partnership with US firm ResMed Inc. The device, expected to be available in 2016, aims to analyze sleep and fatigue using gaming expertise. This is Nintendo's first foray into healthcare, with the division expected to turn a profit in 2015/2016. The company already offers fitness games on its Wii console. By leveraging gaming know-how, Nintendo aims to create a fun and useful product.

site_title: Australia's total new home sales flat in September, strong demand for multi-units
summary: Australia's new home sales remained flat in September, with a 11.0% increase in multi-unit sales offset by a 2.3% decline in detached house sales. Total sales remain at historically high levels, consistent with a healthy year for dwelling construction. Record-low interest rates have driven home price increases and higher clearance rates, while approvals to build new homes trend higher. The Housing Industry Association expects a healthy year for dwelling construction, with the exception of detached and low-density construction.

images.alt_text: Sales of new homes in Australia were flat in September, with strong demand for multi-units offset by a moderate fall in detached house sales, an industry survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: AA Reit unveils DPU of 2.77 cts for Q2, up 0.7% from a year ago
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.77 cents for its Q2 2014, up 0.7% from the previous year. Net property income rose 8.2% to S$19.7 million, while distribution to unitholders increased 19.2% to S$17.3 million. The trust's portfolio is diversified across sectors and property types, with a stable contribution from its investment in Optus Centre in Sydney. Managers remain cautiously optimistic for the rest of the year, despite some pressure in the industrial property sector.

site_title: National Australia Bank plans UK exit after slide in annual profit
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has made exiting its UK operations an "absolute priority" after a 10% decline in annual cash profit due to writedowns for its troubled UK business. The bank's UK operations, including Yorkshire and Clydesdale bank branches, have been a persistent issue, with charges for bad and doubtful debt responsible for annual profit declines four times since 2008. NAB is examining options for the UK business, including a public float, and has already sold non-performing loans and shuffled key management roles.

site_title: LionGold allays concerns over funding for its operations after audit disclaimer
summary: LionGold has sought to reassure shareholders that it can obtain sufficient funding for its operations despite failing to get a clean bill of health from auditors. The company has reviewed its fund-raising initiatives, including a proposed rights-cum-warrants issue and unsecured convertible bonds, and believes it will be able to raise sufficient funds in the next 12 months. The directors have also obtained a loan of S$7.5 million from a high-net-worth individual. LionGold's auditors have issued a disclaimer of opinion for the fiscal 2014 financial statements due to uncertainties over funding and an ongoing investigation.

images.alt_text: Liongold, which has failed to get a clean bill of health from auditors PwC for its latest full-year financial results, has sought to assure shareholders that it is able to obtain sufficient funding for its operations.

site_title: IndoAgri's Q3 net profit up 1.6%
summary: IndoAgri, a leading edible oils and fats manufacturer, reported a 1.6% increase in its Q3 net profit to Rp124.8 billion, driven by higher sales volume and commodity prices. Revenue rose 17% to Rp3,602 billion, with the plantation division contributing significantly due to higher sales of palm products. The company expects Indonesia's domestic demand for palm oil to remain strong, with 58,406 ha of immature oil palm planted.

site_title: Olivier Lim back as Australand chairman
summary: Olivier Lim is set to return as chairman of Australand Property Group, a move seen as a commitment to good corporate governance by the new independent board. Frasers Centrepoint, which acquired Australand in a takeover, has appointed Lim to lead the board despite plans to keep the company private. Lim previously served as Australand's chairman until CapitaLand sold its stake, and will oversee investments in various regions and businesses. The appointment aims to restore transparency and accountability to the company.

site_title: PLife Reit's Q3 DPU rose 8.9% on higher rents, new assets, net income hedge
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported an 8.9% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.9 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, driven by yield-accretive acquisitions, higher rent from existing properties, and a net income hedge. Gross revenue gained 8.5% to S$25.3 million, and net property income rose 8.6% to S$23.7 million. The Reit successfully refinanced all debts due in FY 2015, extending the weighted average debt term to maturity to 3.91 years. Gearing remained at a healthy 34.6%.

site_title: Visa sees mobile payment as big growth driver
summary: Visa Inc reported a better-than-expected adjusted quarterly profit and stated that the mobile payment industry will be a significant growth driver. The company, along with Mastercard and American Express, partnered with Apple to launch Apple Pay, allowing iPhone users to make payments with a tap of a button. Visa forecast 2015 revenue growth in the low double digits and announced a new $5 billion stock buyback program, with shares rising nearly 4% in extended trading. The company expects the mobile payment industry to reach $1 trillion by 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.27% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.27% higher on October 30, 2014, following a dollar surge against the yen after the US Federal Reserve announced no policy changes. Nintendo shares rose 7.33% after the company reported a first-half net profit increase. The dollar strengthened to 108.84 yen, while the euro declined to 137.47 yen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.18%.

site_title: South Korea Nov business sentiment edges down vs Oct
summary: South Korea's manufacturing business sentiment for November decreased to a seasonally adjusted 76, down from 78 in October, according to a Bank of Korea survey. The decline was attributed to weak domestic consumption, with small-to-medium sized businesses showing the greatest pessimism. The index has remained below 100 since February 2011, indicating a persistent economic uncertainty.

site_title: Saudi capital's US$22.5b metro a 'race against time'
summary: Saudi Arabia's $22.5 billion metro system in Riyadh is racing against time to be completed within four years, according to senior official Abdullah Allohaidan. The project, which includes six lines covering 176km, is the largest in the Middle East and aims to address the city's congested roads and growing population. Construction has accelerated in recent weeks, despite road closures and lane-closures. The metro is expected to have a capacity of three million passengers per day and will provide mobility to women, who are not allowed to drive in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Fed ends bond buying, exhibits confidence in US recovery
summary: The Federal Reserve ended its monthly bond purchase program, indicating confidence in the US economy's recovery. The central bank downplayed concerns about labor market slack, inflation, and financial market volatility, citing progress toward unemployment and inflation goals. The Fed retained its guidance on keeping interest rates near zero for a "considerable time" and will continue to reinvest matured securities, preserving its over $4 trillion balance sheet. Rate hikes will depend on incoming economic data, and the Fed now has better-than-even odds of a rate increase in September 2015.

site_title: JPMorgan Singapore hiring to boost cybersecurity
summary: JPMorgan Singapore plans to hire 700 people for its Changi operations, increasing its staff count to 3,500, to boost cybersecurity and investment banking technology. The move comes amid a large cyberattack on JPMorgan's US operations in August. The bank has identified Singapore as a global support centre, allowing its in-house technology to be applied globally. The hiring is also expected to support the growth of its global wealth management programme, targeting clients with US$5-10 million in investable assets.

site_title: IBM, Twitter to partner on business data analytics
summary: IBM and Twitter announced a partnership to help businesses use data from tweets worldwide for decision-making. IBM will analyze trends and consumer sentiment, while training 10,000 employees to advise businesses on Twitter data use. This partnership aims to leverage IBM's analytics and cloud services to enhance business decisions. IBM's CEO, Ginni Rometty, sees this as a milestone, and Twitter CEO Dick Costolo notes that IBM's integration capabilities will help clients make better business decisions.

site_title: Bumpy German roads ominous for economy
summary: Germany's infrastructure disrepair threatens the country's growth prospects due to delayed transportation of goods and increased costs. Chancellor Angela Merkel's pursuit of a balanced budget has led to neglect of roads and bridges, with the International Monetary Fund warning that Germany's investment gap has averaged 2.9% of GDP since 1999. The European Central Bank and Standard & Poor's suggest that investing 1% of GDP in infrastructure could boost euro-area growth by 0.3 percentage point, but critics argue that such investments take time and may not yield immediate results.

site_title: Rocket failure casts spotlight on risks of space flight
summary: A privately owned rocket, the Antares 130, exploded just seconds after liftoff from Wallops Island, Virginia, on its way to the International Space Station. The incident, costing Orbital Sciences at least $200 million, raised concerns about the risks of NASA's reliance on the commercial space industry. Experts predicted the accident may speed up efforts to replace the Russian-designed AJ-26 engine used in the rocket, and NASA expressed confidence in the future of commercial space flight, citing the capabilities of Orbital Sciences and SpaceX.

images.alt_text: The explosion of a privately owned rocket on its way toward the International Space Station cast a spotlight on the risks involved with NASA's reliance on the fledgling commercial space industry, experts said Wednesday.

site_title: Output data adds to evidence of Japan's recovery from tax hike
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 2.7% in September, exceeding expectations, as the country continues to recover from the impact of a tax hike. This follows a 2.3% increase in retail sales, indicating a strong demand for consumer goods. The news boosted Tokyo stock prices, with the Nikkei 225 share average rising 1.5%. The data suggests that the tax hike has been absorbed, and analysts believe it may not be necessary to raise the national consumption tax further.

site_title: US: Wall St edges lower ahead of Fed, Facebook tumbles
summary: US stocks fell in a broad decline on Wednesday, with materials shares leading the market lower ahead of the US Federal Reserve's statement on winding down its economic stimulus program. The S&P 500 lost 3.48 points, or 0.18%, to 1,981.57, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 24.54 points, or 0.54%, to 4,539.76. Facebook tumbled 6.1% to $75.84 after announcing increased spending and a slowdown in revenue growth. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.05 points, or 0.11%, to 16,986.7.

site_title: CIT's S$100m 4-year bonds sold at 3.50%
summary: CAMBRIDGE Industrial Trust (CIT) sold S$100 million four-year senior unsecured bonds at 3.50% interest, exceeding initial price guidance of 3.75%. The transaction is the largest ever debt sold by CIT, with orders exceeding S$165 million from insurance and asset managers, indicating strong credit strength.

site_title: US businesses urge action on fast-track trade authority
summary: US businesses are urging President Barack Obama to make a case for fast-track trade authority on trade agreements before his trip to Asia, citing a narrow window of opportunity before the presidential election in 2016. The trade promotion authority (TPA) bill has stalled in Congress, and trade experts say it's a hurdle in finalizing the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a deal covering 40% of the world economy. If the TPA doesn't pass this year, the most likely window is in the northern spring of 2015, pushing back agreement on the TPP.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Eu Yan Sang's Q1 net profit fell 48% to S$737,000, driven by higher operating costs. Baker Technology reported a 20% rise in Q3 earnings to S$4.3 million, largely due to a foreign exchange gain. Companies face challenges, including protracted unrest in Hong Kong and slower economic growth in China, affecting Eu Yan Sang's core business growth.

site_title: MS Holdings launches IPO of 27m placement shares
summary: MS Holdings, a Singapore-based crane rental operator, launched its initial public offering (IPO) of 27 million placement shares at 25 Singapore cents each, with application closing on Nov 5. The company plans to use net proceeds of S$3.8 million for fleet replacement, business development, and working capital. Revenue grew 6.7% over the past three years, with an average gross margin of 44.2% and strong cash flow. The IPO is seen as a strategic move by the family-run company, now in its third generation, to list and expand its operations.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 profit down 31%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 31% drop in Q3 2014 net profit to S$194.6 million, primarily due to lower unrealised mark-to-market gains. Gross premiums decreased 4% to S$2,124 million, while operating profit from insurance business rose 8% to S$149 million. Despite a weaker Q3 performance, the company's 9-month net profit rose 32% to S$670.8 million, driven by higher unrealised mark-to-market gains and growth in Q3 operating profits.

site_title: World Bank urges China to cut 2015 growth target to 7%
summary: The World Bank has urged China to reduce its 2015 economic growth target to 7% from the current 7.5%, warning that meeting the ambitious target would detract from the government's reform plans. The bank believes that China should focus on reforms rather than specific growth targets, citing the need for a more stable labor market and slower but better-quality growth. The World Bank's comments echo those of the International Monetary Fund, which also advised China to set a growth target of 6.5-7% for 2015.

images.alt_text: The World Bank's message on employment will appeal to its audience in Beijing, where Communist Party leaders who are wary of social unrest have said having a healthy job market is a top policy priority.

site_title: Korea Inc targets "golden singles" amid consumer slump
summary: South Korea's consumer goods makers are targeting "golden singles," young unmarried individuals living alone, as the country's population rapidly ages. This demographic, who spend more on food and other goods, is a bright spot in the economy, which has been plagued by sluggish consumer demand. The average age of first-time marriages has increased to 32.2 for men and 29.6 for women, with many opting to live alone. Companies are responding by catering to this growing market, hoping to boost sales and offset declining consumer demand.

site_title: Learn from these three tragedies to avoid another one
summary: Two Malaysia Airlines tragedies in 2014, Flight MH370 and MH17, resulted in the loss of 298 lives. The MH370 incident involved a complex search operation due to the aircraft's manual tracking system, while MH17 was hit by a missile in rebel-controlled Ukraine. Additionally, South Korea's MV Sewol ferry capsized and sank in April, killing 294 people, with human error and negligence identified as the primary cause. These incidents highlight the need for improved aircraft tracking systems and better safety regulations to prevent future tragedies.

site_title: Nasa to carry on with commercial rocket project despite explosion
summary: NASA vows to continue its commercial space launch program despite a catastrophic anomaly that caused an Orbital Sciences Corp rocket to explode over a Virginia launch pad, injuring no one. The incident, which occurred during a resupply mission to the International Space Station, will not impact the space station's food or supplies. Orbital Sciences has a $1.9 billion contract with NASA to commercialize routine cargo flights and will not attempt another launch until the cause of the explosion is determined.

site_title: SGX's Richard Teng leaving to join Abu Dhabi Global Market (Amended)
summary: SGX's chief regulatory officer Richard Teng is leaving the exchange to become the CEO of Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM), effective February 28, 2015. Teng, who took over the role in January 2014, will oversee the launch of ADGM in 2015. His departure comes after a year of implementing regulatory changes following the 2013 penny stock crash. Teng's expertise in establishing robust regulatory frameworks will be missed, but he expressed excitement about shaping the future of international finance at ADGM.

site_title: Falling oil prices may hurt Najib's push to cut Malaysia deficit
summary: Malaysia's oil prices have plummeted by over 20% since June, undermining the government's revenue and worsening the deficit by more than RM4.4 billion. The government aims to trim the deficit to 3% of GDP in 2015, but a new consumption tax may not be enough to make up for the shortfall. With only about a third of companies registering to charge the tax, the government's revenue projection for 2015 is at risk, and the probability of missing the deficit target is high, according to economists.

site_title: BA using A380 on London route
summary: British Airways has started using its double-decker Airbus A380 jumbo jet on its London-Singapore route, offering three weekly services with promotional tickets starting from SGD 1,380. The 469-seater A380 has 14 First Class, 97 Business Class, 55 Premium Economy, and 303 Economy seats. BA has ordered 12 A380 aircraft, committed to investing SGD 10.2 billion in new planes and services.

site_title: New taxi app takes disruption up a level
summary: Singapore has introduced Hailo, a London-based taxi-booking app, allowing users to book taxis from six local operators and pay with credit cards on the app. Unlike other third-party platforms, Hailo's in-app payment option is available even when booking a taxi on the street. The company's chairman sees this as a "constructive disruption" that could foster a shared economy between taxi companies and third-party apps. Several traditional taxi companies have pledged their support, but Trans-Cab Services remains cautious, while ComfortDelGro, the largest operator, has yet to respond.

site_title: Ex-Sembmarine finance chief slapped with 39-month jail sentence
summary: Former Sembcorp Marine finance director Wee Sing Guan was sentenced to 39 months' jail for falsifying foreign exchange trade valuation reports, resulting in US$303 million in losses for the group.

images.alt_text: Wee pleaded guilty to falsifying the foreign exchange trade valuation reports of Jurong Shipyard.

site_title: Diverse boards perform better: study
summary: A study by the NUS Business School's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations (CGIO) and BoardAgender found that companies in Singapore with diverse boards, including those with at least two genders, ethnicities, or ages, had significantly higher returns on assets (ROA) of 5.1% on average. Boards with diverse composition outperformed those with no diversity indicators. Despite this, Singapore-listed companies' boards were largely uniform, with over 50% being all-male and having all directors from the same generation and ethnic group. The government is urging companies to re-examine their board selection process to increase diversity.

site_title: ECB alone cannot save Europe: Soc-Gen economist
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) alone cannot save Europe from economic woes, according to Societe-Generale economist Michel Martinez. He forecasts the euro area to grow 0.8% this year, 1% in 2015, and 1.3% in 2016. Deflation, a decrease in the general price level, is a major concern, but Martinez believes structural reforms, such as deregulation, will be key to boosting growth. The ECB may buy corporate bonds and private assets, but Martinez warns of potential risks, including a flight to quality and decelerated wage growth.

site_title: Analysts abandon China's Renren on failed growth
summary: Renren Inc., once touted as the Facebook of China, is struggling to diversify its business and boost profit. The stock has lost over three-quarters of its value since 2011, with analysts predicting a 18% drop in the next 12 months to $2.74. The company's sales are sliding, and it's been eclipsed by rivals like Tencent's WeChat and Weibo Corp. Renren's management team is addressing the issue by focusing on a younger audience and diversifying its offerings, including an online financial business. Analysts predict the company's demise, with one saying "they probably should sell the company."

site_title: Amazon ropes in mums to rank holiday toys
summary: Amazon has enlisted the help of 400,000 mothers on its Facebook page to create a list of top toys and games for the holiday season. The "Mom Picks 2014" list, which features 50 products, is used to promote products to other shoppers and provides insights into what items are likely to sell. The list is displayed prominently on Amazon's website and is used to stock inventory and make targeted marketing decisions. The move aims to capitalize on the influence of mothers in online shopping and is part of Amazon's efforts to boost sales during the holiday season, which is projected to reach $82 billion.

site_title: Infineon opens first global data analytics centre in Singapore
summary: Infineon, a semiconductor and systems solutions company, has opened its first global Business Analytics Centre of Competence (BACoC) in Singapore. The centre aims to develop business analytics capabilities and will partner with the National University of Singapore and Temasek Polytechnic. The BACoC will focus on market intelligence optimization and aims to enhance decision-making within three years. The partnership with the Economic Development Board of Singapore and local universities is expected to add S$1 billion in value-added to the Singapore economy by 2017.

site_title: Bitcoin price in retreat, but local players sally forth
summary: Bitcoin activity continues in Singapore despite the currency's year-long decline in value, with local players such as Coin Republic and FYB-SG seeing significant growth. Coin Republic reached S$1 million in annual turnover, while FYB-SG saw volumes decline "significantly" after the rapid rise in bitcoin price in late-2013. New players, including cryptocurrency wallet service CoinHako, are entering the market, and Coin Republic is in funding talks to carry out larger transactions and hire developers. Despite a regulatory plan to curb money laundering and terror financing, local businesses remain optimistic about the future of virtual currencies in Singapore.

site_title: Prime residential property in KL up for en bloc sale
summary: A luxury residential development in Kuala Lumpur's Ampang Hilir area, 7 U Thant, is up for en bloc sale by tender. The 10-storey, 97,564 sq ft property features 24 units of 3-4 bedroom apartments with prices ranging from RM$1,343 to RM$1,343 per sq ft. The project has an occupancy rate of over 85% and is marketed by SLP Premier Homes, with interested parties able to submit offers by November 26. The guide price is approximately RM$131 million (S$51 million).

images.alt_text: 7 U Thant, a freehold, 10-storey luxury development, is just 10 minutes away from KLCC.

site_title: US$ steadies, cautious stance from Fed expected
summary: The US dollar steadied on Wednesday as investors await the Federal Reserve's statement on interest rates, expected to reiterate a cautious stance. The Fed is set to end its US$4 trillion bond-buying stimulus program and may reassure markets that a rate hike is still far off due to weak US inflation and slowing global growth. The Australian dollar rose 0.3% to a three-week high, while the New Zealand dollar also increased. The dollar index held steady at 85.377, awaiting the Fed's statement for further direction.

site_title: Cloud adoption in S'pore: Survey highlights key barriers, objectives
summary: A survey by EMC Corporation in collaboration with IDG Connect found that cloud adoption in Singapore is high, but barriers to adoption remain, with 45% citing security and governance concerns. The most commonly used cloud model is on-premise, private cloud solutions managed by the IT department, with 64% of respondents. Flexibility, scalability, and cost are key factors in determining IT investment. Industries such as banking and finance are leading in cloud adoption, while others like legal and construction lag behind. The survey highlights the need for businesses to remain agile and secure in their cloud investment decisions.

site_title: Progressive wage at Singapore security sector's door
summary: Singapore's government has accepted a proposal for a progressive wage model (PWM) for the security industry, requiring a licensing requirement from September 1, 2016. The model sets a minimum monthly pay of S$1,100 for security officers, rising to S$1,700 or more for senior roles. The proposal aims to improve working conditions, reduce overtime hours, and increase career advancement opportunities for security officers, with expected wage increases of over 30% for around 33,000 workers.

images.alt_text: Some 33,000 security officers are tipped to see a more than 30 per cent jump in their basic wage in a new five-level career progression plan under the progressive wage model.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Singapore banks DBS and UOB are poised to pay out more dividends due to high capital ratios and slowing loan growth. Rising interest rates will lift earnings and return on equity. Genting Singapore's earnings quality is expected to weaken due to an unfavorable business mix and high valuation. CDL Hospitality Trust's 9M14 results are in line with estimates, but the company is expected to post stronger results in 2H14.

site_title: India embarks on US$18b digital plan
summary: India launches a US$18 billion digital plan to expand high-speed internet access and offer government services online. The program aims to provide broadband internet to 250,000 clusters of villages by 2016 and make banking and data accessible via mobile phones. The plan also includes cloud storage for citizens. The Communications and Information Technology Minister, Ravi Shankar Prasad, announced the initiative, marking a "digital revolution" for the nation.

site_title: Evergrande looking into refinancing dollar bonds due in 2015
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group is considering refinancing one of its US$1.35 billion 13% dollar bonds due in January 2015. The company plans to sell 5-year notes by late December to refinance the debt. Moody's cut its outlook on Evergrande to negative due to increased refinancing risk and investments in non-property businesses. This move comes as property sales in China slump, prompting the developer to diversify into infant formula sales. Evergrande's debt exceeds equity, making its dollar bonds the riskiest part of Asia's bond market.

site_title: Fair Consideration Framework boosts Q3 professional job ads
summary: Singapore's job advertisements for professional positions surged 37% year-on-year in Q3, driven by the Fair Consideration Framework, according to Robert Walters. The framework, which requires employers to advertise job postings in a national jobs bank for a certain period, has led to a spike in demand for Singaporean talent. The legal and compliance sector saw the biggest jump, with a 88% increase, while the HR sector grew 67%. The Asia Job Index attributes the growth to the framework, which has elongated recruitment processes and intensified competition for top professionals.

site_title: St Pancras Place to open for sale in S'pore this weekend
summary: The sale of St Pancras Place in London's King's Cross will launch on Nov 1-2 in Singapore, with 25 of 46 units pre-sold to Singaporeans, Hong Kongers, and Londoners. The 999-year leasehold development, set to complete in 2017, offers studio to three-bedroom homes in a Zone 1 location. This follows the near-sellout of Carlton House in Ilford, a 90-unit residential project, with 70 units sold in just over two weeks. The projects are part of London's King's Cross renovation, which includes 50 new buildings, 2,000 new homes, and nearly four million sq ft of commercial space.

site_title: Secondary gas market to boost S'pore's LNG hub ambition
summary: Singapore's wholesale electricity market operator, Energy Market Company (EMC), and gas industry regulator, Energy Market Authority (EMA), are developing a trading platform to facilitate a secondary gas market. This platform aims to provide flexibility and competitiveness in the domestic gas market, aligning with Singapore's ambition to develop an Asian liquefied natural gas (LNG) hub. The platform will allow buyers to trade excess gas supply, promoting price discovery and market liquidity, and is expected to complement the hub's development, which is estimated to take 3-5 years to be realized.

site_title: Accountants set to come under new anti-money laundering, terrorism financing rules
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) has issued a new Ethics Pronouncement 200, effective in November, requiring professional accountants to implement enhanced controls and procedures to counter money laundering and terrorism financing. The pronouncement aligns with international best practices and FATF Recommendations, and applies to public accountants and accounting entities registered under the Accountants Act. Non-compliance may result in investigations by Acra or Isca, and the pronouncement aims to strengthen the integrity and independence of public accountants in combating these financial crimes.

site_title: Cloud Service Provider Registry to have near-real-time analytics
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has announced updates to its Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Registry, which will now offer near-real-time analytics to help enterprises make informed decisions about cloud service providers. The registry, in partnership with Dynatrace, will provide users with real-time information on CSPs' availability and performance, enabling them to compare and select the best provider. The updated registry aims to increase trust and adoption of the cloud, following the adoption of the Multi-Tier Cloud Security Singapore Standard (MTCS SS) by several CSPs.

site_title: S'pore-KL bullet train may miss 2020 deadline
summary: Malaysia's high-speed rail link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore may miss its 2020 deadline, with a new estimate suggesting it could take six to seven years to complete. The project, initially set for completion by the end of the decade, will reduce travel time from five hours to 90 minutes and will be comparable in cost to international benchmarks. Japan has expressed interest in providing funds and expertise to the project, which will have at least four trains and operate four times hourly, with the journey taking about two hours with stops.

site_title: Solar panel maker REC to sell power directly to businesses, industries
summary: Norwegian solar panel maker REC plans to sell power directly to businesses and industries in Singapore through a power-purchase agreement (PPA) scheme. REC will pay for solar panel installations and sell electricity directly to customers at a lower rate than utility companies. The move aims to improve margins and forecast supply and demand trends. Singapore's solar power market is gaining momentum, with plans to add 80-100 megawatts-peak of solar power by the end of next year, aiming for 5% of electricity demand by 2020.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase drops plans to build HQ on West Side Manhattan
summary: JPMorgan Chase has dropped plans to build a $6.5 billion headquarters on the Far West Side of Manhattan after failing to strike a land deal with Related Cos. The bank will instead remain at its existing two buildings in Midtown, with thousands of employees already working there. The decision was made after the bank's board considered increased regulatory scrutiny and cost-cutting measures. Mayor Bill de Blasio had publicly expressed skepticism about the proposed deal, which included a $1 billion subsidy package.

site_title: Higher oil prices forecast to be back soon
summary: Higher oil prices are expected to return soon due to a slowdown in demand growth, which will prove fleeting. Despite a 25% decline in Brent crude prices since June, prices for 2020 contracts remain above $90. Global consumption is projected to grow to 99 million barrels a day in 2019, driven by increased US production and Opec growth. Experts predict a rebound in prices, with Brent climbing to $100 a barrel next year, and a lack of new supply sources will eventually drive prices up, cutting back production and cancelling future developments.

site_title: Shanghai stock link-up will proceed: Hong Kong exchange president
summary: Hong Kong's president of the stock exchange, Chow Chung-kong, confirmed that the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect platform will proceed, despite a delay. The project, which allows cross-trading between the two markets, was initially expected to launch this week but has been delayed due to uncertainty over taxation rules. Chow stated that ongoing democracy protests have not impacted the project's progress, and the delay is largely due to technical and regulatory issues. A start date has not been set, and Chow emphasized that the Hong Kong market is functioning normally despite the unrest.

site_title: Mortgage securities stare down end of QE3 as rally persists
summary: The Federal Reserve's third round of bond purchases is ending, but mortgage-backed debt is not seeing a slump as expected. Despite no new home-loan securities being added, the Fed will continue to buy enough to prevent its holdings from shrinking. This has allowed the market to defy forecasts, with mortgage securities continuing their rally. The end of QE3 has not had a significant impact on the mortgage market, highlighting the Fed's flexibility in managing its stimulus program.

site_title: OSIM shares plunge to one-year low
summary: OSIM International shares plummeted to a one-year low of S$1.935, down 31.5 cents or 14% on Wednesday. The company reported a 28% drop in net profit to S$16.4 million for its third quarter, citing weaker consumer spending in Asia and increased investment costs for its subsidiary TWG Tea. Analysts have downgraded the stock, with CIMB Research slashing its target price to S$2.37, while DBS analyst Alfie Yeo maintained a "buy" call with a lower target price of S$2.59.

site_title: Embracing nationalism to boost global exchange
summary: Indonesia is poised to emerge as a world-class shipping player with its strategic maritime position and massive import and export volume. The Indonesian Port Corporation (IPC) is capitalizing on this potential with a massive expansion project at the Port of Tanjung Priok, which will more than quadruple the port's container handling capacity. Led by president director RJ "Pak" Lino, who has successfully promoted a nationalist approach to boost productivity and efficiency, IPC is now a competitive commercial player and investor, with the government giving it a 70-year concession to run the project.

site_title: Finance chiefs to sign pact to fight tax evasion
summary: Finance ministers from 50 countries are set to sign a deal in Berlin to combat tax evasion and end banking secrecy. The Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement designates institutions responsible for transferring tax data between countries. This move aims to reduce tax fraud and aid the worldwide fight against tax evasion. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that "banking secrecy, in its old form, is obsolete." The agreement is part of the Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes under the OECD and EU auspices.

site_title: Time to 'get cracking' on tough India reforms: Subbarao
summary: Former Indian central bank governor Duvvuri Subbarao advises Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration to implement unpopular economic reforms to boost growth. With falling oil prices easing inflation, the government should ease labor laws, simplify land acquisition, and implement a goods and services tax. This could lead to an 8% economic expansion by the end of Modi's term, according to Subbarao. However, even a 6.5% growth rate may not be sufficient to address India's poverty and job challenges.

site_title: Singapore still best place to do business: World Bank
summary: Singapore has maintained its position as the best country to do business for the ninth consecutive year, according to the World Bank's 2015 report. With a score of 88.27, Singapore topped the list, followed by New Zealand and Hong Kong. The report showed improvements in the UK and China, while Japan declined. The World Bank's analysis found that it's getting easier to do business globally, with the least-hospitable countries converging towards better nations' practices.

site_title: Singapore-led consortium bags US$1.4b Myanmar airport project
summary: A Singapore-led consortium, consisting of Yongnam, Changi Airport Planners and Engineers (Cape), and Japan-based JGC Corporation, has secured a $1.4 billion bid to construct and operate Myanmar's Hanthawaddy International Airport. The 30-year concession will be built and completed by December 2019, with a projected annual passenger handling capacity of 12 million. The airport will serve as the primary gateway for transit routes and cargo, addressing growing tourist arrivals in the country.

site_title: Hackers access White House's unclassified networks
summary: Hackers believed to be working for the Russian government breached the White House's unclassified computer networks, causing temporary disruptions to services. The intruders did not damage any classified systems and no evidence suggests the classified network was hacked. The FBI, Secret Service, and NSA are investigating, with US officials alerted by an ally. The breach is consistent with a state-sponsored campaign, and White House officials say such intrusions are not unexpected.

site_title: Rethink the human's place in the 'digital revolution'
summary: China's demographic profile is expected to change significantly due to the growing global population, projected to reach 11 billion by 2100. The one-child policy has had a lasting impact, with China's women being the primary drivers of reduced birth rates. Data shows that up to nine births are needed to statistically ensure a surviving male child, leading to a smaller family size. This demographic shift poses challenges for China's aging population and workforce, potentially affecting its economic and social stability.

site_title: US ideology has taken precedence over public investment
summary: The US has abandoned investing in public projects, prioritizing ideology over economic growth. Despite a surplus of savings and low interest rates, the federal government has failed to provide aid to states to invest in infrastructure. Instead, Republican policies have blocked initiatives, citing an "overwhelming hostility to government spending." This ideology has led to a decrease in public investment, keeping the economy depressed, and has resulted in the US turning its back on its own history of investing in the future.

site_title: Australia's asset sales a boon for bankers as corporate M&As slide
summary: Australia's government is selling off state assets to finance infrastructure projects, creating a boon for bankers as corporate mergers and acquisitions slow. The sales, which include ports, electricity grids, and data, have generated advisory fees of around A$100 million, triple the total for government-related work last year. The government is offering 15% of the asset sale value to regional authorities, with the goal of raising A$5.5 billion. This influx of government work is expected to drive M&A activity in 2015 and beyond, with bankers eager to capitalize on the opportunities.

site_title: Japanese companies in China hope for Xi-Abe meeting
summary: Japanese companies in China are hopeful for a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, which could lead to improved business relations and smoother approvals. Despite a gradual recovery in sales, some firms are still facing delays in government approvals for projects and business licenses. A handshake between Xi and Abe could symbolize a warming of relations, which have been frosty since a diplomatic row two years ago, resulting in a 40% decline in Japan's direct investment into China in the first nine months of this year.

site_title: New Florida condos bank on wealthy US buyers now
summary: Florida condo developer Jorge Perez is shifting focus to wealthy US buyers for his new project, Auberge Beach Residences and Spa Fort Lauderdale, a $500 million oceanfront development. The project will require buyers to pay 50% deposits to finance construction, a move Perez believes is acceptable to US buyers who have shown resistance to larger downpayments. This shift comes as South Florida's condo market recovers from the 2008 crash, with buyers from Latin America and Canada increasingly hesitant to purchase condos due to concerns about the risk of large deposits.

site_title: Manila's major infrastructure delays frustrate commuters
summary: A 47-kilometre expressway connecting Manila to southern provinces has been delayed due to a San Miguel Corp appeal to President Benigno Aquino over a technicality, frustrating 22.7 million commuters. Meanwhile, SM Prime Holdings Inc and Ayala Land Inc are fighting over the location of a train station, both seeking to place it closer to their respective malls. The project delays threaten Mr Aquino's plan to lure $11.6 billion in investment to spur growth, and the Philippine economy's infrastructure ranks 96th globally.

site_title: US airlines highlight additional problems of enforcing an Ebola travel ban
summary: US airlines have expressed concerns about enforcing an Ebola travel ban, citing technical difficulties with flagging travelers and potential public hysteria. Despite supporting a ban, airlines worry about the impact on consumer demand and the complexity of tracking flights from West African countries. Industry officials have briefed government officials about the challenges, but a ban has not been discussed due to the Obama administration's rejection and Congress being out of session. Airlines have implemented existing health measures, such as checking fever and asking questions, to monitor travelers.

site_title: China shipping delivering toxic pollution cocktail: US environmental group
summary: China's shipping industry is releasing a toxic cocktail of pollution, emitting high levels of diesel particulate matter, oxides of nitrogen, and oxides of sulphur. One container ship can emit as much pollution as 500,000 new trucks daily, with most ships using cheap, high-sulphur bunker fuel. Despite efforts by some cities to address the issue, little has been done at a national level, and environmental regulations for ships are not being enforced in Asia. This could lead to "leakage" of pollution to other ports, undermining efforts to clean up shipping.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to get new CFO in management shake-up
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced a management shake-up, moving CFO Stefan Krause to a new post and giving his duties to Goldman Sachs partner Marcus Schenck. Christian Sewing joins the management board to oversee legal affairs, while Henry Ritchotte will oversee IT efforts. The changes aim to strengthen the bank's capacity to handle challenges ahead, amid tougher regulations and allegations of wrongdoing. The bank reported a net loss of 92 million euros in Q3, citing legal costs, and has paid over US$8.9 billion in fines since 2012.

site_title: Globetronics Q3 profit up at RM18m, revenue higher at RM265m
summary: Globetronics Technology has reported a profit of nearly RM18 million (S$7 million) for the third quarter, a 17% increase from the same period last year, with revenue reaching RM265 million, a 9% increase. The company expects future earnings growth, driven by its sensor business, particularly wearable and proximity sensors. It has also seen increased demand from Chinese smartphone manufacturers and plans to ramp up manufacturing of wearable sensor modules.

site_title: Firms need new mindset to negotiate new economy
summary: Singapore's enhanced Business Excellence (BE) framework aims to help firms navigate the new economy by focusing on customer satisfaction and employee engagement. The new framework, set to be implemented in January, simplifies the certification process, allowing organizations to conduct self-diagnostic assessments and track progress. It also emphasizes future orientation and on-site assessments, aiming to halve the time and effort required for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) to apply for certification. The goal is to enhance business profitability and wages sustainably.

site_title: GLP expands Japan development venture
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is expanding its Japan development venture, GLP Japan Development Venture, with a US$138m injection from each of its partners, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) and GLP. The venture now has a US$2.2 billion investment capacity, bringing GLP's global assets under management to US$13.2 billion. GLP Japan president Yoshiyuki Chosa stated the venture has consistently outperformed, with leasing progressing ahead of schedule and achieving rents higher than budgeted.

site_title: Too much milk may be bad for health
summary: A Swedish study of 61,000 women and 45,000 men found that high milk intake was associated with a higher risk of death, particularly among women. Those who consumed three or more glasses of milk per day had a 90% higher risk of death and 60% higher risk of hip fracture compared to those who drank less than a glass per day. The study also found that fermented milk products, such as cheese and yoghurt, were associated with lower mortality and fracture rates.

site_title: China could "punish" Hong Kong
summary: China may punish Hong Kong if pro-democracy protests continue, according to Joseph Yam, a former Hong Kong central bank chief and China Society for Finance and Banking executive vice president. Yam warned that the city's financial integrity and currency stability are at risk. The protests have paralyzed parts of the Chinese-controlled financial center for a month, sparking concerns about Hong Kong's stability. Beijing's response to the protests remains unclear, but Yam's comments suggest a potential threat of punishment if the protests are allowed to continue.

site_title: Japan co-op plays matchmaker to single depositors
summary: Japan's Tsuruoka Shinkin Bank is hosting a unique event to address its declining population in rural Yamagata prefecture. The lender is organizing a "marriage-hunting" party, known as konkatsu, for 184 single depositors, aged 32, at a local aquarium. The goal is to encourage matchmaking among customers to boost the bank's membership and counter the effects of Japan's aging population and declining rural communities. This innovative approach aims to revitalize the bank's local presence and attract new members.

site_title: US sees new wave of online delivery
summary: A new wave of online delivery services is emerging in the US, with start-ups such as Postmates and Instacart offering quick delivery of meals, groceries, and other items. Unlike major players that went bankrupt in the past, these start-ups are using independent contractors to avoid investing heavily in warehouses and hiring staff. Postmates claims to have the largest US on-demand delivery fleet, and Instacart expects revenue to grow tenfold this year. The companies use smartphones and high-speed internet to deliver items within 60 minutes, with flexible scheduling options for independent contractors.

site_title: Women feel safer on single-sex transport: survey of 15 cities
summary: A Reuters survey of 6,300 women in 15 cities found that 70% of women feel safer on single-sex transport, with Manila and Jakarta having the highest support. However, experts, including Laura Bates and Julie Babinard, argue that this is a short-term fix and may not address the root causes of harassment on public transport, instead segregating women by gender. The trend is seen as a band-aid solution, with experts suggesting that more fundamental issues need to be addressed to create long-term solutions.

site_title: Nomura sees four years of overseas losses nearing an end
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage, expects to become profitable in Asia, Europe, and the US by March 2015, ending four years of overseas losses. The firm aims to reach 50 billion yen (S$588.5 million) in annual pre-tax profit from overseas by March 2016. Following a second-quarter earnings beat, Nomura plans to buy back up to 40 million shares and has seen a 39% increase in net income to 52.9 billion yen. The firm's cost-cutting efforts and improved credit rating have contributed to the turnaround.

site_title: STI up as US gains inspire regional trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose after US stocks gained overnight, with trading value crossing the billion-dollar mark. The STI had 265 gainers to 140 losers. OSIM International fell 14% on its earnings report, which missed expectations. The earnings reporting season in Singapore is in full swing, with market attention focused on the local consumer discretionary play.

site_title: Property, fair-value gains boost Yoma Q2
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' net profit for Q2 2014 more than tripled to S$10.8 million, driven by strong sales of residences and land development rights in Myanmar, as well as fair-value gains on completed properties. The group's property division boosted revenue 53% year-on-year to S$41.2 million, while the sale of 528 units in the Star City project generated S$60.53 million in contractual revenue. The company expects to sustain growth, with plans to enlarge its land bank and open KFC outlets in Myanmar, a partnership with US food giant Yum!.

site_title: First Bank of England hike still seen in Q1 but economists less sure: Reuters poll
summary: A Reuters poll of economists suggests that a first-quarter interest rate hike by the Bank of England is less certain, with only 28 of 54 economists predicting a rise. The poll indicates a shift in expectations, with short sterling interest rate futures now pricing in a second-quarter hike instead. Economists cite lower inflation and weaker growth as key factors in their revised forecasts, with most expecting a gradual rate hike when it occurs.

images.alt_text: A rise in British interest rates in the first quarter of 2015 is now much less certain, according to a Reuters poll in which almost half the economists questioned thought the hike would come later in the year.

site_title: US politics' distorted 'machofication'
summary: US presidents have historically been criticized for not displaying enough "manliness" in their foreign policy, with some being deemed too soft or weak. This criticism has been leveled against presidents since the late 19th century, with Theodore Roosevelt being a notable example of an imperialist US senator who believed that war would maintain US democracy by building manly character in male citizens. Critics argue that a president's manhood is tied to their ability to assert power and dominance on the world stage, with those who fail to do so being seen as weak or ineffective. However, historians argue that these criticisms often overlook the fact that these presidents were principled and astute negotiators who prioritized diplomacy over aggression.

site_title: Creative Technology Q1 losses widen on foreign exchange loss
summary: Creative Technology reported widened first-quarter net losses to US$9.8 million, mainly due to a foreign exchange loss of US$3.3 million. Net sales fell 20% to US$24.3 million, affected by uncertain market conditions. The company warned that second-half revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to the first half.

site_title: Top tennis stars to play in Singapore in Dec
summary: Singapore is set to host the inaugural International Premier Tennis League (IPTL) from December 2-4, featuring top tennis stars including Serena Williams and Andre Agassi. The tournament, which has a US$1 million prize purse, will see eight teams compete in a three-day event, with the Singapore Slammers team including Williams, Agassi, and other active players. The IPTL aims to bring new ideas and innovations to tennis, with added twists such as time-outs, power points, and Hawk-Eye technology.

site_title: S'pore, US toast 10-year success of bilateral FTA
summary: The US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (USSFTA) has celebrated its 10-year success, with bilateral trade and investment growing significantly. The agreement has boosted US exports to Singapore by over 85% and US investments in Singapore by more than tripled. Singapore, in turn, has become the US's top investment destination in the Asia-Pacific, with about 3,000 US companies operating there. The USSFTA has demonstrated that free trade and investment benefit all countries, with top diplomats calling for its continuation and the early conclusion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

images.alt_text: EN years after coming into force, the US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (USSFTA) has paid rich dividends to both countries, by reinvigorating bilateral trade and investment and opening up new opportunities for companies, according to top diplomats from Singapore and the United States.

site_title: Fed to end stimulus, but keep watch on low inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to end its asset-purchase operations, known as quantitative easing, after six years to bring the economy back to "normal" monetary policy. The Fed will not sell its $3.5 trillion in Treasury bonds and mortgage securities, and will keep the benchmark federal funds interest rate at zero. The decision is seen as a response to low inflation, which remains below the 2% target, and the global economy's frail state. The Fed aims to end QE3 at the end of the month, with a potential rate hike in mid-2015 dependent on economic data.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 12.38 points to 3,224.03. A total of 1.15 billion shares were traded, with 265 gains and 140 losses. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for Singapore stocks ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: More SGX steps to boost market liquidity
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched various initiatives to boost market liquidity, following a multi-year low. These include providing tradability and order book statistics to brokers, price impact cost analysis, and weekly IPO factsheets. The exchange has also conducted 12 roadshows to showcase its new tools and has seen a mixed response from brokers. Additionally, the market maker incentive scheme, launched in June, has led to a 20% increase in liquidity for top 50 stocks. SGX acknowledges that there is no single solution to the liquidity issue, but is taking steps to improve the market.

site_title: Former Sembmarine finance chief sentenced to 39 months' jail
summary: Former Sembmarine finance chief Wee Sing Guan, 65, was sentenced to 39 months' imprisonment for falsifying foreign exchange trade valuation reports, resulting in US$303 million in losses for the company. Guan pleaded guilty to nine charges, down from 57 originally charged, and was a director of Jurong Shipyard, a wholly-owned unit of Sembmarine. The charges related to hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of marked-to-market losses on foreign-exchange and options trades positions held with several major banks.

site_title: Khazanah asks banks for MAS restructuring proposals
summary: Khazanah Nasional, the majority owner of Malaysia Airlines, has invited investment banks to submit proposals for a role overseeing the airline's restructuring. The fund plans to buy shares for RM1.38 billion, cut 6,000 jobs, and invest RM6 billion to return the airline to profit within three years. The selected bank will also be in a strong position to win a role on the airline's potential initial public offering within three to five years. This move comes after the airline lost two jetliners in disasters this year and incurred RM4.9 billion in losses since 2011.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as market awaits Fed policy statement
summary: US stocks were mixed in early trade on Wednesday as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy statement, expected to announce the end of the central bank's asset-purchases program. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.16%, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.05%. The Nasdaq Composite Index, however, dropped 0.27%. The Fed is expected to declare the end of its six-year-old quantitative easing program and provide fresh signals on interest rates, which investors are watching closely.

site_title: Singapore group wins bid for new Myanmar airport
summary: A Singaporean-led group, including Yongnam and a Changi airport subsidiary, has won a US$1.4 billion bid to build and operate Hanthawaddy International Airport in Yangon, Myanmar. The new airport, set to open by December 2019, will handle 12 million passengers annually and is part of Myanmar's efforts to increase foreign arrivals and reclaim its status as a regional air hub. The project aims to reduce pressure on the existing Yangon International Airport, which has a capacity of 2.7 million passengers annually.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall in latest week as rates rise: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications declined 6.6% in the week ended Oct 24, with refinancing applications falling 7.4% and home purchase demand dropping 5.0%. Fixed 30-year mortgage rates rose 3 basis points to 4.13%, up from 4.10% the previous week. The decline in mortgage applications is attributed to rising interest rates, which may impact home sales.

images.alt_text: Applications for US home mortgages fell last week as both purchases and refinancing slipped, an industry group said on Wednesday.

site_title: 2 mega private residential projects get URA's provisional nod in Q3
summary: Two mega private residential projects, Sims Urban Oasis and Kingsford Waterbay, secured provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Q3, with Sims Urban Oasis having over 1,024 units and Kingsford Waterbay having 1,165 units. The projects were awarded through state tenders, with prices ranging from S$502 million to S$530.89 million per plot ratio. Additionally, several other projects received URA's provisional nod, including Singapore Post Centre, Mapletree's industrial project, and Fragrance Group's additions and alterations works.

site_title: Dow Jones asks court to deny GT Advanced, Apple's secrecy motion
summary: Dow Jones & Co. has asked a court to deny Apple Inc. and GT Advanced Technology Inc.'s request to keep certain documents related to GT Advanced's bankruptcy under seal. Dow Jones claims this would be an offense to constitutional principles of public access. GT Advanced, which supplied sapphire material to Apple, filed for Chapter 11 protection after a dispute, citing confidentiality clauses. The companies' request was deemed "brazen" and "ransom" by Dow Jones, which argues that no authority supports sealing documents in this case.

site_title: China tries former bank head for corruption: report
summary: China's former head of the Postal Savings Bank of China, Tao Liming, and two employees went on trial for corruption, accused of embezzling $56 million. Tao allegedly diverted funds for personal profit and took bribes. He was formally arrested in 2012 and is part of China's anti-corruption campaign led by President Xi Jinping. The trial marks the latest effort to tackle graft in the one-party state, but critics argue that systemic changes are lacking.

site_title: Facebook spending gets thumbs up from analysts - if not investors
summary: Facebook's third-quarter report revealed aggressive spending plans for 2015, with projected spending increases of 55-75% to invest in growth opportunities. Despite investors initially reacting negatively, analysts remain optimistic, citing long-term growth potential and Facebook's market dominance. No brokerages cut their recommendations, and several analysts view the price decline as a buying opportunity, with a majority rating the stock as "buy" or "overweight." Facebook's shares have risen 50% since the start of the year, and analysts expect the company's broad product portfolio to benefit the business in the next six to eight quarters.

site_title: Heathrow raises 2014 passenger traffic outlook
summary: Heathrow Airport raised its 2014 passenger traffic outlook to 73.4 million, a 0.8% increase from its previous forecast, and 1.5% higher than last year. The airport attributed the increase to strong demand for air travel, despite concerns over the Ebola crisis in west Africa. Unlike previous SARS outbreaks, Heathrow is not seeing a significant impact on travel. The revised forecast has boosted airline and travel stocks, which have been affected by fears of a drop-off in air travel.

site_title: ECB says banks show signs of relaxing loan conditions
summary: The European Central Bank's quarterly bank lending survey shows that eurozone banks are easing loan conditions and demand for loans is increasing, a sign of healing in the financial sector. Credit standards for all loan categories eased in the third quarter, with a small net percentage of banks reporting an easing of credit standards. This finding provides encouragement to the ECB, which has been struggling to see the effects of its ultra-easy monetary policy on the real economy. The survey results suggest a potential improvement in credit activity, particularly for small and mid-sized enterprises.

site_title: Germany, Britain expect patent box deal at G20 meeting
summary: Germany and Britain are expected to reach a deal on closing the "patent box" loophole at the G20 meeting in Brisbane. The loophole allows firms to minimize tax bills by using tax breaks on patented research. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed confidence in a successful outcome, stating the technical work is well under way. The agreement aims to combat tax evasion and ensure fair taxation.

site_title: Don't panic, OPEC secretary general says after oil price fall
summary: OPEC secretary general Abdullah al-Badri reassured that there's no need to panic over the recent oil price collapse, stating that low prices will curb competing supplies and require the group to pump more oil by the end of the decade. He suggested OPEC should not cut production at its November meeting, instead letting the market set prices, and predicted the average price will remain around $100 per barrel by the end of 2014. Al-Badri emphasized the need for OPEC to increase production to meet growing demand, aiming for 40 million barrels per day by 2020.

site_title: Gas Malaysia to raise gas price by 2.3% from Nov 1
summary: Gas Malaysia Bhd announced a 2.3% increase in the average natural gas price in peninsular Malaysia, effective November 1. The price increase follows a 20 sen per liter rise in petrol and diesel prices as part of a government plan to cut subsidies and reduce its budget deficit. The new tariff will be RM19.77 per million British thermal units (mmBtu), up from RM19.32 mmBtu.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.87 points to close at 1,839.55 on Wednesday, driven by gains. A total of 2.01 billion lots worth RM2.11 billion were traded, with 586 stocks gaining and 232 losing value.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise as Fed meeting wraps up
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday following strong gains on Wall Street, driven by anticipation of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. The Dow jumped above 17,000, with Asian stocks rising 0.88-1.38% as traders awaited the Fed's post-meeting statement on quantitative easing. Economists expect the Fed to stay the course on near-zero rates, with interest rates expected to remain unchanged. Oil prices edged higher, and the dollar strengthened against the yen, while gold prices remained steady.

site_title: Britain's Fraud Office to probe Tesco accounting errors: Sky News
summary: Britain's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) will launch a formal criminal probe into accounting errors at supermarket Tesco, following an investigation by the Financial Reporting Council, which found Tesco overstated first-half profits by 263 million pounds. The probe comes as Tesco faces recent profit warnings and management exits. Shares in Tesco dropped half a percent on the news.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares gain on Fed hopes, casino stocks jump
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.3% to their highest close since September 24, driven by anticipation of the Federal Reserve's potential delay in raising US interest rates. Casino stocks surged, with Wynn Macau, Galaxy Entertainment, and Sands China rising 4.9%, 6.3%, and 5.0% respectively. Ping An Insurance and China Life also saw gains of 2.9% and 2.2% respectively after reporting third-quarter profits.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust's S$100m 4-year bonds sold at 3.50%
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) sold S$100 million 4-year bonds at 3.50% interest, exceeding initial guidance of 3.75%. The transaction, the largest ever by CIT, received orders of over S$165 million, with insurance and asset managers contributing to the robust demand. The bond issuance aims to refinance existing borrowings, diversify funding sources, and support CIT's expansion in Singapore and the region. The company's strong credit strength is evident in the robust order book, according to RBS director Winston Tay.

site_title: SGX chief regulatory officer quits to join Abu Dhabi Global Market
summary: SGX chief regulatory officer Richard Teng has resigned to become the chief executive of Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator, leaving on February 28, 2015. Teng made significant contributions to SGX's success as a market regulator, including establishing a direct listing framework for China-incorporated companies. SGX is reviewing candidates for his replacement, while Teng will shape the regulatory landscape internationally in his new role, which aims to launch in 2015 as a financial zone for private banking and wealth management.

site_title: Cloud registry gets real time analytics capabilities in Singapore
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) announced updates to the Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Registry, providing near real-time analytics to help companies choose the best cloud service provider for their needs. The registry now offers dynamic listings, enabling users to compare the performance and availability of multiple CSPs. Compuware will access this information and provide free software tools and expertise to monitor CSPs' performance, enhancing transparency and trust in the cloud computing market.

site_title: Hackers breach White House computer system
summary: The White House's unclassified computer network was breached by hackers believed to be working for the Russian government, according to a US official. The breach occurred in recent weeks, prompting the White House to temporarily disconnect some users from the network. The incident was identified during a routine assessment of cyber threats, and measures were taken to evaluate and mitigate the activity. No damage was reported to the computers and systems, but some elements of the unclassified network were affected. The White House took immediate action to defend its networks.

images.alt_text: The White House's unclassified computer network was recently breached by intruders, a US official said Tuesday, with The Washington Post newspaper reporting that the Russian government was thought to be behind the act.

site_title: German exports to Russia slump 17%: official data
summary: German exports to Russia declined 17% in the first eight months of 2014, reaching 20.3 billion euros, amid European sanctions.
