Machinery exports, accounting for 22.6% of total exports, dropped 17.2%, while heavy goods vehicles and parts plummeted 27.3%. The slump led to Russia falling to 13th place as Germany's largest export market, down from 11th the previous year.

images.alt_text: German exports to Russia plunged by nearly 17 per cent in the first eight months of this year, against the backgrop of European sanctions against Moscow, official data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rally to 3-wk high on dovish Fed outlook, won firmer
summary: South Korean shares reached a three-week high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) surging 1.84% to 1,961.17 points. The rally was driven by expectations of a dovish Federal Reserve stance on interest rates. LG Electronics shares rose 4.3% after announcing higher-than-expected quarterly earnings.

site_title: Etihad, Alitalia offer concessions in bid for EU approval for stake deal
summary: Etihad Airways and Alitalia have offered concessions to the European Commission in a bid for EU approval of the Abu Dhabi airline's 49% stake deal in Alitalia. The concessions include giving up airport slots on the Rome-Belgrade route to facilitate rivals. The European Commission will decide by November 17 whether to clear the deal. This is likely to secure EU approval with minor concessions, following previous airline deals that required airlines to give up slots, facilitate rivals' access, or open up frequent flyer programmes to ease competition concerns.

site_title: SoftBank's humanoid robot lands job as Nescafe salesman
summary: Nestle has partnered with SoftBank's humanoid robot, Pepper, to sell coffee makers at electronics stores in Japan. The company will initially commission 20 robots and expand to 1,000 by the end of 2015. The robots, capable of learning and expressing human emotions, will interact with customers and promote Nescafe coffee machines. This marks the first corporate customer for Pepper, which will retail for $1,830. Nestle aims to leverage Japan's labor shortages and unique marketing tactics to drive growth in the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat ahead of bank results
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday, mirroring the previous day's 0.1% decline, ahead of bank results. Despite strong Wall St advances, investors opted for caution. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,447.7, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index rose 0.3%. Investors are waiting for bank earnings reports later in the week, overshadowing market sentiment.

site_title: UK's private-sector growth slows to seven-month low: CBI
summary: The UK's private sector growth has slowed to a seven-month low, according to the Confederation of British Industry's October growth indicator, which fell to +19. This marks the weakest reading since July 2013. Despite this, the CBI still expects quarterly growth of 0.6-0.7% in 2015, above Britain's historical rate. Slowing eurozone inflation and international conflicts are cited as threats to British growth. The UK's gross domestic product expanded by 0.7% in the three months to September, down from 0.9% in the second quarter of 2014.

site_title: UK inflation expectations hold steady at 5-year low: YouGov
summary: UK inflation expectations remain steady at a 5-year low of 1.9% for the next 12 months, according to a YouGov poll. This is the lowest reading since 2009. Inflation expectations for 5-10 years also decreased to 2.9%. This news is seen as reassuring to the Monetary Policy Committee, as it indicates the public's expectations are focused on low but positive inflation, rather than deflation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.46%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.46% on Wednesday, following strong gains on Wall Street and a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 224.00 points to 15,553.91, while the Topix index rose 1.49% to 1,270.64. The gains were attributed to exporter shares lifted by the weaker yen.

site_title: Seoul: Shares power to 3-week high as shipbuilders rally; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares reached a three-week high, with the KOSPI index rising 1.14% to 1,947.54 points, driven by expectations that the US Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates. Shipbuilders Samsung Heavy Industries and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Engineering surged 7% and 6.7%, respectively. The won strengthened against the dollar as investors anticipated dovish comments from the Fed. Despite this, South Korea's President Park Geun-hye warned of an ongoing economic crisis, while the Bank of Korea noted that exports are performing well.

site_title: China set to punish HK lawmaker for criticising leader
summary: A senior pro-Beijing lawmaker in Hong Kong, James Tien, is likely to be sacked from the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference due to his criticism of the city's leader, Leung Chun-ying. Tien, a prominent businessman and politician, expressed his disapproval of Leung's handling of the ongoing protests, which have paralyzed parts of the city. The decision to remove Tien is seen as a demonstration of Beijing's intolerance for dissent at a critical time, with the central government urging support for Leung to resolve the crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: Osim at one-year low, views from analysts
summary: OSIM International, a lifestyle products group, saw its shares plummet 15% to a one-year low of S$1.915, trading at 33.5 cents lower. The company reported a 28% drop in net profit to S$16.4 million for its third quarter, attributed to increased legal and startup costs, as well as a weaker consumer spending environment in Asia. Analysts have downgraded their target prices, with CIMB Research slashing its price target to S$2.37, while others maintained a "Buy" call with reduced target prices, citing the company's fundamentally sound business despite weak operating conditions.

site_title: China to merge two top state-owned train makers: Xinhua
summary: China is set to merge its two largest state-owned train makers, China CNR Corp and CSR Corp, creating a multi-billion-dollar firm to boost export of high-speed railway technologies. The deal aims to prevent internal competition and follows multiple scandals in the sector. The companies, valued at around $13 billion each, will release "important news" this weekend. The merger is part of China's efforts to expand its high-speed rail network globally, with CNR recently securing a deal to supply trains for the Boston commuter system.

site_title: Private clouds most popular in Singapore, says EMC-IDG survey
summary: A survey conducted by EMC-IDG found that private clouds are the most popular cloud computing solution in Singapore, with 64% of respondents having implemented on-premise, private-cloud solutions. The top concerns for cloud adoption were security and governance, with 88% and 61% of respondents citing these as major objectives. Cost was also a significant barrier, with 29% of respondents citing it as an obstacle. Despite these concerns, 95% of respondents had a defined cloud computing usage and governance policy in place, indicating a growing recognition of the benefits of cloud technologies.

site_title: Singapore is third most popular destination to which MNCs relocate staff: report
summary: Singapore ranks third among popular destinations for multinational companies to relocate staff, according to Cartus Corporation's 2014 data. The US and UK took the top two spots, followed by Switzerland, Hong Kong, India, Germany, mainland China, the Netherlands, and Canada. Cartus Corporation's data, which includes Fortune 50 companies, shows a mix of Westernized management styles and cultural nuances in various countries, advising on business etiquette and cultural differences for those relocating.

site_title: Global consumer confidence improves, India most bullish: Nielsen
summary: Global consumer confidence improved in the third quarter, rising 1 point to 98, according to Nielsen's survey. The US saw a 4-point increase to 108, driven by optimism about job prospects, while India remained the most bullish market. European countries were the most pessimistic, reflecting concerns about war, terrorism, and economic growth. The survey also showed that concerns about the economy and job prospects had eased globally, but in North America and Europe, worries about war and terrorism replaced economic concerns. Consumer confidence has been steadily rising since 2012.

images.alt_text: Consumer confidence in the United States jumped in the third quarter and improved globally, although people were more optimistic about job prospects than their personal finances, a survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Air France results hit by record pilots' strike
summary: Air France reported a significant decline in third-quarter results due to a record pilots' strike, which grounded half of its fleet. The strike, lasting from September 15 to 28, resulted in a 15.9% decrease in passenger traffic and a 17.7% decline in cargo. The strike also led to a 416 million euro ($530 million) loss in turnover. The Air France-KLM group is already facing difficulties, and the strike has further impacted its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Air France on Wednesday said its third quarter results had taken a bashing due to a record pilots' strike, with turnover falling by 416 million euros ($530 million).

site_title: Hong Kong exchange boss vows Shanghai stock link-up will proceed
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange president, Chow Chung-kong, has assured that the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect platform will proceed, despite delays and ongoing democracy protests. The platform, which enables cross-trading between the two markets, had been delayed due to uncertainty over taxation and regulatory approval. Chow stated that the project's progress was not impacted by the protests, which have been ongoing for over a month. The scheme's launch is expected to boost economic cooperation between Hong Kong and China, but its timeline remains uncertain.

site_title: Diversity in corporate boards linked to return on assets, says NUS study
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore found that corporate boards with diversity in gender, ethnicity, and age have significantly higher return on assets (ROA) of 5.1%, compared to 1.1% in companies with no diversity indicators. Companies with at least one female director and multiple generations on their boards enjoyed average ROAs of 3.3% and 3.3%, respectively. Only 7.7% of boards studied displayed diversity across gender, ethnicity, and age, highlighting a need for improvement in Singapore's corporate boards.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange boss vows Shanghai stock link-up will proceed
summary: Hong Kong Stock Exchange President Tan Teck Long has confirmed the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect platform will proceed, despite initial delays. The platform, set to enable cross-trading between the two markets, aims to allow international investors to trade in Shanghai's tightly-restricted exchange and vice versa. The project's progress was not derailed by ongoing democracy protests, and its launch is now expected to occur.

site_title: GLP expands Japan JV with additional equity injection, extends investment period
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) has expanded its joint venture with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) in Japan by injecting additional equity, increasing the venture's size to $2.2 billion. The investment period has been extended for three years, allowing the venture to develop modern logistics properties worth $1.4 billion. The partnership aims to strengthen long-term returns for shareholders, with GLP's global fund management platform growing to $13.2 billion in assets under management.

site_title: Singapore security industry to adopt progressive wage model from Sept 1, 2016
summary: Singapore's security industry must adopt the Progressive Wage Model by September 1, 2016, requiring security officers to receive training and be paid at least S$1,100 per month. The model, proposed by the NTUC-led Security Tripartite Cluster, also aims to reduce the workweek from six days to five or six days and overtime to 72 hours per month. However, overtime reduction will be reviewed in 2017. The government accepted the recommendations, aiming to improve working conditions and wages for security officers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts quarterly net loss as legal costs weigh
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a quarterly net loss of 92 million euros due to heavy legal costs, despite a 4% rise in investment banking earnings. The bank spent 894 million euros on litigation costs in the quarter, bringing total fines and settlements since 2012 to around 7 billion euros. This loss comes as the bank faces ongoing legal challenges and increasing regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Job advertisements for professionals up 37% in Singapore in Q3: Robert Walters
summary: Job advertisements for professionals in Singapore increased 37% year-on-year in Q3, surpassing the regional average of 20%. The legal and compliance sector saw the largest jump, with a 88% rise, driven by stricter regulations in financial services. The Fair Consideration Framework, which elongates recruitment processes and leaves positions open, contributed to the increase in demand for Singaporean talent. This has intensified competition among companies for top professionals, with firms boosting efforts to attract and retain local talent through various benefits and opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.87 points to 1826.55. Volume reached 37.22 million lots worth RM13.98 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 150 to 28, indicating a relatively positive market trend.

site_title: Hello Kitty at 40, giving adults a 'licence to play'
summary: Hello Kitty, created in 1974, is celebrating its 40th birthday. The character, designed by Sanrio, has become a global phenomenon, appearing on over 50,000 products and spawning a multi-billion dollar industry. Initially marketed towards children, Hello Kitty has gained popularity among adults, particularly in Japan and the US, who see it as a way to express their playful side. Sanrio attributes the character's enduring appeal to its versatility, with designs ranging from punk to fashionable collaborations. Despite a recent revelation that Hello Kitty is not a cat but a girl, the brand remains unscathed, with new products and collaborations in the works.

site_title: Former premier Zhu Rongji joins ranks of China's most charitable: survey
summary: Former Chinese premier Zhu Rongji donated nearly US$4 million last year, ranking 60th on China's top philanthropists list. He gave away 23.98 million yuan (US$3.9 million) from book royalties to support poor students and teachers, renovating school facilities. This is a significant contribution, especially considering the relatively low level of charitable giving in developing nations like China. Zhu's donations follow a notable example by Alibaba founder Jack Ma, who donated 1.4% of his firm's stake, worth US$3.5 billion, to set up an education charity.

images.alt_text: Former Chinese premier Zhu Rongji, respected as an economic reformer and fighter against corruption, gave away nearly US$4 million last year to become one of the country's top philanthropists, a survey showed.

site_title: SBI Offshore appoints Mirzan Mahathir to its board as director
summary: SBI Offshore appoints Mirzan Mahathir, son of former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, as non-independent, non-executive director, bringing oil and gas expertise to the board. The appointment follows a S$9.1 million share placement and aims to enhance shareholder value. Executive chairman Chan Lai Thong expects Mirzan's network and experience to accelerate efforts to scale up the company's value chain in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 13.02 points to 3,224.67. Volume was 44.6 million shares worth S$155.3 million, with 91 gainers outnumbering 30 losers. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China can cut 2015 GDP growth target to 7%: World Bank
summary: China can potentially cut its 2015 GDP growth target to 7% without compromising its labor market health, according to the World Bank. The organization advises Beijing to focus on economic reforms rather than rigid growth targets. China aims for a 7.5% growth rate in 2015, but analysts expect 7.4%, the lowest in 24 years. The World Bank's policy message emphasizes the importance of reforms over meeting specific growth targets to maintain a healthy labor market.

site_title: South Korea current account surplus grows in September
summary: South Korea's current account surplus grew to $7.6 billion in September, driven by increased exports of memory chips and steel. The surplus has been in the black for 31 months, with exports reaching $51 billion and imports at $43.3 billion. The services account reported a deficit of $280 million. The central bank forecasts a record current account surplus of $84 billion for the year, citing a strong export-driven economy.

site_title: South Korea faces risk of long-term economic slump: president
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun-hye warned of a long-term economic slump due to low growth, low inflation, and a weak yen. The economy is expected to grow to mid-3% this year, with an employment rate of 65%. The government aims to balance the economy by shifting from manufacturing to service sectors, and has submitted a budget bill with a 5.7% increase in fiscal spending. Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan warned of deflationary risks and promised to keep fiscal policy loose until 2027. The country faces risks of stagnation and an ageing population.

site_title: Enhanced rules for accountants to combat money-laundering and terrorism-financing
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has issued new guidelines for accountants to combat money-laundering and terrorism-financing. The Ethics Pronouncement 200, effective from November, sets enhanced mandatory requirements for implementing controls and procedures against these areas. Non-compliance may result in investigations by Acra or the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants. The guidelines are benchmarked to international best practices and Financial Action Task Force Recommendations, aiming to strengthen the country's anti-money-laundering and anti-terrorism-financing measures.

site_title: Brokers' Take: OCBC reiterates 'buy' call on Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust
summary: OCBC Investment Research has reiterated its "Buy" call on Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT), with a fair-value estimate of S$1. The trust's management believes the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong won't affect Festival Walk, its shopping mall. MGCCT's latest financial results showed a 10.4% year-on-year growth in distribution per unit and a 3.6% growth in tenants' sales. The trust's operating metrics exhibit resilience, with a 99.2% portfolio occupancy and positive rental uplift. MGCCT's share price has risen 6.1% since OCBC initiated the "Buy" call, outperforming the FTSE ST Reit Index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: The Hour Glass, CDLHT, Sheng Siong, Wing Tai, Yoma, GEH
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on Wednesday include The Hour Glass after its acquisition of Watches of Switzerland, Yoma Strategic Holdings with a 200% increase in net profit, Sheng Siong with a 15.4% rise in net profit, and Great Eastern Holdings with a 31% drop in net profit. Wing Tai Holdings reported a 1% dip in net profit, while CDL Hospitality Trusts posted an 11.9% increase in gross revenue.

site_title: Australia: Shares up on firm resources, JB soars on higher sales, new stores
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5,458.6 on Wednesday, driven by gains in the resources sector and a 8.6% surge in JB Hi-Fi Ltd. The company announced plans to open eight new stores in FY 2015, boosting sales 0.5% year-to-date. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also rose, while copper prices hit a two-week high. However, financial stocks fell, led by losses in Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, Westpac Banking Corp, and National Australia Bank.

site_title: Tharman: Home prices correction not there yet (Amended)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that Singapore's property prices have not seen a "meaningful correction" yet. Prices in private and HDB resale markets have shown some correction over the last 4-5 quarters, but more is needed to reverse the sharp price run-up in recent years. The share of borrowers taking multiple housing loans has decreased, and the average tenure of new private housing loans has been trimmed. Recent price drops, including a 0.7% decline in private property prices and a 1.7% decline in HDB resale prices, are seen as a step towards achieving a meaningful correction.

site_title: Social e-commerce firm YuuZoo enters gaming market with its first mobile game
summary: YuuZoo Corporation Limited, a social e-commerce firm, has launched its first mobile game, Honey Snatch, a physics-based, match-3 puzzle game, following its successful launch on iTunes. The game has garnered over 5,000 installations and "very positive" player feedback, with short-term retention at 30-40%. CEO Thomas Zilliacus sees gaming as a lucrative market segment that opens up significant revenue opportunities for the company, with the global mobile game market projected to reach $23.9 billion by 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up 0.87% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.87% at the open on Wednesday, driven by a surge in Chinese equities ahead of the corporate earnings season. The Hang Seng Index increased 203.65 points to 23,732.01.

site_title: Yoma Strategic Q2 net profit more than doubled on strong property sales
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' Q2 net profit more than doubled to S$10.8 million, driven by strong sales of residences and land development rights in Myanmar. Revenue surged 53% to S$41.2 million, with the Star City project contributing 80% of total revenue. The company recorded S$25.2 million in LDR sales for Star City Zone C, with performance fees and profit share to be recognized in coming quarters.

site_title: Japan Sept industrial output rises 2.7% m-o-m
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 2.7% in September, reversing the 1.9% decline in August, according to government data. This increase met economists' median estimate of a 2.2% rise. However, manufacturers expect a 0.1% drop in October and a 1.0% increase in November. The data provides a positive outlook for Japan's factory activity and broader economy.

site_title: French central bank chief tells life insurers to cut payout rates
summary: French central bank chief, Noyer, urges life insurers to cut payout rates as interest rates fall, making payouts increasingly difficult. With record low yields on government bonds, insurers offering guaranteed returns are at risk. Noyer expects a significant fall in payout rates this year, allowing insurers to adjust pay without putting themselves at risk. The move is seen as a response to France's attractive tax breaks for life insurance savers, with AXA and CNP Assurances dominating the market.

site_title: Bitcoin brokerage Coin Republic surpasses S$1 million in turnover
summary: Coin Republic, a Singapore-based bitcoin brokerage, has surpassed S$1 million in annual turnover, according to its founder David Moskovitz. Despite a decline in bitcoin prices from US$750 to US$350, the company's growth in volume indicates demand for an alternative means of exchange in Singapore. Moskovitz attributes the price decline to bitcoin's growing acceptance by major merchants and subsequent conversion of holdings into fiat currency. He remains bullish on bitcoin's prospects in Singapore and the region, citing the company's ability to operate profitably despite market volatility.

site_title: Lower mark-to-market gains dragged Great Eastern Holdings' Q3 net profit
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 31% drop in Q3 net profit to S$194.6 million due to lower unrealised mark-to-market gains. The insurance business generated an 8% increase in operating profit to S$149 million, driven by higher contributions from non-participating funds and investment-linked funds. New sales declined 22% to S$213.9 million, mainly due to policies maturing and strong product take-up. Despite challenges, the company aims to invest in expertise and systems to operate efficiently in a changing environment.

site_title: 'Terror threat': US boosts security at government buildings
summary: The US has increased security at government buildings amid threats from Islamist groups, following two attacks in Canada that killed two soldiers. The decision, made by Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson, aims to safeguard US government personnel and facilities. The actions, not disclosed, will be reevaluated as necessary, with a focus on protecting against terrorist attacks and promoting public safety. The move comes as the US and its allies combat the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.73% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.73% on Wednesday, driven by strong gains on Wall Street and a weaker yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index reached 15,442.39 points. Investors remain cautious awaiting the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which is expected to announce the end of its stimulus program. Japan's industrial production rose 2.7% in September, supporting the dollar's value against the yen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average in New York also jumped above 17,000 for the first time since October 3.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway sells marketing unit
summary: Berkshire Hathaway Inc has sold its marketing and direct mail unit, World Marketing Inc, to a Wisconsin businessman, Robert M. Kraft. The deal's terms were not disclosed. Milwaukee-based Optimus Financial Services helped secure financing from Associated Bank. This sale marks a rare instance of Berkshire Hathaway selling a company, with billionaire Warren Buffett building the conglomerate into a diverse portfolio.

site_title: Giken Sakata's FY14 net profit up, expects Indonesian oil business to start contributing
summary: Giken Sakata reported a FY14 net profit of S$2.1 million, up 374% from the previous year, despite a 45.5% decline in revenue due to the discontinuation of a turn-key project. The company's gross profit rose 23.8% to S$11.7 million, and its gross profit margin increased to 17%. Giken Sakata expects its Indonesian oil business, acquired in September 2014, to start contributing to earnings in the first quarter of FY2015, with plans to increase average daily oil production and build up its reserve portfolio.

site_title: Singapore, New Zealand, Hong Kong best for business
summary: The World Bank's annual "Doing Business" report ranks Singapore, New Zealand, and Hong Kong as the world's easiest places to run a business, with top scores of 88.27, 86.91, and 83.25, respectively. China, Brazil, and India ranked 90th, 120th, and 142nd, respectively. The report measures business operating environment, including starting a company, getting electricity, and resolving commercial disputes. Singapore's favorable business environment is attributed to its efficient regulatory system, while countries like Eritrea and Russia struggled with lengthy bureaucratic processes and high costs.

site_title: Bank of England's Cunliffe says can keep rates low for longer
summary: The Bank of England's Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe stated that the economy can maintain record-low interest rates for longer than initially thought due to weak pay, low inflation, and a weaker international outlook. This suggests that a rate rise may not occur before the middle of next year, as two policymakers who previously supported a rate hike are unlikely to find further support. Sterling fell slightly against the dollar and euro, reinforcing the market's view that the BoE is unlikely to raise rates soon.

site_title: Time Warner's HBO to cut 7% of staff
summary: Time Warner's pay TV network HBO is cutting 7% of its US staff, approximately 150 jobs, amid pressure to boost profits. The company, under CEO Richard Plepler, is shifting resources to areas with potential for revenue growth, including a planned stand-alone online streaming video service. HBO's domestic workforce will be reduced from 2,400, while the company has also announced cuts at its Turner Broadcasting and Warner Bros. units. This move comes after Time Warner rejected a takeover bid from Twenty-First Century Fox and faces pressure to boost its stock price.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps 1%, S&P ends above key level
summary: US stocks rose 1% on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 ending above its 50-day moving average for the first time in almost a month. Strong earnings from companies like Amgen Inc and consumer confidence data boosted the market. Energy stocks led the gains, while Twitter Inc fell 9.8% after disappointing earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.12% to 17,005.75, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.75% to 4,564.29, setting fresh records.

site_title: Spotlight thrown on highly leveraged borrowers
summary: A spotlight has been cast on highly leveraged borrowers in Singapore, with nearly 3% of unsecured-credit borrowers owing debts exceeding their annual income. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Credit Counselling Singapore have introduced a centralized repayment system to help these individuals, amid regulations to stop excessive unsecured borrowing. Despite a strong household balance sheet, some consumers are at risk of debt problems due to overspending, retrenchment, and pay cuts, with debt from gambling affecting 17% of debtors.

site_title: Common sense prevails in IMO committee
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has agreed to review and revise the guidelines for ballast water management systems (BWMS) to address industry concerns about the costs and effectiveness of new equipment. The revision will ensure that shipowners who have already installed type-approved systems prior to the revised guidelines are not penalized, and port states will refrain from applying criminal sanctions or detaining ships during a trial period. The move is seen as a victory for common sense and a step towards reducing the estimated $100 billion investment required for new BWMS by 2016.

site_title: New Zealanders to vote on flag change
summary: New Zealand will hold a binding referendum in 2016 on changing its national flag, a move supported by Prime Minister John Key. The current flag, featuring the Union Jack, will be replaced with a new design featuring a silver fern on a black background. A cross-party committee will select potential designs, with the public voting in two referendums: one in 2015 and another in 2016 to choose between the new design and the existing flag. The move aims to create a more recognisable New Zealand identity.

site_title: CCS - from unpopular entity to key negotiator
summary: Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) has come a long way since its establishment in 2004, transforming from an unpopular entity to a key negotiator in the banking industry. Initially struggling to secure funding, CCS received support from charitable organizations and eventually the Association of Banks in Singapore. The organization has since helped over 11,600 distressed debtors and submitted more than 6,000 restructuring proposals, providing value to stakeholders and parties involved. This shift in attitude marked a turning point, with CCS now recognized as a professionally managed organization that facilitates debt restructuring.

site_title: MERS still 'significant' threat to Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia's health ministry confirms MERS-CoV remains a significant threat, with at least 17 infected in the western city of Taif since September 5, half of the 38 cases reported in the kingdom since then. The virus, transmitted from camels to humans, has killed 333 people in Saudi Arabia since June 2012, with 780 confirmed cases. Health officials are concerned about breaking transmission chains in Taif and urge proper hand-washing, coughing etiquette, and avoiding contact with camels to reduce the risk.

site_title: Wing Tai Q1 profit dips 1% to S$24.2m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 28% drop in revenue to S$160.1 million for its Q1 2014, with net profit dipping 1% to S$24.2 million. Operating profit fell 14% to S$37.2 million, mainly due to lower contributions from development properties. The company expects a difficult operating environment in the Singapore property market this fiscal year.

site_title: Malaysia PM backs idea of creating Islamic mega bank
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak supports the creation of a large Islamic mega bank, which would develop a global footprint for Islamic finance and position it as an alternative to conventional banking. A proposed merger between CIMB Group Holdings Bhd and two smaller peers would create a sharia-compliant bank with financial clout and regional scope. Razak aims to integrate Islamic finance into the wider market, not just in the Muslim world, and believes the industry is addressing issues such as governance and human capital to support the mega bank concept.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak said on Tuesday that he backed the idea of creating a large stand-alone Islamic bank, in order to develop a global footprint for Islamic finance and position it as an alternative to conventional banking.

site_title: A dim winter for Europe as risks of blackouts rise
summary: A study by Cap Gemini warns of increased risks of blackouts in Europe this winter due to reduced thermal power-generating capacity and a growing reliance on renewables. Belgium is cited as an example, and France is at risk of blackouts from 2015. The study blames utility company closures, economic slump, and competition from cheaper US coal imports for the reduced capacity. European power prices have fallen to below zero, and the European Union's investment in renewables has increased significantly, further exacerbating the issue.

site_title: ECB's foray into bond buying may help Europe's rich get richer
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi may be increasing income inequality in the euro region through its asset purchases, similar to the US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing. Critics, including Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz and former Bank for International Settlements chief William White, warn that this could exacerbate the gap between the rich and the poor. The ECB aims to boost inflation, but its non-conventional tools, such as large-scale asset purchases, may widen income inequality, particularly among those who don't hold the assets that benefit from the ECB's actions.

site_title: Merger ahead for two Chinese trainmakers
summary: China's State Council has ordered the merger of trainmakers China Northern Locomotive & Rolling Stock Industry Group Corp and CSR Group into one company. The consolidation aims to facilitate winning foreign contracts and create a company with $33.6 billion in sales and $1.44 billion in net income. China is expanding its high-speed rail network to sustain its economic boom and is competing aggressively for overseas rail projects in emerging markets. The merger will enable a Chinese trainmaker to better compete against Japanese companies overseas, particularly Hitachi and Kawasaki Heavy Industries.

site_title: Parallel car imports accelerate, thanks to Japanese models
summary: Parallel car imports in Singapore have surged by 40.3% in the first nine months of 2014, with 1,239 registered, surpassing the year-to-date spike of 17.7% in the total passenger car market. Toyota and Mercedes-Benz remain the top two parallel import brands, while Honda has taken third place, replacing BMW. Toyota's new Harrier model, introduced in the first quarter, has contributed to its extended lead. Parallel imports currently account for 6.2% of total car sales, up from 5.2% in 2013.

site_title: MAS's sobering take on S'pore economy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has presented a sobering outlook for the Singapore economy, forecasting GDP growth to remain constrained at 2.5-3.5% in 2014, with productivity growth and core inflation expected to stay above historical averages due to labour cost pressures. The manufacturing sector faces difficulties, but companies are moving up the value creation chain. The MAS expects moderate growth in 2015, with uneven sectoral performance, and notes that domestic-oriented sectors will remain resilient despite external headwinds.

site_title: SingTel partners Microsoft in new cloud offering
summary: SingTel has partnered Microsoft to offer a new cloud operating system network (COSN) to its customers in the Asia-Pacific region. The solution allows enterprise customers to move data and workloads between public, dedicated private, and SingTel's virtual private cloud. This partnership makes SingTel the first Asia-Pacific telco to offer COSN, providing seamless interoperability between Microsoft-based private clouds and SingTel Managed Cloud. The collaboration enables customers to harness cloud power while keeping mission-critical data on-premises.

site_title: DBS China completes first RMB-SGD direct trade in China's interbank market
summary: DBS Bank (China) has completed its first RMB/SGD spot deal in China's interbank market, marking the first RMB/SGD deal since the launch of direct RMB/SGD trading on Tuesday. This deal is also the first RMB/SGD deal completed by DBS Bank (China) as an official RMB/SGD market maker.

site_title: NASA orbital rocket explodes after launch
summary: A NASA Orbital Sciences Corporation unmanned spacecraft, Cygnus cargo ship, exploded just six seconds after launch on a resupply mission to the International Space Station. The incident occurred on the Antares rocket at Wallops Island, Virginia, and fires were seen burning at the launch pad. The cause of the explosion is unclear, but damage is limited to the facility, and there is no indication of personnel in danger. The mission, CRS-3, was intended to deliver 5,000 pounds of supplies to the six astronauts on the ISS.

images.alt_text: An Orbital Sciences Corporation unmanned spacecraft exploded Tuesday six seconds after launch on a resupply mission to the International Space Station, NASA said.

site_title: China should not practise duplicitous policy
summary: China is seeking to reassert its leadership role in international organizations, such as the Apec forum, while maintaining a peaceful image. The country has taken steps to ensure quality air during the meeting and is engaging in diplomatic efforts with neighboring countries, including Vietnam and Japan. However, China's past duplicitous policy, including supporting insurgent groups in countries like Malaysia, has raised concerns about its commitment to international law. Despite improving its international performance since the 1970s, China appears to be selectively adhering to international rules, highlighting the need for greater transparency and consistency in its foreign policy.

site_title: OSIM run of record profits loses steam
summary: OSIM International, a Singapore-based lifestyle products company, reported a 28% decline in net profit to S$16.4 million for the three months ended Sept 30, 2014, due to "several millions" of legal costs and investment costs for opening new TWG Tea outlets. Revenue edged up 3% to S$158.2 million. Despite this, OSIM's CEO Ron Sim remains optimistic, citing positive fundamentals and a dominant market position. The company plans to expand TWG Tea to 45 outlets by year-end and launch two new products in the holiday season.

site_title: Obama can still make a difference with a Republican Congress
summary: US President Barack Obama's final two years in office may be hindered by a Republican Congress, but he can still achieve significant foreign policy successes. He may secure a depleted Islamic State presence in Iraq and Syria, stabilise Afghanistan's national unity government, and negotiate a comprehensive nuclear agreement with Iran. Additionally, Obama can push for the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, two key international trade agreements. Historically, two-term presidents have secured notable international achievements in their final years, with Clinton and Reagan examples cited, suggesting Obama can still make a lasting impact.

site_title: Surbana signs MOU to work on Dalian projects
summary: Surbana International Consultants has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the government of Dalian, Liaoning province, to work on various projects for a new 140-sq-km airport coastal business district. The district will be located at the intersection of three economic zones and aims to transform Dalian into a vibrant international eco-smart city within five to 10 years. Surbana will collaborate on urban planning, architectural design, and project management, leveraging its expertise in eco-city planning and design.

site_title: Facebook Q3 revenue rises 59%, shares down slightly
summary: Facebook's Q3 revenue rose 59% to $3.2 billion, exceeding Wall Street targets. The company's mobile ads drove growth, accounting for 66% of advertising revenue. However, WhatsApp, acquired for $22 billion, reported a loss of $232.5 million in the first six months of 2014. Despite this, analysts believe WhatsApp is a "long-term play" and its growth in users is key. Facebook's net income increased to $806 million, with 1.35 billion monthly users and 864 million daily users. Shares were down less than 1% at $80.20 in extended trading.

site_title: Few takers for Arctic route despite thaw
summary: Despite rapid ice melting and rising temperatures, few firms are taking the Arctic route for business due to high costs, West-Russia tension, and loan problems. Ice-breaking tankers cost $100 million more than normal vessels, and railways require hundreds of millions of dollars to upgrade. Winter darkness, ice, and vast distances make Arctic investments unfeasible for many companies. Loan funding is also hindered by uncertainty over tensions between the West and Russia, making projects like the Yamal LNG project uncertain.

site_title: Art-lovers laud Picasso museum reopening in Paris
summary: The Picasso Museum in Paris has reopened after a four-year renovation process, exceeding its original size. The museum's expansion was marred by controversy, including budget overruns, staff firings, and high-level disputes. The renovation was completed despite initial delays and a new director, Anne Baldassari, was dismissed. The museum now houses the world's largest Picasso collection, attracting art lovers and providing a unique opportunity to experience the artist's work in a grand setting.

site_title: Untapped continent
summary: African nations are increasing their borrowing in the sovereign debt market, with sub-Saharan countries raising nearly $7 billion so far this year. Despite concerns over economic woes and political instability, yields on new bonds in Ghana, Kenya, and Nigeria have dipped, indicating improved market outlooks. Investors are drawn to emerging market debt due to higher yields, which can be more than three times as high as those on US Treasury securities. However, investors also face risks, including fragile institutions and corruption, and some countries have defaulted on other forms of debt.

site_title: Dollar steady in Asia before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar remained stable in Asia before the Federal Reserve's two-day policy meeting, which is expected to conclude its six-year-old stimulus program. The dollar edged up to 107.86 yen, while the euro rose to US$1.2701. Traders will be monitoring the Fed's language on interest rates, which may change once the stimulus program ends. Bank policymakers are expected to discuss the first rate hike, but recent global economic turbulence may delay any movement.

site_title: HK-China trade data gap widens to US$13.5b
summary: China's reported exports to Hong Kong widened by a record US$13.5 billion in September, a discrepancy attributed to fake export-invoicing that distorts economic figures. The gap occurred despite China's government rules on importing capital, as speculators exploit yuan appreciation by disguising money inflows as payment for goods exported to foreign countries or territories. This raises concerns over China's economic growth, with analysts questioning the export surge and warning of moderating economic growth.

site_title: US consumers sue Takata over alleged airbag defects
summary: US consumers sued Takata Corp over alleged airbag defects, claiming the company and car manufacturers like Toyota and Honda defrauded them by concealing crucial information. The lawsuit, filed in a US District Court in Florida, seeks class-action status on behalf of consumers nationwide. The lawsuit claims Takata failed to disclose safety issues with airbags made between 2000 and 2007, which have linked to at least four deaths and dozens of injuries. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is also investigating the issue.

site_title: Parker leads India hedge funds
summary: Nandita Agarwal Parker, founder of Karma Capital Management, is leading India-focused hedge funds with a decade-long track record of success. Her top-performing fund, Karma STAR, has a 15.58% annualized return and is set to boost assets to $500 million in three years, driven by hopes of economic revival under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Parker's success is seen as a step towards progress for women in the field, and her story is inspiring others, including women who head two of India's biggest banks.

site_title: Tiny fly delays Australia-China cattle trade
summary: Australia's efforts to export live cattle to China have stalled due to the presence of Bluetongue disease in the Australian herd, spread by midges. Talks have stalled, with no timetable for an agreement, despite high demand for meat in China. The virus poses a major threat to China's 140 million-strong sheep flock, the world's largest. Any deal is now expected to be delayed until at least 2015, with China's domestic prices remaining high due to limited land, water, and feed, and rising demand from the US.

site_title: IDA unveils 'smart nation' initiatives
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has unveiled a series of initiatives to build a vibrant and sustainable data ecosystem, aiming to make Singapore the world's first "smart nation". The initiatives include Data-as-a-Service (DaaS), a pilot programme that provides cloud computing services to participating data providers, and a partnership with SAP Asia to boost big data innovation among small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups. IDA also announced the accreditation of three start-ups, Tagit, KAI Square, and V-Key, which will have access to government projects and funding.

site_title: Productivity must rise in long term: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to boost productivity to support long-term economic growth, citing education, training, and sunrise businesses as key strategies. He acknowledged the challenge of maintaining high wages without corresponding productivity gains, but argued that the country's unique strengths, such as its skilled workforce and business-friendly environment, can help mitigate this issue. Lee also expressed concerns about regional and global challenges, including peace and security issues, and the need for Singapore to address its own economic and social challenges to ensure sustainable growth.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Raffles Medical Group (RMG) reported a 10.4% year-on-year growth in distribution per unit to 2.35 Singapore cents in Q3 2014, driven by a 30.2% jump in gross revenue. However, foreign patient load declined due to rupiah weakness, and staff costs may increase in the next two quarters. The company is considering expanding its operations in China, which could drive long-term earnings growth. Analysts maintain a "hold" stance on RMG due to its sturdy financial performance and growth prospects, which have been priced in.

site_title: Challenges push manufacturers to higher-value activities
summary: Singapore's manufacturers are shifting towards high-margin, capital-intensive activities as they adapt to uneven external demand and falling global prices. Over the past two decades, they have moved away from resource-intensive activities, with steady labor productivity growth and employment growth of less than 50%. The electronics sector, in particular, has driven this shift, with manufacturers responding to domestic supply constraints and weak demand abroad by changing their business models and focusing on niche production and services. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects this trend to continue, driven by global trends such as cloud computing.

site_title: US energy firms unfazed by plunging oil prices
summary: US energy companies remain confident they can adapt to the 24% drop in oil prices, with many expecting to return ample profits. Improved technology and multiple basins allow shale producers to shift work to more profitable sites. Industry leaders believe prices between $80 and $100 a barrel will be sufficient for their sector to thrive. Despite the price decline, some operators can profit at lower prices due to increased efficiency and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q3 net profit up 15.4% at S$12.2m
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 15.4% increase in its Q3 net profit to S$12.2 million, driven by higher revenue and better margins. Revenue rose 4.8% to S$186.4 million, with comparable same-store sales growing 3.4% and new stores experiencing a 1.4% year-on-year increase. The company attributed the growth to competitive buying and direct purchasing, which improved its gross margin to 24.2%. For the nine-month period, net profit increased 21% to S$35.8 million, while revenue rose 5.9%.

site_title: Europe opens firm but stocks here weaken
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 14.46 points to 3,211.65 on Tuesday, dragged down by a sell-off in Noble Group, banks UOB and OCBC, and Keppel Corp. A dealer attributed the sell-off to a possible exit by a big fund or weak earnings expectations. Markets are waiting for the Federal Open Markets Committee (FOMC) meeting on Wednesday, where the Fed may provide hints on raising short-term interest rates, potentially affecting the selling cycle.

site_title: UBS misses Q3 earnings estimate on legal provisions
summary: UBS AG, Switzerland's largest bank, posted a smaller-than-estimated third-quarter profit due to setting aside 1.84 billion Swiss francs for legal costs related to alleged currency rigging. The bank's net income rose to 762 million francs, missing the average estimate of 804 million francs. UBS expects ongoing legal and regulatory costs, and authorities have started settlement talks with the bank over allegations of foreign-exchange manipulation, potentially involving "material monetary penalties".

site_title: OCBC names organiser of 2015 cycling event
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Pich Event Management to organise the OCBC Cycle 2015 event, a cycling event to be held at the Singapore Sports Hub in August 2015. The event aims to improve safety measures, including capping participant numbers and deploying more marshals and paramedics. The event will also feature activities and charity components, with OCBC working with various companies and organisations to support the cause. The new event is a response to last year's fatal accident during the event.

site_title: AIIB: Yet another symbol of the changing balance of global power
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) was launched in Beijing, marking a shift in the global balance of economic and political power. The US-inspired institution is being challenged by emerging economies, including China, India, and Russia, who seek to escape post-war, US-dominated institutions. The AIIB's creation underscores the desire for a multi-polar world, with China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei stating that the bank will set high standards and avoid "bureaucratic, unrealistic and irrelevant policies." The AIIB's launch is seen as a response to the dominance of Anglo-Saxon economic development priorities and a challenge to US-led institutions.

site_title: Deutsche's Asia wealth business woos mega-rich
summary: Deutsche Bank's Asia-Pacific wealth-management business aims to increase revenue by 20% in 2015 by targeting ultra-high net-worth individuals with at least $100 million of investable assets. The unit, led by Mark Smallwood, will focus on Singaporeans, Hongkongers, and other affluent groups, offering structured-finance products and alternative investments. The move comes as the region's growing ranks of rich individuals are expected to surpass North America, with assets at Asia's top 20 wealth managers growing 12% to $1.36 trillion in 2013.

site_title: Singapore bankers expecting less bubbly Christmas
summary: Singapore bankers expect a bonus this year, with 71% of respondents expecting a payout, but fewer are anticipating bumper bonuses, with only 42% expecting an increase. The number of bankers expecting a smaller bonus has increased to 22%. This reflects a more realistic expectation, with professionals citing the makeup of the market, including more staff in middle and back offices, as the reason for lower bonus expectations.

site_title: Investors doubt Fed will start lifting rate in mid-2015
summary: Investors are expressing doubt about the Federal Reserve's plan to start lifting interest rates in mid-2015, contradicting forecasts from Fed officials and most Wall Street economists. Despite a robust US outlook, investors are betting on a later tightening due to global economic and political turmoil, including the Ebola virus, low inflation, and resurgent violence in the Middle East. Most economists still expect the Fed to keep rates low for a "considerable time" and the first rate increase may occur in the third quarter or later, with some predicting a June rate increase.

site_title: Honda cuts sales forecasts on recalls, competition
summary: Honda Motor Co Ltd cut its sales forecasts for this year due to competition in Japan and China, as well as the impact of recalls on new model launches. The company's operating profit fell 4.1% to 164.4 billion yen in July-September, missing estimates. Honda expects to sell 4.62 million vehicles globally this year, 4.3% fewer than previously estimated. The company cited a weak yen as a factor helping it stick to its operating profit estimate, but will re-examine its car development process due to multiple recalls.

site_title: 2 confirmed list sites, 1 reserve list site open for tender
summary: JTC has launched tenders for two confirmed list sites in Singapore, including a 0.8-ha site at Tuas South Street 9 with a 20-year tenure and a maximum gross plot ratio of 1.0, and a 1.6-ha site at Tanjong Penjuru with a 20-year tenure and a maximum gross plot ratio of 2.5. The sites are zoned for business-2 development or heavier industrial use. The tenders close on December 23. The shorter tenure for the Tanjong Penjuru site is aimed at meeting the needs of industrialists at affordable prices.

site_title: Del Monte tops in value
summary: Del Monte Pacific topped the net buys list in Singapore's S$1 billion market capitalization stocks, with mutual funds buying S$21.7 million worth of shares. Meanwhile, mutual funds sold S$97.5 million worth of Ascendas Reit. These transactions provide insight into where fund managers are focusing their attention, but note that alternative investors and institutional money managers may not be disclosing their trades.

site_title: New York's hottest new trend: clubbing for kids
summary: New York's hottest new trend is clubbing for kids, with over 300 children aged 6-12 attending a Halloween-themed party at The VIP Room nightclub in the Meatpacking District. Organized by CirKiz, the events allow children to experience the music and dance scene in a safe and controlled environment, with parental supervision and strict volume controls. The brainchild of DJ Jesse Sprague and his wife, the parties aim to inspire kids to pursue artistic interests and develop creative minds. Similar events are planned in other cities, including Atlanta, Orlando, and Taiwan.

site_title: Luxury car drivers see smaller fall in fuel prices
summary: Luxury car drivers are seeing a smaller decline in fuel prices compared to regular drivers. The shale oil boom is driving down the cost of low-octane petrol, while premium fuel prices remain stable. The price gap between the two grades has widened to 40 US cents a gallon, the largest since 2008. The US is producing more oil, reducing its reliance on foreign sources, and refinery maintenance is also contributing to the price disparity. As a result, regular petrol prices are expected to fall below US$3 in the next couple of weeks.

site_title: Jobseekers' prospects hit by feeble growth in Europe
summary: The euro area is experiencing feeble growth, leading to stagnant job prospects for many. Unemployment rates remain high, averaging 11.5% in September, with France, Italy, and Spain having rates above 10%. Economists predict no significant improvement in 2015, with some regions, such as Germany, also facing economic slowdowns. Companies are cutting staffing levels and reducing working hours in response to weak demand, further exacerbating the economic downturn.

site_title: FCL to seek shareholders' approval at Nov 12 EGM
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Limited (FCL) will hold an extraordinary general meeting on Nov 12 to seek shareholders' approval for two counts. The first is retroactive approval of the company's acquisition of Australand Property Group, and the second is approval for an interested person transaction where TCC Prosperity Limited will subscribe for up to 50% of the proposed perpetual capital securities. The proposed offering aims to diversify funding sources, manage debt, and bolster the balance sheet. Net debt to total equity post-acquisition would improve to 83%.

site_title: HK protesters call for talks with Beijing
summary: Hong Kong democracy activists are calling for direct talks with Beijing officials, marking one month of mass protests. The Umbrella Movement, which began on October 1, demands China rescind its decision requiring all 2017 city leader candidates to be vetted. Protest leader Alex Chow will seek a meeting with China's Prime Minister Li Keqiang if the Hong Kong government fails to relay protesters' demands. Billionaire Alibaba founder Jack Ma attributed the protests to "young people who don't have hope" and urged both sides to listen.

site_title: Labour market remains chief source of inflation
summary: Singapore's inflation is expected to remain driven by the tight labour market and rising wages, with businesses in education, healthcare, and meals more likely to pass costs to consumers. However, retailers facing intense competition will struggle to raise prices. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) forecasts core inflation to rise slightly into early next year, averaging 2-2.5% this year and 2-3% next year. Overall consumer price inflation is expected to remain subdued, with a forecast of 1-1.5% this year and 0.5-1.5% in 2015.

site_title: Singapore to build renewable energy micro-grid
summary: Singapore is building the world's first micro-grid to integrate multiple renewable energy sources, including solar, wind, tidal-current, and diesel, as part of its clean energy hub in South-east Asia. The Renewable Energy Integration Demonstrator Singapore (Reids) project, costing S$8 million, will produce 1 MW of electricity and test technologies in tropical conditions. The project aims to provide electricity to island communities and remote villages, and strengthen grid stability in urban areas. Industry players, including GDF Suez and Vestas, have expressed interest in testing technologies in the region.

site_title: LionGold still reeling from stock crash, files late annual report
summary: LionGold, a Singapore-based gold mining company, has filed its delayed 2014 annual report, revealing a significant decline in its financial performance. The company's share price crashed after a "penny stock" crash in October 2013, and a probe by Singapore's white-collar crime buster exacerbated the situation. LionGold suffered a net loss of S$189.1 million and a cash outflow of S$23.19 million, with its market capitalization dwindling from S$1 billion to S$27 million. The company's board has lamented the "events that altered things considerably" and plans to restructure its operations and debt obligations.

site_title: Durable goods orders in Sept post biggest drop in 8 months
summary: US durable goods orders fell 1.3% in September, the second consecutive month of declines, with core capital goods orders dropping 1.7% and aircraft orders dropping 16.1%. Consumer confidence rose to a seven-year high, however, as Americans' assessments of the labor market improved. Single-family home prices rose 5.6% year-over-year in August but fell short of expectations. The Commerce Department's GDP estimate is expected to show the economy expanded at a 3.0% annual pace in the third quarter.

site_title: Surge in retail sales cheers Japanese govt, BOJ
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe received positive economic news as retail sales surged 2.3% in September, beating analyst predictions. The increase, fueled by sales of clothing, food, and beverages, suggests the economy is recovering from a sales tax hike in April. The news also paves the way for restarting Japan's idled nuclear reactors. The Bank of Japan's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, remains optimistic about achieving a 2% annual inflation target, but the sluggish economy has raised doubts.

site_title: Credit-card hacking is top crime worry in US: poll
summary: A Gallup survey found that credit-card hacking is the top crime concern for Americans, surpassing other worries such as mugging or murder. As major retailers experience cyber breaches, awareness of the hacking threat has increased. The survey comes as the number of reported breaches continues to rise, with thieves stealing credit card data from tens of millions of customers.

site_title: A call for more infrastructure
summary: India faces significant infrastructure challenges to catch up with China by 2050, with a population expected to reach 1.7 billion and urbanization increasing. India's infrastructure gap with China has widened, with China having built 35,000 km of four-lane highways and over 9,200 km of high-speed train tracks, while India has 6,000 km of four-lane highways. India's electricity generation capacity is also behind China, with 99% of its population having access to electricity. The country's infrastructure deficit is estimated to be $1 trillion over the next five years, hindering development and making it difficult to meet budgeted fiscal deficit targets.

site_title: Media's blockbuster business tool: big data
summary: Media companies are leveraging big data to gain a competitive edge in the industry. Executives must focus on business outcomes rather than just collecting data. Traditional media companies struggle to sift through data and deliver content that resonates with audiences. In contrast, technology-based media companies like Facebook, Google, and Netflix excel at understanding data. To keep up, traditional media companies need to develop new skills and capitalize on the opportunities presented by big data. This shift is crucial for their success in the market.

site_title: Investors see buy opportunity in short-selling of Japan stocks
summary: Investors with $293 billion in client assets are taking a buy opportunity in Japanese stocks due to high short-selling. The Topix index has tumbled 7.7% from its six-year high, but shares have rallied an average 9.7% over the past three months following surges in bearish bets. Experts say the pessimism is a signal to buy, citing history and positive factors such as declining yen, which will boost company earnings and consumer confidence.

site_title: The Hour Glass buys Watches of Switzerland for S$13.3m
summary: The Hour Glass (THG) acquired Watches of Switzerland (WOS) for S$13.3 million, expanding its luxury watch portfolio and reach into suburban Singapore. The acquisition, funded from internal sources, will make WOS a 100% subsidiary of THG. The deal is seen as an opportunity to tap into Singapore's suburban retail landscape and enhance the group's position in the watch retail sector. THG's boutiques will be boosted to 37, with WOS's five shops becoming part of the group. The acquisition comes at a time when the luxury watch business in Singapore is facing a challenging time due to the decline in Chinese tourists.

site_title: 11-country tour to market London's Battersea begins
summary: The 11-country tour for London's Battersea Power Station project begins, showcasing 539 new homes in Phase 3. The homes will be priced from £495,000 (S$1.02 million) for studio apartments to £3.2 million for four-bedders. The project, valued at £8 billion, has been hailed as the "jewel in the crown" of central London's regeneration area. However, a proposed annual "mansion tax" on UK properties valued at £2 million may dampen enthusiasm, and market experts caution against buying properties now due to the uncertainty surrounding the tax.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Prospect Place and Prospect Park - part of Phase 3 of the Battersea project that will be launched for sale in the Republic from Oct 31 to Nov 2.

site_title: StanChart Q3 profit falls 16%; plans cost cuts
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 16% drop in operating profit for the third quarter to $1.5 billion, mainly due to a jump in bad loans and higher regulation and compliance costs. The bank plans to cut costs by $400 million in 2015 to combat a downturn in emerging markets. It expects underlying profits in the second half to be lower than last year, partly due to a higher UK bank tax and regulatory costs. The bank faces structural issues and regulatory scrutiny, with analysts predicting it will struggle to drive returns above cost of capital in the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Veterans join RBS Asia-Pac markets business
summary: The Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has hired Colin Holdstock and Glen Goh to head its Asia-Pacific markets business in Singapore. Holdstock, a veteran, will oversee cash and non-deliverable forwards, emerging markets short-term interest rate trading, and currency options trading. This move is part of RBS's efforts to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: CDL Hospitality's DPU down slightly in Q3
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a slightly lower income available for distribution per stapled security of 2.61 Singapore cents in Q3 2014, down from 2.64 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue rose 11.9% to S$40.1 million, driven by the recognition of full revenue from its Jumeirah Dhevanafushi hotel. Net property income grew by 2.4% to S$33.8 million, despite a decrease from Claymore Link. The group remains cautious in an uncertain global economic climate, with a record occupancy of 92% in Q3.

site_title: McDonald's could be next activist investor target
summary: McDonald's, the world's largest restaurant chain, faces vulnerability as it loses customers to rivals like Wendy's and Chipotle. The company's valuation relative to earnings is lower than its American peers, making it a potential target for activist investors. With a cash reserve and low debt, activist investors like Carl Icahn and Nelson Peltz could push for share buybacks or changes in strategy. McDonald's has already returned $4.6 billion to shareholders this year, but its profit fell 30% in the last quarter, and the stock has fallen 5.2% this year.

site_title: Volkswagen says to launch over 20 electric vehicle models in China
summary: Volkswagen plans to launch over 20 electric vehicle models in China, including small cars, SUVs, and plug-in hybrids, by the end of the decade. The company aims to catch up with global rivals like Tesla and BMW in the Chinese market, where pollution concerns have led to stricter regulations. China aims to have 5 million green vehicles on the road by 2020. Volkswagen's expansion is part of the company's efforts to introduce more than 15 electric or plug-in hybrid cars by 2018, many of which will be locally produced.

site_title: Obayashi-Woh Hup venture bags S$1.57b Jewel, T1 job
summary: A joint venture of Woh Hup and Obayashi Singapore has won the S$1.57 billion contract to construct Project Jewel at Changi Airport and expand Terminal 1. Construction will begin by year-end, with completion expected by end-2018. The project will include leisure attractions, retail outlets, and hotel rooms, as well as improved arrival and departure facilities. The enhancements aim to cement Singapore's status as an air hub, competing with regional and international upgrades.

site_title: STATS ChipPac posts US$5.29m Q3 net loss
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a semiconductor packaging and test services provider, posted a net loss of US$5.29 million in the third quarter, down from a net profit of US$13.3 million a year ago. Revenue edged up to US$403.77 million, with adjusted EBITDA at 22.3% of revenue. The company expects Q4 revenues to be flat to 6% lower, with adjusted EBITDA in the range of 20-24% of revenue.

site_title: KrisEnergy sees big growth in sales next year
summary: KrisEnergy Ltd, a Singapore-based energy-exploration company, expects significant growth in sales next year, projecting a 15,000 barrels per day production by 2015, doubling to 35,000 by 2017. The company is forecast to report a net income of US$31.5 million and revenue of US$239 million, marking its first annual profit. This growth is attributed to the development of existing fields and new fields coming online, with executive director Richard Lorentz stating that the next 12-18 months will be a crucial period for the company.

site_title: Sour on economy, more Americans back Republicans: poll
summary: A poll by ABC News and Washington Post found that 70% of Americans rate the economy negatively, with 56% disapproving of President Barack Obama. Nearly 3 in 10 respondents said they will vote in the midterm elections to punish the president. Republicans are expected to win control of the Senate, with 46% of voters predicting a Republican victory. Disaffection with politicians is high, with 40% saying it makes no difference which party controls Congress.

site_title: Renewable energy push doesn't rest on just oil prices: Iswaran
summary: Singapore will maintain its commitment to investing in renewable energy, despite falling oil prices. Second Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran stated that the investment in renewable energy development (R&D) is driven by broader considerations, not just oil prices. This commitment aligns with Singapore's goal of becoming a leader in sustainable energy. The country's focus on renewable energy is part of its overall strategy to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and mitigate climate change.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE will not waver in its commitment to invest in renewable energy in spite of falling oil prices.

site_title: URA release of Paya Lebar Central site, with conditions, draws mixed views
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released a 164,794 sqm mixed-use site in Paya Lebar Central, with nearly 55% for office use and the rest for retail, entertainment, F&B, and residential. URA has limited strata office units to five and retail units to three to preserve the project's image and quality. Market watchers expect 3-8 bids with top prices ranging from S$700 to S$1,000 psf ppr, and the site's attractiveness to deep-pocketed investors. The tender will close on March 31 next year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Google teams up with PwC on client solutions
summary: Google has teamed up with PwC to offer joint knowledge and capabilities to clients, providing innovative services via Google Apps. The collaboration aims to help companies collaborate more effectively, better use technology and information, and adapt to the rapidly changing world. Clients will gain access to PwC's business insights and Google's technology platforms, while PwC will bring deep industry experience and cutting-edge client insights. The two companies will work on current solutions and develop new offerings in three areas, including cloud transformation and embracing the future of work.

site_title: US home prices rise less than expected in August: S&P/Case-Shiller
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.6% year-over-year in August, the slowest increase since November 2012, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller composite index. This fell short of economists' expectations of a 5.8% gain. On a seasonally adjusted basis, prices dropped 0.1% for the month, while non-seasonally adjusted prices rose 0.2%. Despite the decline, the national index increased for its eighth consecutive month, showing an overall increase in home prices.

site_title: US consumer confidence rebounds in October
summary: US consumer confidence rebounded in October, rising to 94.5 from 89.0 in September, according to the Conference Board. The present situation component edged up to 93.7, while the expectations component surged to 95.0. This boost in confidence is a welcome sign for retailers ahead of the holiday season, with consumers regaining confidence in the short-term economy and labour market.

site_title: Air France-KLM "firmly denies" Dutch newspaper reports on job cuts
summary: Air France-KLM firmly denies Dutch newspaper reports that it plans to slash 7,500 jobs, or 25% of its Dutch arm, through outsourcing. The airline stated in a statement that the reports are "pure speculation" and "false information." The job cuts were expected to be announced at the release of quarterly earnings on Wednesday, according to the head of the trade union for airline personnel in the Netherlands. Air France-KLM will not let "false figures" circulate in the media. The airline has not provided any confirmation on job cuts.

images.alt_text: Air France-KLM said it "firmly denies" Dutch newspaper reports that it is planning to slash 7,500 jobs at its Dutch arm, or 25 per cent of the total, largely through outsourcing.

site_title: China unveils legal reform plans, but says party to remain in control
summary: China's Communist Party has unveiled plans to reform its judicial system, aiming to fight corruption and prevent abuses of power. The party pledged to speed up legislation to prevent forced confessions and ensure timely corrections, following a series of corruption investigations. However, the judiciary will remain under party control, and officials must pledge allegiance to the constitution before taking office. The reforms are part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has been criticized for suppressing human rights and dissent.

site_title: Swedish central bank cuts interest rate to zero
summary: The Swedish central bank, Riksbank, cut interest rates to zero on October 28, 2014, to ward off deflation risk and maintain economic growth. This decision comes after persistently low inflation and a delay in tightening policy until the middle of 2016. The move sent the Swedish crown to a four-year low against the US dollar and euro, and economists criticized the bank for being behind the curve on inflation concerns. The Riksbank raised its growth forecast for this year but downgraded next year's outlook slightly.

site_title: Twitter's efforts to engage users yet to fully pay off
summary: Twitter's efforts to boost user engagement and growth have been unsuccessful, with the company's timeline views per user falling 7% in the third quarter and its user base growing at a 23% rate, down from 39% in the same period last year. The stock fell 14% to a near four-month low, prompting rating and price target cuts from at least four brokerages, with analysts citing deceleration in monetization and unsustainable growth in ad prices as concerns.

site_title: Nine out of ten Hong Kong activists say will fight on for a year
summary: Hong Kong protesters, mostly students, say they will continue to occupy the streets for more than a year to push for full democracy and counter China's tightening grip on the city. In a Reuters survey, 87% of protesters said they are willing to stay on the streets for over a year, and 93% said they would regroup and launch fresh protests if forcibly cleared. The protests, which began in September, are fueled by China's imposition of a restrictive framework for a city-wide vote in 2017 and growing wealth inequality, with 59% and 38% of protesters citing these factors as major motivations, respectively.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end 0.45% lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.45% lower on Tuesday, closing at 3,211.65 points. The Straits Times Index fell 14.46 points, with 1.19 billion shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 236 to 147.

site_title: 'Possible another plane shot down MH17'
summary: Dutch prosecutors investigating the MH17 crash believe the aircraft might have been shot down from the air, but a ground-to-air missile attack is more likely, according to a senior prosecutor. The Russian government claims a Ukrainian military aircraft shot down the Boeing 777, but Western officials have disputed this. The Dutch will ask Moscow to provide radar data to support the Ukrainian claim, and a US report previously stated evidence suggested a ground-to-air missile was fired by Russian-backed forces in eastern Ukraine, where the wreckage lies.

site_title: Noble Energy quarterly net income more than doubles
summary: Noble Energy Inc reported a significant increase in its third-quarter net income, more than doubling to US$419 million or US$1.12 per share, driven by increased natural gas sales and prices. Excluding a hedging charge, the company earned US$110 million. This marks a substantial improvement from the year-ago quarter.

site_title: Germany in Europe: From near-destroyer to reluctant leader
summary: Germany, once destined to be Europe's principal nation, has emerged as the continent's supreme power after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. However, this turnaround is marked by irony, as Germany's past as a hub of European imperialism has left a legacy of distrust. Today, France and the UK are divided, with the UK's far-right UKIP dictating the national agenda, while Germany has become the world's second-biggest immigrant nation and a reluctant leader in Europe, facing challenges such as racism and the rise of right-wing leaders in neighboring countries.

site_title: Colin Holdstock, Glen Goh join RBS's Asia-Pacific markets business
summary: The Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has hired Colin Holdstock and Glen Goh to head its Asia-Pacific markets business, both based in Singapore.
