Holdstock joins as managing director and head of cash and non-deliverable forwards, emerging markets short-term interest rate trading, and currency options trading. Goh joins as managing director, head of NDF and STIRT, reporting to Holdstock. Holdstock comes from Nomura, where he was the head of FX Options for Asia ex-Japan since 2010.

site_title: PwC and Google to jointly help companies transform businesses
summary: PwC and Google have teamed up to help companies transform their businesses in three areas: improving productivity, leveraging technology and information, and breaking new ground. The collaboration combines PwC's business insights with Google's cloud-enabled collaboration and productivity tools. The partnership aims to enhance collaboration, speed, and ultimately, business transformation for the digital era. PwC has begun introducing Google for Work products to its own operations and transitioning employees to Google Apps, showcasing the partnership's impact.

site_title: US durable goods orders drop in September
summary: US durable goods orders declined 1.3% in September to $241.6 billion, missing analysts' expectations of a 0.6% increase. The decline followed a 18.3% drop in August, mainly driven by a sharp decrease in transportation orders. Excluding transportation equipment, orders fell 0.2%.

site_title: OSIM Q3 profit down 28% partly on TWG Tea's legal, start-up costs
summary: OSIM International reported a 28% decline in net profit to S$16.4 million in its third quarter, ended Sept 30, 2014. Revenue edged up 3% to S$158.2 million. The decline is attributed to "several millions" of legal costs and investment costs for opening new TWG Tea outlets in China and Taiwan. OSIM subsidiary TWG Tea is embroiled in two lawsuits, and sales were also affected by weaker consumer sentiment and reduced sales of OSIM products at Brookstone outlets in the US.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on solid earnings from DuPont, Pfizer
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday following solid earnings reports from DuPont and Pfizer. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 82.71 points (0.49%) to 16,900.65, while the S&P 500 rose 9.78 (0.50%) to 1,971.41. DuPont's earnings jumped 50% to $433 million, while Pfizer's earnings rose 2.9% to $2.7 billion. Investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which may end its bond-buying program and provide guidance on interest rate hikes in 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.53 points to close at 1,825.68 on Tuesday, driven by gains from some 1.58 billion lots valued at RM1.79 billion. The market saw 284 gainers and 529 losers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drift lower as investors eye Fed; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.3% to 1,925.68 points, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's two-day meeting for clues on interest rate hikes. The won strengthened against the dollar amid market weariness over the Fed's dovish statements.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 1.63% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.63% on Tuesday, following a surge in Chinese equities ahead of the corporate earnings season. The Hang Seng Index gained 377.13 points to 23,520.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 2.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 2.39%. This marked an end to a three-day losing streak, with turnover reaching HK$67.71 billion and 158.1 billion yuan, respectively.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q3 net profit up 15.4%
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 15.4% increase in net profit to S$12.2 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2014. Revenue for the same period rose 4.8% to S$186.4 million. For the nine-month period, net profit increased by 21% to S$35.8 million, while revenue rose 5.9% to S$547.6 million. Earnings per share for the group improved, with the counter closing half a Singapore cent lower at 63.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: DBS China completes first RMB/SGD direct trade in China's interbank market
summary: DBS Bank (China) Limited completed the first RMB/SGD spot deal in China's interbank market, marking a milestone in the direct trading of the two currencies. The deal, facilitated by DBS China's head of trading, Kyle Tan, will enable Chinese businesses and Singapore corporates to convert RMB into SGD directly, reducing FX risks. This follows the launch of direct RMB/SGD trading between China and Singapore, aimed at boosting economic ties between the two nations.

site_title: India's top court slams failure to form Delhi government
summary: India's top court criticized authorities and politicians for failing to form a government in New Delhi over eight months after the previous administration's resignation. The court urged a resolution, stating that Delhi residents deserved a democratically elected government. Lieutenant Governor Najeeb Jung and the national government were targeted for their delay. President Pranab Mukherjee has now given consent to invite the BJP to form a new government, following a petition from the Aam Aadmi Party seeking fresh elections.

site_title: Indonesia says Chevron gas project set back by up to 2 years
summary: Indonesia's Indonesia Deepwater Development (IDD) gas project has been delayed by up to two years to around 2020, pushing the country's prospects of remaining a major gas exporter. The delay affects the $12 billion project, with Chevron Corp initially planning to proceed with the first stage but reassessing the second stage. As Indonesia scales back LNG exports, it plans to import LNG from the US starting in 2018. The delay is part of a broader shift in Indonesia's energy strategy, with a focus on meeting domestic demand.

images.alt_text: The target for full operation of the Indonesia Deepwater Development (IDD) gas project has been delayed by up to two years to around 2020, a senior official said, reducing the country's prospects of remaining a major gas exporter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.38%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.38% on Tuesday, October 28, 2014, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's next policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 58.81 points to 15,329.91, while the Topix index fell 0.18% to 1,252.00. Camera and copier giant Canon declined following a weak profit report.

site_title: Inflation target timing not like 'train schedule' :BoJ deputy chief
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Kikuo Iwata expressed doubts about the timeline for reaching the 2.0% inflation target, saying it's not as rigid as a train schedule. This remark may fuel doubts about the ambitious goal, which was initially set to be reached in about two years. Iwata stated that monetary policy aims to influence behavior, not follow a fixed timeline. Economists say it's unlikely the target will be reached by the end of spring next year, but Iwata said the goal will be achieved as soon as possible within the 2015-2016 period.

site_title: US business spending weakens despite upbeat sentiment
summary: US business spending weakened in September with a 1.7% decline in non-defense capital goods orders, the largest drop in eight months. This contrasts with upbeat business sentiment, as reflected in recent surveys. Overall durable goods orders fell 1.3% and core capital goods shipments slipped 0.2%. The decline may prompt economists to lower third-quarter GDP estimates, which are expected to show a 3.0% annual pace. Despite this, unfilled orders of core capital goods increased 0.6% and inventories rose moderately.

images.alt_text: A key gauge of capital goods orders by US businesses recorded its biggest drop in eight months in September, but the surprise decline was likely to be temporary as business sentiment has been upbeat in recent months.

site_title: Spanish banks seen taking 18b euro in ECB cheap loans: Economy Minister
summary: Spanish Economy Minister Luis de Guindos expects banks to take up to 18 billion euros in the European Central Bank's next auction of cheap long-term loans in December. This is part of an ECB stimulus package to revive the eurozone economy. In the first auction, lenders took 82.6 billion euros, less than expected. The loans are four-year investments, and the amount taken will likely increase in the next auction.

site_title: Standard Chartered shares tumble to 5-year low as profit slumps on bad debts
summary: Standard Chartered's shares plummeted 8% to a 5-year low, falling to 996p, after the bank reported a 16% drop in quarterly operating profit due to rising bad debts and higher regulatory costs. The bank expects underlying profits to be lower in the second half of the year, citing weak trading revenues and losses in South Korea. CEO Peter Sands aims to cut $400 million in costs next year, but analysts predict earnings forecasts will be cut by 15% this year and 2015.

site_title: [Update] Hot stocks: ISEC Healthcare and Serrano
summary: CATALIST-LISTED ISEC Healthcare ended its stock trading debut on Tuesday at S$0.37, up 32% from its IPO price of S$0.28. The medical eye care-service provider had 70 million placement shares subscribed for, generating approximately S$19.6 million in application monies. Separately, shares of Serrano, a provider of interior fit-out solutions, ended its debut trade at S$0.235, up about 2% from its IPO price of S$0.23, with application monies received amounting to approximately S$6.6 million.

site_title: US regulator tells BP it has closed energy price-fixing probe
summary: US regulator Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has closed its energy price-fixing probe into BP, with no charges or fines. The investigation, launched in 2013, was related to BP's submission of prices to Platts, the world's leading oil pricing agency. Other regulators, including the European Commission and Japanese Fair Trade Commission, are still investigating BP and other oil majors. The FTC's decision marks a significant development in the ongoing probe, but no timeline has been set for completion of the inquiries.

images.alt_text: BP said on Tuesday it was told by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) it was closing its probe into anticompetitive practices in oil price reporting and assessment, but other regulators were still investigating.

site_title: China's Q3 property loans fall 23% q-o-q as market cools
summary: China's property loans decreased 23.3% in Q3 compared to the previous quarter, reflecting a cooling housing market. The total property loans issued for the first nine months reached 2.1 trillion yuan, a 5% increase from the same period last year. Despite this, outstanding mortgages by the end of September rose 17.5% from the same period last year. The Chinese government has taken measures to boost the economy, including cutting mortgage rates and downpayment levels, amid a decline in average home prices for the fifth consecutive month.

site_title: 71% of Singapore bankers confident of a bonus; fewer expect bumper payouts: poll
summary: A survey by eFinancialCareers found that 71% of Singapore bankers are confident of receiving a bonus this year, with a stable figure compared to last year. However, fewer are expecting bumper payouts, with 42% expecting an increase and 22% anticipating a smaller bonus. The survey polled 696 professionals and showed that companies are taking a more strategic approach to bonus payouts, prioritizing top performers and increasing basic salaries. This shift is seen as a result of companies trying to manage staff expectations.

site_title: Woh Hup and Obayashi Singapore joint venture lands S$1.57 billion contract for Project Jewel and Changi's T1 expansion
summary: A joint venture between Woh Hup and Obayashi Singapore has secured a S$1.57 billion contract to construct Project Jewel and expand Changi's Terminal 1. Construction will begin by the end of 2014 and is expected to be completed by the end of 2018. The project includes the redevelopment of a 3.5-hectare site into a larger arrival hall and improved parking facilities. The facilities at Project Jewel will enhance existing services and offer retail, leisure, and hotel options. The joint venture, led by Woh Hup, will partner with Changi Airport Group and Jewel Changi Airport Trust.

site_title: Alibaba sets eye on online travel with new platform
summary: Alibaba has launched Alitrip, an independent online travel platform, as part of its efforts to tap into China's growing online travel market. The platform, which was previously run as Taobao Travel, will offer services including hotel bookings, visa applications, and travel services, with over 10,000 merchants already on board. The move comes as China's online travel market saw a 20% year-on-year increase in the third quarter to reach $11.9 billion in transaction value. Alibaba sees huge "unmet demand" for travel services in China and aims to enrich its ecosystem with Alitrip.

site_title: JTC launches two confirmed-list sites and one reserve-list site
summary: JTC Corporation launched two confirmed-list sites, one in Tuas South Street 9 and one in Tanjong Penjuru, zoned for Business-2 development. Additionally, a reserve-list site was launched in Tuas South Street 7 under the 2014 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme.

site_title: StanChart Q3 profit tumbles on South Korea restructuring, impairments
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 16% drop in operating profit for the third quarter, largely due to rising costs from South Korea restructuring and increased impaired loans. The bank expects profits to fall for a second consecutive year, citing a slowdown in emerging markets growth and weak trading. Regulatory scrutiny, including a fine from New York's financial regulator, also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Honda Motor Q2 profit falls 4%, misses estimates
summary: Honda Motor reported a 4.1% fall in second-quarter profit to 164.4 billion yen ($1.52 billion), missing analyst estimates. The company struggles with US and Japan product recalls, potentially delaying new model development. Honda keeps its full-year forecast at 770 billion yen. The result also comes after US consumers filed a lawsuit over defective airbags and Honda's fifth domestic recall of its Fit hybrid subcompact. Shares closed 0.7% lower.

site_title: Ukraine unlikely to receive IMF loan tranche this year: finance minister
summary: Ukraine is unlikely to receive a second $2.7 billion IMF loan tranche this year due to the ongoing government formation and a need for a realistic 2014 budget. The delay may leave Ukraine with only $760 million in EU aid this year. The country is struggling to resolve a gas pricing dispute with Russia and faces a $3.1 billion debt payment by the end of the year, which could deplete its gold and foreign reserves.

site_title: More debtors seek help from Credit Counselling Singapore
summary: Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) reported a 112% increase in debtors seeking help from 2009 to 2014, with 1,509 individuals counselled in the first eight months of 2014. The average outstanding debt grew 22% to $94,765, attributed to rising income and consumer loans. CCS president Kuo How Nam emphasized that the increase does not indicate a worsening debt situation, but rather increased awareness and a larger loan base.

site_title: SingTel partners Microsoft to offer new cloud solution
summary: SingTel has partnered Microsoft to offer a new cloud operating system network (COSN) to its customers in the Asia-Pacific region. The solution enables enterprises to move data and workloads between public, dedicated private, and SingTel's virtual private cloud. This collaboration provides seamless interoperability between Microsoft-based private clouds and SingTel Managed Cloud, offering flexibility, enterprise-grade security, and cost savings. SingTel will be the first telecommunications service provider in Asia-Pacific to offer COSN, catering to enterprises that use widely available Microsoft applications.

site_title: Property prices not yet at 'meaningful correction': DPM Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that Singapore property prices have not experienced a "meaningful correction" yet. Despite some price drops in private and HDB resale properties over the past four to five quarters, prices are still ahead of household income growth. A meaningful reversal is necessary to avoid property prices outpacing income growth in the long term.

site_title: OCBC appoints new organiser for cycling event in 2015
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Pich Event Management to organise OCBC Cycle 2015, a cycling event to be held at the Singapore Sports Hub on August 29-30, 2015. OCBC terminated its agreement with Spectrum Worldwide after last year's event, which was marred by a fatal crash. The event will be sanctioned by the Singapore Cycling Federation and supported by Sport Singapore. OCBC plans to collaborate with 12 companies to create pre-event activities and will continue its charity component, supporting local organisations such as the Singapore Children's Society and the Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: 3% of unsecured-credit borrowers in S'pore have debts exceeding annual income: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that 3% of unsecured-credit borrowers in Singapore have debts exceeding their annual income. Approximately 65% of these individuals have incomes above the median, with more than half holding tertiary-education qualifications. Over-spending is the common reason for falling into debt problems. The average outstanding debt is S$84,000, with debtors owing money to an average of seven banks and financing firms.

site_title: Apple CEO fires back as retailers block Pay
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook fired back at CVS and Rite Aid after the drugstore chains blocked Apple Pay, citing better security and privacy. Despite the setback, Apple Pay has seen over a million credit card registrations and more transactions than other "contactless" payment methods. Cook said there are "plenty of other retailers" to sign up with Apple Pay, and the company aims to enhance mobile device utility. Industry experts say Apple Pay stands a chance of becoming the first widely used payments feature on smartphones.

site_title: BP announces slump in profits
summary: BP's third-quarter profits plummeted 63% to US$1.29 billion, down from US$3.78 billion in the same period last year, due to sliding crude oil prices. The company attributed the decline to lower energy prices and increased competition in the market.

images.alt_text: Profits at BP slumped in the third quarter, the British energy giant said on Tuesday against a backdrop of sliding crude oil prices.

site_title: E-waste inferno burning brighter in China's recycling capital
summary: China's Guiyu town is a major electronic waste recycling hub, with 1.6 million tonnes of e-waste processed annually, generating $600 million in revenue. However, the industry's environmental cost is high, with toxic air and water pollution affecting local residents, particularly children, who have high lead levels in their blood. The town's e-waste problem is expected to worsen, with China set to surpass the US as the world's largest e-waste producer by 2017. Critics argue that the industry's lax regulations and focus on economic growth prioritize profits over human health and the environment.

site_title: Centralised repayment system to be set up for distressed borrowers from next year
summary: Singapore's Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) will launch a centralized repayment system for distressed borrowers starting next year. The system, coordinated with banks, will consider borrowers' income, spending needs, and loan obligations. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the initiative during CCS's 10th anniversary luncheon, aiming to simplify debt repayment for borrowers with debts owed to multiple banks.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank investing US$627m in Indian online giant Snapdeal
summary: SoftBank is investing $627 million in Indian online marketplace Snapdeal, becoming its largest shareholder. The deal, expected to be completed by the end of November, values Snapdeal at $2 billion. SoftBank aims to boost its presence in India's booming online market, which is expected to reach $32 billion in sales by 2020. This investment is part of SoftBank's strategy to deploy significant capital in India over the next few years.

images.alt_text: SoftBank said Tuesday it would invest US$627 million in Snapdeal, becoming the largest shareholder in India's leading online marketplace as the Japanese mobile carrier strengthens its presence in the fast-growing market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise 0.20% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.20% in the opening exchanges on Tuesday, driven by anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which could provide insight into interest rate plans. The Hang Seng Index gained 46.60 points to 23,189.83.

site_title: IDA launches Data-as-a-Service pilot
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) launched a Data-as-a-Service (DaaS) pilot to address dataset visibility and accessibility in the private sector. Data providers from various industries can participate, with the first 25 sign-ups receiving US$3,000 in cloud computing credits from Amazon Web Services (AWS). IDA will hold workshops and data challenges to raise awareness of the DaaS platform, aiming to increase dataset visibility and reach new customers.

site_title: Société Générale appoints regional head of trade for South-east Asia, India, Middle East
summary: Société Générale has appointed Sonal Priyanka as regional head of trade for South-east Asia, India, and the Middle East, based in Singapore. She will report to two senior executives and is part of the group's strategy to expand its trade services in Asia. Priyanka previously held roles at Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation in Singapore, and Citibank and GE Commercial Finance in India.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma tops China rich list: Forbes
summary: Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, has become China's richest person with a fortune of nearly $20 billion, according to Forbes' annual "China Rich List". Ma's wealth increased after Alibaba's record-breaking IPO on the New York Stock Exchange, valued at over $240 billion. The number of Chinese billionaires surged to 242 this year, despite a slowdown in the country's economy. Ma topped the list, followed by Robin Li of Baidu and Pony Ma of Tencent, with their respective fortunes of $14.7 billion and $14.4 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall after reaching a 6-wk high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.12% to close at 5,452, after reaching a 6-week high on Monday. Weak global data and the resources and energy sectors weighed on investor sentiment. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 0.08% to close at 5,338.33. The decline was attributed to financials bouncing back from losses, but global economic concerns and US-EU trade talks remained a focus.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed, eyes on Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with Tokyo down 0.76%, Sydney 0.42%, and Seoul 0.33% lower. Hong Kong rose 0.44% and Shanghai 0.79%. The Fed is expected to end its asset-buying program and discuss interest rates, with traders concerned about the impact on the global economy. The dollar edged up to 107.95 yen, while the euro gained after better-than-expected eurozone bank stress test results. Oil prices fell, and gold rose to $1,227.45 an ounce.

site_title: Hot stocks: ISEC Healthcare and Serrano trading thin
summary: ISEC Healthcare and Serrano Limited, two debutantes on the Singapore Catalist board, have had lackluster showings in the first half of the day. ISEC Healthcare's shares traded at S$0.365, while Serrano's shares traded at S$0.23, both down from their opening prices. The Singapore Exchange noted that the listing of ISEC Healthcare brings the total number of SGX-listed healthcare companies to 26, with a combined market capitalization of over S$35 billion. The Catalist now has 150 companies with a combined market capitalization of S$11 billion.

site_title: Singapore and China agree to enhance joint efforts to guard intellectual property
summary: Singapore and China agreed to enhance joint efforts to guard intellectual property through a Memorandum of Understanding. The agreement, signed at the 11th Singapore-China Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation meeting, aims to strengthen cooperation in areas such as intellectual property laws and policies, financial products, and valuation and appraisal. The partnership seeks to promote a more robust intellectual property protection system and facilitate the exchange of ideas and experiences between the two countries.

site_title: Singapore ramps up research to integrate renewable energy sources
summary: Singapore is building the region's first micro-grid to integrate multiple renewable energy sources, including solar, wind, and tidal-current power. The project, led by Nanyang Technological University, will test and demonstrate various technologies at the Semakau Landfill site. The initial S$8 million project is expected to draw in additional S$20 million from industry players. The goal is to produce enough electricity to power 250 HDB flats, addressing acute energy needs in Asia, particularly in island communities and remote villages.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.02 points to 1823.13. A total of 34.21 million lots were traded, worth RM12.01 million, with 91 gainers and 49 losers.

site_title: Citizens unite on data
summary: Citizens unite on data through various initiatives such as g0v.tw, DataScience.sg, and DataKind in Singapore, showcasing the growing impact of public interest in data-driven projects. Open data has become increasingly popular among enthusiasts, rather than corporations, leading to innovative work in the field. This trend is expected to continue, with citizens taking the lead in leveraging data for social good.

site_title: One month into Hong Kong protests, defiance on the streets
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests, one month old, continue to face pressure to maintain momentum despite government resistance to their demands. Protesters, who have set up camps across three major thoroughfares, are under pressure to shift tactics to force a response from authorities. The Chinese government insists on screening candidates for the 2017 election, which protesters say is designed to ensure a pro-Beijing candidate. Protest leaders, including Joshua Wong, are determined to continue the protests, while some grumble about a lack of direction from leadership.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 10.96 points to 3,215.15. The market saw 58 losers and 50 gainers, with volume reaching 84.5 million shares worth S$111.2 million.

site_title: Virgin Australia chairman to step down
summary: Virgin Australia chairman Neil Chatfield will step down after seven years, citing the airline's strong position to guide the company into the future. Chatfield led the airline through a turbulent domestic market, marked by a bitter rivalry with Qantas. Both airlines recorded annual net losses of A$355.6 million and A$2.84 billion respectively. Chatfield will remain in his role until a replacement is found, as the airline continues to expand with the recent acquisition of Tigerair Australia.

site_title: OCBC names next head of HR, with current head's retirement due in mid-2015
summary: OCBC Bank announced that Jason Ho will succeed Cynthia Tan as Head of Group Human Resources from July 1, 2015, upon her retirement. Ho, 52, is currently the head of Asset & Liability Management and will be appointed Deputy Head of Group Human Resources in January 2015 to facilitate a smooth transition.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint seeks shareholders' approval for Australand acquisition
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) will hold an extraordinary general meeting on Nov 12 to seek shareholders' approval for two counts: the acquisition of Australand Property Group and an interested-person transaction. TCC Prosperity Limited will subscribe for up to 50% of FCL's proposed perpetual capital securities offering, valued at S$300 million or lower. CEO Lim Ee Seng hopes the acquisition will fuel FCL's growth, and the proposed offering will improve the company's capital structure and balance sheet.

site_title: Broker's Take: CDL Hospitality Trusts' Q3 DPU within expectations, says OCBC
summary: OCBC Investment Research stated it will review its recommendation for CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) following the company's Q3 DPU of 2.61 Singapore cents, down slightly from last year. The trust reported a 11.9% increase in gross revenue to S$40.1 million, driven by the full revenue recognition of its Jumeirah Dhevanafushi hotel, acquired last December. The result met expectations, allowing OCBC to maintain its assessment of CDLHT's fair estimate.

site_title: Two Japan ministers acknowledge political fund improprieties
summary: Two Japanese cabinet ministers, Environment Minister Yoshio Mochizuki and minister in charge of women's empowerment Haruko Arimura, acknowledged improprieties in their use of political funds. Mochizuki incorrectly reported party expenses as costs in 2008 and 2009, while Arimura's affiliated group received donations from a company fined for tax evasion. Both ministers intend to stay in their jobs despite the revelations, which come amid public criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government. The incidents follow the resignation of two other ministers over similar issues.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge lower as investors eye
summary: South Korean shares edged lower on Tuesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which is expected to conclude with the end of quantitative easing. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.2% to 1,928.10 points, influenced by weak US services data and German business sentiment. Despite this, defensive sectors like telecoms and insurance companies rose, while oil refiners plummeted due to crude price drops. Analysts expect minimal market reaction to the Fed's announcement, citing already priced-in concerns.

site_title: Australia stops processing visas from Ebola-hit countries
summary: Australia has temporarily suspended processing humanitarian and immigration visas from West African countries affected by the Ebola outbreak, citing concerns over the risk of the disease reaching the country. Immigration Minister Scott Morrison announced the move, which includes canceling non-permanent visas and requiring permanent visa holders to undergo a 21-day quarantine period. This measure comes as the Ebola outbreak in West Africa has killed nearly 5,000 people, and Australia has contributed A$18 million to fight the disease.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat from 6-week high on resources, energy
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, retreating from a six-week high, due to weak global data and pressure from the resources and energy sectors. Disappointing US services sector data and weak German business sentiment contributed to the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 23.3 points to 5,435.6, amid falling iron ore and oil prices, with BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group experiencing significant losses.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.17% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.17% lower on October 28, 2014, amid caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index declined 25.44 points to 15,363.28. Investors are closely watching the Fed's decision on quantitative easing and its impact on the currency market. The dollar was at 107.88 yen, and the euro fetched US$1.2699. Trading was expected to be muted, with Wall Street stocks finishing little changed the previous day.

site_title: URA launches tender for the second land parcel in Paya Lebar Central
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for a 3.9-hectare mixed-use site in Paya Lebar Central, which can generate about 165,000 sq m of gross floor area. The site is slated for office, retail, and residential use and is expected to be a key development in the area. The tender period will last about 22 weeks and close on March 31, 2015. The site is well-connected to major MRT stations and has excellent frontage along major roads. The sale of the site follows the successful award of a nearby site in 2011.

site_title: China Sept industrial profits edge up 0.4% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial profits rose 0.4% in September from a year earlier, reversing an August decline, and increased 7.9% in the first nine months of 2014. This marks a reversal from the 0.6% decline in August. The data comes as China's annual economic growth slowed to 7.3% in the third quarter, the weakest pace since the global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: China's industrial profits in September edged up 0.4 per cent from a year earlier, reversing a 0.6 per cent annual decline in August, data showed on Tuesday. - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL Hospitality Trusts, GLP, Raffles Medical, debutantes ISEC Healthcare and Serrano
summary: Several stocks to watch include CDL Hospitality Trusts, which posted a 2.61 Singapore cent income per stapled security in its third-quarter results, down from 2.64 cents last year. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) unveiled a fund-management platform in Brazil worth US$3.7 billion, while Raffles Medical Group reported a 11.3% year-on-year net profit increase. Debuting companies ISEC Healthcare and Serrano, a homegrown interior fit-out solutions provider, will list on Catalist on Tuesday, with plans to use the proceeds for business expansion and working capital.

site_title: Japanese firm in air bag crisis uses unique chemical to inflate devices
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese firm, has been linked to at least four deaths and over 30 injuries in the US due to air bags deploying with too much force, spraying metal shrapnel at occupants. The company's use of an unusual explosive chemical, ammonium nitrate, has been identified as a key factor, as it can be rendered unstable by moisture. Investigations are ongoing, with over 8 million cars recalled to fix the hazard, and doubts are growing about auto safety and regulatory effectiveness.

site_title: Japan Sept retail sales rise 2.3% y-o-y
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 2.3% in September from a year earlier, exceeding economists' expectations. This is the fastest increase since March and follows a 1.2% annual rise in August. The rise suggests consumer spending is gradually picking up, despite a national sales tax increase to 8% in April. Another sales tax hike to 10% is scheduled for next year, sparking debate about its timing.

site_title: (No headline) - KRSAMSUNG28
summary: US mortgage rates have climbed for the first time in five weeks, according to recent data. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs has acquired 262 billion won worth of hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, while New World is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants at its 21 Collyer Quay location.

site_title: Rousseff promises reforms after narrow poll win
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff narrowly won re-election, promising reforms to tackle poverty and revive the economy. Despite her narrow victory, Rousseff faces significant challenges, including a stalled economy, high inflation, and a widening budget deficit. To restore investor confidence, Rousseff must implement fiscal discipline, including tax and pension reforms, and cut spending on popular welfare programs. Failure to do so could lead to a credit rating downgrade. Rousseff's second term is set to begin on New Year's Day, with the economy expected to face headwinds from global economic trends and a slow growth pace.

site_title: Twitter user-engagement falls 7%, shares dive
summary: Twitter reported a 7% decline in user engagement in the third quarter, sparking a 9% stock selloff. Despite this, the company saw a 23% increase in monthly active users to 284 million. This growth rate met investor expectations, but some worry that Twitter's growth has peaked. The company also projected fourth-quarter revenue that may miss Wall Street's expectations, adding to investor concerns.

site_title: German business sentiment drops to lowest in almost two years
summary: German business confidence dropped to its lowest in almost two years, reaching 103.2 in October, according to the Ifo institute's business climate index. This marks a sixth consecutive month of decline, fueled by a recession-haunted economy, sanctions, and a slowing global market. Economists predict little to no growth in the second half of the year, and factory orders, industrial production, and exports plummeted in August. The European Central Bank has ramped up stimulus to avoid deflation, while some industries, such as luxury vehicles, show signs of growth.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar faces final appeal against sodomy conviction
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim faces a final appeal against his sodomy conviction, which carries a five-year prison term. A ruling against him would likely end his political career and inflame tensions. Anwar, 67, has maintained his innocence and remains optimistic about the outcome. A decision is expected this week, with a ruling against him potentially leading to his jailing and disqualification from the next general election. The conviction has shaken the opposition alliance led by Anwar, but analysts suggest it could galvanize the opposition.

site_title: Xbox One price cut in US for holiday season
summary: Microsoft is temporarily reducing the price of its Xbox One consoles in the US for the holiday season. The price cut, starting on November 2, will bring the base model Xbox One to $349, a $50 discount from its current price. This marks the second price reduction for the consoles since their launch last year, aiming to boost holiday sales.

site_title: GLP expands fund-management platform in Brazil
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) has expanded its fund-management platform in Brazil, with a 68% growth in assets under management to US$12.6 billion. The company formed GLP Brazil Income Partners II (GLP BIP II) and expanded GLP Brazil Development Partners I (GLP BDP I), acquiring a portfolio of Brazil assets and a strategically-positioned land parcel in Rio de Janeiro. GLP will hold a 40% stake in GLP BIP II and remain the asset manager of the BRL2.5 billion portfolio.

site_title: Credit-card hacking is Americans' top crime worry: poll
summary: Credit-card hacking is Americans' top crime worry, surpassing other crimes such as getting mugged or murdered, according to a Gallup survey. As major retailers report cyber breaches, awareness of the hacking threat has increased, with a high percentage of respondents saying they have been victims. This concern is driven by the growing number of major retailers experiencing data breaches. The survey highlights the growing concern over credit-card security in the face of increasing cyber threats.

site_title: Gender equality at work more than 80 years off: report
summary: A report by the World Economic Forum (WEF) predicts that achieving complete gender equality in the workplace will take 81 years, until 2095. Despite progress in areas like healthcare and education, women still face significant disparities in the workforce, with 60% of women having access to economic participation and opportunity, compared to 100% for men. The report highlights the need to accelerate progress, particularly in areas like politics, where women still hold just 21% of decision-making positions globally.

site_title: UK's Cameron escalates row over EU bill, press rails at Brussels
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has refused to pay a 2.1 billion euro bill to the European Union by December 1, citing the bill as "unacceptable" and "deliberate sabotage." Cameron's decision comes as the UK's Eurosceptic media praises him for taking a stand against the EU. The EU has warned that Britain's cherished EU budget rebate could be at risk if it tries to change the rules in response to the bill. Cameron's Conservatives fear the anti-EU UK Independence Party threatens their re-election chances, and the opposition Labour party has criticized the prime minister for being "asleep at the wheel."

site_title: JLL revamps Singapore capital markets team
summary: JLL has revamped its Singapore capital markets team with senior director changes, effective November 1. Greg Hyland, a 14-year veteran, will head the team, bringing strong relationships with institutional investors and China-based investors. Karamjit Singh, who will take an enlarged role, will lead business development and enhance client relationships. Tan Hong Boon will be seconded to JLL's Malaysia business for 12 months to support the country's rapid growth. The changes aim to sharpen the firm's focus on key local and institutional clients, and increase access to regional investors.

site_title: Does raising minimum wage hurt employment?
summary: A study examining the impact of minimum wage policies on employment in China found that a 10% increase in the minimum wage lowers employment by about 1% across all firms. However, the impact varies by firm type, with low-wage firms experiencing a larger decline in employment. Meanwhile, the minimum wage raises wages by about 1% for high-wage firms, but only 2.5% for low-wage firms. The study suggests that policymakers must consider these differential effects when setting minimum wages to balance the impact on employment and wages.

site_title: Goldman slashes 2015 oil price forecast as glut grows
summary: Goldman Sachs has lowered its 2015 oil price forecast, predicting US$75 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and US$85 a barrel for Brent, a decrease of US$15 from previous estimates. The move follows other analysts' predictions of a supply glut due to rising production and slower global economic growth. The US benchmark is expected to fall near 25% over the past five months, adding pressure on crude futures.

site_title: Salmon farmers shun risky growth despite price leap
summary: Norway's top salmon farmers, Marine Harvest ASA and Cermaq ASA, plan to maintain steady production despite high prices and growing demand. They prioritize solving issues such as sea lice outbreaks and disease to avoid rapid growth, which can lead to problems. The industry expects a 3% increase in global supply and a 7% rise in demand next year, driven by consumers seeking healthier diets. Salmon demand is expected to double by 2020, according to the Global Salmon Initiative.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed ahead of Fed; oil shares fall
summary: US stocks finished little changed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 12.53 points to 16,817.94, and the S&P 500 dipping 2.95 to 1,961.63. Investors are awaiting the two-day Federal Reserve monetary policy meeting, which may determine the central bank's plan to end its bond-buying program and raise interest rates in 2015. Petroleum stocks fell due to a Goldman Sachs forecast cut for first-quarter 2015 oil prices, while Merck fell 2.0% after reporting below-expected earnings.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO : REUTERS

site_title: US drafting rules to plug coal royalty loophole
summary: The US government is drafting rules to close an accounting loophole that has allowed coal companies to avoid paying royalties on exports to Asia. The loophole, which was uncovered in a 2012 Reuters investigation, has cost taxpayers tens of millions of dollars. The new rules would require companies to pay royalties on sales to the first unaffiliated customer, or "arm's length sale," in the supply chain. The move aims to collect on the true value of coal sales and prevent companies from pocketing additional profits.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings has become the first online travel agency in the Asia-Pacific to participate in TripAdvisor's instant booking feature, allowing users to make hotel reservations directly on the TripAdvisor site. The partnership is expected to increase bookings and expand hotel inventory globally. Boustead unit BP Engineering Solutions won an RM90 million construction contract to build a medical device manufacturing facility in Kedah, Malaysia. ST Aerospace injected US$4.87 million into its commercial pilot training business, affirming its confidence in growing pilot training capacity.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts posts slightly lower income available for distribution in Q3 2014 (Amended)
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a slightly lower income available for distribution in Q3 2014, at 2.61 Singapore cents, down from 2.64 cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue increased 11.9% to S$40.1 million, driven by the full recognition of Jumeirah Dhevanafushi hotel revenue. Net property income grew by S$0.8 million, mainly due to the hotel's contribution. The Reit's performance was impacted by a slight decrease in income available for distribution.

site_title: More pain as WTI crude oil futures are poised to hit contango
summary: WTI crude oil futures are poised to enter contango for the first time since January, signaling a weaker market. The US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil futures market has seen a 25% decline in outright oil prices since summer. This could make the long-only commodities space less attractive to institutional investors, who have been negatively impacted by the market's recent performance. The International Energy Agency has also cut its 2015 oil demand growth forecast, further supporting the notion of a weaker market.

site_title: DBS ties with HSBC, StanChart in S'pore trade finance
summary: DBS Bank has tied with HSBC and Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore's trade finance market, according to a 2014 study by Greenwich Associates. The top five banks in Asia serving large corporates are HSBC, Standard Chartered Bank, Citi, Deutsche Bank, and ANZ Bank. Companies in Asia are increasingly using trade finance as a source of capital and for process improvement, with 72% of large corporates using the service in 2013. DBS's global transaction services business generates nearly S$1.5 billion in revenue annually.

site_title: Economic inequality is becoming more gender neutral
summary: Economic inequality has become more gender neutral, according to a study by three economists. In the 1980s, almost no women were in the top one percent, but now there are many, with women's representation still below their overall workforce share. This shift challenges the notion that economic inequality is driven by gender disparities.

site_title: Battle for content keeps Facebook hot on publishers' heels
summary: Facebook continues to expand its influence in publishing, with over 1.3 billion users driving engagement through its News Feed. The platform has improved content curation, featuring news that leads to stronger engagement levels. As mobile usage increases, traditional publishers face challenges adapting their business models to the small screen. Facebook has proposed a solution, allowing publishers to host their content within its mobile app, generating revenue through ads. However, this move raises concerns about publishers losing control over their content, with Facebook's chief product officer stating that the company's interests align with those of publishers.

site_title: Rousseff must fight graft to placate angry Brazil
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has won re-election but must tackle corruption, a central issue in her campaign. Allegations of embezzlement at state oil giant Petrobras nearly derailed her campaign, with Rousseff denying knowledge of the scandal. Despite her victory, Rousseff's pledge to crack down on graft may be tested, and the Petrobras scandal could continue to haunt her administration. Analysts warn that corruption and gridlock in Congress could undermine her efforts to deliver on her campaign promises.

images.alt_text: Having won re-election, Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff must now deliver on her pledge to crack down on corruption or be dogged by the scandals that nearly derailed her campaign. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: South Korea Oct expected inflation falls to record low, consumer confidence slips
summary: South Korea's consumer confidence fell to a three-month low in October, with the composite consumer index (CCSI) dropping to 105. This marks the lowest level since July. Consumers also expect inflation to fall to a record low of 2.7% for the next 12 months, which is within the Bank of Korea's target band of 2.5-3.5%. The economy's recovery remains fragile, with exports impacted by cooling global growth, suggesting potential need for further monetary easing.

site_title: Passenger numbers at Changi dip 0.5% in Sept
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore saw a 0.5% dip in passenger numbers to 4.25 million in September, with traffic to South-east Asia, Africa, and the Americas softening. Aircraft landings and takeoffs declined 5% and 2.7% respectively. Despite this, India registered double-digit growth, while China and Thailand traffic dipped due to travel restrictions. The airport's passenger growth for the nine-month period was nearly flat, with cargo shipments increasing 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport Group said that in September, 'traffic to South Asia and Northeast Asia grew by 11 per cent and 2 per cent respectively, but other regions, including South-east Asia, Africa and the Americas, saw lower passenger movements'.

site_title: Low oil prices hurting US shale operations
summary: US shale operations are struggling due to low oil prices, with the number of active oil rigs falling by 19 in the latest data from Baker Hughes. The total number of active rigs now stands at 1,590, the lowest level in six weeks. Experts predict further declines in the rig count unless oil prices reverse, with some regions becoming unprofitable at current prices, such as the Tuscaloosa shale in Louisiana.

site_title: New corporate governance rating framework for SMEs (Amended)
summary: A new corporate governance rating framework for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, known as Gems, has been developed to assess the governance standards of these companies. The framework found that 79% of SMEs lack independent directors with industry experience, and 65% lack unrelated substantial shareholders. However, 97% of SMEs were audited by a certified public accountant or a mid-tier firm. The framework aims to provide a more tailored approach to evaluating corporate governance standards for SMEs, which may not be adequately addressed by existing guidelines.

site_title: S'pore's corporate governance must go beyond legal compliance
summary: Singapore's corporate governance must move beyond mere legal compliance to effectively protect shareholder interests and maintain market confidence. A recent survey found that two-thirds of SGX-listed companies lack sustainability information, while the Asian Development Bank reported that Singapore scored well in disclosure and transparency but fell short on stakeholder rights. To improve, companies should prioritize sustainable business practices, disclose more comprehensive information at annual general meetings, and provide detailed explanations of their dividend policies.

site_title: ST Index ends on a weary, flat note
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.56 points or 0.11% to close at 3,226.11 on Monday, driven by gains among regional peers and a positive stress test outcome by European banks. The gains were partly attributed to Wall Street's 0.8% increase last Friday and China's Shanghai Composite falling 0.5% after the delayed Shanghai-Hong Kong bourse link. The US Federal Reserve is expected to end its asset purchase program and may acknowledge new risks to the outlook in its statement, which will be closely watched by market participants.

site_title: KL links fuel subsidy to income
summary: Malaysia plans to implement a multi-tier fuel subsidy system based on income eligibility, with those earning over RM10,000 (S$3,890) not entitled to subsidies and those earning less than RM5,000 receiving a full subsidy. The system, which uses the national identity card, aims to reduce fuel subsidies but has raised concerns about its complexity and potential for abuse. The government has yet to decide on the new mechanism, which could be a step towards reducing fuel subsidies and increasing efficiency in the system.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group posts 11.3% rise in Q3 profit
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 11.3% year-on-year increase in Q3 profit to S$15.43 million, driven by growth in healthcare services and hospital services. The company plans to expand Raffles Hospital by year-end, adding 220,000 square feet, and is also expanding specialist centers and the emergency department. Revenue increased 11.1% to S$94.49 million, with operating profit rising 8.1% to S$18.15 million. The group expects to benefit from the Community Health Assist Scheme and is considering expanding its operations in China.

site_title: HPH Trust Q3 profit falls 9% to HK$490.7m
summary: HPH Trust reported a 9% drop in Q3 net profit to HK$490.7m, despite a 1.7% revenue rise to HK$3.42b. The port operator saw a 2.1% increase in container throughput at its Hong Kong terminals, while its Shenzhen terminal saw a 12.4% increase. The group attributed the decline in profit to higher costs and inflation, but remains optimistic about its outlook due to growth in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 9 per cent drop in its third-quarter net profit on Monday to HK$490.7 million (S$80.7 million).

site_title: Pending sales of US existing homes rise less than forecast
summary: Pending sales of US existing homes rose 0.3% in September, less than forecast, as credit and inventory remain hurdles for a sluggish housing recovery. The median projection of a 1% gain was also missed. Purchase contracts climbed 1% in the 12 months ending in September, the first year-over-year increase since September 2013. Historically low mortgage rates and improving employment rates may trigger a modest upturn by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore firm creates world's first NFC-powered smart padlock
summary: Singapore-based company JSB Tech has developed the world's first NFC-powered smart padlock, eGeeTouch, which can be unlocked with a tap of a smart device, smartphone, or smartwatch. The padlock features patented NFC technology, allowing for multiple unlocking devices and superior security. It won the "Best New Product" award at the 2014 Japan DIY Homecenter Show and will retail for approximately $79.90. The product's development could revitalize the global padlock industry, which has remained stagnant since its founding in 1862.

site_title: Government stimulus spurring South Koreans into debt binge
summary: South Korean households are accumulating debt at the fastest rate in eight years due to a big-bang stimulus package launched by Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan, which has boosted borrowing by 9.32 trillion won (S$11.23 billion) in the August-September period. The debt build-up, mainly for home purchases, has raised concerns about deflationary pressures and could undermine the government's growth strategy. The worsening global economic outlook and persistent property market weakness may lead to heavier debt loads and deflation, contradicting Choi's "Choinomics" policies.

site_title: Chinese developer gets extension to repay loan
summary: China's Agile Property Holdings has secured a 12-month extension to repay US$265 million of its US$475 million loan, resolving a major refinancing risk. The loan will be repaid with the proceeds of a US$213 million rights issue. Agile's shares rose 2.2% after the news, but some analysts remain skeptical about the company's long-term future due to its debt and slumping margins. The company has also won approval to extend another HK$2.7 billion loan with conditions that its chairman must remain in place.

site_title: Good governance, valuations pique funds' interest in Japan stocks
summary: Funds are increasing their investments in Japanese stocks, driven by good governance and valuations. A 900 million euro Asia-Pacific equity fund has 44% of its portfolio invested in Japanese stocks, surpassing the 40% weight on the MSCI AC Asia Pacific index. This influx of capital could help awaken the Japanese market from its slumber.

site_title: Credit Suisse S'pore proves mettle with Temasek-linked jobs
summary: Credit Suisse Singapore is set to post its best revenue showing for its investment banking arm since 2009, thanks to large M&A deals linked to Temasek Holdings. The bank has also been actively participating in mid-sized acquisitions in Singapore to maintain deal-making momentum. According to Edwin Low, co-head of South-east Asia investment banking, these efforts have contributed to the bank's success. This marks a significant improvement from the 2009 financial crisis, and the bank is expected to continue its growth trajectory.

site_title: Home builders lead returns in China bond markets
summary: China's home builders are leading returns in the country's bond market, with yuan-denominated real estate securities advancing 4.3% since June 30. Premier Li Keqiang's efforts to ease property restrictions and open financing channels have helped the industry, with at least 12 home builders planning to raise 76.7 billion yuan in the interbank market. The government's support is seen as a stabilizing factor for the industry, which has been impacted by falling new home prices and debt.

site_title: 2 US retailers disable Apple payment system
summary: US retailers CVS Health Corp and Rite Aid Corp have disabled Apple's mobile payment system, Apple Pay, in their drugstores, following a consortium of retailers' own competing payment system, CurrentC. The move comes as Apple seeks to replace the consumer wallet with its mobile payment system, which is projected to jump to $90 billion in 2017. Apple's entry into mobile payments follows failed efforts by other companies, and the disabled system is seen as a significant setback for the technology.

images.alt_text: 220,000 US merchants have technology in place to read the signals that enable Apple Pay customers to make a purchase.

site_title: KLW to acquire stake in Mega Sun for 85m yuan
summary: KLW Holdings has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire a 45.45% stake in Mega Sun Development for 85 million yuan (S$17.7 million). The acquisition will give KLW a 25% stake in Suzhou Jiaxin Real Estate Development Company Limited, which is developing Fu Yuan Luxury Villas in Suzhou. The project is expected to be launched in the current quarter and completed around 2017. The acquisition will be funded through proceeds from prior fund-raising exercises, allowing KLW to gain experience in the property development business.

images.alt_text: Listed door manufacturer and investment holdings company KLW Holdings has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement with Prosperity Real Estate Holdings to acquire a 45.45 per cent stake in Mega Sun Development for 85 million yuan (S$17.7 million).

site_title: India reveals names to recover foreign assets
summary: India's government has revealed the names of three businessmen accused of stashing funds in foreign bank accounts. The move is part of the country's efforts to recover billions of dollars in "black money" hidden abroad. The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party, which won power in May, has pledged to crack down on the issue. The names of the businessmen are not disclosed in the article, but the government's action is seen as a step towards recovering the illicit funds.

site_title: Ingredient in chocolate found to boost memory
summary: A small study published in Nature Neuroscience found that consuming high amounts of cocoa flavanols, an antioxidant in chocolate, can improve memory skills in healthy individuals aged 50-69. Participants who drank a mixture high in flavanols performed 25% better on a memory test compared to those who drank a low-flavanol mixture. The study, led by neurologist Dr. Scott A. Small, suggests that flavanols may help delay age-related memory decline, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and determine the optimal amount of flavanols for memory improvement.

images.alt_text: On average, the improvement of high-flavanol chocolate in liquid form meant the participants performed like people two to three decades younger on the study's memory task.

site_title: Euro rises on relief over ECB health test
summary: The euro rose against other major currencies following the European Central Bank's clean bill of health for eurozone banks, with a combined capital shortfall of 25 billion euros at the end of 2013. The ECB's audit found all major banks cleared the stress tests, reducing concerns of a repeat crisis. The euro rose to US$1.2704 and 137.14 yen, while the US dollar slipped against the yen ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: London's financial districts hiring more women
summary: London's financial services industry has increased its recruitment of women and overseas staff, changing its "old boy's club" image. Women now make up 29% of the workforce, with 5% being Chinese and 12% Indian. The increase is driven by the growing importance of Chinese and Indian firms and London's efforts to become a regional hub. Companies see diversity as valuable, and efforts to promote it are bearing fruit, particularly for female workers. This shift aims to broaden the talent pool and encourage different perspectives.

site_title: London property market hit by uncertainty
summary: The London property market is experiencing uncertainty, with prices softening in recent weeks. Developers are turning to Asia to boost sales, but local buyers are resisting high prices. An estimated 12,000 new units are in the pipeline, with foreign buyers facing higher stamp duties and capital gains tax. The market is expected to continue uncertain until the May 2015 election, with some economists predicting a post-election interest rate hike. Estate agents are struggling to negotiate deals, and some sellers are cutting prices by 5-15%.

site_title: China, Singapore to start direct currency trading on Tuesday
summary: China will begin direct currency trading with Singapore on Tuesday, allowing the Singapore dollar to move 3% on either side of the central midpoint. The move promotes bilateral trade and investment between China and Singapore, and follows China's recent direct currency trades with the US, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and Britain, as well as the euro. This is part of China's efforts to increase the use of the yuan, while maintaining control over its capital account.

site_title: New Ford CEO sets sights on reviving the fortunes of Lincoln
summary: New Ford CEO Mark Fields is investing up to $5 billion to revamp the struggling Lincoln luxury brand, aiming to triple global sales to 300,000 vehicles by 2020 and restore its US and Chinese presence. The plan includes a new premium vehicle platform, which will also be used by the Ford brand, and a significant investment in product development and facilities. Fields aims to reposition Lincoln as a true competitor to luxury leaders like Mercedes-Benz and BMW.

site_title: The TPP's missing ingredient
summary: The US is seeking to finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade deal, but its approach may be flawed. The TPP's initial scope was modest, involving 12 countries, but Japan's inclusion and potential engagement with China through this or a similar framework raises concerns. The US should consider including a currency clause in the agreement to prevent countries from manipulating their currencies, which would give the US a competitive advantage and limit unfair trade practices. This approach has been proposed by experts, and both Democrats and Republicans in the US Congress support limiting currency manipulation.

site_title: Three German shipping banks pass ECB stress test
summary: Three German shipping banks, HSH Nordbank AG, Commerzbank AG, and Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, passed a stress test by the European Central Bank (ECB) with a 10% common equity Tier 1 ratio, exceeding the minimum threshold of 5.5%. The test was conducted as part of the ECB's Asset-Quality Review, which aimed to rekindle confidence in the banking system after six years of turmoil. The shipping lenders had significantly reduced their shipping exposure and gotten rid of the most risky assets, according to a professor of finance.

site_title: Big-brand contemporary art fairs are a successful business model
summary: The 41st edition of the Foire Internationale d'Art Contemporain (FIAC) in Paris showcased a diverse range of international artists, with 191 exhibitors and a satellite fair, (Off)icielle, featuring emerging galleries. The fair attracted wealthy collectors and art enthusiasts, with notable sales including a Paul McCarthy sculpture for an undisclosed price and a Gerhard Richter painting for $2.8 million. FIAC's ability to attract French billionaire collectors, such as François Pinault and Bernard Arnault, further solidified its reputation as a leading contemporary art fair. The event's success highlights the lucrative business model of big-brand contemporary art fairs.

site_title: OKP's profit falls 2.4% to S$281,000 in Q3 even as revenue rises 0.8%
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, reported a 2.4% drop in net profit to S$281,000 in Q3 2014, despite a 0.8% increase in revenue to S$26.2 million. Earnings per share remained flat at 0.09 Singapore cent for the quarter.

site_title: Absence of fair value gain hits Second Chance's Q4 earnings
summary: Second Chance Properties reported an 88% decline in net profit to S$5.7 million in Q4 2014, with revenue falling 16.1% to S$17.9 million. The group's full-year net profit fell 71.1% to S$16.5 million, attributed to lower retail prices and fair value gains on properties. The company declared a dividend of 3.5 cents per share for FY2014, with plans to distribute a minimum of 3.55 cents per share for FY2015.

site_title: More businesses to enjoy power supplier choices
summary: Singapore is set to further liberalize its electricity market, allowing more businesses to buy power directly from electricity retailers or the wholesale electricity market. The contestability threshold will be lowered to 2MW an hour from July 1, 2015, adding 10,000 commercial or industrial consumers. This move is expected to bring about cost savings of about 12% for eligible consumers. The government is also investing S$45 million to build the power sector, including energy storage technologies and a training fund for Singaporean workers.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% due to investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the stock market, the US and EU stocks edged down amid tariff threats. The NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. US stocks opened lower amid Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: Shrinking the talent gap in SMEs
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in attracting and retaining human capital due to government moves to tighten the inflow of cheap foreign labor. The government has introduced three schemes to support SMEs: the Enhanced Training Support Scheme, the Wage Credit Scheme, and the SME Talent Programme. However, the Wage Credit Scheme is set to end in 2015, and SMEs are concerned about the impact on labor costs. Japan's "Shukko" system, where larger firms lease workers to SMEs, could be adapted to boost human capital development in Singapore's SMEs. This could involve the government incentivizing SMEs to "lease" specialist skilled workers from large firms and subsidizing the cost of hiring such individuals.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate to make offer for remaining PCRT units (Amended)
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited (PREHL) has announced a voluntary conditional offer to acquire the remaining units in Perennial China Retail Trust (PCRT) in exchange for PREHL shares. The offer is valued at S$0.70 per unit, with PREHL shares to be issued at S$1.3353 each. PREHL's CEO, Pua Seck Guan, believes the acquisition will provide asset class and geographic diversification, and increase the group's net asset value to S$2.62 billion. The offer is conditional on reaching a 50% stake in PCRT and is expected to be completed by December 8.

images.alt_text: PERENNIAL Real Estate Holdings Limited (PREHL) has announced its firm intention to make a voluntary conditional offer to acquire the remaining units in Perennial China Retail Trust (PCRT) in exchange for PREHL shares.

site_title: Remember high- growth woes amid low-growth worries
summary: Singapore's economy, once driven by cheap foreign labor, is facing growth woes despite restructuring efforts. The country's pursuit of high growth has led to concerns about competitiveness as productivity remains low and labor costs rise. China's experience with rapid credit use and deflationary pressures serves as a cautionary tale. Singapore's government has invested billions in productivity schemes and education, but results have been slow. The ultimate goal for policymakers should be to improve the average worker's lot by ensuring they have necessary skills for rising real incomes, rather than just high growth.

images.alt_text: INVESTORS might be scared of slow global growth and deflation. But growth isn't everything. Just ask China, where ballooning debts were putting it on the path of spectacular collapse. PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: EU bank stress test: A tale of two capital scores
summary: The European Union's stress test revealed that 24 banks failed with a capital shortfall of 24.6 billion euros, but if fully phased-in EU rules were applied, the number of failures would increase to 34. The test showed that banks relied heavily on instruments like goodwill and deferred tax assets, which are being phased out under the EU's Capital Requirements Regulation. The results also highlighted differences in how banks in Germany and France performed under the fully loaded capital definition. The European Banking Authority is providing the market with tools to apply pressure on banks, and regulators will continue to monitor the banks' progress towards reaching the Basel III goal.

images.alt_text: To clear the stress-test thresholds, some banks made liberal use of instruments, whose admissibility as core capital will be gradually phased out under the EU's Capital Requirements Regulation.

site_title: Silver lining for Japan foreign investment
summary: Foreign investors, including those from Singapore, have poured US$5.21 billion into Japan in the first six months of this year, more than double the US$2.36 billion for the whole of 2013. Singapore firms alone invested US$533.69 million, up from US$325 million in 2013. The surge is attributed to Japan's renewed effort to draw foreign investment, with the government implementing a "three arrows" strategy to revive the economy, which includes fiscal stimulus, monetary easing, and structural reforms.

site_title: Local manufacturer races to tap potential in medical technology
summary: Local manufacturer Racer Technology has developed a diagnostic kit that can test for Ebola and other diseases in minutes, thanks to its microfluidic chip technology. The company, led by CEO Willy Koh, is racing to tap into the growing demand for medical technology and aims to grow its revenue from S$40 million to S$90 million in the next five years. Koh's strategy involves diversifying into healthcare and lifestyle products, and the company is competing with Chinese firms for medical technology projects. Racer Technology is set to participate in the world's largest medical trade fair, Medica/Compamed, in November to secure international contracts and partnerships.

site_title: Ex-trader to launch oil-focused commodities hedge fund
summary: An ex-trader, Stephen Smethurst, is launching a Geneva-based oil-focused commodities hedge fund, Zafiro Capital Commodities Trading Fund, despite the near 25% drop in oil prices since June. Smethurst believes discretionary funds can still earn strong returns by taking a targeted approach. The fund will invest 70% in energy, 30% in base and precious metals, and agricultural commodities, with a minimum investment of $1 million and standard management fees. Smethurst's fund aims to capitalize on the current market volatility and outperform larger, less nimble funds.

site_title: Deflation expected to lift growth in US but plunge Europe into crisis
summary: The US economy is expected to experience benign deflation, driven by rising oil and gas supplies, which could lift growth and boost investor confidence. In contrast, Europe is at risk of debilitating bad deflation, exacerbated by weaker growth, higher unemployment, and intractable bad debts. The European Central Bank's stress tests revealed 25 banks failed, with a total shortfall of €25 billion. The US has seen sales growth of 6% in the third quarter, while West Europe suffered a 0.5% decline. Deflation has had a "bad rap" in the past, but nations can prosper if driven by supply, not demand.

site_title: Tesco's borrowing costs soar as bonds plunge
summary: Tesco's borrowing costs have soared as its bonds plummeted and credit-default swaps surged, following Moody's downgrade to one level above junk. The UK grocer's £16 billion debt and high financial leverage have raised concerns about its ability to retain its investment-grade status. Tesco's shares have lost half their value this year, and the company is under pressure to raise capital through asset sales or share offerings. A Deloitte investigation into overstated profits and a series of profit warnings have further eroded investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Tesco shares have lost half of their value this year amid an accounting scandal and a series of profit warnings.

site_title: MAHB may sell stake in Sabiha Gokcen
summary: Malaysia Airport Holdings Bhd (MAHB) may sell a minority stake in Istanbul's Sabiha Gokcen airport, following its planned full ownership in the coming months. MAHB will buy the outstanding 40% stake for $360 million instead of accepting a US offer from Turkey's TAV Holdings. MAHB aims to maintain majority control for the short term, with plans to finalize the purchase in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval.

site_title: US pending home sales higher in September
summary: US pending home sales increased 1.0% in September to 105.0, driven by slowing price gains and growing inventory. The National Association of Realtors attributed the rise to higher housing supply, which is preventing price hikes. Despite this, tight credit from mortgage lenders continues to hinder activity. The NAR hopes regulators will modify lending rules to broaden access to mortgages, citing the current low mortgage rates as a potential boost to buyers.

site_title: Cameron backs rail line across northern England
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron backs a proposed high-speed rail line, HS3, across northern England, linking Manchester and Leeds. The line, dubbed a "Crossrail for the north," aims to boost the British economy and create a "northern powerhouse." The proposal is included in a report by High Speed 2 Ltd chairman David Higgins, which suggests a western line via Crewe and an eastern line via South Yorkshire and the East Midlands. The project could cut journey times between Liverpool and Leeds in half and improve connectivity between northern cities.

site_title: New Indonesia ministers face host of challenges
summary: Indonesia's new Cabinet, led by President Joko Widodo, is facing criticism for being overly reliant on party loyalists, with 21 out of 34 ministers being affiliated with the Indonesian Democratic Party - Struggle. The lineup has been described as "lightweights" and "unqualified" to address the country's slowing economy and infrastructure issues. Despite the concerns, President Widodo has expressed confidence that the new ministers will learn their jobs and prove themselves. The Cabinet's composition has been seen as a compromise between the President's desire for change and the party's influence.

site_title: Catcha unit gives growth stage firms a US$75m boost
summary: Catcha Group has launched a US$75 million venture fund in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur to support growth-stage companies in new media, mobile, and technology in South-east Asia. The fund, managed by Catcha Ventures, aims to fill the gap in available growth funds in the region. Based in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, the fund will support companies in new media, mobile, and technology sectors.

site_title: Advent sells Christ jewellery stores to 3i
summary: Advent, a buyout group, has sold its Christ jewellery stores to 3i, a rival private equity firm, as part of a restructuring plan ahead of a planned exit from the investment. The unit, which generates $507 million in annual revenue and employs 2,400 staff, was sold for 400 million euros including debt. Advent plans to sell or float Douglas, the parent company, on the Frankfurt stock exchange by mid-2015. Other buyout groups had also made offers for Christ, but Advent chose 3i.

site_title: Amazon unveils TV stick, challenging Chromecast
summary: Amazon has unveiled the Fire TV Stick, a media stick device allowing users to stream content to television sets, challenging Google's Chromecast. The device, priced at $39, provides access to Amazon Instant Video and other services, boasting 50% more processing power and twice the memory of Chromecast. It also features Amazon's "Advanced Streaming and Prediction" technology, anticipating viewer preferences and buffering content for faster playback. The Fire TV Stick competes with other similar devices, including Microsoft's Wireless Display Adaptor and Roku Streaming Stick.

site_title: TPP talks gaining momentum but no breakthrough yet on market access
summary: US and Japan failed to reach an agreement on market access in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) despite significant progress in talks, leaving a crucial hurdle to securing the broader pact. The 12-nation trade deal aims to expand US presence in Asia, with President Barack Obama expressing hopes of concluding a deal by the end of the year.
