Outstanding issues include agricultural imports, intellectual property rights, and state-owned enterprises, with protesters gathering outside the Sydney hotel where negotiations took place.

site_title: Pan-Asean platform for European businesses launched
summary: The European Union-Asean Business Council (EU-ABC) was launched in Singapore, marking a key milestone in the commercial relationship between Europe and Asean. The council, a pan-Asean platform for European businesses, aims to advocate for trade and investment interests in South-east Asia. It will provide two-way knowledge transfer and contribute to policy-making, with a focus on boosting trade, development, and growth. The launch coincides with the appointment of a new European Trade Commissioner, the finalization of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, and the appointment of a dedicated EU Ambassador to Asean.

site_title: Falling oil prices could be a curse for KL
summary: Falling oil prices are expected to negatively impact Malaysia, a rare net oil exporter in Asia, as a significant portion of its fiscal revenue is oil-related. Despite lower fuel subsidies, the country's fiscal deficit is projected to worsen by 0.2% of GDP due to lower oil revenue from national oil corporation Petronas. However, Petronas may still sustain its dividend payments to the government, and the decline in oil prices will have little impact on Malaysia's current account deficit.

site_title: Week-long pow-wow takes off on strong footing
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 5th Singapore Corporate Governance Week, with 125 companies participating in the initiative to uphold and advance good corporate governance standards. The week-long program has received support from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, Singapore Accountancy Commission, and Singapore Exchange. The event aims to enhance shareholder value and promote transparency among stakeholders, as stated by SIAS. Companies such as CapitaLand, Halcyon Agri Corporation, and StarHub have expressed their commitment to good corporate governance, emphasizing the importance of transparency and board engagement.

site_title: Completion of APS RTO deal extended
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (APS) has extended the completion of its reverse takeover deal with miner Coeur Gold Armenia for the second time, pushing the deadline from February 25, 2014, to 12 months later. The deal involves APS issuing 1.35 billion new shares to fund the purchase of GR Business Holdings' stake in the miner for $500 million. APS shares plummeted 15% to 5 Singapore cents on Monday, following the announcement. Lim Soon Fang and Hano Maeloa increased their stakes in the company.

site_title: Second Chance Properties Q4, full-year net profit slump on absence of fair value gain
summary: SECOND Chance Properties reported a 88% decline in Q4 net profit to S$5.7 million, with full-year net profit falling 71.1% to S$16.5 million due to a lack of fair value gain on properties. Revenue declined 16.1% to S$17.9 million in Q4 and 10.1% to S$48.5 million for the full year. The group declared a dividend of 3.5 cents per share for FY2014, with plans to distribute at least 3.55 cents per share for FY2015.

site_title: Tokyo pulls out all stops in tussle for high-speed train projects
summary: Japan is competing fiercely with China to supply high-speed rail systems to countries in Southeast Asia, including Singapore and Malaysia. The Singapore-Malaysia corridor project, which could involve an integrated high-speed rail system linking multiple countries, is a high-stakes bid for Japan. Japan has also submitted proposals for HSR systems in Thailand and Vietnam, while China is building extensive networks in its own country and competing aggressively for international sales. Japan's Shinkansen system, a pioneering high-speed rail technology, is being exported globally, with the US and India also being targeted, as the country seeks to expand its overseas market share.

site_title: Coal India ordered to improve online auction terms
summary: India's antitrust regulator, the Competition Commission of India (CCI), ordered Coal India Ltd to change its online auction terms, ruling that the current methods abused the company's dominant position. The CCI did not fine the state-owned miner, unlike last year when it fined Coal India US$289 million. Existing contracts penalize companies for not buying contracted coal, but Coal India won't assume responsibility if it fails to supply on time. The order aims to improve transparency and fairness in coal supply.

site_title: JLL announces senior director changes in Singapore capital markets business
summary: JLL has announced senior director changes in its Singapore capital markets business. Karamjit Singh, previously head of the Singapore capital markets team, has been promoted to international director and will lead the firm's business development drive. He will continue to oversee the Singapore residential team and collective sales business. Tang Wei Leng joins JLL's Singapore capital markets team as a regional director on November 1, while Tan Hong Boon will be seconded to JLL's Malaysia business for 12 months to provide strategic and operational support. Greg Hyland now heads the Singapore capital markets team.

site_title: Britain reduce plans for first electricity capacity auction
summary: Britain has reduced its plans for the first electricity capacity auction from 50.8 GW to 48.6 GW. The auction aims to ensure sufficient backup power for Britain's renewable energy sources during the 2018/19 winter. Firms capable of generating 62 GW of capacity have qualified for the auction, set for December 16. Successful bidders will be paid a price for holding capacity on standby and a premium if called upon. The results will be publicized on January 5.

site_title: Israel turns to Asia in bid to expand alliances
summary: Israel is seeking to expand its alliances in Asia, shifting away from its historical ties with Western countries. Despite being geographically located in the Middle East, Israel has traditionally been viewed as part of the West due to its European immigrant origins and strong diplomatic relationships with Western nations. The US has played a significant role in maintaining Israel's military edge and providing diplomatic support, making it the largest recipient of American foreign aid. This shift towards Asia is seen as a response to obstacles in making peace with Arab neighbors and integrating into the Middle East.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse appoints Kengeter as new CEO
summary: Deutsche Boerse appoints Carsten Kengeter as its new CEO, replacing Reto Francioni, effective next June. Kengeter, a former UBS executive, brings experience in fixed income, currencies and commodities, as well as knowledge of Asia and Europe's capital markets. Francioni, who turns 60 in August, is stepping down after nearly a decade at the helm, citing the need to pass the baton. Kengeter's appointment aims to secure future growth for the exchange operator.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Boerse has named investment banker and former UBS executive Carsten Kengeter as its new CEO from next June, replacing Reto Francioni after nearly a decade at the helm.

site_title: Victoria Beckham tops British managers list
summary: Victoria Beckham has been ranked the top British manager by Management Today magazine, praised for her "finely tuned business acumen". Her fashion label has grown from £1 million to £30 million in turnover over five years, creating 61,556 jobs. Beckham, married to former footballer David Beckham, has expanded from three employees to 100 staff. The magazine highlighted the 100 managers as "real job creators", significantly outpacing the British economy's employment growth.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 48.10 points to 16,757.31, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declining 7.17 and 14.41 points, respectively. The decline followed disappointing German economic data and the re-election of Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff, who is viewed as unfavorable towards business. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting, starting Tuesday, to see if the central bank will end its bond-buying program and raise interest rates in 2015.

site_title: ECB stimulus may lack desired scale
summary: The European Central Bank's plan to buy private sector assets may not achieve its desired scale, with the illiquid nature of the asset-backed securities market and scarcity of quality paper hindering progress. The ECB aims to increase its balance sheet by up to 1 trillion euros, but the current program may not be sufficient. Policymakers are under pressure to revive the euro zone economy, which is growing slowly and struggling with low inflation. The ECB may consider alternative measures, such as government bond purchases, to boost stimulus.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day higher, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 4.29 points to 1,823.15. A total of 2.29 billion lots worth RM1.85 billion were traded, with 633 gainers and 230 losers.

site_title: Bank stress test relief lifts European assets
summary: European stocks rose 1% as the euro zone's banking sector passed stress tests, with fewer than one in five top lenders failing. The single currency and low-rated government bonds also gained. Despite this, concerns remain about the sector's long-term attractiveness due to non-performing loans and hidden losses. Asian equities followed suit, driven by the ECB's test results and positive US and British data. Other markets, including Brazilian and Russian stocks, also reacted to the news.

site_title: India reveals names in quest for hidden foreign assets
summary: India's government revealed the names of three businessmen accused of stashing funds in foreign bank accounts, including Pradip Burman, Pankaj Chimanlal Lodhiya, and Radha Timbola. The move is part of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party's effort to crack down on "black money" and recover billions of dollars parked abroad. The government filed an affidavit in the Supreme Court, a pledge made by the party after winning power in May, to get tough on the issue.

site_title: Italy promises EU new measures to reduce deficit
summary: Italy has promised the EU new measures to reduce its structural budget deficit by 0.3% of GDP in 2015, after being warned it risked breaching EU fiscal rules. The country will pool an additional $5.7 billion to speed up deficit reduction efforts. This comes after Italy initially proposed a 0.1% deficit reduction, prompting EU concern. Italy's debt-to-GDP ratio is forecast to be 133.4% in 2015, exceeding the EU ceiling of 60%.

site_title: Boustead unit wins RM90 million contract to build facility in Malaysia
summary: Boustead unit BP Engineering Solutions Sdn Bhd, a subsidiary of Boustead Projects, has secured an RM90 million contract to build a medical device manufacturing facility in Malaysia's Kulim Hi-Tech Park. The project is expected to be completed in Q2 2015. This contract adds to Boustead Projects' expansion into Malaysia, increasing its order book backlog to over S$487 million.

site_title: Obama plans executive actions to strengthen US manufacturing
summary: President Barack Obama plans to launch executive actions to strengthen US manufacturing, investing $300 million in emerging technologies such as advanced materials and digital manufacturing. The investments will be matched by private sector resources, aiming to drive innovation, secure a skilled workforce, and improve the business climate. The actions include establishing manufacturing "centers of excellence," launching apprenticeships, and piloting new technologies for small manufacturers.

site_title: Samsung Elec says scaling down LED lighting business
summary: Samsung Electronics is discontinuing its LED lighting business in all markets except South Korea, where it will continue to operate. The decision comes after the company identified the LED market as a new growth business in 2010. This move is part of Samsung's strategy to focus on other areas of growth.

site_title: Indonesia's economy to grow 5.2% in Q3: central bank governor
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 5.2% in the third quarter, according to Bank Indonesia's deputy governor Perry Warjiyo. The country's growth this year is forecast to be in the range of 5.1-5.5%. October's month-on-month inflation is seen at 0.38%, while year-on-year inflation reached 4.7%. This growth rate is a positive indicator for Indonesia's economy.

site_title: Singapore: Shares up at the end of trading
summary: Singapore shares rose on Monday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,226.11, up 3.56 points. Trading volume reached 1.13 billion shares worth S$999 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 222 to 194. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains for Singapore stocks, ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: Asiatravel to boost room sales through tie-up with TripAdvisor
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings, the first Asia-Pacific online travel agency to participate in TripAdvisor's instant booking feature, has announced the tie-up. The instant booking feature allows users to make hotel reservations on TripAdvisor while remaining on the site, removing "friction" from the booking process. This partnership aims to increase bookings and improve downstream conversion for both TripAdvisor's hotel and online travel agency partners.

site_title: China, Singapore to start direct currency trading on Tuesday
summary: China and Singapore will start direct currency trading of the yuan and Singapore dollar on Tuesday, expanding the use of the yuan in international trade. This move follows China's existing direct currency trades with the US, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and Britain, and its recent addition of the euro. The direct trade aims to promote bilateral trade and investment between the two countries, lower currency conversion costs, and meet the needs of economic entities.

site_title: Transneft suspends oil loadings except for Makhachkala
summary: Russian pipeline monopoly Transneft has suspended oil loadings through all Russian ports except for Makhachkala due to bad weather conditions. The suspension affects major ports like Novorossiisk, Kozmino, Primorsk, and Ust-Luga, with loadings halted on Oct 27 and Oct 28. Transneft spokesman Igor Dyomin stated that only the Caspian port of Makhachkala had "working conditions." The suspension is expected to impact Russia's 4 million barrels of daily oil exports.

site_title: France to trim 2015 budget deficit by US$4.7b
summary: France plans to cut its 2015 budget deficit by $4.7 billion, exceeding the EU's deficit limits. Finance Minister Michel Sapin attributed the reduction to lower-than-expected interest costs and increased revenues from tax fraud crackdowns and eliminating certain tax deductions. The move is expected to allow France to respect EU deficit rules, with the European Commission set to review the government's 2015 draft budget by Wednesday.

site_title: Goldman slashes 2015 oil price forecast
summary: Goldman Sachs has lowered its 2015 oil price forecast, predicting US$75 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and US$85 a barrel for Brent, significantly lower than previous estimates. The bank attributes the decline to rising output outpacing demand, driven by increased production in Brazil, the Gulf of Mexico, and Opec countries. The forecast also suggests that Brent crude could fall as low as US$80 a barrel in the second quarter. This bears out the views of other financial institutions, with Standard Chartered Bank's Paul Horsnell also cutting his forecast.

site_title: Iron ore futures in China, Singapore slip
summary: Iron ore futures in China and Singapore declined on Monday, with iron ore for May delivery falling 0.4% to US$86 a tonne and November delivery falling 0.5% to US$79.57 a tonne. The decline follows a near one-month high in mid-October and a recent glut in supply. The market's volatility has made it difficult for traders to conclude deals, with some seeking letters of credit to secure sales. The price decline marks a 40% loss for iron ore this year, amid slowing Chinese demand growth.

site_title: Tehran draws rich Western tourists
summary: A luxury train, the "Jewels of Persia," carrying 70 Western tourists, including 12 Australians and 55 Britons, arrived in Tehran on Monday after a two-week journey from Budapest. The $31,000 per person tour included stops in Isfahan, Shiraz, and Yazd, and is part of a growing trend of foreign visitors to Iran, which saw a 35% increase in tourist numbers and $6 billion in revenue in 2023. Organizers plan to offer eight more trips from Budapest and four from Tehran next year, with prices reaching $37,000 per person.

site_title: ST Aerospace injects capital into its commercial pilot training business
summary: ST Aerospace, a subsidiary of ST Engineering, has injected US$4.87 million into its commercial pilot training business, ST Aerospace Academy (STAA), bringing the total equity investment to US$12.98 million. This move affirms ST Engineering's confidence in the business and supports growing pilot training capacity globally, without expected impact on consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current fiscal year.

site_title: UK retailers see fastest growth in 3 years
summary: British retailers reported the fastest sales growth in over three years, with a +31 retail sales balance in October, surpassing economists' forecasts of a decline to +25. This lifted the three-month average retail sales balance to +33, its highest level since February 2011. The improvement in sales is attributed to the clothing sector, which rebounded after mild weather in September discouraged shoppers from buying winter fashions.

site_title: China's Xiaomi to set up India customer data centre to deflect privacy concerns
summary: China's Xiaomi plans to set up a data centre in India to store local user data, addressing concerns about privacy that may hinder its expansion in the country. The move comes after the company migrated data from its Beijing servers to Amazon Web Services in Singapore and the US. Xiaomi has faced privacy controversies, including accusations of funneling user data back to its servers. The company claims it collects data only with permission and is attempting to contact Indian authorities for more information. This move aims to alleviate concerns and secure rapid growth in India's third-largest smartphone market.

site_title: German business confidence falls to near two-year low
summary: Business confidence in Germany, Europe's largest economy, fell to a near two-year low in October, with the Ifo economic institute's business climate index dropping to 103.2 points, its lowest level since December 2012. This decline, the sixth monthly drop, suggests the recovery is unlikely to regain momentum at the end of the year, with economists expecting German GDP to rise by 1.3% this year and 1.5% next. The eurozone's biggest economy has reached a critical stage between a soft spell and almost-stagnation, casting a question mark over the eurozone's recovery.

images.alt_text: Business confidence in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, fell to the lowest level for nearly two years in October, a key survey showed on Monday, placing a question mark over recovery in the eurozone as a whole.

site_title: Prosecutors seek death penalty for Korea ferry disaster captain
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea have demanded the death penalty for Captain Lee Joon-Seok of the Sewol ferry, which sank in April killing over 300 people. Lee is accused of abandoning passengers while hundreds were still trapped inside the ship. The prosecution also seeks life sentences for three senior crew members. The trial's recommendation will be reviewed by the court, which will decide the fate of the crew members. Lee and others faced the capital charge of "homicide through wilful negligence."

site_title: German Amazon workers called to strike in pay dispute
summary: German Amazon workers are set to strike at five locations across Germany due to a pay dispute. The Verdi labour union called the strike at distribution centres in Bad Hersfeld, Leipzig, Graben, Werne, and Rheinberg, with workers walking out from Monday to Wednesday and Monday and Tuesday respectively. The strike is in response to a row over pay and conditions, with no further details provided.

site_title: Britain risks fines unless it pays EU tax bill
summary: Britain faces the possibility of fines if it fails to pay an extra $2.66 billion to the EU budget by December 1, as demanded by the European Commission. Prime Minister David Cameron has refused to pay, calling the demand "unacceptable" and claiming he won't be forced into paying. EU Budget Commissioner Jacek Dominik says Britain's refusal could lead to fines, but notes that the country's rebate and special treatment under the budget system make it hard for them to justify non-payment. The EU budget is based on a formula agreed by all member states, and changing it would require new legislation.

images.alt_text: Britain must contribute an extra US$2.66 billion to the EU budget or face fines, the European Commission said on Monday, after a furious Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron insisted that London would not pay.

site_title: OKP Q3, nine-month net profit hurt by higher costs
summary: OKP Holdings, an infrastructure and civil engineering company, reported a 2.4% drop in net profit to S$281,000 for the third quarter ended Sept 30, with revenue rising 0.8% to S$26.2 million. The nine-month net profit dropped 49.9% to S$1.69 million due to higher administrative costs and lower gross profit. The company attributed the decline to a competitive pricing environment, higher labour and construction material costs. Despite the challenges, OKP Holdings remains optimistic with a pipeline of projects and a net construction order book of S$186.8 million extending to 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.63%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.63% on Monday, driven by gains on Wall Street from the previous week. The Nikkei 225 index climbed to 15,388.72, while the Topix index reached 1,254.28. However, investor caution ahead of a US Federal Reserve policy meeting limited market gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares ended the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.68% lower on Monday due to the postponed launch of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect platform. The Hang Seng Index fell 158.97 points to 23,143.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index hit a one-month low. The delay impacted Chinese mainland markets, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.51% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.44%.

site_title: DBS ties with big boys in trade finance
summary: DBS Bank has secured a top-three spot among global banks in trade finance, according to a 2014 Greenwich Associates study. The study found that HSBC dominates trade finance across Asia, with 42% of large companies using the bank for trade finance. DBS tied with Standard Chartered Bank for third place in Singapore. Companies are increasingly using trade finance for capital and process improvement, with local banks gaining market share due to aggressive pricing. The study highlights a highly competitive market with a focus on intra-Asian corridors.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise as global risk revives, Fed eyed
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose on Monday as global risk concerns decreased following upbeat US earnings and economic data. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.3% at 1,931.97 points. The won rose 0.5% to 1,052.2 to the dollar. This upward trend was attributed to reduced concerns over the global economy, allowing investors to reassess risk and invest in the market.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on hopes for US economy
summary: Australian shares rose to a six-week high on Monday, driven by Wall Street's strong momentum as investors await the US Federal Reserve's potential end to quantitative easing. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed up 0.9% at 5,459.0, its highest close since September 15. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also rose 0.8%. The positive sentiment was fueled by hopes for a US economic recovery, despite concerns about the Fed's stimulus plan.

site_title: Rousseff re-elected president of Brazil: official result
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has been re-elected, defeating center-right challenger Aecio Neves by around three million votes, with 51.52% of the vote share. Rousseff, Brazil's first woman president, won the election despite a bitter campaign and corruption scandals, including allegations of embezzlement at state-owned oil giant Petrobras. The outcome is seen as a referendum on 12 years of government by the Workers' Party, with voters weighing the PT's social legacy against Mr Neves's promise of economic revival.

site_title: Japan trade minister got funds from foreign-owned firm, returned: media
summary: Japan's trade minister, Yoichi Miyazawa, received 400,000 yen (US$3,700) from a foreign-owned firm in 2007-2008, despite being unaware of the majority foreign investor stake, and has since returned the funds. This latest scandal, amid previous ministerial resignations and fund misuse allegations, has tarnished Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet. Despite Abe's cabinet facing scrutiny, his support rates remain around 50% and no immediate rerun of his 2007 resignation is predicted.

site_title: Asian markets mainly up, China slips as stock trading scheme falters
summary: Asian markets were mainly up Monday, with Tokyo, Seoul, and Sydney gaining 0.37%, 0.42%, and 0.56% respectively, due to a stable euro and a clean bill of health for eurozone banks. However, China was hit by the postponement of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme, with Shanghai dropping 0.67% and Hong Kong falling 0.94%. The delay is attributed to recent pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down 0.77% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.77% at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index down 179.99 points to 23,122.21, following the delay of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme, initially set to launch at the end of October.

site_title: Four entrepreneurs named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2014
summary: Four entrepreneurs, Kar Wong, Susan Chong, Ong Tze Boon, and Alfred Chua, were named winners of the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2014 award in different categories. They will compete to represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award in 2015. The winner will be announced at the EY EOY Awards Gala on December 2. Additionally, the EY-Barclays Family Business Award of Excellence was presented to B.P. De Silva Holdings, an honorary award on the EOY platform.

images.alt_text: The EY Entrepreneur Of The Year in the Engineering Services and Process Equipment category is Kar Wong, the managing director of Advanced Group of Companies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.74%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.74% higher on Monday, driven by a stable dollar against the yen and gains on Wall Street last week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 112.64 points to 15,404.28. The euro remained stable after the European Central Bank gave eurozone banks a clean bill of health.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai cross-trading scheme postponed
summary: Hong Kong's Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme has been indefinitely postponed due to ongoing pro-democracy protests. The scheme, which allows cross-trading between the two markets, was expected to launch this week but has been delayed indefinitely. Charles Li, head of Hong Kong's stock exchange, warned that the protests could impact the project's progress and potentially harm the city's financial stability. The delay is also due to concerns over taxation and regulatory issues, with investors expressing uncertainty about the project's future.

images.alt_text: A watershed scheme to allow cross-trading between Hong Kong and Shanghai's stock markets has been delayed indefinitely.

site_title: British government backs east-west England high-speed rail link
summary: The British government has backed the development of an east-west high-speed rail link between northern England cities, dubbed High Speed 3. The proposed link could reduce journey times between Leeds and Manchester to 26 minutes from 55 minutes. An interim report will be produced in March 2025, with the first phase of the HS2 project between London and Birmingham set to open in 2026. The government will review ways to bring down the cost of HS2 and future high-speed rail projects, drawing on international experience.

site_title: South Korea risks economic own goal as stimulus fuels debt binge
summary: South Korea's stimulus package, worth over $11 billion, has fueled a debt binge among households, with borrowing from banks increasing by a net 9.32 trillion won (US$8.83 billion) in August-September. This is the most since 2006 and has raised concerns about deflationary pressures. With global growth cooling and the property market showing underlying weakness, analysts warn that South Korea risks scoring an economic own goal, saddling households with heavier debt loads and undermining the government's strategy to boost growth.

site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector still contracting
summary: The European Central Bank reported that loans to the private sector in the euro area declined by 1.2% in September compared to the same month in 2013, a slightly lower rate than in August. This contraction in lending has dampened economic activity in the 18 eurozone countries. In contrast, the overall eurozone money supply grew 2.5% in September, higher than the 2.1% growth in August. The ECB's stress tests on eurozone banks cleared all but 25 banks as having adequate capital, raising confidence in the banking sector.

images.alt_text: Loans to the private sector in the euro area, a gauge of economic health, fell year-on-year in September, but by slightly less than in August, the European Central Bank said on Monday.

site_title: Changi Airport's operating indicators for Sept down; small rise for first three quarters
summary: Singapore Changi Airport's operating indicators declined in September, with 4.25 million passenger movements, a 0.5% year-on-year drop. Aircraft landings and takeoffs fell by 5%, while cargo processed decreased by 2.7%. Traffic to South Asia and North-east Asia grew, but to South-east Asia, Africa, and the Americas dipped. The airport saw slight growth in the first three quarters, with 40.09 million passengers and 255,260 aircraft movements. Traffic to Jakarta and Hong Kong remained the top routes.

site_title: More businesses to gain from liberalisation of power market
summary: Singapore to further liberalize its electricity market, allowing up to 10,000 more commercial and industrial consumers to buy power directly from retailers or the wholesale market by July 1, 2015. The contestability threshold will be lowered to 2MW an hour, benefiting businesses that consume less than this amount. A S$25 million programme will also be launched to enhance power system stability and integrate intermittent solar energy.

images.alt_text: More businesses will be able to buy power directly from electricity retailers or the wholesale electricity market from next year, as Singapore gradually liberalises its electricity market.

site_title: Taiwan eyes homegrown submarines after 13-year wait on US deal
summary: Taiwan is moving forward with plans to build its own submarines after a 13-year wait on a US deal, with a design to be completed by the end of the year. The move comes as China's navy expands rapidly and Taiwan's military considers a strategic deterrent against Beijing's growing naval assertiveness. Taiwan's government aims to acquire submarines to strengthen self-defence, but experts warn that overcoming technical challenges and potential objections from Beijing will be significant hurdles. The country's shipbuilder, CSBC Corp Taiwan, has indicated it can build a pressurised hull, but constructing a submarine is complex.

site_title: Accountancy bodies launch management accounting principles for better decision-making
summary: The Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (CIMA) and the American Institute of CPAs (AICPA) launched new global management accounting principles to improve decision-making for organizations. The four principles focus on breaking down silos, identifying relevant data, driving impact analysis, and promoting integrity. Research found that 73% of companies worldwide believe empowering workers to make autonomous decisions will be key to success, and 91% globally want a process to extract insights from financial and non-financial data. The principles are designed to address data overload, dispersed workforces, and the speed of change.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.63 points to 3,228.18. The market saw 63.5 million shares traded for S$111.9 million, with 86 gainers outnumbering 39 losers. The 5-day rally continues ahead of GDP data, with no major market-moving news reported.

site_title: White House questions new Ebola rules, nurse plans to sue
summary: The White House has expressed concerns that mandatory Ebola quarantines imposed by New York and New Jersey could hinder the fight against the disease. Kaci Hickox, a nurse who was placed in a 21-day quarantine after returning from treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone, plans to sue the state, arguing her constitutional rights were violated. Medical professionals note that Ebola is difficult to catch and is spread through direct contact with bodily fluids, raising questions about the effectiveness of the quarantine policy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.30 points to 1821.82 on Monday, driven by gains. Volume reached 37.33 million lots worth RM17.5 million, with 159 gainers to 32 losers. The market opened higher, contrary to the decline in European and US stocks due to concerns over US-EU tariffs.

site_title: Wall Street finally turning on Amazon as Bezos magic fades
summary: Amazon missed expectations in its latest earnings report, with a poor 7-18% revenue growth forecast for the holiday quarter. The company's stock fell 8.3% on Friday to a year's low, wiping out $12 billion in value. Investors are wary of Amazon's triple-digit price-earnings ratio and its persistent unwillingness to throttle back spending on side projects. Analysts have cut their price targets, with some calling for significant changes, but others remain optimistic, citing Amazon's core businesses and potential for future growth.

site_title: Keeping Ebola at bay
summary: Asian countries can prevent widespread Ebola outbreaks by implementing strong secondary response measures, including medical facilities, contact tracing capabilities, and quarantine premises. Cooperation between countries is crucial, with a focus on traveller screening programs and rapid deployment teams to support local control efforts. Effective airport screening and quarantine regimes are also essential. While no country is fully shielded from the threat of health scourges, Asia's strong medical and public health systems can prevent a community outbreak. The region should share best practices, engage in global efforts, and consider funding pharmaceutical and biotech research into disease prevention and treatment.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won boosted by positive earnings and econ data
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose due to positive earnings results and economic data, boosting the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) 0.3% to 1,932.03 points. The local currency also increased by half a percent to 1,052.1 against the dollar. Positive US data, including sales of new homes and GDP growth in Britain, also contributed to the market's improvement. Market participants await the US Federal Reserve's announcement on its bond-buying program and will monitor the KOSPI's performance, which is expected to rebound this week.

site_title: KLW Holdings acquires 45.45% of Mega Sun for RMB85 m
summary: KLW Holdings has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire a 45.45% stake in Mega Sun Development for RMB85 million. The acquisition will fund the purchase through prior fund-raising exercises. After the acquisition, KLW Holdings will hold a 25% stake in Suzhou Jiaxin Real Estate Development Company Limited, which is developing Fu Yuan Luxury Villas in Suzhou. This is KLW Holdings' second foray into the real estate business, following the acquisition of a Melbourne property in September.

site_title: China's overseas investment schemes set to freshen offshore yuan pool
summary: China is studying pilot schemes to allow domestic investors to make overseas investments using the Chinese currency, aiming to inject fresh capital into the stagnant offshore yuan pool. The RQDII and QDII2 schemes, designed by the People's Bank of China, will enable investment in offshore markets. This move comes as yuan deposits in Hong Kong, the biggest offshore yuan hub, reached a 2-year low of 937 billion yuan (US$153 billion) at the end of August. The central bank aims to revitalize the offshore yuan market and boost economic growth.

site_title: London's finance firms hiring more female, overseas staff: study
summary: London's financial services industry has increased recruitment of women and overseas staff, shifting away from its "old boy's club" image. Women now make up 29% of the workforce, with a 15% rise in female staff at analyst and associate levels. Overseas staff, including Chinese and Indian workers, have also increased, with 5% of City staff being Chinese and 12% being Indian. This shift is driven by the industry's efforts to attract diverse talent and broaden its talent pool, with many companies recognizing the value of diverse backgrounds and experiences.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group's Q3 net profit up 11.3%
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 11.3% increase in Q3 net profit to S$15.43 million, driven by 11.1% growth in revenue to S$94.49 million. Revenue from healthcare services rose 16.4%, while hospital services revenue increased by 7.3%. The group maintained a healthy cash position of S$124.5 million and plans to monitor market conditions in China and Hong Kong for new opportunities.

site_title: Four in five eurozone banks pass ECB health test
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) comprehensive health test of eurozone banks has found that 25 out of 130 banks had a combined capital shortfall of 25 billion euros at the end of 2013. However, 12 banks have since made up 15 billion euros of the shortfall, leaving 13 banks with a 10 billion euro shortfall. The test, aimed at preventing a repeat of the 2008 crisis, was deemed successful, with only nine banks failing, including nine in Italy. The ECB's vice president stated that the test will boost public confidence in the banking sector, facilitating more lending and economic growth.

site_title: Soaring notes at d'Leedon
summary: CapitaLand's d'Leedon condominium in Singapore hosted the Earth Harp, the world's longest playable stringed instrument, at a celebration party. Lim Ming Yan, president of CapitaLand, played the harp with musician William Close, who set a world record for playing a piece titled Mini Symphony For The Earth Harp. The event took place as the condominium had seen over 85% sales.

site_title: Adjustment pains for construction sector
summary: Singapore's construction sector faces tough times due to a manpower shortage and higher operating costs, resulting in payment delays and project delays. Payment delays rose 3.8 percentage points to 51.4% in Q2, with only slightly more than two in five payment transactions being prompt. Cost overruns and a shortage of skilled manpower are major concerns, with some companies facing financial difficulty. However, the sector remains robust, with abundant projects driven by government infrastructure projects, and the government is placing more emphasis on quality rather than just prices when awarding projects.

site_title: US regulator imposes first fine over data security
summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has imposed a $10 million fine on two telecom companies, YourTel America and TerraCom, for storing personally identifiable customer data online without proper security measures. The companies collected information from applicants to the government's Lifeline program and kept it on publicly accessible servers, potentially affecting 300,000 customers. This is the FCC's first data security enforcement action, signaling a growing role for the agency as a privacy regulator. The fine will be shared between the two companies.

site_title: BNP Paribas Asia-Pacific's strategy bearing fruit
summary: BNP Paribas Asia-Pacific's business is gaining momentum as its strategic focus on corporate, investment, and private banking begins to bear fruit. The bank is confident its revenues from the region are on track to meet or exceed expectations, with revenues reaching 1.4 billion euros in the first half of 2014. The bank's growth has come from expanding market share in trade finance, growing its private bank client base, and adding 350 new corporate clients since 2013. Despite slowing growth in the region, BNP Paribas remains committed to its strategy, adjusting it to local situations and investing in its services offerings.

site_title: Shophouses and retail units in Far East Plaza for sale
summary: Four adjoining retail shops in Far East Plaza and nine conservation shophouses in Peck Seah Street have been launched for sale through public tender. The retail shops range from 624 to 1,248 sq ft and are offered in two-unit or four-unit deal structures, with a guide price of S$6 million per pair or S$9,615 per sq ft. The shophouses, zoned for commercial use, have a combined land area of 8,213 sq ft and a guide price of S$49 million or S$2,497 per sq ft. Tenders close on Dec 2 and Dec 9, respectively.

images.alt_text: The retail shops in Far East Plaza, #02-64/65/68/69, front the main concourse of the shopping mall.

site_title: Auto lending puts Canada banks at risk, says Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that Canada's auto lending industry poses a significant risk to banks, including Toronto-Dominion Bank and Royal Bank of Canada. Auto loans have quadrupled since 2007, with private-passenger vehicle loans increasing from $16.2 billion to $64 billion. The high 20% compounded annual growth rate is more than double that of mortgages and credit cards. Moody's estimates that borrowers may face negative equity and banks may experience collateral deficiencies, putting lenders at risk in an economic slump.

site_title: Cash-rich Gulf states set to ride out oil-price plunge
summary: Gulf states, including Saudi Arabia, are unlikely to cut oil production to combat the price decline, as they are flush with cash and have built fiscal reserves worth $2.45 trillion. Despite a global oil glut, the six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) are in a strong position to resist pressure to reduce output, with Saudi Arabia's financial reserves estimated to last three years at current prices. The GCC states' reliance on oil revenues has prompted calls for economic reforms to diversify their economies and reduce dependence on oil.

site_title: Volatility healthy, value investors can act
summary: Market volatility has sparked alarm, but experts believe it may be a healthy corrective move. The recent price action is likely a correction, driven by weaker energy prices and macroeconomic factors rather than US retail sales. Central banks' talk of higher interest rates and geopolitical tensions have contributed to the volatility. However, the macro backdrop remains stable, with the US recovery intact and potential stimulus from the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan. Value investors can act now, but patience is required to weather the volatility. The correction presents a buying opportunity in equities, with lower inflation expectations supporting bond markets and ECB QE.

site_title: No easy retirement in South Korea
summary: South Korea's elderly face significant challenges in retirement, with nearly 50% living in "relative poverty" due to meager pensions and limited job opportunities. Many retirees struggle to find suitable work, with some being rejected from even simple jobs due to their age. The government has introduced new skills training, but courses are often not age-appropriate. As a result, many retirees turn to self-employment, with the majority failing within three years. To address the issue, the government has passed legislation to delay retirement until 60 and signed a pact with employers to adopt a wage-peak system, allowing workers to stay on longer.

site_title: GDP growth, Fed policy and profit reports to decide bull-bear bout
summary: US stocks face a crucial week as third-quarter economic growth, Fed policy, and corporate earnings reports are released. The S&P 500 rallied last week, its longest winning streak since 2011, amid strong earnings reports from major companies like Apple and Microsoft. The rally came despite European and energy-sector worries. The outcome will decide the epic battle between bulls and bears in October.

site_title: Citi's car loan scheme not game changer
summary: Citi Singapore has launched a new car loan scheme offering in-principle approval for customers before they shop for a car, starting at 1.48% interest rate. However, dealers wield significant influence in the car loans market, potentially undermining the direct-loan model. Dealers can offer freebies and exclusive tie-ups to discourage direct-loan applications, and Citi acknowledges its relationship with dealers will change. Industry sources suggest dealers can still embed lost commissions into the overall car price, limiting consumer benefits.

site_title: Dollar snaps 2-week slump versus major peers
summary: The US dollar snapped a two-week slump, rising against major peers, as data showed US economic momentum remained intact despite global growth concerns. The dollar gained 0.7% to $1.2671 per euro and 1.2% to 108.16 yen, while the rand rallied 1.4% to $10.9303 per dollar. The Federal Reserve's quantitative-easing strategy is forecast to end, supporting the dollar's recovery. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rose 0.4% to 1,068.16, its highest level since June 2010.

site_title: 'Flying car' meets US air-ground safety rules, says manufacturer
summary: Terrafugia, a company dubbed as "the flying car company," has announced its "Transition" model, a vehicle that transforms from a car to a plane in 20 seconds with foldable wings. The vehicle has built-in safety features, including a parachute and airbags, and is street-legal when in car mode. However, it requires a sports pilot's license and a runway to take off, limiting its accessibility. The Transition's development is seen as a first practical step in setting a standard for regulating flying cars, with Terrafugia planning to develop a future model that won't require a runway.

site_title: Google's Pichai to oversee main services
summary: Google's CEO Larry Page has appointed Sundar Pichai to oversee the company's main products, including search, maps, and commerce. Pichai will oversee six former direct reports, freeing Page to focus on the bigger picture. This change aims to simplify Page's management structure and allow him to concentrate on strategic decisions.

site_title: Judging the true independence of a director
summary: Independent directors play a crucial role in corporate governance, but the definition and assessment of their independence are debated. The Code of Corporate Governance defines an independent director as someone with no relationship that could interfere with their judgment. However, the board or nominating committee may not be the best judge of a director's independence due to conflicts of interest. Third-party options, such as shareholders or an independent third party, have been proposed to vet independence. To increase scrutiny, regulations could require ID disclosure and annual approval by shareholders, motivating them to take their role more seriously.

site_title: Stronger US$ causing market volatility
summary: The US bull market is expected to continue despite recent market volatility. The growth prospects for the US economy have not changed, and the market's confidence in the US recovery has been the main driver of the five-year bull market in equities. Investors are advised not to follow the herd and reduce equity allocations during this period of market weakness, as it offers attractive valuations to get on board. The US weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly, providing a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Dishing out high-quality hawker fare
summary: New group executive chef Mark Richards has revamped the menu at Ujong, a restaurant offering a comprehensive variety of local food options. The revamped menu features a mix of hawker classics, Chinese, and Peranakan fare. Richards' dishes, such as satay, char kway teow, and chicken curry, are well-executed and enjoyable, but some dishes, like popiah and lobster kueh pie tee, fall short. Overall, the restaurant's food is a step up from its previous incarnation, with a stronger culinary foundation and more authentic flavors.

site_title: When iPhones ring, the economy listens
summary: The iPhone has become a significant financial force, with sales driving economic growth and impacting the stock market. Since the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus launch on September 19, consumers have ordered the devices at a faster rate than Apple can deliver, creating a ripple effect throughout the economy. The iPhone's high price point, averaging $603, contributes to Apple's substantial profit margins, estimated at around 50% by analyst Toni Sacconaghi. The iPhone's financial impact extends beyond Apple, influencing the broader economy and stock market, with Apple's stock accounting for 18% of the Standard & Poor's 500 index's year-to-date rise.

site_title: Hong Kong Umbrella Movement inspires smartphone game
summary: A new smartphone game, "Yellow Umbrella," has gained popularity among Hong Kong protesters, with over 40,000 downloads since its release. The game, developed in five days, features a tower defense format where players use incense sticks, money, and other items to defend against police and protesters. The game also includes cultural references to the Hong Kong protests and features a character inspired by Chinese deity Guan Yu, who is prayed to for protection. The game's creator aimed to show support for the peaceful protesters and highlight their struggle for democracy.

site_title: Jokowi unveils Cabinet; next move a delicate balancing act
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled his 34-member Cabinet, including a coordinating ministry of maritime affairs, to address the country's severe port bottlenecks. The announcement comes after a week of false starts due to opposition from anti-corruption watchdogs and party luminaries. Key appointments include Tedjo Edy Purjianto as coordinating minister for maritime affairs and Rini Soemarno as minister for state-owned enterprises, despite concerns over her past involvement in the Bank Century bailout. The Cabinet's diverse lineup aims to demonstrate Widodo's commitment to reform and work for the people.

site_title: When big data becomes a tool in the battle to contain Ebola
summary: Researchers in Boston used big data technology to track the spread of Ebola nine days before it was declared an epidemic, spotting the disease on social media and online reports. The approach, developed by HealthMap, could help curb epidemics and has been used mainly for detection. Experts say predictive analytics, like those used in marketing and music recommendations, could be useful in fighting diseases like Ebola. Microsoft has announced its cloud computing platform Azure will be available to Ebola researchers, and tech companies have pledged multimillion-dollar donations to the effort, but Silicon Valley needs to do more to prevent the disease from spiraling out of control.

site_title: Heavy buys, no sales by directors
summary: Singapore Exchange directors made significant purchases of shares in various companies, totaling S$7.3 million, while directors made no sales. The buying activity was driven by a decline in share prices of Keong Hong Holdings, Keppel Land, Figtree Holdings, Sino Grandness Food Industry Group, and Sing Holdings. In contrast, acquisitions were made by TTJ Holdings, Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group, and Sarine Technologies following a rise in their share prices.

site_title: Aspial's CEO running for board seat at LCD Global
summary: Aspial's CEO Koh Wee Seng is running for a board seat at LCD Global Investments, with backing from Hong Kong billionaire Anson Chan. Chan expressed concerns about LCD's future, citing the company's significant debts and stalled projects. He also questioned the qualifications of the incoming Japanese executives on the board. Koh's 23.5% stake in LCD, including his Aspial Corp, has been increasing since the Lum brothers' failed takeover attempt. The annual general meeting is set to take place this Thursday.

site_title: Germany will not back UK on EU migration reform: report
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has stated that she will not support restrictions on the freedom of workers to move around the European Union, potentially derailing UK Prime Minister David Cameron's plans for EU migration reform. Merkel emphasized the importance of fundamental principles of free movement, saying Germany would not "tamper with" these principles. This stance comes as Cameron seeks to respond to concerns about immigration and counter the rise of the UK Independence Party.

site_title: Poll shows falling support for Abe after two female ministers quit
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration has seen a decline in support after two female ministers resigned over claims of misusing political funds. A poll shows Abe's support rate fell to 53% from 62%, with the disapproval rate rising to 37%. The resignations of Industry Minister Yuko Obuchi and Justice Minister Midori Matsushima dealt a blow to Abe's efforts to promote women to his administration. New Industry Minister Yoichi Miyazawa is now facing pressure over his own conflicts of interest, including shares in the Fukushima nuclear plant operator.

site_title: Union rejects Jaguar Land Rover pay offer, to poll workers for likely strike
summary: A British union has rejected Jaguar Land Rover's final pay offer of a 3% rise over three years linked to pensions and bonuses, leading to a ballot of workers for possible strike action. The union, which represents over 16,000 employees, considers the offer "disgraceful" given the company's £2.5 billion profit. A second ballot is expected to ask workers if they wish to strike, which the union is "confident" will be approved. The dispute comes ahead of a general election in the UK and amid rising labour costs.

site_title: Social Innovation and How IT Works
summary: Hitachi, a Japanese corporation, prioritizes social innovation and uses its advanced Information Technology (IT) to improve people's lives, focusing on sustainable solutions in transportation, water treatment, energy, healthcare, and telecommunications. The company's experience in IT enabled the development of efficient and eco-friendly systems, such as Japan's Shinkansen high-speed railway, which produces less CO2 per passenger than cars. Hitachi is hosting the Hitachi Innovation Forum in Singapore to share its innovative solutions and capabilities, aiming to address problems faced by ASEAN societies and businesses, and to empower business and society with information.

site_title: HP to sell stake in networking business
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) plans to sell approximately 51% of its stake in H3C Technologies Co, a networking subsidiary valued at around $5 billion, to an Asian buyer. This sale comes as HP considers splitting into two companies, with H3C being too complex to manage. The networking group generated $2.53 billion in sales in 2013, a 1.8% increase from the previous year. The sale is part of HP's efforts to become more nimble and focus on core areas, following a shift in the networking industry.

site_title: Volatility is back as worry replaces complacency
summary: Markets are experiencing a surge in volatility as investors shift from complacency to worry about the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has seen nine sessions with price movements of over 200 points, and concerns about global growth are on the rise. The International Monetary Fund's downgrade of global growth forecasts and weak data from key economies have fueled worries. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index may experience month-end window-dressing, and investors should be cautious of "buy in anticipation, sell on news" when banks report their Q3 earnings.

site_title: Global experts discuss productivity issues
summary: A panel of 19 experts from the built environment industry met in Singapore to discuss ways to improve construction productivity. The meeting reviewed the country's Construction Productivity Roadmap and emphasized the need for a mindset shift and the adoption of new technologies. Experts recommended changing design approaches and construction processes, such as Design for Manufacturing and Assembly, and leveraging Building Information Modelling (BIM) to optimize off-site manufacturing. The industry is also encouraged to partner with overseas firms and engage specialist consultants to make construction technologies more cost-effective.

site_title: Moscow okays law to clamp down on offshore tax shelters
summary: Russia's government has approved a new tax law to crack down on offshore tax shelters, part of a broader "deoffshorisation" effort to bring Russian businesses and money back home. The law forces Russian owners of companies abroad to pay taxes in Russia, and introduces modifications to the tax code to tax controlled foreign companies. The law is part of President Vladimir Putin's efforts to increase tax revenues, amid pressure from Western sanctions over the Ukraine crisis. The law will now be submitted to parliament for consideration.

site_title: Eurozone's top lenders that failed ECB test have plugged capital holes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has found that roughly one in five of the eurozone's top lenders failed a landmark health check at the end of last year, but most have since repaired their finances. Italy's financial sector faces the biggest challenge, with nine banks falling short, and only €10 billion remaining to be raised. The exercise aims to spur banks to lend more, but its effectiveness remains uncertain, with some analysts cautioning that it is only the beginning of a banking clean-up in Europe.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: A funding for social entrepreneurs, "Makers of More," is available to implement ideas making economic, environmental, and cultural impacts. The competition, run by Arthur Guinness Projects and Ashoka, offers up to 30,000 euros (S$48,000) for winners. Meanwhile, Olam International donated US$250,000 to fight Ebola, and the KK Women's and Children's Hospital received a S$10,000 donation from OCBC Bank. Singapore aims to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with an Asean country by end-2025 and is exploring carbon offsetting legislation for airlines.

site_title: Thailand refutes allegations of slavery in defence of its prawn industry
summary: Thailand has defended its prawn industry, denying allegations of slavery and torture in its fisheries sector. The country claims to be addressing the issue, citing measures such as issuing official papers to 1.4 million workers, including 50,000 in the fishing industry. However, labour rights activists, including Andy Hall, remain unsatisfied, citing lack of inclusion of workers and trade unions in training programs and saying "nothing on the ground has changed." Despite this, Thailand aims to bring illegal migrants into the formal labour market and improve working conditions, with a new law requiring minimum pay and time off for fishing company managers.

site_title: Renault chief sees lower Europe car sales rise
summary: Renault chairman Carlos Ghosn expects a slower growth in Europe's car market next year, predicting a 6% growth rate, which is below his previous estimate. The European market is growing at 6% this year, its best since the 2007 crisis. Ghosn attributes the growth to the global economic recovery and says he doesn't see another 6% increase in 2015, instead predicting a more moderate growth in line with GDP. Renault and Nissan are committed to increasing production in China, where car sales are slowing due to weaker domestic economic growth and a corruption crackdown.

site_title: Goldman Sachs Asset Management buys Australia bank shares
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management has increased its investment in Australian bank shares, buying the stocks amid a sell-off. Fund manager Dion Hershan views the weakness as temporary, citing the banks' well-capitalized status and expected high dividend yields. The nation's four largest lenders fell the most in a quarter since 2011, amid concerns over a government inquiry into the finance industry. Despite concerns over capital requirements, Hershan expects loan growth and sees the banks as undervalued. The banks' mean dividend yield of 5.4% is higher than the national average in Canada, the US, and the UK.

site_title: Investors look to stock exchanges to tap African growth
summary: Western investors are increasingly looking to Africa's stock exchanges to tap into the continent's growth, driven by the IMF's prediction of 5.1% economic expansion in sub-Saharan Africa. This has led to a proliferation of stock exchanges across the continent, with countries such as Mozambique and Tanzania setting up their own markets. Western exchanges are also exploring double-listing with their African counterparts, but face challenges such as liquidity and varying levels of political and economic stability. Despite these hurdles, African companies can access Western capital in a stable and transparent environment, offering opportunities for high returns.

images.alt_text: The JSE is the largest by market capitalisation, more than four times as much as its nearest rival Nigeria.

site_title: Play it right, and they will come
summary: The inaugural BNP Paribas WTA Finals in Singapore drew a record-breaking 129,000 attendees, surpassing the 100,000 mark for the first time since 1993. Despite initial concerns about weekday afternoon sessions, most matches were well-attended, with four sold-out sessions and 95% of VIP Racquet Club tickets sold. The tournament's affordable ticket prices and VIP packages contributed to the success, with prices ranging from S$17 to S$196. The event featured world-class tennis, including thrilling matches between top players, and a lively Singapore crowd that added to the excitement. The tournament's popularity has ensured its return for the next four years.

site_title: Fed holding on to US$4t amassed since QE started
summary: The Federal Reserve plans to hold onto its $4.48 trillion balance sheet, accumulated since quantitative easing began in 2008, to keep borrowing costs low and support the economy. Ending the third round of bond buying this week, the Fed aims to keep inflation near its target and provide stimulus. Holding onto bonds limits public market supply, keeping prices up and yields lower, providing similar stimulus to a potential interest rate cut. The Fed's decision to continue holding the balance sheet is seen as a way to maintain momentum and keep the economy on track.

site_title: China's mining sector sets guidelines for overseas ops
summary: China's mining industry group has introduced guidelines for socially responsible behavior among overseas operations, covering labor rights, community relations, and environmental protection. Developed in collaboration with the German development agency GIZ, OECD, and Global Witness, the guidelines aim to reduce investment risks and minimize harm to host countries. China's direct overseas mining investment is estimated at $90 billion, and the guidelines are part of a broader push for best practices across Chinese industries. Adoption is expected to be slow and piecemeal, with companies needing to gain knowledge and understanding before implementing the guidelines.

site_title: Arab Bank to contest Hamas financing ruling
summary: Arab Bank Group has begun an appeal against a US jury ruling that found it liable for financing Islamic militant group Hamas, with the bank describing the verdict as "unjust" and "exposed" to "enormous liability." The US civil lawsuit, the first of its kind to reach trial, found Arab Bank liable for giving material support to Hamas and ordered it to compensate victims of 24 attacks attributed to the group. The bank's chairman, Sabih Masrii, stated that the bank is financially sound with a strong capitalization and liquidity position, and has taken measures to deal with the situation.

site_title: P&G plans to pursue Duracell's spin-off into stand-alone firm
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) plans to spin off its battery brand Duracell into a stand-alone firm, marking the first step in a plan to shed up to 100 of its 200 brands. The move aims to focus on 70-80 core products, such as Tide, Charmin, and Crest, as the company seeks to prioritize legacy businesses. The spinoff is seen as a strategic move to streamline operations and drive innovation, with investors having the option to exchange P&G shares for Duracell shares.

site_title: Local players target regional construction wave
summary: Local Singaporean construction firms are expanding their global footprint, with some aiming to generate nearly half of their annual revenue from foreign contracts. Companies like Ong&Ong and CKM Buildtech have secured significant revenue from projects in Asia, particularly China, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Despite the industry average of 4.75% for export contracts, these firms are bucking the trend, with Ong&Ong's foreign-accrued revenue projected to reach half of total revenue. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) is supporting these efforts through internationalization initiatives, and some firms are leveraging their expertise in high-density living to tap into emerging economies.

site_title: Doubts over S'pore's restructuring push
summary: Singapore's economic restructuring policy, aimed at lifting productivity and curbing cheap foreign labor, is facing doubts over its effectiveness. Despite heightened costs, benefits are unclear, with economists citing the need for policy fine-tuning. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has flagged the threat to Singapore's competitiveness, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) faces pressure to deliver significant productivity gains. The government's aim is to shape inclusive, productivity-driven growth, rather than hitting a target number. Policy watchers expect the MAS to issue its Macroeconomic Review, which may provide answers to the conundrum, but the risks of business closures, layoffs, and higher costs remain.

images.alt_text: It's an uncomfortable question that's being asked. With heightened costs and yet unclear benefits, whether Singapore's economic restructuring policy is working out is an issue that is increasingly coming to the fore. PHOTO: ST FILE

site_title: US recalls trigger full review of car-safety regulator
summary: The Obama administration is conducting a comprehensive review of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) amid concerns over safety lapses by the agency. The review comes after a record year for recalls, including the Takata airbag issue, which has resulted in at least three deaths and over 100 injuries. The inquiry will examine the agency's handling of recalls, including the Takata case, and its response to Congressional scrutiny. A new top administrator is expected to be named within two weeks, following criticism of the agency's record and practices.

site_title: Children learn coding as UK eyes digital future
summary: The UK has made coding a compulsory subject for children in publicly-funded schools from the age of five, aiming to equip them with the skills needed to compete in the 21st Century. The overhaul of the computing curriculum follows industry warnings that children were not learning the necessary skills. Pupils are using basic animation software to learn coding concepts, with some as young as six years old, and are finding it an engaging and exciting way to learn. The move is seen as a crucial step to address a shortage of skilled workers in the digital sector, which accounts for 5% of the country's growth.

site_title: Japanese PM Abe's public support slumps in wake of resignations-Yomiuri poll
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's public support has slumped to 53% after the resignation of two high-profile cabinet ministers, according to a Yomiuri poll. The poll found 37% disapprove of the government, up from 30% in a previous poll. Abe's government faces pressure to turn around the struggling economy, with analysts cutting annual growth forecasts for a fifth straight month. Abe's cabinet faces questions over finances, and his efforts to contain the damage through swift replacements may not be enough to restore confidence.

site_title: Breaking new ground
summary: The Singapore Construction Productivity Week (SCPW) showcased new construction technologies and incentives to boost productivity in the built environment sector. Over 6,000 visitors attended the event, which included the Build Smart Conference and BuildTech Asia show. The government announced a S$55 million addition to the Construction Productivity and Capability Fund to encourage private sector players to adopt new technologies, such as Prefabricated Pre-finished Volumetric Construction (PPVC) and Cross Laminated Timber (CLT). The government aims to support 40-50 productivity improvement projects over the next five years, with a focus on raising the quality of the construction sector's workforce and integrating new technologies like Building Information Modelling (BIM) across the construction value chain.

images.alt_text: BCA's Dr Keung (left) and Ms Fu viewing a prototype robotic tiling machine for automated floor tiling at BuildTech Asia.

Participants of BCA's Skilled Builders Competition competing in fitting out a Prefabricated Bathroom Unit. Skills tested include the installation of drywall panels, plumbing, sanitary and architectural finishing works.

site_title: China-led new infrastructure bank puts ADB on defensive
summary: China is launching the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a new institution that could rival the Asian Development Bank (ADB), with an authorized capital of $100 billion. The bank's headquarters will be in Beijing, and China will be the largest shareholder, with India as the second-largest. The AIIB aims to focus on infrastructure lending, but its scope may extend beyond that, unlike the ADB. The move has raised concerns among the US, Japan, and other countries about the lack of governance, environmental, and lending standards. The AIIB is expected to begin operations in 2015, with the possibility of more countries joining in the future.

site_title: Deep rifts remain at UN talks on global climate pact
summary: UN climate talks in Bonn failed to make significant progress due to deep rifts over responsibilities for reducing fossil fuel emissions. Despite a 2015 deadline looming, countries remain divided on key issues such as the legal form of the agreement, obligations for rich and poor nations, and assessing national carbon curbing pledges. The talks resulted in open-ended discussions, with many countries feeling they lost valuable negotiating time, and a lack of clarity on how to address the threat of climate change.

images.alt_text: With a 2015 deadline looming large for a global pact on curbing climate change, six days of UN talks have closed in Bonn with delegates and observers deflated over a lack of progress.

site_title: Williams demolishes Halep for 3rd straight crown
summary: Serena Williams won her third consecutive WTA Finals title, defeating Simona Halep in straight sets (6-3, 6-0) at the BNP Paribas WTA Finals in Singapore. Williams, the World No. 1, avenged her earlier loss to Halep, who had previously won a "bagel set" against her. Williams won the title, earning US$2.05 million and the Billie Jean King Trophy, cementing her status as the undisputed queen of women's tennis.

site_title: Austrian drones fly high, over Ukraine and beyond
summary: Austrian company Schiebel's Camcopter drones have gained prominence after completing surveillance missions at the Winter Olympics and G-20 summit. The 3.5-meter-long mini-helicopter equipped with cameras, radars, and sensors is being used by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) to monitor a ceasefire in Ukraine. With its unique technology allowing it to land on ships at sea, the Camcopter has become a prime choice for missions such as locating refugee boats and combating illegal fishing. The company has sold over 200 Camcopters to clients including the US, South Korea, and the Italian navy.

site_title: China trade accord unlikely to aid Aussie producers: survey
summary: A survey by the Australian Industry Group found that over half of 160 Australian manufacturers believe a free-trade deal with China would negatively affect their business. The survey, which is part of a submission to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, showed that only 11.2% of manufacturing respondents expect their business to benefit. Manufacturers cited concerns over increased competition from cheaper Chinese imports and a lack of a level playing field. The survey's findings contradict the government's claims that a China free-trade deal could enable local manufacturers to source competitively priced inputs and find more opportunities in global supply chains.

site_title: Port squeeze threatens US retailers' holiday stocking plans
summary: A shortage of trucking equipment and possible labor disruptions at the Los Angeles/Long Beach port complex are delaying shipping containers for up to three weeks, threatening timely delivery to retailers for the holiday season. Retailers including JC Penney, Macy's, and Walmart are affected, with some shipments stuck for over two weeks. The delays are attributed to the sale of container trailers and other non-core assets by shipping lines, leaving 8,000 truckers scrambling to find chassis, and protracted labor negotiations.

images.alt_text: The backlog of containers is creating extra work. Statistics from the Pacific Maritime Association, which represents 29 ports along the West Coast, show hours paid to terminal workers jumped 24 per cent this September over the same month last year.

site_title: Prices mixed on global growth outlook
summary: Global raw material prices experienced a mixed week due to investors tracking the outlook for global economic growth and the Ebola virus outbreak. Oil prices rebounded by over 2% amid market uncertainty, while commodities prices remained volatile. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, and Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall for the second half.

site_title: Canada vows tougher laws as citizens worry in face of attacks
summary: Canada vowed to strengthen anti-terrorism laws following the second soldier killed by homegrown radicals, Corporal Nathan Cirillo. The government plans to toughen security measures, including giving the Canadian Security Intelligence Service more powers, despite concerns over potential civil liberties. An opinion poll found 55% of Canadians lack confidence in police's ability to deter homegrown threats, and a mosque in Alberta was vandalized, sparking fears of a backlash against Muslims. The government aims to balance security with civil liberties, but critics warn of potential court challenges to the new measures.

site_title: Renault chief sees Europe auto market slowing in 2015
summary: Renault chairman Carlos Ghosn expects a slower growth in Europe's auto market in 2015, citing a moderate increase in line with GDP growth. The European market is currently growing at six percent, the best since the 2007 crisis. Despite this, Renault and Nissan plan to add production in China, where the auto market is slowing due to domestic economic growth and corruption. Renault has signed an agreement with Dongfeng to start production in 2016 with an initial capacity of 150,000 vehicles per year.

site_title: US: S&P 500 posts best week since Jan 2013
summary: US stocks closed at their best week since January 2013, driven by strong earnings from Microsoft and Procter & Gamble. The Dow Jones rose 127.51 points, the S&P 500 gained 13.77 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 30.92 points. Concerns over Ebola in the US eased, contributing to the positive market trend.

site_title: Big data becomes tool in Ebola battle
summary: Researchers in Boston used big data to detect the Ebola outbreak nine days before it was declared an epidemic in Guinea. By analyzing social media, local news reports, and online data, they developed an algorithm that provided early warnings of the disease's spread. Microsoft has made its cloud computing platform Azure available to Ebola researchers, and donations from Mark Zuckerberg and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation have been pledged. Experts say big data can be useful in curbing epidemics, but more needs to be done to leverage technology in the fight against communicable diseases like Ebola.

site_title: China's auto market growth may halve to 7% this year: industry body head
summary: China's auto market growth is expected to halve to 7% this year due to a slowing economy, according to Dong Yang, secretary general of the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers. This marks a significant decrease from last year's 13.9% growth. Despite the decline, Carlos Ghosn, head of Nissan, remains optimistic about China's long-term trend, citing low car ownership levels. Vehicle sales in China rose 7% in the first nine months of the year, but the industry is expected to reflect the economic slowdown.

site_title: South Korea fund to abstain from Samsung merger vote, wants share buybacks
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS) will abstain from voting on a proposed merger between Samsung Heavy Industries and Samsung Engineering, and instead plans to ask the companies to buy back its 5.9% holdings in both units. The move comes after the merger plan, which would involve the absorption of Samsung Engineering by Samsung Heavy, has led to a 20% decline in shares of both companies.
