If enough shareholders join NPS in asking for stock buybacks, the merger agreement could be canceled.

site_title: Momentum building on Pacific trade deal: Australia, US
summary: Representatives of Australia and the US announced momentum is building towards a pan-Pacific trade agreement, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), during talks in Sydney. The 12-nation pact, which encompasses 40% of the global economy, has been slowed by debate on key details. US Trade Representative Mike Froman said there is now momentum to narrow differences ahead of leaders meetings in Asia, with a goal to conclude the agreement by the end of this year. Proponents see the pact as freeing up trade and improving opportunities for jobs, while critics warn of potential negative impacts on the environment and public rights.

site_title: Tennis: Coric stuns Nadal in Basel, Federer through
summary: Croatian tennis player Borna Coric stunned world number two Rafael Nadal 6-2 7-6 (4) in the Swiss Indoor tournament, while local favorite Roger Federer advanced to the semifinals with a 7-6 (4) 6-2 win over Grigor Dimitrov. Coric, 17, is being compared to Novak Djokovic and could move into the rankings if he wins the title. Federer will face Ivo Karlovic in the semifinals, while Coric will play in-form David Goffin.

site_title: Eurozone risks 'relapse into recession' without structural reforms: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi warned that the eurozone risks a relapse into recession if structural economic reforms are not implemented. Draghi emphasized the need for a four-pronged strategy, including monetary policy, reforms, sound public finances, and healing the bloc's sick banks. He urged governments to draw up a reform program by December, which was welcomed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The eurozone faces a recovery halt, depressed prices, and near-record unemployment, with France and Italy pushing for more spending room in exchange for new commitments on reforms.

site_title: Fifth of eurozone banks fail ECB health check
summary: The European Central Bank's health check of 130 eurozone banks revealed that nearly one in five banks failed the stress test, with 25 banks failing the assessment. The failing banks are in Ireland, Italy, Greece, and Austria, and will need to raise capital by November 10. Only 10 of the failing banks will need to raise more cash, while the rest will be allowed to continue operating. The ECB will assume its banking supervisor role on November 4 and hopes the health check will uncover any potential issues before it takes over.

site_title: HP seeking buyers for corporate-networking business in China: WSJ
summary: Hewlett-Packard is seeking buyers for its corporate-networking business in China, H3C Technologies Co, due to US technology companies facing challenges in the country. HP is expected to sell at least 51% of the business, valued at around $5 billion, and may retain a minority stake. The buyer must be based in China to win government approval. Potential buyers include private-equity firms and Chinese technology companies, with US firms such as Cisco and IBM unlikely to be involved.

site_title: China's top graft-buster says fight will never end
summary: China's top graft-buster, Wang Qishan, stated that the country's fight against corruption will never end. Since President Xi Jinping's campaign began, senior officials, including former domestic security chief Zhou Yongkang, have been removed. Wang emphasized the need for "consistency, intensified supervision, discipline, and accountability" to build a clean government. The Communist Party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is set to begin its annual plenum, which may not have a clear end date. Wang noted that a clean government and fair market are essential for investment.

site_title: Transforming China's architectural scene
summary: Lyndon Neri and Rossana Hu, founders of Shanghai-based Neri&Hu Design, are part of a new breed of architects transforming China's architectural scene. The couple, born in the Philippines and Taiwan respectively, have gained international recognition for their innovative designs, including the Waterhouse at South Bund hotel and the Platform sofa for De La Espada. Neri&Hu's approach combines Eastern and Western elements, with a focus on meaning and purpose in their designs. They were named 2014's Designer of the Year by Wallpaper* Magazine and have won numerous awards for their work.

site_title: Indonesia graft body probes former ministers
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency, KPK, is investigating former ministers under President Joko Widodo's administration, who were previously cleared by the Corruption Eradication Commission. The agency is now assessing the revised cabinet list and plans to submit results to the president. This move shows Widodo's commitment to fighting corruption, following the scandals that eroded his predecessor Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's support. The investigation aims to ensure the new cabinet is composed of "clean, clear and great ministers" to avoid problems with the KPK.

site_title: Huge Brent options trade revives talk of Mexico back on hedging path
summary: Mexico has reportedly restarted its annual hedging programme, shifting from the US market to the European benchmark Brent after a large options trade. A 5-million-barrel oil options trade was executed at a US$70 strike price, sparking speculation that the country has resumed its programme. The annual deals aim to protect public finances heavily dependent on crude revenue, which had been put on pause due to falling oil prices. The move comes as Mexico sells most of its production to the United States, but also begins hedging with Brent, considered a better proxy for waterborne exports.

site_title: Rules for returning Ebola health workers need coordination: US official
summary: US officials are discussing new rules for healthcare workers returning to the US after treating Ebola patients in West Africa. The proposed measures aim to prevent additional imported Ebola cases while minimizing unintended consequences. Governors of New York and New Jersey announced unilateral quarantine measures, but US officials want coordinated efforts. The goal is to fortify the US against Ebola while eliminating the threat at its source in West Africa.

site_title: Google's Pichai to oversee major products and services: blog
summary: Google's CEO Larry Page has appointed Sundar Pichai to oversee the company's major products and services, including search, maps, commerce, advertising, and infrastructure. Pichai will oversee six previously-reporting executives and is seen as a potential CEO material. This move centralizes control over key services, including Google's core search and advertising units.

site_title: Two killed, four wounded in Washington state school shooting
summary: A student at Marysville-Pilchuck High School in Washington state fatally shot a classmate and wounded four others in a cafeteria following a fight. Jaylen Fryberg, a 15-year-old Native American student, took his own life after the shooting. The victims were all young people, with three in critical condition and the fourth in serious condition. The incident marks the latest in a series of deadly school shootings in the US, prompting a national debate over gun laws, following a similar incident in 2012 at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

site_title: Two US states to quarantine health workers returning from Ebola zones
summary: The US states of New York and New Jersey will automatically quarantine medical workers returning from Ebola-hit West African countries, exceeding federal requirements. This move comes after a doctor who treated patients in Guinea tested positive for Ebola, and follows a series of steps implemented by the Obama administration to prevent the spread of the virus. The states' new policy applies to medical workers returning through John F Kennedy International Airport in New York and Newark Liberty International Airport in New Jersey, and is seen as a precautionary measure to protect public health.

site_title: Apple urged by Ralph Nader to reduce buybacks and raise wages: WSJ
summary: Consumer advocate Ralph Nader urged Apple CEO Tim Cook to reduce share buybacks and raise wages, citing poverty wages and poor working conditions in Apple's supply chain. Nader criticized Apple's $133 billion cash pile, which he believes could be used to improve wages and working conditions. This comes as labor activists and right groups have long criticized Apple's manufacturing practices, including a 2010 Foxconn suicide crisis that led to increased audits and reviews of its supply chain. Apple declined to comment on Nader's letter.

images.alt_text: Consumer advocate Ralph Nader sent a letter to Apple's chief executive officer Tim Cook urging the company to reduce its spending on share buybacks and use the money to raise wages, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

site_title: Indonesia president appoints technocrats to top economic posts
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo appointed technocrats to lead the top economic ministries, including former state-owned enterprises minister Sofyan Djalil as coordinating minister for economics, and vice minister Bambang Brodjonegoro as head of the finance ministry. The appointments aim to implement reforms addressing costly fuel subsidies, investment, and infrastructure issues. With Indonesia facing economic headwinds, the new ministers have been praised for their experience and track record, and are expected to address the country's fiscal problems and improve its basic services.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, also known as Jokowi, on Sunday assigned professional technocrats to lead the top economic ministries and implement much-needed reforms that address costly fuel subsidies, cooling investment and the country's creaky infrastructure.

site_title: Tokyo investors eyeing Fed meet, Japan data next week
summary: Tokyo investors will focus on a US Federal Reserve policy meeting and Japanese economic data, including inflation and GDP figures, next week amid concerns about the spread of the Ebola virus. The Fed is expected to exit its stimulus program, while mixed US data has raised questions about the strength of the world's top economy. Japanese stocks rose on Friday, driven by a weaker yen and cheap shares, but investors will monitor the situation in New York where the city has confirmed its first Ebola case.

site_title: Ford to overhaul Lincoln brand, this time with big bucks
summary: Ford is investing at least $5 billion over the next five years to overhaul its struggling Lincoln brand, which has seen sales decline from 187,121 in 1998 to 81,694 last year. The new plan includes a significant investment in a new premium vehicle platform, known as D6, which will underpin several future Lincoln vehicles. The platform will be flexible and can be configured for front-, rear- and all-wheel-drive vehicles. The goal is to triple Lincoln's global sales to 300,000 vehicles by 2020 and restore the brand's luster as a premium automotive marque in the US and China.

site_title: Say no to clothes made with Angora rabbit fur
summary: Angora rabbit farms in China are subjecting the animals to extreme suffering as their fur is ripped out by the fistfuls. The fur is used in luxury fashion items, such as sweaters and scarves, due to its silky texture and softness. Most farms pluck the fur, often at a cost to the animal's welfare. The industry prioritizes profit over animal welfare, with cheap fibre being in high demand by brokers, designers, and retailers. The use of angora fur is a cruel reality masked by the fashion industry's glamorous facade.

site_title: UK agent alert points at housing momentum reversal
summary: London's property market appears to be experiencing a reversal of momentum, with Foxtons, a real estate agent, warning of a potential buyers' strike. The company's sales commissions increased 17% in the first nine months of the year but dropped 7.8% in the third quarter. Domestic buyers are responding to expectations of higher borrowing costs, and foreign buyers, who have driven the market's growth since 2013, are also losing interest due to sterling's decline and UK political uncertainty. Foxtons now expects earnings to be 15% below forecasts.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust Q2 DPU up 9.4%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 9.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.97 Singapore cents for its Q2 2014, driven by a 6.3% rise in gross revenue to S$70 million. The trust attributed the growth to higher rental income from new and replacement leases, as well as step-ups in existing leases. Despite challenging market conditions, VivoCity remains well-received by shoppers, and the trust plans a S$5.5 million asset enhancement project. Unitholders will receive their distribution on Dec 4, 2014.

site_title: Qantas sees 1H profit after record FY14 loss
summary: Qantas expects to post a pre-tax profit in the first half of 2015 after a record net loss of A$2.84 billion in FY14, driven by restructuring costs and a writedown of its international fleet. The airline is on track to complete its major cost-cutting programme, with plans to reduce jobs by 80% and pay down A$1 billion in debt by the end of June 2015. Qantas attributes its expected return to profitability to a weaker Australian dollar and falling oil prices, despite weak domestic demand.

site_title: UK to boost funding for fight against Ebola
summary: The UK has pledged to sharply increase its funding to combat the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, with a further £80 million to be allocated towards setting up 200 Ebola care units in Sierra Leone. The move comes as the World Health Organization warns that the virus is still spreading "exponentially" in the hardest-hit countries. The UK has already pledged £125 million, and billionaire Paul G. Allen has committed an additional $100 million to the effort. European leaders have struggled to agree on a common response, but the EU has announced new research funding to develop better treatments.

site_title: Office segment the star performer but what'll happen when the party ends?
summary: Singapore's office segment has emerged as the market's star, with prices and rents rising steadily in the third quarter. The office price index for the Central Region rose 1.6% and the office rental index increased 2.6%, driven by tight supply and limited new completions. However, major office projects are expected to be completed in 2016-2017, potentially leading to a slowdown in the market. Analysts predict continued growth in office rents, with some expecting a 15% increase in 2015 and 15.5% in 2016, before a pullback in 2016.

site_title: Williams to face Wozniacki in semi-final
summary: The BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals in Singapore saw four players advance to the semi-finals on Friday. Simona Halep, Caroline Wozniacki, Agnieszka Radwanska, and Serena Williams made it through, while Maria Sharapova, Petra Kvitova, and Ana Ivanovic were eliminated. Wozniacki, who has a 0-9 record against Williams, will face the American in the semi-final. The championship final is set for Sunday night with the winner claiming the US$6.5 million prize money and the Billie Jean King trophy.

site_title: French unemployment hits new record
summary: Unemployment in France reached a new record of 3.43 million in September, with a rise of 19,200 people joining the jobless queue. This marks a significant increase since President Francois Hollande's election in 2012. Labour Minister Francois Rebsamen acknowledged the failure to reduce unemployment, stating that the government's labour market reforms need more time to take effect. The government plans to finance tax breaks with public spending cuts, sparking controversy among left-wing party members. Economists predict that 1.5% average growth is needed to reduce unemployment, and some believe it may take until 2016 to see a decrease.

site_title: CCT Q3 DPU up 2.9% to 2.10 Singapore cents
summary: CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter to 2.10 Singapore cents, driven by a 4.8% jump in distributable income to S$61.6 million. The portfolio committed occupancy rate is 99.4%, above the market occupancy rate of 96.6%. CCT signed new leases and renewals of approximately 131,000 square feet, with a 4.9% increase in monthly average office rent. The Reit is in advanced stages of negotiation for another 75,000 sq ft of space, positioning it well to achieve its 50% target leasing commitment by the end of the year.

site_title: Wild about wild plants
summary: Clarins owner Christian Courtin-Clarins emphasizes the importance of sustainability in the beauty industry, citing his family's focus on preserving natural environments. He has spearheaded various initiatives, including a drinking water supply network in Madagascar, desertification prevention in China, and school meal programs worldwide. The company uses wild plants, often foraged by locals, in its natural-based formulations, which are effective but not certified "organic" due to their non-farmed origin. Courtin-Clarins aims to eventually use purely organic ingredients, prioritizing environmental protection for future generations.

site_title: Football legends to square off
summary: Former Liverpool football stars Patrik Berger, Robbie Fowler, and Jerzy Dudek will face off against a Singapore team featuring Fandi Ahmad and other local players in the Castlewood Group Liverpool Masters on November 15 at the Jalan Besar Stadium. The event, a testimonial for retiring striker Aleksandar Duric, is part of a growing sports tourism scene in Singapore, which has already hosted major events such as the Formula One night race and the Women's Tennis Association tournament. The match is expected to be sold out, with tickets starting at S$10.

site_title: China home prices fall 1.3% in September
summary: China's home prices fell 1.3% in September, marking the fifth consecutive monthly drop and erasing a year's gains. This decline raises concerns about the government's ability to cushion the blow to the economy, which accounts for 15% of China's economy. The slowdown in the housing market has also affected 40 sectors, including steel and manufacturing. Despite a slight easing of the monthly drop, inventories of unsold homes remain high, and developers have slowed land purchases, making a quick recovery in the property market uncertain.

site_title: Rough patch? Life can be such a pitch
summary: The Sports Hub in Singapore has been plagued by a lack of suitable grass for rugby games, leading to the postponement of a friendly match and a Jay Chou concert. The issue stems from the field's inability to dry quickly after watering, resulting in diseased leaves. To address the problem, the Sports Hub has purchased special lighting to aid in grass growth, a costly solution estimated at S$1.5 million. The incident highlights the challenges of maintaining a suitable sports facility in a tropical climate.

site_title: Plan for straw poll on govt proposals
summary: Hong Kong protesters plan to hold a straw poll on government proposals rejected earlier in the week, as their five-week-old street campaign pushes for democracy in the Chinese-controlled city. The electronic poll, to be held on Sunday, will ask protesters if the government's offer to submit a report to Beijing on the protests would have practical purpose. The move comes after talks with officials on Tuesday failed to break the deadlock, with protesters seeking universal suffrage and an end to the current leader's tenure.

site_title: 21 nations back new regional lender
summary: China and 20 other countries signed a memorandum of understanding to establish the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a new regional lender aimed at addressing the region's growing demand for transportation, dams, and other facilities. The AIIB, with an initial capital of $50 billion, is seen as a counterweight to Western-backed international development banks like the World Bank and Asian Development Bank. The US expressed concerns about the institution's governance and transparency, while Australia, Indonesia, and South Korea have yet to formally participate.

images.alt_text: CHINA and 20 other countries moved forward on Friday towards setting up an Asian infrastructure lender seen as a counterweight to Western-backed international development banks.

site_title: Chic buys
summary: A preview sale at Club 21 Bazaar in Singapore has attracted long queues, with up to 90% off on designer items from brands like Marc Jacobs and Balenciaga. The sale, which started on Wednesday, will continue until Sunday. The event offers deep discounts on various fashion items, making it a popular destination for bargain hunters.

images.alt_text: Marc Jacobs organza dress, S$1,000 (UP S$5,290).
Marni studded belt, S$90 (UP S$560).
Anne Valerie Hash sleeveless panelled blouse S$175 (UP S$860) and Preen pythonprinted skirt, S$200 (UP S$1,060).
Marc Jacobs ombre plaid dress, S$560 (UP S$5,590).
Valentino men's cardigan, S$300 (UP S$1,290).
Marc Jacobs ivory top, S$260 (UP S$1,760) and Marc Jacobs checked skirt, S$200 (UP S$1,060).
Stella McCartney platform boots, S$250 (UP S$1,660).
Alexander Wang bonded lambskin coat, S$750 (UP S$4,960).
Tim Coppens men's baseball jacket, S$730 (UP S$3,660).

site_title: LA port chief sees initial union deal within weeks
summary: Los Angeles Port Chief Gene Seroka expects a tentative agreement with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union on new contracts for West Coast ports within weeks. The deal would address issues such as job retraining, salaries, and work rules as automation reduces positions. A successful outcome is crucial to reducing bottlenecks in shipping and trucking, with cargo ships currently waiting to be unloaded. The Port of Los Angeles, which handles nearly half of US maritime trade, is seeking to resolve issues such as empty container placement and truck chassis responsibility.

site_title: EU leaders agree on most ambitious 2030 climate change targets
summary: EU leaders agreed on ambitious 2030 climate change targets, aiming for a 40% cut in greenhouse gas emissions and 27% renewable energy supply. The deal was reached despite environmental groups' criticism, and is seen as a step forward ahead of the Paris climate conference in 2015. The agreement also promotes energy efficiency gains and interconnection links between member states, aiming to bolster energy security and reduce reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: The ins and outs of share buybacks
summary: Corporate insiders tend to buy stocks for themselves when the market is low, but when companies make buybacks on behalf of shareholders, it's often a sign of weak financial decisions. Unlike insider buying, which is guided by long-term fundamentals, company buybacks are driven by short-term cash flow and the desire to boost earnings per share. This can lead to overvalued stocks and excessive debt, ultimately harming the company's long-term health. Experts say that insiders make better decisions when buying for themselves, but companies' buyback decisions are often misguided and driven by other objectives.

site_title: EU budget rules at centre of tensions over growth
summary: Germany and France emphasized the importance of economic growth in the eurozone's budget strategy amid EU summit tensions. German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned against high spending to revive the economy, instead advocating for a balance between growth and budget consolidation. The European Commission is reviewing member states' budget plans and plans to present a list of infrastructure projects to finance them by December. Economists have expressed doubts about the effectiveness of this approach in addressing the eurozone's stagnation and deflation.

site_title: New panel to review appeals by SMEs for Spring S'pore grant
summary: A new panel, comprising 17 industry experts, will review appeals from small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore for the capability development grant, starting from November 1. The panel, chaired by Sim Giok Lak, will provide independent and objective recommendations to the grant application assessments. The move aims to complement and strengthen existing processes, particularly for complex cases, and provide business perspectives to the grant application assessments.

site_title: Fed to stress-test 31 large US banks for dire scenarios
summary: The Federal Reserve is conducting annual stress tests on 31 large US banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, to assess their ability to withstand economic turmoil. The tests, which began in 2009, use hypothetical scenarios to gauge the banks' resilience in the face of a decline in equity and housing prices, a sharp downturn in the global economy, and other adverse conditions. The results will determine whether banks must build up capital buffers and potentially forgo stock buybacks and higher dividends.

site_title: MGCCT's Q2 DPU up 10.4% on rental boost
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 10.4% increase in distributable income for its Q2, driven by higher rentals. The Reit's income available for distribution rose to S$43.5 million, with a 1.606 Singapore cent distribution per unit. Net property income increased by 9% to S$55.1 million, with a 9.4% gain for the half-year. Occupancy rates for Festival Walk and Gateway Plaza were 98.6% and 92% respectively, with rents improving by 21% and 32% respectively. The Reit expects stable Hong Kong retail and Beijing office markets.

site_title: American universities produce most billionaires
summary: The University of Pennsylvania is the top producer of billionaires, with 25 of the world's current billionaires obtaining their bachelor's degrees from the institution. Harvard University comes in second, followed by Yale University, University of Southern California, and Princeton University. US universities dominate the list, accounting for all top five billionaire-producing universities, with 16 out of the top 20 being in the US. The study also shows that 35% of billionaires do not have a tertiary-level degree, with notable dropouts including Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg.

site_title: Record wave of new homes could swamp prices and rents (Amended)
summary: A record number of new private homes (20,852 in 2014, 23,769 in 2015) could lead to a prolonged period of stagnant or rising prices and rents in Singapore, despite a moderate 0.7% decline in private home prices in Q3. New condo sales plummeted 42.6% quarter-on-quarter, while new units launched fell 54.5%. Consultants predict that competition in the leasing market will intensify, with more HDB flats entering the rental market, potentially drawing buyers back to the market and leading to a bottoming out of prices by Q1 2015.

site_title: Making history again
summary: Several high-end watch brands, including Panerai, A Lange & Söhne, and Audemars Piguet, have released limited edition timepieces to celebrate their heritage and showcase innovative designs. Panerai reissued its 1996 Slytech watches, A Lange & Söhne celebrated its 20th anniversary of the Lange 1, and Audemars Piguet unveiled the Royal Oak Offshore Self-winding Tourbillon Chronograph. Additionally, Jaeger-LeCoultre's Master Grande Tradition Grande Complication watch features a unique flying tourbillon and trebuchet hammers.

site_title: CapitaRetail China Trust's Q3 DPU up 10.3%
summary: CapitaRetail China Trust posted a 10.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.35 Singapore cents for its Q3 2014, driven by new mall contributions and rental growth. Gross revenue rose 30.2% to S$51.4 million, with net property income increasing 29.2%. The trust remains optimistic on China's long-term economic prospects, citing consumption growth. The Reit closed 2.5 cents higher at S$1.59.

site_title: Feminine complexity
summary: Luxury watch brands are now catering to women's tastes, offering a wider range of sophisticated timepieces. Gone are the days of simple, bejeweled quartz watches; mechanical complications are becoming increasingly common. Brands such as Montblanc, Roger Dubuis, and Van Cleef & Arpels are producing high-end, mechanical watches with intricate designs and complications, including the Montblanc Bohème Perpetual Calendar Jewellery and Van Cleef & Arpels Lady Arpels Heures Filantes Poetic Complication. This shift is a response to women's growing demand for luxury watches and is seen as a significant market opportunity for watchmakers.

site_title: STI posts 1.7% weekly gain in two-tier market
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) posted a 1.7% weekly gain in the two-tier market, driven by action in the top-end stocks such as banks and the Jardine group. The index closed at 3,222.55 on Friday, with turnover amounting to 1.2 billion units worth S$892.7 million. Despite muted retail activity, the STI's movements were largely dictated by expectations of Wall Street's performance. A short-selling report on China food company Sino Grandness (SG) contributed to its 12.5% decline to a 52-week low.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q3 profit pales in absence of big year-ago sale
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 21.4% drop in net profit to S$14.9 million for the Q3 period, mainly due to a significant site sale from the previous year. Revenue declined 37.6% to S$54.7 million. The company's nine-month net earnings fell 93.7% year-over-year. The decline was partly attributed to the absence of the S$81.3 million mixed-use development site sale from the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) acquired three serviced residences in Greater Sydney for A$83 million, representing a 2% discount to an independent valuation. The acquisition expands ART's pipeline and maintains its "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.40. Sino Grandness's share price fell 12.5% after a short-seller questioned its financial credibility, with management attributing discrepancies to business-model variances and methodology differences. Despite refuting claims, the allegations have dented confidence, and the "hold" rating remains in place.

site_title: Making time for Asia
summary: Swiss luxury watchmaker Richemont Group's Watches & Wonders fair in Hong Kong made a successful return, with 16,000 visitors and 13 luxury brands showcasing their latest timepieces. The event saw a significant increase in women's timepieces, with 35% of customers identified as female, according to Montblanc CEO Jerome Lambert. Brands are responding to the growing demand from women collectors, with exclusive Asian-market releases and new feminine lines. The event aimed to reposition watches as a statement piece, rather than just a necessity, with owners seeking to commemorate special events.

site_title: StarHub, Nokia to offer multi-view video feeds at live events
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telco, is partnering with Nokia to offer multi-view video feeds at live events, enhancing the viewing experience for spectators. A trial of Nokia's Liquid Applications solution was conducted at the Singapore Indoor Stadium during the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals, delivering four high-definition video feeds in real-time with ultra-low latency. The solution caches content at base stations, reducing lag and improving streaming quality, offering subscribers the best mobile broadband experience. Further trials are planned before introducing the service to subscribers.

site_title: Google buys 6 Silicon Valley office buildings for US$585m
summary: Google has acquired six office buildings in Redwood City, California, for US$585 million. The properties, part of the Pacific Shores Center office park, total 934,200 square feet of Class A office space and include a 38,000 sq ft fitness centre. The acquisition is part of Google's real estate expansion and hiring spree, with the company expecting to hire aggressively for the remainder of 2014. This deal follows a recent signing of office-lease agreements worth US$1 billion up to 2028.

site_title: S'pore factory output contracts 1.2% in Sept
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output contracted 1.2% in September, worse than expected. However, this performance is still seen as boosting third-quarter GDP estimates, with industrial production growth averaging 1.9% year-on-year. Economists expect a slight upward revision to Q3 GDP growth to 2.5% year-on-year.

site_title: SAP to set up innovation centre here
summary: SAP is setting up an innovation centre in Singapore, focusing on breakthroughs in smart cities, industry, healthcare, and digital consumers. The centre, expected to open by the end of 2014, will foster local economic opportunities through co-innovation with customers and partners, research collaboration with universities, and providing local startups with access to latest technologies. SAP aims to develop innovative products, identify untapped markets, and create user-centric solutions. The centre will have over 100 people working on it, including SAP employees, partners, customers, and researchers.

site_title: An Asian persuasion
summary: Hong Kong's luxury watch market saw brands incorporating Asian elements, such as the number '8' and dragon motifs, to appeal to collectors. Brands like Baume and Mercier, Richard Mille, and Cartier released limited-edition watches with red and dragon designs, often with auspicious numbers like 88 or 188. These exclusive timepieces featured intricate details, including dragon scales and tourbillon regulators, to showcase their craftsmanship and luxury. The trend was seen at Watches & Wonders in Hong Kong, with watches like the RM 51-01 Tiger and Dragon Michelle Yeoh Tourbillon and the Pasha de Cartier Skeleton Dragon.

site_title: Japan minister in fresh crisis after S&M scandal
summary: Japan's Industry Minister Yoichi Miyazawa faces renewed pressure over his stake in Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the Fukushima nuclear plant he oversees. Miyazawa denies a conflict of interest, insisting he won't sell his 600 shares worth $1,850, which he bought before the 2011 disaster. The government says he disclosed his holdings and will place them in trust. The scandal is the latest blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration, which has seen two cabinet ministers resign over misspending accusations.

site_title: 'Cloud', Xbox help Microsoft beat Q1 earnings expectations
summary: Microsoft reported quarterly profits ahead of expectations, with net profit at US$4.5 billion and revenue rising to US$23 billion, its best ever for the fiscal first quarter. The company's Xbox consoles and cloud services for enterprises contributed to the revenue growth. Shares rose 2.75% in after-hours trade. Microsoft chief executive Satya Nadella attributed the results to the company's focus on innovation, customer engagement, and cloud services. Revenue from commercial offerings, including cloud services, grew 128% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: MR NADELLA: Says the Microsoft cloud offering 'empowers every business across every industry in every geography'

site_title: Quarters of an urban nomad
summary: Hajar Ali, the founder of luxury travel company Urbane Nomads, has lived in a 196 sq. m. penthouse apartment off Serangoon Road for 10 years. The apartment is filled with quirky items collected from her travels to far-flung locales, including kilims, sculptures, antique lamps, and headdresses. Ali, the first woman to cross the world's largest sand desert, the Middle East's "Empty Quarter," has a unique home that reflects her love of travel and cultural exploration. The apartment features a poem by Persian poet Hafez, African and Vietnamese accessories, and a hamsa amulet, among other items.

images.alt_text: WORDS OF WISDOM: A poem by Persian poet Hafez was painted by Ms Hajar along the length of her living room wall
