The move aims to foster investment and support the country's economy, which has been affected by a cooling manufacturing sector and a softening housing market. This is part of Premier Li Keqiang's promise to launch major investment projects in various sectors to support the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 1.37% higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.37% to 23,403.97 points, driven by a third consecutive advance on Wall Street. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.56% to 2,326.55 points, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.11% to 1,316.03 points. The gains in Hong Kong were largely attributed to the US market's advance, despite ongoing uncertainty over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Most BoE policymakers firmly against rate hike
summary: Most Bank of England policymakers opposed raising interest rates due to limited inflation pressure and concerns about potential economic shocks. Only two members, Martin Weale and Ian McCafferty, voted to raise rates to 0.75% from 0.5%, citing unbalanced economic recovery and delayed interest rate effects. The majority believed the economy was not yet ready for a rate hike, with pay growth lower than needed to meet the Bank's 2% inflation target. This decision suggests the Bank is in no hurry to tighten monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Most Bank of England policymakers were firmly against raising interest rates when they met earlier this month, seeing little evidence of inflation pressure, with only two continuing to vote to tighten monetary policy - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Daimler sees US$780m windfall from sale of Tesla stake
summary: Daimler AG announced it will sell its 4% stake in Tesla Motors Inc. for $780 million, resulting in a significant cash inflow and boosting earnings before interest and taxes for 2014. The sale does not affect the cooperation agreement to supply Mercedes-Benz cars with Tesla battery technology. Proceeds from the sale will be used to strengthen Daimler's operational business. Daimler's CEO Dieter Zetsche stated that the partnership with Tesla remains successful and will be continued.

site_title: Apple sees iCloud attacks; China hack reported
summary: Apple reported that its iCloud server has been the target of "intermittent" attacks, with security blog GreatFire.org attributing the attempts to Chinese authorities. Apple stated that the attacks did not breach iCloud servers and did not impact user sign-in on iOS devices or Macs using Safari browser. The company warned users to be cautious when connecting to non-secure websites and to ignore security warnings. Apple has not confirmed the involvement of Chinese authorities in the attacks, but cited a security bulletin citing the hack attempts.

site_title: More hackers targeting mobile phones to get bank info: survey
summary: Hackers are increasingly targeting mobile phones to steal bank information, with 60% of malicious programs targeting Android devices designed to steal money or banking credentials. A Kaspersky Labs report found over 588,000 Android users worldwide faced financial malware attacks, six times higher than the prior year. The largest number of victims were in Russia, with other countries affected including Ukraine, Spain, and India. The report warns of "Trojan-Banker" and "Trojan-SMS" malware that allow hackers access to bank accounts.

site_title: Australian inflation eases after scrapping of carbon tax
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 0.5% in the September quarter, easing inflation to 2.3% annual rate, below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target range of 2.0-3.0%. The removal of the carbon tax contributed to the softer inflation, giving the central bank room to maintain its record-low interest rate of 2.5%. Key contributors to the CPI rise included a 14.7% jump in fruit prices and increases in property purchases, rates, and motor vehicle service fees, while electricity and petrol prices dropped.

images.alt_text: Australian consumer prices rose 0.5 per cent in the September quarter, official figures showed Wednesday, as the annual rate of inflation eased following the removal of a controversial carbon tax - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: China premier says taking time for reforms to gain traction
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that reform measures are taking time to gain traction, despite China's economic performance being within a "reasonable range" in the first nine months of the year. The country's economy is facing downward pressure, with a slowest pace since the global financial crisis in the September quarter, and risks missing its official target for the first time in 15 years.

images.alt_text: It is still taking time for reform measures to gain traction, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang was quoted as saying by the Foreign Ministry - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Shaky Japanese economy hit by growing trade deficit
summary: Japan's economy is facing a record annual trade deficit, with a widening September shortfall of $8.96 billion. The deficit, the worst on record for the month, comes as the country's economy struggles with a string of weak figures and a sharp contraction in the second quarter. The trade deficit for the first nine months of the year has increased by 35% from the previous year, underscoring concerns about the impact of the April consumption tax hike. The government's economic growth plan, "Abenomics," is under pressure, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's decision on a second tax hike remains uncertain.

site_title: ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence Index dips in October
summary: The ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence Index dropped 0.5 points to 120.2 points in October, reflecting faltering confidence about personal financial situations. Only 19.2% of respondents expect their financial situation to improve next year, down 6 percentage points from the previous month. The index's chief economist, Glenn Maguire, attributed the decline to uncertainty among Singaporean consumers, with risks leaning towards weaker confidence.

site_title: Hong Kong netizens lampoon government negotiators
summary: Hong Kong government negotiators faced ridicule from netizens after tense talks with student leaders. The student leaders, wearing "Freedom Now" T-shirts, demanded full democracy in the southern Chinese city. The talks made little headway, but online satirists mocked the government team, portraying them as out-of-touch and ineffective. The government team was described as empty vases, garbage bins, and Teletubbies, highlighting the disconnect between the government and protesters.

site_title: Argentine leader resumes work after being sick
summary: Argentina's President Cristina Kirchner has resumed her work schedule after being sick with pharyngitis, a painful sore throat condition, which initially forced her to postpone a domestic trip. She had previously been forced to cancel a trip to Paraguay due to a similar condition and underwent surgery for a subdural hematoma and thyroid gland removal in 2012. The change in plans comes after a two-day rest period, and the government has confirmed she has resumed her official duties.

site_title: Private equity firms wooing small investors
summary: Private equity firms, such as Carlyle, are targeting individual investors, including doctors, lawyers, and wealthy entrepreneurs, to raise capital. The firms are creating a new way for individual investors to access their private equity funds, with a minimum investment of $250,000. This move aims to tap into the growing trend of Americans saving for retirement through 401(k)s, which has led to a shift away from traditional pension funds. Industry experts warn that smaller investors may not fully understand the risks involved, while firms like Blackstone and Carlyle see individuals as a largely untapped source of capital.

site_title: India's Modi burnishes economic credentials with reform blitz
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has introduced a series of economic reforms, including scrapping fuel subsidies, simplifying labor rules, and opening coal mining to private players. The reforms aim to boost the country's stagnant economy and create jobs for its 1.2 billion people. Analysts say the reforms are a good start, but more significant changes are needed to address labor issues and bring in a national goods-and-services tax. Modi's government plans to sell state-owned assets and scrap outdated laws to further ease regulations and attract foreign investment.

site_title: HK tycoons can be part of protest solution
summary: Hong Kong's business leaders may play a role in resolving the current standoff with pro-democracy activists by relaxing their grip on special corporate votes. The current system allows companies to decide more than 40% of the seats on the committee that nominates candidates for the city's chief executive, despite holding less than 7% of the votes. Relaxing this grip could ease divisions over electoral reform and reduce tensions over inequality. This could help avoid a bigger confrontation and promote stability in the city.

site_title: Washington Post 'Watergate' editor dead at 93
summary: Ben Bradlee, legendary former Washington Post editor who oversaw the reporting on the Watergate scandal that led to President Richard Nixon's resignation, died at 93. Bradlee, known for his courage and commitment to the truth, inspired reporters and transformed the notion of political investigative journalism. During his leadership from 1968 to 1991, the Post won the Pulitzer Prize for its Watergate stories and played a key role in the successful legal challenge to the publication of the Pentagon Papers. President Barack Obama hailed Bradlee as a genius and a champion of journalism, saying that "journalism was more than a profession - it was a public good vital to our democracy."

site_title: India to allow commercial coal mining by foreign companies
summary: India plans to allow foreign companies to mine coal commercially, opening the door for global giants like Rio Tinto to access the country's fifth-largest coal reserves. The move, announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, aims to bring order to the country's chaotic power industry and end chronic blackouts. The government will auction 74 coalfields to private firms within four months, with revenue paid to states where the blocks are located. The move is expected to boost coal production and pressure Coal India to increase output, with industry experts saying it's a key step towards meeting India's growing energy needs.

images.alt_text: India could allow commercial coal mining by foreign companies if they set up units in the country, opening the door for global giants like Rio Tinto to access the world's fifth-largest coal reserves, a source familiar with the matter said - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Rising Chinese incomes defy GDP slowdown
summary: China's economy slowed to its weakest pace since 2009 in the third quarter, but rising incomes and stable inflation have helped the government refrain from implementing broad-based stimulus. A growing share of output is now going to citizens, rather than the state, which is contributing to the slowdown. Despite this, China's citizens remain secure in their jobs, with incomes rising and inflation restrained.

site_title: Switzerland top destination for expats: poll
summary: Switzerland tops the list as the world's favorite destination among expats, according to a poll by HSBC. The country ranked high due to its better work-life balance, availability of outdoor activities, and family-centric culture. Asia, particularly Singapore and China, also emerged as top destinations, with high salaries and good quality of life. The top 5 countries were Switzerland, Singapore, China, Germany, and Bahrain, while Egypt and the United Kingdom ranked last.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up nearly 2.0% in opening trade
summary: Tokyo stocks rose nearly 2.0% in opening trade on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp drop the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.97% to 15,096.63, driven by US stocks posting robust gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 1.31% and 1.96% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.40% on Apple's strong earnings report. Currency rates were largely unchanged, despite Japan's trade deficit expanding 1.6% year-on-year in September.

site_title: Airbus Helicopters expects China to become biggest market by 2020
summary: Airbus Helicopters expects China to become its largest global market by 2020, driven by Beijing's plan to lift restrictions on low-altitude airspace starting in 2015. The company aims to increase annual sales in China to 150 units from around 30-40 now. This growth is attributed to the emergence of civil private helicopter operators, previously dominated by state companies. By 2020, China is expected to surpass the US as Airbus Helicopters' biggest market, with sales projected to surpass those in the US.

site_title: SMEs remake themselves amid cost pressures
summary: Singapore small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are re-examining their business models to reduce costs and stay competitive amid manpower and cost pressures. A survey by DP Information Group found that 51% of SMEs plan to re-evaluate their business models, while 50% aim to increase production capacity. Many are also expanding overseas, with 20% of SMEs now doing business abroad, up from 14% in 2013. However, the proportion of SMEs generating more than 70% of their revenue overseas has fallen, and those with weak credit ratings pose a risk to the business ecosystem.

site_title: Yahoo profit surges on Alibaba divestment, mobile
summary: Yahoo's quarterly profit surged to $6.8 billion, driven by a $6.3 billion gain from its Alibaba shares sale. Revenue from operations increased by 1% to $1.15 billion, exceeding expectations. Yahoo's mobile Internet initiatives also showed improvement. CEO Marissa Mayer welcomed the results, which boosted Yahoo shares by 2.7% in after-hours trade. The strong performance is a relief for Mayer, who faces pressure to show the company's ability to succeed beyond its Alibaba investment.

site_title: Quiet critic of BOJ's 'monetary shamanism' turns up the volume
summary: Izuru Kato, a Japanese economist, has criticized the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) stimulus policy as "monetary shamanism," arguing it relies too heavily on psychology and fails to explain why inflation should rise despite subdued economic growth. Kato's warnings about the policy's limitations and potential risks, including high inflation and a bloated balance sheet, are resonating with some BOJ policymakers and academics. His views have gained attention as markets lose faith in the BOJ's ability to achieve its inflation target.

site_title: One by one, Paris luxury hotels hit by strikes for better pay
summary: Employees at the luxury Royal Monceau-Raffles hotel in Paris have gone on strike, demanding a 2-euro ($2.50) hourly wage increase, citing low wages compared to the hotel's high prices. The strike follows similar protests at two other Hyatt hotels in Paris, where workers were granted better salaries. Employees, including chamber maids, valets, and cooks, are also seeking improved working conditions. The CGT union says the strike is part of a rising movement that could spread to other luxury hotels in the city.

images.alt_text: After high-profile strikes at two upmarket hotels in Paris, it was the turn of employees at the luxury Royal Monceau-Raffles to protest Tuesday for a salary increase - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: US: Stocks jump on Apple earnings, talk of ECB stimulus
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, driven by Apple's strong earnings report and speculation about European Central Bank stimulus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.31% to 16,614.81, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.96% and 2.40%, respectively. The Nasdaq jumped over 100 points, largely due to Apple's 2.7% gain. The European Central Bank's potential expansion of bond-buying initiatives also lifted European bourses.

site_title: KOP appoints two new hotel heads
summary: KOP Limited has appointed two new senior management officials for its hotel arm, KOP Hospitality. David Garcia, previously hotel manager at Cranley Hotel in London, has been promoted to resident manager of Montigo Resorts, Nongsa in Batam, overseeing the entire 12-hectare resort. Mark Battle, joining from Royal Park Hotel in London, will manage Cranley Hotel, responsible for performance, profitability, and positioning. Both will report to their respective superiors.

site_title: GrabTaxi raises US$65m in Series C funds
summary: GrabTaxi, a Singapore-based taxi-booking app, raised US$65 million in its third and largest round of funding, bringing total funding to US$90 million. The round was led by US firm Tiger Global and aims to hire top engineers and data scientists to improve the app's features and driver retention programs. The company plans to expand its network to 17 cities in six South-east Asian countries and compete with rival Uber. With over 2.1 million app downloads and 2 bookings per second, GrabTaxi aims to establish itself as the largest taxi network in the region within six months.

site_title: Kate makes first appearance since royal pregnancy as she welcomes President Tony Tan
summary: Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, made her first public appearance since announcing her second pregnancy, meeting with Singapore's President Tony Tan on his state visit to Britain. The meeting took place at the Royal Garden Hotel in London, where Kate expressed her eagerness to get out of the house due to morning sickness. The visit marked the first time a Singaporean president has visited Britain, and Kate is around 12 weeks pregnant, due to give birth in April.

images.alt_text: Prince William's wife Kate on Tuesday made her first public appearance since her pregnancy was announced as she welcomed Singapore's President Tony Tan on his state visit to Britain - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Clinton: Women's rights 'under assault' by Republicans
summary: Hillary Clinton warned Republicans are underestimating the importance of women's rights, stating they are "under assault" nationwide. At a Democratic campaign rally, she urged Americans not to vote for those who prioritize the past over compromise. Clinton's speech focused on supporting Colorado Democrats, particularly Senator Mark Udall, in the November midterm election. She criticized Udall's challenger, Cory Gardner, for his anti-abortion stance, emphasizing that women's rights are crucial for the entire country. Clinton's appearance in battleground states highlights her efforts to fill the political gap for Democrats ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: Malaysian markets closed on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. No specific news or events related to Malaysian markets were reported in the provided articles.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: EPF fails to get waiver on mega-merger vote
summary: Bursa Malaysia has rejected the Employees Provident Fund's (EPF) plea to cast its vote on the merger of CIMB Group, RHB Capital, and Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB), citing a clear-cut conflict of interest due to EPF's significant stake in the firms. The regulator deemed the fund's potential to influence the merger to its own benefit, posing a risk of potential abuse. The decision makes the outcome of the mega bank merger, valued at RM72.5 billion, harder to predict, with analysts citing the potential for Abu Dhabi's Aabar Investment to block the deal.

site_title: US unveils plan to loosen mortgage rules
summary: The US government has unveiled a plan to loosen mortgage rules, aiming to make it easier for first-time homebuyers and lower- and middle-income Americans to secure loans at low interest rates. The plan, announced by Melvin L Watt, the nation's chief housing regulator, includes relaxing terms of the government's bad loans buy-back policy and exploring smaller down payment options, potentially as low as 3%. The move is intended to reassure mortgage banks and stimulate the housing recovery, which has been hindered by tight credit policies and a wariness of taking on new debt.

site_title: UK needs extra 60,000 new homes a year: Lloyds
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has stated that the UK needs at least 60,000 new homes built annually to ease the country's housing shortage. The bank plans to set up a £50 million equity fund to support smaller house builders, and its CEO, Antonio Horta Osorio, will advocate for a public policy goal to increase housing supply. Other options to improve supply and affordability include freeing up public land and making construction on former industrial sites more economically viable.

site_title: Pan Pacific Hotels Group launches Tianjin property
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group has launched its fifth hotel in China, the Pan Pacific Tianjin, marking the company's biggest overseas market to date. The 289-room hotel is part of a mixed-use development and offers various amenities. China has been a key growth market for the group, with a pipeline of six upcoming properties in Asia and Europe. The company aims to capitalize on China's expanding tourism market, with its CEO stating that the country's dynamic developments will drive growth for the group.

site_title: Treasuries beating stocks in October
summary: Treasuries have outperformed stocks in October, with the Bloomberg Global Developed Sovereign Bond Index returning 1.8% compared to the MSCI All-Country World Index's 4% decline. The outperformance is driven by signs of slowing global economic growth, with yields declining five basis points to 2.14% in the US. Analysts predict further yield falls and a shift towards 30-year Treasuries, as investors seek safe havens. This is the largest outperformance since May 2012, with other major markets, including Australia and Japan, also seeing declines in yields.

site_title: China property investment slows further
summary: China's real estate investment slowed further in the first nine months of 2014, with property sales and new construction tumbling. Revenue from property sales dropped 8.9% and new construction fell 9.3%, contributing to a near six-year low in broader economic growth. Analysts attribute the slowdown to a sagging housing market, massive developer inventories, and reluctance from banks to extend new loans. Despite recent rate cuts and downpayment relaxation, improvement in the sector is expected to be slow, with economists warning of continued economic slowdown.

site_title: Adidas must unlock Reebok's value: analysts
summary: Adidas is preparing to sell its Reebok unit to a Hong Kong-based private-equity investor, potentially for $2.2 billion, in an effort to recoup the $10 billion lost by shareholders this year. The sale, which could happen at a loss, is seen as the best first step for Adidas to regain value. Reebok, acquired by Adidas in 2006 for $3.8 billion, has lost popularity and may be better off being sold than revived. This move is expected to help Adidas recover from a significant financial loss this year.

site_title: Keppel: Industry fundamentals still strong
summary: Keppel Corp posted a 9.5% drop in Q3 net profit to S$414m due to lower profit from its property division, but its offshore and marine (O&M) segment helped offset the decline. CEO Loh Chin Hua remains optimistic about the industry's fundamentals, citing sound order books and a strong demand for oil and jack-ups in the long-term. He believes oil prices will recover and stabilize, driven by increasing global oil demand and investments from national oil companies. Keppel's O&M division secured S$3.7 billion in new contracts, with a net orderbook of S$12.7 billion.

site_title: Sears to lease retail space to UK's Primark
summary: Sears Holding Corp has leased retail space to Primark Stores Ltd in seven Sears stores in the Northeast US. The deal is part of Sears' efforts to raise money, as the company announces a potential $625 million rights offering. This move aims to generate capital for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Carney faces scrutiny after outage of payments system
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney faces scrutiny over the management of Britain's payments system after a nine-hour outage in October 2014, the worst disruption in seven years. The Real Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) mechanism was suspended, affecting £575 billion of daily payments, including homebuyers' transactions. The UK Parliament's Treasury Committee wants assurances that the cause has been found and addressed, emphasizing the need for a reliable system. Carney announced a thorough, independent review to address the issue.

site_title: Mapletree Ind Trust sees stress in business park segment
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 5.3% increase in Q2 distribution per unit to 2.6 cents, driven by higher rental rates and revenue from completed development projects. However, occupancy levels in its business park segment dipped, with median rental rates decreasing to S$4.00 psf/month. The Reit's CEO noted that the business park segment is facing stress due to the softening industrial market. Despite this, MIT reported a robust set of results, with net property income rising 4.1% and gross revenue increasing 6.2%.

site_title: US car sector facing safety crisis due to killer air bags
summary: The US car sector is facing a safety crisis due to defective air bags made by Takata, a Japanese car supplier. Over 14 million vehicles from 11 carmakers have been recalled worldwide, with more than 5 million vehicles urged to get their air bags fixed immediately. The defect causes the air bag's propellant to burn too strongly, leading to rupture and shrapnel. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has warned owners of vehicles with high-humidity areas, such as Florida, to act immediately, but some carmakers have expressed difficulties in providing replacement parts, leading to potential delays in repairs.

site_title: Hwa Hong's Q3 profit up on disposal gain
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation's third-quarter profit surged 73.7% to S$3.9 million due to a disposal gain of S$6.9 million from investment properties. Revenue declined 10.9% to S$4.3 million, primarily from rental segment decreases. The company expects volatility in global equity markets to impact returns from equity investments. Net profit for the nine-month period almost doubled to S$11.4 million.

site_title: Q3 DPU of CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust falls 6.2%
summary: CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust (CMMT) reported a 6.2% decline in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.12 sen, down from 2.26 sen last year. Net property income fell 2.2% to RM50.6 million, while gross revenue rose 0.7% to RM77.9 million. The decline is attributed to a 5.7% drop in distributable income to RM37.7 million. CMMT's CEO-designate, Low Peck Chen, attributed the decline to the completion of Phase 1 asset enhancement works at East Coast Mall, which will provide a boost to net property income upon completion.

site_title: Mutual funds turn net sellers
summary: Global mutual funds were net sellers of Singapore-listed utilities and transportation stocks in the three months to Oct 17, with S$27.8 million in net sells and S$16.9 million in net buys. Sembcorp Marine and SATS Ltd were among the top sells, while Hutchison Port Holdings and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings led the buys. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into fund managers' investment strategies and can help identify areas of focus.

site_title: China's Sept steel output close to peak level
summary: China's steel production rose 1.3% in September to its highest level in three months, exceeding expectations despite weak demand and low prices. This surge may worsen Shanghai rebar futures prices and dent spot iron ore prices due to a supply glut. China is the world's top steel producer, and high output could lead to price instability in the global market.

site_title: Insurer split offers US$4b benefit: hedge fund
summary: Genworth Financial, a US$6.3 billion insurer, may reap US$4 billion for shareholders by splitting its global mortgage-guarantee operations from its US life and long-term care coverage business. A split could boost shares by 64%, according to estimates. Billionaire John Paulson suggests separating the businesses to reverse the slump, which has seen Genworth's shares trading below the price at which General Electric Co took it public in 2004. CEO Tom McInerney has signaled openness to considering a split, possibly as soon as 2016.

site_title: Ebola's ripple effects put Africa's economic recovery in jeopardy
summary: The economic recovery of Africa is threatened by the ripple effects of the Ebola outbreak, with corporate events cancelled, investors declining visits, and multinationals on high alert. The IMF has cut its growth forecast for the continent. The economic impact is being felt even in countries untouched by the virus, highlighting the virus's far-reaching consequences.

images.alt_text: DAMAGE CONTROL: Health workers spraying themselves with chlorine disinfectants after removing the body of a woman who died of the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone last week. The stigma still lingers in places that have been declared Ebola-free.

site_title: Japan's convenience stores fighting coffee war
summary: Japan's convenience stores, including Seven-Eleven and Lawson, are competing fiercely in the country's coffee market, with prices starting at 100 yen (S$1.20) and attracting millions of customers. This "coffee war" has boosted coffee consumption in Japan, increasing sales and pushing the market to a record high. Convenience store coffee has become a key driver of customer traffic and sales, with high margins and quality playing a significant role. The competition is expected to continue, with Starbucks Coffee Japan planning to expand its premium tea and ready-to-drink products.

site_title: Re-creation blues for Big Blue
summary: IBM Corp is struggling to transform itself through "relentless reinvention" as the company's old-line businesses have been shut down or sold, while cloud and security units face stiff competition. Despite CEO Ginni Rometty's emphasis on reinvention, IBM's efforts to push future growth are proving challenging. The company's transformation plans may be hindered by its reliance on legacy businesses and the intense competition in emerging markets.

site_title: Apple's back to record-busting earnings
summary: Apple reported record-breaking earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, with profit rising 13% to $8.5 billion and revenue jumping to $42.1 billion. The company sold over 39 million iPhones, with the new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus driving sales, and also saw strong Mac sales. Despite a decline in iPad sales, Apple remains bullish on the product, citing promising developments with IBM and a recent alliance. The company's fiscal year ended with a profit of $39.5 billion and revenues of nearly $183 billion.

images.alt_text: BIGGER, BETTER: New iPhones with larger screens helped fuel a 13% surge in Apple's Q4 profit to US$8.5b.

site_title: Microsoft's Nadella tops tech industry pay with US$84m
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella received a total compensation package worth $84.3 million this year, mostly due to one-time stock awards valued at $79.8 million. The massive stock awards were designed to keep Nadella at the company while it searched for a new CEO and to give him long-term incentives. His pay package will be more modest in the future, with a target compensation of $18 million for fiscal 2015. Nadella's comments on equal pay for women in technology have raised questions about the company's pay practices.

site_title: Free fall in 10-year Treasuries stuns market
summary: A 10-year US Treasury yield plummeted to 1.9% on October 22, 2014, before rebounding to above 2% within 15 minutes. This unusual drop occurred amid global market turmoil, with European stock markets sliding. The unexpected move has sparked debate over its cause, with possible explanations ranging from increased demand to computerized trades or new regulations. The Treasury yield's sharp drop and subsequent rebound has left investors and traders stunned.

site_title: Triyards' Q4 earnings hit by revenue fall
summary: Triyards Holdings Ltd reported a 49% drop in net profit to US$5.3 million in Q4, driven by a 36% decline in revenue to US$48.8 million. The company attributed the revenue fall to lower recognition of revenue from two self-elevating units. Despite a 9% drop in gross profit, the group proposed a dividend of one Singapore cent per share. CEO Chan Eng Yew expressed optimism about the company's future earnings, citing newly-acquired capabilities and rising momentum of liftboat contract wins.

site_title: French economy stifled by rules pegged to staff size
summary: French President Francois Hollande is pushing through market reforms to address the country's stagnant economy and high unemployment. The reforms aim to limit bureaucratic demands on small and medium-sized businesses, such as rules on staff size and works councils. The goal is to boost growth and job creation, with estimates suggesting it could lead to 140,000 new jobs. However, implementing the reforms may prove tricky, with employer-union relations at a low ebb and the risk of a government-imposed solution by decree.

site_title: Exxon reaffirms confidence in S'pore's edge
summary: ExxonMobil has broken ground for two new plants in Singapore, cementing the country's position as the company's top specialty chemicals manufacturing site. The halobutyl rubber and hydrocarbon resins plants will have capacities of 140,000 tonnes and 90,000 tonnes, respectively, and are expected to be completed in 2017. The investments will add 140 new jobs and enhance Singapore's manufacturing capabilities, with ExxonMobil having invested over $10 billion in the country so far. The move reflects the company's confidence in Singapore's edge in the industry, driven by its innovative technologies and low distribution and logistics costs.

site_title: China's third-quarter growth touches 5-year low
summary: China's third-quarter economic growth slowed to 7.3% in the third quarter, its lowest pace in five years, due to a downturn in the property sector, overcapacity, and weak export demand. Despite this, analysts remain cautiously upbeat, citing stabilisation in GDP growth and a welcome rebalancing away from excess investment. The government has introduced support measures to address the slowdown, but economists expect the 7.5% growth target for the year to be missed, with a revised target of 7% for 2015.

site_title: Taxis vs Uber saga
summary: Traditional taxi companies are resisting the rise of ride-sharing services like Uber, citing concerns over permits and pricing. However, the industry's resistance is seen as a futile attempt to adapt to changing consumer expectations and technological advancements. Uber's success lies in its ability to innovate and respond to customer needs, offering a unique and affordable experience. Despite the taxi industry's efforts to defend its interests, Uber continues to grow, with an estimated value of $17 billion, and is exploring new services such as helicopter rides.

site_title: LME to launch HK-based commodities contracts
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) plans to launch Hong Kong-based commodities contracts to capitalize on the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme. This move aims to replicate the success of the stock connect program in the commodity space. The LME, now owned by Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd, expects to push forward its offshore business in renminbi (RMB) and introduce RMB-denominated contracts in the near future. The launch is seen as a significant step in expanding the LME's presence in China's industrial metal market and strengthening its ties with the country's financial system.

site_title: US faces trade curbs in meat labelling row
summary: The US faces potential trade sanctions from Canada and Mexico after the World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled that the country's meat labelling regulations do not fully comply with international fair trading rules. The US had failed to change its labelling rules, requiring retailers to list the country of origin on meat. This decision follows an earlier WTO challenge.

site_title: Strong Asian voice needed in global reform
summary: A high-level summit in Singapore emphasized the need for a strong Asian voice in global financial regulatory affairs. The Institute of International Finance (IIF) CEO Summit, attended by 130 senior executives and officials, highlighted the region's unique needs and the importance of safeguarding Asia's interests in the new financial system setup. The summit aimed to create a platform for Asian end-users and regulators to collaborate, with the IIF facilitating this agenda through its member institutions and newly opened representative office in Singapore.

site_title: Amazon signs deal with Simon & Schuster
summary: Amazon has signed a multi-year deal with publisher Simon & Schuster to sell print and digital books, maintaining the author's share of income generated from e-book sales. The agreement gives Simon & Schuster control of digital-book pricing, but Amazon claims it will lead to lower prices for readers. The deal comes amid a months-long dispute between Amazon and Hachette Book Group over pricing, with many authors siding with Hachette.

site_title: Chinese demand for loans lifts Aussie firm
summary: A mortgage provider in Australia, Yellow Brick Road Holdings, has seen a significant increase in demand for loans from Chinese investors, accounting for nearly a third of home loans written in September. The firm lent A$320 million to Chinese investors, with demand doubling in the past year. The surge in foreign investment is supporting Australia's housing market, with outstanding mortgages rising 6.7% and dwelling prices climbing 9.3% in the past year. The Australian government is reviewing its lending practices amid concerns over the impact of foreign investment on the housing market.

site_title: ARA Harmony Fund crosses 5-year mark
summary: ARA Harmony Fund has achieved an internal rate of return (IRR) of 27.4% over its five-year term, surpassing its initial target. The fund's equity multiple has increased to over three times, driven by a significant uplift in the value of its portfolio, Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre, which rose from S$235 million to S$663.25 million. CEO John Lim attributed the fund's success to ARA's core competence in driving better asset performance. The fund's performance fee is expected to contribute to ARA's earnings per share.

site_title: Temasek launches S$100m S Rajaratnam fund
summary: Temasek Holdings launched the S$100 million S Rajaratnam Endowment (SRE) to promote regional cooperation and development, guided by the late S Rajaratnam's vision of a "global city". The endowment will partner with regional and international organisations, think tanks, and the private sector to address complex challenges in geopolitics, demographics, and resource use. Its flagship event, The Singapore Forum, will be launched in April 2015, focusing on geo-strategic and governance issues. The SRE also aims to support youth development programs, such as the Youth Model Asean Conference.

site_title: Fall in jet fuel prices may lift AirAsia profits
summary: AirAsia's profitability is expected to boost due to a 17% decline in jet fuel prices since mid-2014. The airline's earnings per share are projected to increase by 2.8% in FY15 and 5% in FY16, according to Hong Leong Investment Bank. Lower fuel costs and a stronger US dollar will positively impact the airline's bottom line. The bank upgraded AirAsia's stock to a "trading buy" with a target price of RM2.57, citing the potential for increased earnings.

site_title: Govt open to more talks after fruitless 1st dialogue
summary: Hong Kong's government has expressed willingness to hold more talks with democracy protest leaders after a fruitless first dialogue with student leaders. Chief Secretary Carrie Lam described the talks as "constructive" but noted the government's firm stance on vetting candidates for the 2017 leadership election. Student leaders have yet to decide on a second round of talks, with the government warning that time is running out for restoring law and order. The government's position remains unchanged, with Chief Executive Leung Chun Ying hinting at a procedural concession in choosing the next leader.

site_title: Gold hits six-week high on concerns over slowing growth
summary: Gold prices reached a six-week high on concerns over a global economic slowdown, driven by China's slower growth and European Central Bank's plans to buy corporate bonds. Spot gold rose to $1,255.20 an ounce, its highest since September 10, while US gold futures climbed to $1,253.20. Analysts say a delay in raising interest rates would be positive for gold, but the market remains wary, with gold holdings falling 1.18% in the SPDR Gold Trust.

site_title: Region's growth potential looking good to aesthetics group Merz
summary: Merz, a leading aesthetics company, is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in Singapore, which it has chosen as its regional launchpad. The company aims to become a one-stop provider of aesthetic solutions, bolstered by its recent acquisitions of Anteis and NEOCUTIS, and Ulthera Inc. It expects significant growth in the region, with an estimated annual growth rate of 28% over the next five years, driven by the increasing demand for aesthetic procedures and products.

site_title: Wozniacki serves Sharapova a surprise
summary: Caroline Wozniacki, the lowest-ranked player in the BNP Paribas WTA Finals, pulled off a stunning upset against world number two Maria Sharapova in a three-hour and 15-minute match. Wozniacki won 7-6(7-4), 6-7(5-7), 6-2, overcoming Sharapova's strong serving and a dramatic distraction during the second set. Wozniacki remained calm and focused, ultimately closing out the match and advancing to the next round.

site_title: Russia's Norilsk to add US$400m from asset sales to dividend
summary: Russia's Norilsk Nickel plans to add $400 million from asset sales to its interim 2014 dividend, exceeding its initial target of $1 billion. The company aims to return $2 billion to shareholders in 2014, focusing on low-cost production projects and selling non-core assets. Norilsk's dividend payment supports indebted aluminum giant Rusal, controlled by billionaire Oleg Deripaska, and its shareholders have agreed to delay a $1 billion special dividend until 2018.

site_title: Modi's gas gambit faces a big hurdle
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi raised natural gas prices by about a third, the country's first increase since 2010, to boost output and reverse a decline in production. The new tariff of $5.61 per million British thermal units will be reviewed every six months. While some explorers welcome the increase, power generation companies are concerned that electricity distributors may curb demand for gas-fired supplies, potentially affecting production. The move aims to balance the need for increased revenue with minimal burden on consumers.

site_title: Some bright spots amid SGX's Q1 profit fall
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) fiscal first quarter net profit fell 16% to S$78 million, or 7.3 Singapore cents per share, due to a 29% decline in securities revenue. However, derivatives revenue rose 4% to S$53.7 million, driven by increased volumes in China-related futures and iron ore derivatives. The exchange attributed the decline to low volatility and invested in improving liquidity, with its incentive programs showing early success. Despite the challenges, SGX remains committed to its long-term strategy.

site_title: HNWI big on integrated digital platform
summary: Wealth management firms in Asia-Pacific are at risk of losing clients due to the lack of an integrated digital platform, with 83% of high net worth individuals (HNWI) in the region expressing concerns. The Asia Pacific Wealth Report 2014 by Capgemini and RBC Wealth Management found that HNWIs in the region expect most of their wealth management relationship to be digital in five years. Global banks are investing heavily in digitalization, but those that fail to do so risk becoming irrelevant in the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: DIGITAL CONTACT, GROWING WEALTH: Asia Pacific is the only region where HNWIs believe having digital contact with their wealth managers is more important than direct contact. The number of HNWIs in the region also rose 17 per cent to 4.3 million, and their wealth grew 18 per cent to US$14.2 trillion in 2013. In contrast, the growth rates in the rest of the world were 13 and 12 per cent respectively.

site_title: Malaysia proposes making of an Asean car with Indonesia
summary: Malaysia proposes joint development of an Asean car with Indonesia, aiming to boost Proton Holdings' prospects. The plan, announced after a meeting with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, involves a feasibility study and participation from Proton Holdings. Additionally, Malaysia considers reviving a program to scrap old cars, which could help boost the car manufacturer's sales and economy of scale. The move aims to capitalize on Indonesia's large population and growing car market, while also addressing the issue of high car ownership costs in Malaysia.

site_title: Facebook sues lawyers over 2010 scam lawsuit for stake
summary: Facebook has sued lawyers representing Paul Ceglia, a man who claimed a 50% stake in the social network, for filing a "fraudulent lawsuit" in 2010. Ceglia's suit was later dismissed after Facebook proved the case was based on a "doctored contract and fabricated evidence." Facebook and founder Mark Zuckerberg are seeking damages from lawyers at DLA Piper and Milberg LLP for "frivolous" litigation, claiming they knew Ceglia was a convicted felon with a history of scams. The lawsuit also accuses Ceglia's lawyers of relying on an "implausible story and obviously forged documents."

site_title: Total CEO killed in Moscow business jet accident
summary: French oil major Total's CEO Christophe de Margerie was killed in a business jet collision with a snow plough during takeoff at Moscow's Vnukovo International Airport on October 20, 2014. The incident occurred just minutes before midnight Moscow time, with the plane bound for Paris. Total confirmed the death with "deep regret and great sadness".

site_title: Odisha sees 23% fall in iron ore output
summary: Odisha, India's largest iron ore producer, expects a 23% decline in production to 60 million tonnes for the fiscal year ending March, due to court-ordered mine shutdowns pending licence renewals. The state's April-September production fell 23% to 23 million tonnes. Industry restrictions have led to a decline in India's iron ore production to 136 million tonnes in 2013/14. Steel companies like JSW Steel plan to increase iron ore imports by up to 80% to meet domestic shortages.

site_title: Housing sector gets a boost as home resales hit one-year high
summary: US home resales surged 2.4% in September to an annual rate of 5.17 million units, the highest level in a year, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks a rebound from a slowdown in the second half of 2013. However, the housing sector remains hindered by sluggish wage growth, which has limited first-time buyers. Investors, who drove the market recovery, withdrew from the market, accounting for 14% of transactions, down from 19% last year. The outlook for the housing sector remains favorable, but first-time buyers must step up to sustain the recovery.

site_title: S'pore is Lonely Planet's top destination
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the top destination by Lonely Planet's Best in Travel 2015. The country led the list of Top 10 Countries for 2015, followed by Namibia, Lithuania, Nicaragua, and Ireland. Singapore's attractions, including its rich history and culture, luxury shopping, and world-class dining, are highlighted as reasons for its ranking. The country's affordability, particularly in hawker centers and public transportation, is also emphasized, despite being the most expensive city in the world.

site_title: Japanese brands power up car sales chart
summary: Japanese car brands have surged in Singapore's car sales chart, with Toyota holding the top spot and Mercedes-Benz second, after a 17.7% increase in new car registrations. Nissan and Mazda have jumped to third and fourth place, displacing Audi and Volkswagen, while Honda has risen to eighth. The boom in demand is driven by replacement buyers trading in ageing vehicles, with Toyota's bread-and-butter models experiencing a resurgence in popularity. The full-year industry volume is expected to top 29,000, an improvement from 2013's 22,472 registrations.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit on track to meet FY14 DPU forecast
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported a 1.546 Singapore cent DPU for the third quarter, beating its forecast by 2%. The Reit's net property income exceeded its forecast by 1.7% due to income from newly acquired Tellus Marine and lower maintenance costs. With a 99.9% portfolio occupancy rate, Soilbuild Reit is on track to meet its FY14 DPU forecast of 5.97 Singapore cents. The Reit has recently acquired two factories for S$55 million, expanding its portfolio value beyond S$1 billion.

site_title: STI recaptures 3,200 level in late surge
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 21.69 points higher at 3,202.74 on Tuesday, driven by a strong opening for Europe and expectations of a strong US session. Genting Singapore fell 1 cent to S$1.04 after a downgrade from Macquarie Equities Research, while Ezion Holdings' shares rose 2 cents to S$1.465 after Nomura reaffirmed its "conviction buy" with a target price of S$2.67. Japfa Ltd's shares remained unchanged at S$0.75 after Standard Chartered initiated coverage with an "outperform" and S$0.95 target price.

site_title: LNG gaining momentum as a marine fuel
summary: LNG (liquefied natural gas) is gaining momentum as a marine fuel, with European port authorities and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) discussing harmonization of technical standards and procedures. The MPA plans to launch a pilot LNG bunkering program by early 2017, providing funding for up to six LNG-fuelled vessels. The program aims to establish operational standards and procedures for LNG delivery in Singapore, paving the way for the use of LNG as a marine fuel in the region.

site_title: Takashimaya to open Bangkok store in 2017
summary: Takashimaya Co will operate a department store, Siam Takashimaya, in Bangkok's ICONSIAM shopping mall, set to open in 2017. The company, in partnership with ICONSIAM Co, will have a 51% stake in the venture. The 80,000 sq m mall will feature a shopping center, residence towers, and attractions, with Siam Takashimaya occupying 36,000 sq m of rentable space. This marks Takashimaya's first department store in Thailand and its second overseas expansion, following a store in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Citi swerves in with direct car loan model
summary: Citi is launching a direct car loan model in Singapore, allowing customers to apply for and receive in-principle approval before shopping for a car. This model cuts out traditional middlemen, such as car dealers, and offers interest rates starting at 1.48%. The move aims to provide customers with more control and potentially lower interest rates compared to the existing model.

site_title: Fix bank culture or face being broken up, says US Fed Reserve
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley warns banks that changing corporate culture and employee compensation to prevent misdeeds or face being broken up. He suggests measures like deferred compensation plans, centralized registry for tracking individual offenses, and paying fines out of senior manager debt compensation. If bad behavior persists, large banks may need to be downsized and simplified to manage effectively, potentially leading to their breakup. This comes amid recent scandals involving Libor and foreign exchange trading.

site_title: HK govt hopeful for more talks with protesters
summary: Hong Kong's government held its first talks with pro-democracy protest leaders, seeking further discussions after three weeks of mass rallies and roadblocks. The talks came after the government extended an olive branch, offering to create a more democratic committee to help choose its successor. Government negotiators responded positively, hoping for further talks, while protesters remain uncertain about the outcome of the discussions.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q3 unit distribution higher
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 12.4% increase in total distributable income to S$58.3 million in Q3, resulting in a DPU of 2.328 Singapore cents. The increase was driven by the completion of Suntec City Phase 2 and contributions from 177 Pacific Highway. Net property income rose 21.1% to S$48.8 million and gross revenue increased 8.5% to S$71.5 million. The Reit's retail and office portfolios maintained high occupancy rates, with 98.9% and 100% committed occupancy, respectively.

site_title: WTO Doha deal would make the world US$11t richer: economists
summary: A global free trade deal, stalled since 2001, could add $11 trillion to the world economy and pull 160 million people out of poverty by 2030, according to economists. Implementing the deal would cost around $1 billion but yield at least $2,000 in benefits for every dollar spent. Developing countries would be the biggest winners, with a return of $3,400 for every dollar invested. The deal could make the world 10% richer and improve the lives of every person in developing countries by $1,000.

site_title: Philadelphia's commercial property heats up
summary: Philadelphia's office properties are experiencing a boom in demand, with office sales in the first half of the year reaching US$1.4 billion, a record high since 2006. The average price per square foot has risen to a record US$283, driven by investors seeking higher yields, rising rents, and falling vacancies. Institutional investors are turning to Philadelphia, where government, universities, and hospitals are major employers, and companies like Comcast and Sunoco Logistics Partners LP are headquartered. The city's vacancy rate has fallen to 14.1%, and effective rents have climbed to US$20.50 a square foot.

site_title: US FDIC issues final risk retention rule for board vote
summary: The US Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) has issued a final rule requiring banks to retain at least 5% of the risk on their books when securitizing loans, aiming to prevent another financial crisis like the 2007-2009 crisis. The rule, mandated by the 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law, encourages banks to be more prudent when lending money by having "skin in the game." The rule is expected to be adopted by other regulators, including the Federal Reserve and Securities and Exchange Commission, in the coming days.

site_title: ST Aerospace bags S$450m of new contracts in Q3
summary: ST Aerospace secured S$450 million in new contracts in Q3, covering airframe, component, and engine maintenance, freighter conversion, cabin modification, and engine wash services. The contracts include heavy checks and interior modification projects for international airline customers in Asia, Europe, and the US. The company also completed the installation of a wireless in-flight entertainment system on two Boeing 737 aircraft and secured two new European customers for metal and structural castings. Shares in ST Engineering remained unchanged at S$3.64.

site_title: WTO prepares for crisis talks as India keeps veto on global deal
summary: India has refused to drop its veto on a global trade deal, prompting World Trade Organization chief Roberto Azevedo to announce a week of crisis talks. India is demanding approval for stockpiling subsidized food alongside new customs rules, a stance that has stalled negotiations. This is a unique situation in the WTO's 19-year history, with diplomats warning that failure to reach an agreement could lead to smaller groups and undermine the organization. Azevedo described the situation as "horrific" and "complex."

site_title: Italy uncovers 1.7 billion euro vast corporate fraud
summary: Italy's financial police have broken up a corporate fraud ring that defrauded the state of 1.7 billion euros (US$2.2 billion) in tax since 2001. Two Rome businessmen created a system using false invoices to perpetrate the fraud, which involved 62 suspects and the seizure of goods worth over 100 million euros. The investigation led to the recovery of 13 billion euros in tax evasion last year, with authorities vowing to crack down on tax evasion and raise 3.8 billion euros from measures next year.

site_title: European shares rally on report ECB mulling corporate bonds buys
summary: European shares rallied on Tuesday after the European Central Bank (ECB) considered buying corporate bonds to revive the region's economy. The move, which could be approved in December, aims to free up banks' balance sheets for lending, particularly in struggling southern European countries. The Euro STOXX banking index rose 3.5% and top European shares gained 1.8%, following a 13-month low hit on Thursday. The ECB's asset-quality review and potential corporate bond purchases are seen as steps to alleviate economic pressures, with investors also monitoring US-EU trade talks and China's slowing economic growth.

site_title: Briefing
summary: The European Commission fined JPMorgan, UBS, and Credit Suisse a total of 94 million euros for participating in financial cartels, including rigging the Swiss franc Libor benchmark interest rate. Royal Bank of Scotland, which alerted the cartels, was not sanctioned. Meanwhile, the US tariffs on Vietnam have raised concerns for the Asian garment industry, with Malaysia also seizing assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, and the UK economy contracted for the second month in a row.

site_title: Fed inspector general: NY Fed stumbled in handling of JPMorgan London Whale
summary: The Federal Reserve's Office of Inspector General found the New York Fed's handling of J.P. Morgan's $2 billion London Whale losses in 2012 was marred by limited resources and competing priorities. Examiners identified London Whale risks as early as 2008 but failed to conduct planned follow-up examinations. The report criticized the New York Fed for over-relying on certain personnel and lacking sufficient resources to address the issue. The flaws in the handling of the crisis raised concerns about the Fed's oversight capabilities.

site_title: Samsung devices get top US security clearance
summary: Samsung devices, including the Galaxy S4, S5, Note 3, and Note 10.1, have received top US security clearance allowing officials to use them to send classified information. The approval, granted by the National Security Agency, expands to more secret information, giving Samsung, the world's largest smartphone maker, access to a wider range of US government contracts. The clearance is made possible by Samsung's Knox software, which adds a layer of security for data on the devices. The approval is seen as a significant milestone for Samsung's mobile business.

site_title: US: Stocks up in early trade
summary: US stocks rose in early trade on Tuesday, driven by Apple's strong earnings, which jumped 13% to $8.5 billion, despite third-quarter profit drops from Coca-Cola and McDonald's. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.46%, 0.84%, and 1.13%, respectively. Apple's strong iPhone sales contributed to the surge, offsetting the impact of profit drops from major US companies.

site_title: Oil prices hold gains on China oil demand rise
summary: Oil prices held gains around $86 a barrel on Tuesday as robust Chinese oil demand boosted the market. Implied demand in China jumped 6.2% in September, its highest since February, and factory output beat expectations, boosting hopes of a strengthening recovery. However, concerns about the global economy and oversupply capped price gains, with Brent crude still down nearly a quarter since June. Analysts expect the rally to be short-lived, with Citi cutting its price forecasts for Brent and US crudes.

site_title: EU hits big banks for bailout war chest
summary: The European Commission has proposed a new eurozone rescue fund, where big banking groups will contribute 90% of the 55 billion euro bailout, while small banks, including Germany's regional lenders, will contribute less. The Single Resolution Mechanism aims to spare taxpayers from the costs of dealing with failing banks. The plan, which still requires approval from member states, has been criticized for placing an extra burden on multinational giants. The EU's biggest banks, holding 85% of the banking sector's assets, will contribute the majority of the fund, with smaller banks contributing less.

site_title: US existing home sales hit one-year high in September
summary: US existing home sales rose 2.4% in September to an annual rate of 5.17 million units, the highest level in a year, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks a gradual recovery in the housing market after activity stalled in 2013 due to rising mortgage rates. Despite being down 1.7% compared to the same period last year, the sales pace is the strongest since September 2013. The rebound in home building in September also suggests housing is regaining its footing.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU up 1.7% at 2.328 Singapore cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 1.7% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.328 Singapore cents for the third quarter, with total distribution income up 12.4% to S$58.3 million. Retail portfolio occupancy stood at 98.4%, while office portfolio occupancy reached 100% for all four properties. CEO Yeo See Kiat expressed confidence in the office portfolio's performance in 2014, citing a balance of 2.1% and 17.9% of office leases due to expire in 2014 and 2015 respectively.

site_title: Growth of S'pore's population of high net worth individuals slower than region in 2013
summary: Singapore's population of high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) and wealth grew 5% and 7% in 2013, respectively, slower than the regional average. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 17% increase in HNWI population and 18% in wealth, driven by strong economic growth and real estate prices in key markets. Japan and China, accounting for two-thirds of the region's HNWI population, grew their wealth by 24% and 20%, respectively, in 2013.

site_title: Poland eyes expanding LNG terminal to increase energy security
summary: Poland plans to expand its liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in Swinoujscie to boost energy security and reduce dependence on Russian supplies. The $3 billion terminal, initially set to accept 5 billion cubic meters annually, will be expanded to 7.5 billion cubic meters with a third storage unit. The expansion aims to diversify gas supplies and increase Poland's energy security, but it has been criticized for its high import costs, with Poland contracting to import 1.6 billion cubic meters of gas from Qatar for 20 years.

site_title: EU can't let austerity override investment: Austria's Faymann
summary: Austria's Chancellor Werner Faymann said the European Union cannot prioritize austerity over investment to spur slowing economies. He disputed the European Commission's call for Austria to run a balanced budget in 2015, stating "frugality is good, but austerity is not an end in itself." This stance sets up a potential clash with Brussels, as other EU countries, including France and Italy, resist cutting their deficits to stimulate economies.

site_title: SGX Q1 profit down 16% to S$78 million
summary: SGX's Q1 profit declined 16% to S$78 million due to low stock-market liquidity. Securities revenue fell 29% to S$49.1 million, while derivatives revenue rose 4% to S$53.7 million. The company recommends a 4 cents per share dividend, unchanged from last year.

site_title: Pan Pacific opens its fifth hotel in China in Tianjin
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group has opened its fifth hotel in China, the Pan Pacific Tianjin, marking the country as its biggest overseas market. The hotel is located in Tianjin and has 289 guestrooms and 30 serviced suites. This opening follows the group's first Pan Pacific hotel in China in 2009, as part of its strategy to grow its presence in the country. The company has a pipeline of six upcoming properties in various regions.

site_title: Met defies protests to stage 'Klinghoffer' opera
summary: The Metropolitan Opera in New York has opened "The Death of Klinghoffer," an opera by US composer John Adams, despite protests from Israel supporters. The 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise-liner is dramatized, exploring the grievances of Israelis and Palestinians. Critics argue the opera humanizes murderers, while others see it as a thought-provoking exploration of complex issues. The opera has sparked controversy, but the Metropolitan Opera has defied picketers and disruptions to stage the production.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end the day higher
summary: Singapore shares rose on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 21.69 points to close at 3,202.74. The benchmark index saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with 229 gainers outnumbering 182 losers. Volume reached 1.13 billion shares worth S$962.8 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose marginally, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 18.32 points to 23,088.58, driven by China's data showing its economy grew at the slowest rate since the global financial crisis. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.72% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.76%.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: The changing face of salesman incentives
summary: Salesman incentives are undergoing significant changes as companies prioritize market share and talent. The traditional "insurance agency model" of commission-based sales has evolved to focus on profits and group incentives. Companies like Starbucks and Glaxo SmithKline are experimenting with novel schemes, such as bundled roles and external ratings, to improve sales and customer satisfaction. However, critics argue that these incentives can lead to short-termism and favor goal scorers over team players. A balanced incentive policy is needed to steer efforts towards sustainable goals, and companies are exploring complex algorithmic models and technology solutions to achieve this.

site_title: Singapore's Keppel Corp Q3 net profit slides 9%
summary: Keppel Corporation, Singapore's largest jackup rig builder, reported a 9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$414 million, primarily due to a 37% drop in property division's pretax profit. However, the offshore and marine segment saw a 27% gain. The company received new orders worth S$3.7 billion, bringing its total outstanding order book to S$12.7 billion.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's Q3 DPU of 1.546 Singapore cents beats forecast by 2%
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported a Q3 DPU of 1.546 Singapore cents, beating the forecast by 2%. Net property income for the quarter was S$14.2 million, exceeding the forecast by 1.7%. The trust is well-placed to deliver its forecast distribution for the full year, with a majority of its portfolio focused on business parks and high-specifications.

site_title: CIMB, RHB shares halted ahead of 'material announcement'
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, RHB Capital Bhd, and Malaysia Building Society Bhd have suspended trading of their shares pending a material announcement. The three lenders agreed to merge on October 9, valued at around US$22 billion, creating the country's largest banking group.

site_title: Malaysian state pension fund barred from voting in CIMB-led bank merger
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has been barred from voting in the proposed merger of CIMB Group Holdings Bhd and two rivals, as it is a major shareholder in all banks involved. The bourse ruled that the potential conflict of interests involving the EPF has not been sufficiently mitigated. This may allow Dubai-based Aabar Investments, a shareholder in RHB Capital Bhd, to increase its voting power and potentially gain a bigger say in shaping the creation of Malaysia's largest bank, valued at around US$22 billion.

site_title: CNA to issue 58.15m new shares at S$0.052 a share
summary: CNA Group plans to issue 58.15 million new shares at S$0.052 each, raising approximately S$3 million to repay debts to four companies. The shares represent 13.72% of CNA's existing share capital and 12.07% of its enlarged share capital. The issue price is the volume weighted average price on October 20, 2014.

site_title: Philippines looks to big companies to avert power shortage
summary: The Philippine government plans to rely on big businesses with diesel-fuelled power generators to avert rolling brownouts in 2015, amid a looming electricity shortage. The country's power shortfall is estimated to be 700 MW, with potential participants including San Miguel Corp, JG Summit Holdings Inc, and Ayala Corp. The government aims to secure commitments from firms with a combined capacity of 1,400 megawatts to ease demand from the grid. President Aquino is also seeking emergency powers to enter into power deals, but lawmakers question the need for special authority.

site_title: McDonald's profit slumps, sales fall
summary: McDonald's reported a 30% decline in net income to $1.07 billion in the third quarter due to global sales falling amid a food-safety scandal in China and intense competition in the US. Earnings per share were below the Wall Street estimate of $1.37. The decline in sales and profit follows a year of struggles for the fast-food giant, with the company citing a food-safety scandal in China and increased competition as major factors contributing to the slump.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 2.03%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 2.03% on Tuesday, following a near four-percent rise the previous day, as investors locked in profits. The Nikkei 225 index fell 306.95 points to 14,804.28, while the Topix index dropped 1.55% to 1,205.36. The yen strengthened against the dollar, and weak China growth data negatively impacted sentiment.

site_title: Tightened vacancies send office rents further up in Q3: CBRE
summary: Singapore's office rents rose further in Q3 due to tightened vacancies, with the island-wide vacancy rate dropping 54 basis points to 3.8% and Grade A rents growing 3.3% to S$10.95 psf/month. The upward trend is expected to continue, with rental growth projected to ease by H2 2015. Low vacancy and steady demand underpin the growth, with the impending supply wave anticipated to arrive from mid-2016 through 2017.

site_title: Asia shares slip after China growth data
summary: Asian markets slipped on Tuesday, giving up gains from the previous session, as China's economy grew at its slowest pace in five years, 7.3% in July-September. Despite upbeat industrial production figures, shares in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo fell, while Seoul and Sydney rose slightly. The Dow and S&P 500 in the US also rose, but failed to boost Asian markets, which are heavily influenced by China's economic performance.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q2 DPU up 5.3%
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 5.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.60 Singapore cents for its Q2 2014 fiscal quarter. The increase was driven by higher rental rates and revenue from completed development projects. Net property income rose 4.1% to S$56.2 million, while gross revenue grew 6.2% to S$77.9 million. Unitholders will receive their quarterly DPU by Dec 4, 2014.

site_title: Australia central bank deputy governor warns of risks in low-rate world
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia deputy governor Philip Lowe warned that very low global interest rates pose risks to asset prices and economic fundamentals, urging caution from investors. Lowe said investors need to evaluate how their investments might turn out in less benign scenarios and that central banks alone cannot drive sustained economic growth. He emphasized the importance of government policy, including infrastructure spending, in achieving the G20's goal of a 2% global GDP growth increase by 2018.

site_title: US urges Japan to be 'bold' in Pacific trade pact talks
summary: US Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker urged Japan to be "bold and creative" in talks for the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pact, saying both countries are "a lot closer" to a deal than in recent months. The 12-nation pact is crucial for securing a broader agreement, with President Obama hoping to have a deal by year-end. However, talks hit a snag in September over farm exports, with the US demanding Japan lower barriers to agricultural imports. The US and Japan are set to meet in Australia and Beijing to discuss further negotiations.

site_title: EU fines JPMorgan, UBS, Credit Suisse total US$120m
summary: The European Commission fined JPMorgan, UBS, and Credit Suisse a total of $120 million for participating in cartels in the financial sector. JPMorgan was fined $61.7 million for rigging the Swiss franc Libor benchmark interest rate between 2008 and 2009, while UBS and Credit Suisse received $12.7 million and $9.2 million, respectively, for participating in a cartel on Swiss franc interest rate derivatives. Royal Bank of Scotland alerted the cartels to the Commission and was not sanctioned.

images.alt_text: The European Commission fined JPMorgan, UBS and Credit Suisse a total of 94 million euros (US$120 million) on Tuesday for taking part in cartels in the financial sector. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Smartphone sales in key South-east Asian markets exceeded US$16.4b in last year: GfK
summary: Smartphone sales in seven key South-east Asian markets exceeded $16.4 billion in the past year, according to a GfK report. Sales volume increased by 44% and value by 24% compared to the previous year. Chinese brands gained significant market share, with a 6% increase, while international brands lost share due to price competition. The growth is attributed to the adoption of smartphones in developing countries, with Indonesia, Vietnam, and Thailand performing exceptionally well, reporting high growth in sales volume and revenue.

site_title: InterContinental posts rising revenues
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group reported a 7.0% increase in global revenue per available room (RevPAR) in the third quarter, driven by 8.4% growth in the US and 6.1% growth in Europe. The company expressed optimism over the annual outlook, citing strong momentum in the business and positive booking trends. RevPAR growth was largely unaffected by pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. InterContinental Hotels Group owns the InterContinental, Crowne Plaza, and Holiday Inn hotel chains.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on China growth concern; won up on amended rate hike view
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.77% to 1,915.29 points, despite better-than-expected China data, due to concerns over China's economic outlook. The won strengthened against the dollar, closing at 1,054.7 to the dollar, amid expectations of an early Federal Reserve rate hike ahead of US inflation data.

site_title: Broker's Take: Genting Singapore a decent bet for a potential Japan IR win: OCBC
summary: Genting Singapore's share price has fallen to its lowest level in over four years, but OCBC Investment Research considers it a "decent bet" for a potential Japan IR win, valuing it at S$1.03 per share. The company is seen as a strong contender for Japan's US$10 billion integrated resort project, which has been delayed by opposition to a new Bill on gambling. Despite near-term negatives, OCBC believes Genting Singapore's value is emerging, making it a hold for investors.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 5.96 points to 3,187.01. The rally followed a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 46. Volume was 54.6 million shares worth S$77.4 million.

site_title: Amazon, Simon & Schuster sign book retail deal
summary: Amazon has reached a multi-year deal with American book publisher Simon & Schuster, allowing print and electronic editions of Simon & Schuster books to be marketed and retailed by Amazon. The deal, set to take effect in early January, will make books continuously available for sale through the holiday season and beyond. Simon & Schuster will retain control over retail prices, while Amazon will provide a financial incentive for the publisher to deliver lower prices for readers.

site_title: Thailand's junta-picked council starts work on reforms
summary: Thailand's National Reform Council, a 250-member body chosen by the ruling junta, began work on reforms aimed at closing the country's political divide. The council's tasks include recommending a new constitution, which may include clauses preventing those convicted of corruption from entering politics. Critics dismiss the reforms as an attempt to dilute the influence of ex-premier Thaksin Shinawatra, while supporters see them as a step towards restoring power to voters. The new constitution is expected to address the country's deep-seated divisions and Thaksin's enduring electoral popularity.

site_title: Siam Takashimaya department store to open in Bangkok's Iconsiam development
summary: Takashimaya Co will operate a department store, Siam Takashimaya, in Bangkok's Iconsiam development, scheduled to open in 2017. The joint-venture company, Siam Takashimaya (Thailand), will be 51% owned by Takashimaya Singapore and 49% by Iconsiam Co. The development, backed by three Thai firms, has attracted $1.97 billion in private investment. Siam Takashimaya will be the anchor tenant, occupying an 80,000-square-meter site with a shopping mall, residence towers, and attractions. This marks Takashimaya's expansion into the Asean region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.82 points to 1803.96 on Tuesday, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 97 to 52. Volume reached 27.56 million lots worth RM9.96 million.

site_title: China September industrial output up 8.0% on-year: govt
summary: China's industrial output rose 8.0% year-on-year in September, according to the government, while retail sales expanded 11.6% and fixed asset investment increased 16.1% in the first nine months of the year. These indicators suggest a strong economy, but policymakers may face pressure to maintain growth.

site_title: Half of Singapore SMEs have overseas revenue: IE Singapore
summary: Half of Singapore SMEs now have overseas revenue, up from 46% in 2013, as they seek sustainable growth. This year's DP SME Development Survey found that SMEs of all sizes are expanding globally, with top markets including Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand.
