The company's net asset value per share stood at 11.2 Singapore cents as of September 30. Qian Hu plans to be more aggressive in strengthening its fundamental position and generating cash.

site_title: MAS urges shareholders to accept Khazanah buyout offer
summary: Malaysian Airline System Bhd (MAS) has urged its minority shareholders to accept a buyout offer from major shareholder Khazanah Nasional, valuing the airline at US$421 million. The audit committee found the offer "fair and reasonable" and recommended its acceptance. MAS aims to return to profitability within three years through a restructuring exercise and workforce cuts. The airline has been hit by two major disasters, including the disappearance of Flight MH370 and the downing of Flight MH17. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on November 6 to vote on the proposal.

site_title: Theatre practitioner, sculptor and poet awarded Cultural Medallion
summary: Singapore's Cultural Medallion has been awarded to theatre practitioner Alvin Tan, sculptor Chong Fah Cheong, and poet K T M Iqbal. The medallion, Singapore's highest award for artistic excellence, comes with an $80,000 grant. The recipients expressed gratitude for the recognition, with Chong noting that his art is rooted in everyday experiences and Iqbal highlighting the growth of poetry in Singapore. The medallion was first introduced 35 years ago and has been presented to 115 artists, recognizing their significant contributions to the Singapore arts scene.

site_title: Developer sales in Q3 lowest since worst phase of global crisis
summary: Singapore's private home developers sold 1,596 units in Q3, a 40% drop from Q2 and the lowest figure since 2008, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Sluggish sales and price declines are expected to continue due to the cooling measures, with property consultants predicting a full-year sales range of 7,000-9,000 units. Developers have cut prices selectively, and the market is expected to remain muted unless the government revises the cooling measures.

site_title: S$42m grants to boost cyber security in Singapore
summary: Singapore has allocated S$42 million in grants over 2-5 years to boost cyber security through 7 research projects. The National Research Foundation's National Cyber Security R&D Programme aims to improve cyber infrastructure security. The projects focus on mobile security, network security, and digital forensics, and are led by institutions such as the Singapore University of Technology and Design. The grants will be used to prevent potential cyber threats, including those that could disrupt critical infrastructure like the power grid, and to develop secure cyber-physical systems.

images.alt_text: 'More than 1,000 organisations across 84 different countries, mostly in the energy and industry sectors, have reportedly been affected by malicious software from just one hacking group. Whatever their origins or motives, they are able to hide under the cloak of anonymity offered by the Internet, complicating efforts to take action against them.' - Mr Teo

site_title: Endorsement darling
summary: Maria Sharapova, the world's highest-paid female athlete, earned US$24.4 million in 2014, with only US$2.4 million from tennis tournament prize money. The majority of her earnings came from endorsements of brands like Nike, Tag Heuer, and Avon Products. Sharapova plans to expand her Sugarpova candy line, now sold in over 30 countries, into a lifestyle brand with clothing and accessories. She values aligning with brands that share similar values and has taken risks in her business ventures, crediting her success to her willingness to try new things and learn from others.

images.alt_text: Sharapova says she wants to build Sugarpova into a lifestyle brand.

site_title: Noble receives US$3.36b in payments
summary: NOBLE Group, Asia's largest commodities trader by revenue, received US$3.36 billion in payments, including US$1.5 billion from Cofco for its 51% stake in Noble Agri. Noble also repaid US$1.86 billion from Noble Agri. The payments reduced Noble's pro-forma leverage to 1.3 times for the 12 months ended June 2014. Fitch Ratings affirmed Noble's ratings at BBB- and expects leverage to remain below 2.75 times. This deal was part of a consortium led by Cofco to buy Noble Agri.

site_title: Gingko Tree Investment in talks to buy Munich office park: sources
summary: GINGKO Tree Investment Ltd, a unit of China's foreign currency reserves, is in talks to buy a Munich office park valued at 500 million euros. The property, currently rented to Siemens AG, is being negotiated with property owners HIH Hamburgische Immobilien Handlung GmbH and RFR Group. This deal would be part of Asian funds' increasing investment in German commercial properties, seeking stable rental returns in Europe's largest economy, driven by rising prices in London.

site_title: SIA up 8 cts after intra-day high
summary: Singapore Airlines shares closed at S$9.69, up 8 cents from an intra-day high of S$9.78, despite being under pressure for a month. The stock has been struggling since reporting a 71% dive in Q1 net profit. Analysts attribute challenges to low-cost carriers and Gulf carriers on short- and long-haul routes, as well as operating environment issues in South-east Asia. Credit Suisse has a target price of S$9.45, while OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" on the stock, citing possible gains from Changi Airport's rebate programme and SIA's new alliance with Air New Zealand.

images.alt_text: SHARES in Singapore Airlines (SIA) receded from a high of S$9.78 in intra-day trading to close at S$9.69 on Wednesday, up eight cents - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: US retail sales give cautionary sign on consumer demand
summary: US retail sales declined 0.3% in September, a surprise drop that signals weakening consumer demand. Despite expectations of a decline, the reading was lower than forecast. Weakness in auto dealers and gasoline stations contributed to the decline. Analysts attribute the drop to slowing global economic growth, with auto production cooling and oil prices falling. The result provides cautionary signs for the strength of consumer demand, highlighting the need for policymakers to reassess their economic strategies.

site_title: S'pore mobile ad startup raises record Series B
summary: A Singapore-based mobile advertising startup, AdNear, has raised a record US$19 million in Series B funding, surpassing GrabTaxi's US$15 million in May. The investment will be used to accelerate global expansion, productize data offerings, and invest in R&D. AdNear's location intelligence platform sends location-relevant ads to mobile audiences on behalf of retailers. The company counts major clients such as SingTel, P&G, and IKEA, and has a presence in several countries, including Singapore, Hong Kong, India, Australia, and Japan.

site_title: China visitor arrivals almost halved in second quarter
summary: Singapore's second-quarter tourism saw a 6% decline in visitor numbers to 3.6 million, largely due to a 47% drop in Chinese arrivals. However, the decline appears to be easing, with some economists suggesting it may have bottomed. Chinese visitors' average spend helped reduce the overall decline in receipts by 24%. The decline in tourism is attributed to China's severe economic downturn.

site_title: STI inches up after three days in the red
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.32 points or 0.14% to 3,198.72 on Wednesday, snapping out of its three-day losing streak, after benign Chinese inflation data and gains in banking stocks provided support. China's consumer price inflation hit a four-year low in September, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng also advanced. Oil prices continued to decline, with the International Energy Agency reducing its forecast for oil demand this year and next.

site_title: ERA Realty beefs up strength in GCB dealmaking
summary: ERA Realty Network has strengthened its presence in the GCB market by acquiring 60 sales agents from JLL Residential, bringing its total sales force to 6,016 agents. Additionally, 100 more JLL agents have joined PropNex. This move bolsters ERA's dominance in the Singapore property market.

site_title: WHO deal backs higher tobacco taxes to cut smoking
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has adopted guidelines recommending countries increase tobacco taxes to reduce smoking rates. 179 countries signed the agreement, allowing individual countries to set their own taxes on cigarettes. The guidelines suggest that tobacco taxes should account for 70% of cigarette retail prices, with the aim of reducing tobacco use, which is responsible for six million deaths worldwide each year. The move is opposed by the tobacco industry, which argues that it infringes on national sovereignty and is fiscally unsound.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Singapore Post to develop fully integrated e-commerce logistics hub, driven by growing e-commerce market and logistics demand. Analysts increase free cash flow to equity growth assumption to 9% for FY2019-FY2023, raising fair value estimate from S$1.78 to S$2.09. In contrast, Vard Holdings is downgraded to "sell" due to marginally negative Q3 Ebitda and possible book value de-rating. Valuetronics Holdings maintained as "buy" with a target price of S$0.41, citing potential upside and dividend yield.

site_title: Vard's ratings cut as recovery drags
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilding company, has released negative profit guidance for the third quarter, sparking concerns about its recovery. The company attributed the decline to slower-than-expected productivity improvements at its new shipyard in Brazil and cost overruns on several projects. Analysts have cut their ratings and forecasts, with DBS Group Research reducing its FY14/15F core earnings estimates by 54% and OSK-DMG cutting its estimates by 32% and downgrading the stock to "sell". Vard's share price has fallen 12.5 Singapore cents to 69.5 cents.

site_title: New 'Poodle' bug on Web threatens email and banking accounts
summary: Google researchers have discovered a security bug, dubbed "Poodle," in widely used Web encryption technology that could allow hackers to take over email, banking, and other services. The bug is linked to an 18-year-old encryption standard, SSL 3.0, and has prompted browser and server software makers to advise users to disable the standard. To protect users, disabling SSL 3.0 is recommended until a patch is released. The discovery highlights the need for updated security measures to prevent future vulnerabilities.

site_title: Time Warner to set HBO free, launch over-the-top service
summary: Time Warner plans to launch a standalone over-the-top service for HBO in 2015, allowing consumers to watch the channel with a broadband connection. This move comes as the company aims to boost growth and revenue, with forecasted adjusted earnings per share of $6 by 2016 and $8 by 2018. The decision is seen as a significant milestone for HBO, which has traditionally relied on cable distributors. The launch is expected to compete with Netflix, which saw its shares decline 3.4% following the announcement.

site_title: Indonesia tin curbs may cut 2015 output in half, cause protests
summary: Indonesia plans to limit tin output and shipments, potentially slashing production by half in 2015. The government aims to support benchmark prices, which have hit 14-month lows, but the move has sparked opposition from industry groups, who fear it will lead to protests. The plan, proposed by the outgoing government, sets a target of 40,000 tonnes of production, but industry leaders have expressed concerns about the lack of consultation and the potential for unrest. The implementation of the plan is expected to be implemented by the new government, which takes office on Monday.

site_title: Triyards Holdings acquires Strategic Marine
summary: Triyards Holdings has acquired Strategic Marine's facilities in Singapore and Vietnam for A$23.3 million. The acquisition, valued at A$19.7 million, will extend the group's market reach and tap the target companies' clientele base. Triyards will pay the purchase price entirely by cash from its issuance of new shares and internal cash resources. The deal is part of the group's strategy to expand its business and earnings base through organic expansion and selective acquisitions.

site_title: Wal-Mart says to slow store openings, invest more in ecommerce
summary: Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, plans to open 180-200 small format stores in the US in the next fiscal year, down from 270-300, and 60-70 Supercenters. The company will invest "a bit less" in stores and more in e-commerce. This shift aims to adapt to changing consumer habits and increasing competition.

site_title: ABS EBA report on "qualifying" securitisation highlights faults of current treatment
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) has issued a report on "qualifying" securitisation, calling for regulators to align its treatment with other asset classes bearing similar risks. The report proposes a two-stage approach to identify sound and simple assets, assessing transparency and simplicity, and credit quality. The EBA aims to limit the inconsistency of capital charges based on external ratings and reduce the reliance on these charges. The proposal, which builds on industry-led criteria, could lead to lower capital charges for ABS products meeting requirements on both levels, regardless of seniority.

site_title: Toyota recalls 1.75m cars to fix brakes, fuel leaks
summary: Toyota is recalling 1.75 million vehicles worldwide to fix flaws in the braking and fuel systems. The affected models include luxury sedans and compact hatchbacks. The recall is Toyota's fourth this year, following similar recalls by General Motors. Toyota says there have been no reported fires, crashes, injuries, or fatalities. The company is under US supervision after a settlement for unintended acceleration recalls. The recall is expected to have no significant impact on Toyota's brand image.

site_title: Airbus to pass 1,000 net orders after IndiGo deal: exec
summary: Airbus is poised to exceed 1,000 net orders for 2014 after securing a deal with Indian carrier IndiGo for 250 revamped A320neo jets. This deal, combined with previous orders, puts Airbus on track to surpass its forecast of 1,000 net orders and 1,350-1,400 gross orders. This marks a significant improvement over the first nine months of 2014, when Airbus lagged behind Boeing with 791 net orders. The company's sales chief, John Leahy, expects 2014 deliveries to be similar to last year's record of 626 aircraft.

site_title: Malaysian Airline urges shareholders to take the buyout offer
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) urged minority shareholders to accept a buyout offer from its major shareholder, Khazanah Nasional Bhd, valued at 1.38 billion ringgit (US$421 million) per share. The airline, hit by two separate jet disasters this year, aims to return to profitability within 3 years through a 6-billion-ringgit restructuring. MAS plans to cut 30% of its workforce and is seeking a new CEO as part of the plan. The company's directors found the offer "fair and reasonable" and will hold an extraordinary general meeting on November 6 for minority shareholders to vote.

site_title: Trading unit helps JPMorgan return to profit in Q3
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a profit of $5.57 billion in the third quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of $380 million, thanks to improved results from its Wall Street operations. Revenue rose 5% to $25.2 billion, driven by investment bankers and traders. Despite legal expenses and a cyberattack affecting 76 million households, CEO Jamie Dimon expressed optimism about the US economy's broad-based recovery. Dimon also stated that recent global economic turbulence may slow American growth, but expects growth to continue.

site_title: China inflation in Sept eases to near 5-yr low
summary: China's consumer inflation slowed to a near five-year low in September, easing to 1.6% from a year earlier, as falling prices for food, fuel, and commodities. This reading, the lowest since January 2010, suggests rising risks of deflation and weak domestic demand. China's policymakers are expected to continue rolling out stimulus measures, with economists predicting a possible interest rate cut if conditions deteriorate further. The producer price index fell 1.8%, its 31st consecutive monthly decline, further indicating economic weakness.

site_title: US budget deficit shrinks to US$483b: Treasury
summary: The US budget deficit decreased to $483 billion in fiscal 2014, the lowest level since 2008, due to boosted tax collections from economic growth. This represents a 29% decrease from the previous year and a 2.8% share of gross domestic product, the lowest since 2007. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew and White House Budget Director Shaun Donovan hailed this as a "return to fiscal normalcy."

site_title: Oil falls to US$84, near 4-year low, on oversupply
summary: Oil prices fell to a 4-year low of $84 a barrel, with Brent crude dropping 25% from its June peak, due to a surge in global oversupply and faltering global growth. OPEC producers, including Saudi Arabia and Iran, have signaled a willingness to lower prices to curb supply growth from non-OPEC producers. Weak economic data from Europe and Asia has cut demand growth expectations, and US shale oil production is set to grow in November, further fueling the decline.

site_title: MTP will lower liquidity, raise listing cost: SMCCA
summary: The Small and Middle Capitalisation Companies Association (SMCCA) in Singapore opposes the proposed Minimum Trading Price (MTP) rule by Singapore Exchange, citing that it will reduce liquidity and increase listing costs for small and mid-cap companies. The proposed MTP of 20 cents per share will have "no meaningful value" to the capital markets, according to SMCCA, and will lead to further consolidation of shares, confusion among shareholders, and erosion of wealth. The association also argues that the regulators' role should remain with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, not the exchange.

site_title: Record mortgage settlement pushes Bank of America into Q3 loss
summary: Bank of America reported a net loss of $70 million for the third quarter, largely due to a record $16.65 billion mortgage settlement with the US government. The settlement, tied to the bank's purchases of Countrywide Financial and Merrill Lynch, may finally allow the company to put the housing bubble behind it. Despite the loss, the bank's shares rose 0.4% and its investment banking fees increased 4% to $1.4 billion.

site_title: Tata Steel says in talks to sell Europe long products business
summary: Tata Steel Ltd is in talks to sell its Europe long products business, which employs approximately 6,500 people, to the Klesch Group. The business includes assets in the UK, France, and Germany. The decision is aimed at concentrating resources on strip products activities, where there are greater cross-European production and technological synergies. Tata Steel acquired the Corus business in 2007 for $13 billion.

site_title: Portugal's budget meets deficit rules, aims to ease austerity
summary: Portugal's 2015 budget deficit is set at 2.7% of gross domestic product, meeting EU fiscal limits. The country aims to ease austerity measures and encourage economic recovery, despite a fragile economy. Portugal's growth estimates are lower than Ireland's, predicting 1.0% expansion this year and 1.5% in 2015. The government has refused to impose more hardship, citing the need to boost economic growth. A ratings agency maintains a positive outlook for Portugal, but notes a risk of slipping public deficit in 2015.

site_title: Spain told by EU to recover corporate tax breaks
summary: The EU's anti-trust regulator has ordered Spain to recover corporate tax breaks given to companies such as Telefonica, Santander, and Iberdrola to spur foreign acquisitions. The tax breaks, totaling tens of millions to several billions of euros, were granted about a decade ago. The decision aims to address concerns about unfair competition and promote a level playing field among companies. Spain must recover the tax breaks from the affected companies, which include major phone and banking groups.

site_title: SPH's FY2014 net profit down 6.2% y-o-y
summary: SPH's FY2014 net profit fell 6.2% to S$404.3 million due to lower advertising and circulation revenue. However, its property division reported a 3.5% increase in operating revenue, helping to stem earnings decline. The group's operating profit dropped 5.5% to S$349.0 million, but profit before taxation rose 8.0% to S$528.4 million. A final dividend of 14 cents per share was declared, and shares closed up 1 cent at S$4.17.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Press Holdings (SPH) reported on Wednesday a 6.2 per cent drop in net profit for the year ended Aug 31, 2014, as its newspaper and magazine business took a hit from lower advertising and circulation revenue. - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 9.54 points lower
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed 9.54 points lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index at 1,786.84. 2.04 billion lots valued RM2.16 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 659 to 209.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Lufthansa unit Germanwings hit by new pilots' strike
summary: Germanwings, a low-cost airline belonging to Lufthansa, has been hit by a new pilots' strike. The pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit called for a 12-hour walkout from noon Thursday, affecting all Germanwings flights across Germany, due to a dispute over retirement benefits. The union accuses Lufthansa management of refusing to consider compromise solutions, while Lufthansa pilots are fighting a plan to raise the minimum retirement age and involve pilots in pension financing. The strike is the latest in a series of labor disputes in Germany's transportation sector.

site_title: EU watchdog says bankers' allowances breach bonus rule
summary: The EU's banking watchdog, the European Banking Authority (EBA), has ruled that nearly all new types of allowances paid to bankers in the EU breach the EU's cap on bonuses. The allowances, which were given to bankers earning over 500,000 euros a year, were deemed to be discretionary and not part of basic pay, making them subject to the bonus cap. Banks have until the end of the year to change their pay policies, or risk losing top staff. The ruling aims to restrain reckless behavior among bankers and restore trust in the banking system.

site_title: UK jobless rate falls again, recovery shows signs of cooling
summary: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 6.0% in the three months to August, the lowest level since October 2008, but job creation slowed, and workers' earnings failed to keep pace with inflation. The Bank of England is watching for signs of a pickup in labor costs as it considers raising interest rates. Economists predict a first rate rise in mid-2015 or later, despite some signs of gradual earnings growth.

site_title: Boosting economic growth should get top priority at G20 summit
summary: The G20 summit, set to take place in Brisbane, Australia, will focus on boosting economic growth. The event, featuring 20 major economies, comes as the world grapples with pressing issues. Russian President Vladimir Putin's attendance has sparked controversy, following the downing of a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet in Ukrainian airspace in July. The summit aims to overshadow this controversy and address economic concerns, with leaders expected to prioritize growth over other pressing issues. The meeting will bring together the world's top economies to discuss key global issues and drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: Just four weeks to go before the leaders of 20 economies meet in Australia at the annual G20 summit, the final gathering of the world's major powers on such a scale before the year ends - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Singapore: Shares end 9.56 points higher
summary: Singapore shares rose 9.56 points to close at 3,203.96 on Wednesday, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Straits Times Index saw 1.37 billion shares worth S$865.5 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 144.

site_title: China blocks BBC website amid Hong Kong protests
summary: China blocked the BBC website on October 15, 2014, amid pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The move is the first time the BBC's website has been completely blocked in China since 2010. The BBC's Chinese-language website has been blocked since 1999. The blocking comes as a video of Hong Kong police beating a protester went viral online, sparking outrage and calls for prosecution. The move is part of China's vast censorship system, which blocks sensitive content and commentary on human rights and government criticism.

site_title: AbbVie cools on US$55b Shire deal after US tax changes
summary: US pharmaceutical company AbbVie is reconsidering its $55 billion takeover of Shire after US government moves to curb deals aimed at cutting tax bills. The deal, announced in July, would create a new US-listed holding company with a tax domicile in Britain, but US tax changes may make it more expensive. Shire's shares plummeted 27% as a result, while AbbVie's stock price fell $13 billion. The US Treasury's proposals limit tax inversion deals, and AbbVie's board will meet on October 20 to decide whether to withdraw or modify its recommendation.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom hit with US$88m EU antitrust fine
summary: Deutsche Telekom has been fined 69.9 million euros (US$88.4 million) by the European Commission for squeezing out rivals in Slovakia's broadband market over five years. The penalty, the second for the company, was due to excessive wholesale rates charged by its Slovak unit, making it impossible for competitors to generate a profit. The European Commission aims to fight against dominant companies that engage in margin squeeze tactics, which harm consumers and competitors alike.

site_title: Qian Hu posts 10% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: Qian Hu Corporation reported a 10.2% decline in Q3 net profit to S$79,000, driven by higher costs. Revenue fell 0.2% to S$20.5 million, while the cost of sales increased 1.9% to S$14.6 million. Earnings per share remained unchanged at 0.02 Singapore cents.

site_title: France flags deregulation measures as budget clash with EU looms
summary: France's Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron outlined deregulation measures to boost competition and simplify the economy, as the country prepares its 2015 budget for EU review. The measures, set to be sent to parliament in December, include limited deregulation of pharmacies, job sectors, and bus transport. Macron aims to address EU concerns about France's deficit-cutting promises, which are expected to be rejected. The measures are seen as a show of goodwill, but may not be enough to avoid a clash with the European Commission. France's budget deficit is expected to remain at 3% until 2017.

site_title: Statoil's CEO quits for top job at BG Group
summary: Statoil's CEO Helge Lund is leaving to become CEO of BG Group, a British gas and oil producer, after a 10-year tenure at Statoil. Lund's departure comes as BG struggles with declining production and lower oil prices. Lund's new role at BG is seen as a challenge, with analysts suggesting the company may benefit from a fresh perspective. Lund's guaranteed pay at BG will be £2 million (US$3.18 million) per year, a significant increase from his Statoil salary. Lund will start at BG on March 2.

site_title: Toyota to recall 1.67 million vehicles globally
summary: Toyota is recalling 1.67 million vehicles globally due to brake problems and other glitches that pose a fire risk. The issues include improperly shaped brake parts and fuel delivery pipe problems, affecting vehicles made between 2005 and 2012. The recall comes after Toyota recalled 2.27 million vehicles in April over airbag and fire risks, and is the latest in a string of recalls affecting the company's reputation for quality and safety.

site_title: Gender gap shrinking in schools, workplace: report
summary: A new report by the Boston Consulting Group found that global gender gaps have decreased significantly over the past 10 years, particularly in early education and the labor market. Primary school attendance reached 91% worldwide, and the gender ratio in the labor force improved from 95 girls to 100 boys in 2000 to 98 girls to 100 boys in 2014. However, women still lag behind in STEM fields, and a report predicts that if more women pursued STEM subjects, up to four million more women could access STEM jobs by 2025, generating 28 million jobs worldwide.

site_title: Airbus A350 wins key approval for 370-minute extended ops: sources
summary: Airbus has secured European safety approval for its A350 passenger jet, granting Extended Operations (ETOPS) clearance to fly for up to 370 minutes in the event of one engine failure, exceeding the 180-minute limit. This allows the twin-engined jet to take on nearly all commercial routes. The decision follows Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, which has a 330-minute ETOPS clearance. The approval marks a significant advantage for Airbus, with the difference seen as mainly a marketing one, as both jets leave sufficient margins to operate on most routes.

site_title: Tablet sales show fresh signs of cooling: survey
summary: The market for tablet computers is cooling off rapidly, with 229 million worldwide tablet sales predicted in 2014, up 11% from the previous year. Consumers are favoring hybrid or two-in-one devices over tablets, citing a shift towards newer PCs and large-screen smartphones. Gartner attributes this trend to changing consumer preferences, with Ranjit Atwal stating that some users are not replacing their tablets with new ones, but rather opting for alternative devices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.92%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.92% higher on Wednesday, rebounding from five days of losses due to a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 137.01 points to 15,073.52, while the Topix index gained 0.77% to 1,223.67. The market bounce-back was attributed to the yen's decline, which helped lift the market.

site_title: Swedish govt says to raise education spending by SEK3.4b in 2015
summary: Sweden's new centre-left government plans to increase education spending by 3.4 billion crowns (US$468 million) in 2015 and 5.6 billion in 2016, citing a "serious condition" of the school system with falling results, low teaching profession attractiveness, and increasing inequality. Prime Minister Stefan Lofven stated that the government will present its budget bill on October 23.

site_title: China's CICC chairman also leaving after CEO quits: sources
summary: China International Capital Corp's (CICC) chairman Jin Liqun is set to leave the bank this year, following the resignation of CEO Levin Zhu, who is the 'princeling' son of former premier Zhu Rongji. The departures come amid declining fortunes for the country's first investment bank, which has struggled to keep up with nimbler rivals. The loss of senior positions may delay CICC's plans to debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange and has a negative impact on the market due to the managers' influence and public praise.

site_title: Singapore retail sales expand 5.4% in Aug, bolstered by sales of motor vehicles
summary: Singapore's retail sales expanded 5.4% year-over-year in August, driven by a 49.5% increase in vehicle sales. Without vehicle sales, retail sales would have declined 1.6%. Other categories, such as watches and jewelry, and telecommunications apparatus, saw month-on-month growth. Total retail sales value for August reached S$3.2 billion, up from S$3 billion a year ago.

site_title: Ng Joo Hee to be PUB chief executive from Jan 6
summary: Commissioner of Police Ng Joo Hee, 48, will become the new Public Utilities Board (PUB) chief executive on Jan 6, 2015, concurrently serving as MEWR deputy secretary (Special Duties). He takes over from Chew Men Leong, who led PUB from 2011 to 2014 and later became LTA chief executive.

images.alt_text: Commissioner of Police Ng Joo Hee, 48, will become MEWR deputy secretary (Special Duties) and also concurrently be the new Public Utilities Board (PUB) chief executive on Jan 6, 2015. - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Seoul: Shares weighed down by global growth concerns; won a shade higher
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.2% to 1,925.91 points, weighed down by global growth concerns. The won strengthened slightly against the dollar. Investors curbed aggressive bets amid worries about slowing global economic growth, despite the Bank of Korea's decision to cut its policy base rate.

site_title: India's IndiGo agrees to buy 250 Airbus A320neo aircraft
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, has agreed to buy 250 Airbus A320neo aircraft worth $25.7 billion at list prices. This deal would be the largest number of jets sold by Airbus in a single order, extending the European planemaker's lead in the Indian market. The order is expected to close Airbus's worldwide deficit in orders versus Boeing during the first nine months of the year. This marks IndiGo's expansion plans in one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets, as the airline already operates a fleet of 83 Airbus A320s.

site_title: Qualcomm trumps Microchip with US$2.5b deal for Britain's CSR
summary: Qualcomm Inc has agreed to buy chip maker CSR Plc for US$2.5 billion, surpassing rival Microchip Technology to acquire the British Bluetooth specialist. The deal represents a 56.5% premium on CSR's share price. Qualcomm CEO Steven Mollenkopf said the acquisition will strengthen the company's presence in portable audio, automotive, and wearable devices. The deal is expected to further enhance Qualcomm's technology leadership in Bluetooth and audio processing.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm Inc has agreed to buy chip maker CSR Plc for US$2.5 billion, pushing out its rival Microchip Technology to win the British Bluetooth specialist which is growing in areas like automotive and wearable devices. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: British unemployment rate hits new five-year low at 6%
summary: Britain's unemployment rate has reached a new five-year low of 6% in the June-August period, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks the lowest point since late 2008, with 1.97 million people unemployed and a 154,000 decrease from the previous quarter. The data suggests a strong labor market, providing a positive economic indicator for the UK.

site_title: German inflation stuck at 0.8% for third month in a row
summary: German inflation remained stuck at 0.8% for the third consecutive month in September, the lowest level since February 2010. This ultra-low inflation rate has fueled concerns of deflation, which could harm economic activity and lead to job losses. The European Central Bank has cut interest rates and implemented measures to ease monetary conditions in response to the low inflation rate, which is significantly below its annual target of 2.0%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish up as global equities stabilise
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, stabilizing global equities, as protests showed signs of calming. The Hang Seng Index closed at 23,140.05 points. The rally was driven by improved market sentiment after Hong Kong police appeared to regain control over pro-democracy protesters. Weak China inflation data, however, added to concerns about faltering global economic growth.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Japan toymaker unveils tiny talking, singing humanoid
summary: Japan's toymaker Tomy unveiled "Robi jr.", a 7.9-inch, 20-centimeter humanoid robot that can converse in 1,000 phrases, sing 50 songs, and move its limbs. The robot is designed to resemble a six-year-old and features voice recognition and calendar functions. It will be sold in Japan and Taiwan/Hong Kong at a price of $140 each, with plans to sell 50,000 units annually. The robot's mood affects its singing responses, with options to sing or ask for a later time. It is expected to debut in early 2015.

site_title: US encouraged by progress with Japan on Pacific trade pact, but 'tough' issues remain
summary: US-Japan talks on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact made progress, but "tough" issues remain, including barriers to agricultural imports. The US wants Japan to lower tariffs, while Japan seeks to protect sensitive products. US Deputy Trade Representative Wendy Cutler said the two sides agreed to meet next week and move negotiations to Sydney ahead of ministerial meetings. US President Barack Obama hopes to have a deal by year-end, but experts are skeptical of the two economies making necessary compromises.

site_title: SMCCA to SGX: Minimum Trading Price will not increase market liquidity
summary: SMCCA opposes Singapore Exchange's (SGX) proposed Minimum Trading Price (MTP) of 20 cents a share, citing concerns that it will reduce market liquidity and increase listing costs. The association argues that MTP will not effectively curb misconduct and abuse, and will instead confuse shareholders and investors. SMCCA also questions the regulatory role of SGX in enforcing MTP, suggesting that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) should be responsible for regulating issuers.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S Small and Middle Capitalisation Companies Association (SMCCA) believes that Singapore Exchange's (SGX) proposed adoption of a Minimum Trading Price (MTP) will add "no meaningful value to the capital markets" but instead reduce liquidity and add to listing cost. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Developers sell 648 private homes in Sept, up from Aug's 437 units
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 648 private homes in September, up from 437 units in August. This represents a significant increase from the same period last year, when 1,649 units were sold. The figures, excluding executive condos, show a similar improvement. The Urban Redevelopment Authority reported these sales based on monthly submissions from developers.

site_title: Singapore tourism receipts up 2% in H1 14, while tourist arrivals fall 3%
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts increased 2% to S$11.8 billion in the first half of 2014, despite a 3% decline in tourist arrivals to 7.5 million. Visitor arrivals from non-Chinese markets rose 2%, while China's decline was attributed to new tourism laws. Hotel room revenue grew 5.2% in Q2 and 9.1% in H1, with average room rates and occupancy rates also showing slight increases.

site_title: Apple looks to rev up fading tablet growth
summary: Apple is set to unveil thinner, more powerful iPads ahead of the holiday season, but may struggle to boost tablet sales, which are forecast to rise only 11% this year. This decline, despite 55% growth last year, is attributed to a surplus of handheld, touch-screen devices. Apple's iPad sales have fallen for two straight quarters, threatening 15% of the company's revenue. Investors focus on the iPhone, Apple's main revenue generator, as a prolonged iPad downturn looms.

site_title: SPH newspapers to celebrate 50 years of Singapore music with 2015 concert
summary: Two SPH newspapers, The Business Times and The Straits Times, will present Sing50, a concert celebrating 50 years of Singapore music, on August 7, 2015, at the National Stadium. The event will feature well-loved homegrown compositions performed by a mainly Singaporean cast, including original singers and composers, and will also include performances by up to 100 pianists and a 1,000-strong choir. The concert aims to spark inter-generational exchange and bring back musical memories of the past 50 years. The event is part of SG50 celebrations, a calendar of jubilee events for 2015.

site_title: Fujitsu, A*Star, SMU invest S$54m in Singapore centre to solve urban challenges
summary: Fujitsu, the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), and the Singapore Management University (SMU) have invested S$54 million in an Urban Computing and Engineering Centre of Excellence to address urban challenges. The five-year partnership aims to harness high-performance computing to develop solutions for sustainable urban operations, focusing on efficient resource usage and traffic congestion. Researchers will use Singapore as a "living lab" to test-bed next-generation solutions, combining strengths in Big Data, high-performance computing, and decision-making. The centre will develop methods for improving commuter traffic and port operation optimization.

site_title: 'Tis be the season for SAAR
summary: The article discusses the concept of the seasonally adjusted annual rate (SAAR), a statistical measure used to analyze economic data. SAAR removes seasonal fluctuations, leaving only the trend cycle and irregular component. It is calculated by annualizing the seasonally adjusted quarterly growth rate. The article notes that SAAR is used for quarter-on-quarter comparisons, not year-on-year comparisons, as seasonality remains relevant in the latter. The X12-Arima procedure, developed by the US Census Bureau, is used for seasonal adjustments.

site_title: Banks hire HK traders on lure of China bourse link
summary: Banks in Hong Kong are hiring traders and analysts to capitalize on the upcoming link between the Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges, expected to boost trading volumes and generate new business opportunities. BNP Paribas and Standard Chartered have hired 19 and 8 staff respectively, while China Renaissance Securities plans to build a new equities business in Hong Kong. The link, set to allow direct trading of Shanghai-listed shares, is expected to increase the average daily value of trading on the HKEx by 38% to HK$93 billion by 2015.

site_title: Stocks to Watch: SingPost, Hotel Properties, Vard Holdings, Cordlife, Tuan Sing
summary: Singapore's SingPost to open a S$182 million e-commerce logistics hub in Tampines in 2016. Hotel Properties has formed a 70:30 joint venture to buy a freehold property in London for S$225 million. Vard Holdings warned of "marginally negative Ebitda" for its third quarter due to slower-than-expected improvements in productivity. Cordlife Group set up a S$500 million multicurrency debt issuance programme, while Tuan Sing Holdings issued S$80 million in notes due in 2019.

site_title: New iPads aim to boost Apple in premium tablet market
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPads aimed at boosting its premium tablet market share, amid a cooling global tablet market. The new iPads will feature enhanced features such as fingerprint reading and the Apple Pay mobile wallet. Despite the market slowdown, analysts predict that Apple's focus on the premium segment will help the company maintain its market share. The new iPads are expected to cater to business users, particularly in the healthcare and sales industries, where tablets can make jobs more efficient.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up 0.17% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% at open on October 15, 2014, ahead of Chinese inflation data release. The Hang Seng Index increased 39.53 points to 23,087.50, amid clashes between pro-democracy protestors and police in the city.

site_title: Hong Kong tension rises as police officers suspended over beating of protester
summary: Hong Kong authorities suspended 45 police officers after footage of them beating a protester went viral. The incident occurred during a protest in a Chinese-controlled city, where protesters had barricaded a major road with concrete slabs. Police used pepper spray and arrested protesters, but one officer appeared to beat and kick a protester for several minutes. The move aims to address public outrage and maintain stability in the city.

site_title: Facebook challenging Google in online ad market
summary: Facebook is challenging Google's dominance in the online ad market, with its "Audience Network" expanding the social network's ad platform beyond its borders on mobile apps. Facebook's share of the US$140 billion online ad market has doubled to nearly 8% over the past two years, while Google's share has dipped to 44.6%. Facebook's ability to leverage its 1.3 billion users and track behavior across devices is seen as a key advantage, with eMarketer predicting that the company could provide a major boost to Facebook revenue.

site_title: Italy and China sign business deals worth US$10b
summary: Italy and China signed business deals worth approximately US$10 billion, deepening Beijing's commercial ties with the eurozone's No. 3 economy. The deals cover sectors such as energy and engineering. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi stated that the agreements are a "beginning" and will lead to further accords. China has already spent over 5 billion euros buying stakes in Italian companies this year.

site_title: Mops may have caused Qantas flight's midair flood: report
summary: A Qantas Airbus A380 experienced a midair flood of water after a pipe coupling in the galley came undone, potentially caused by a cleaning mop. The incident, dubbed "Lakes on a Plane," occurred on a 14-hour flight from Los Angeles to Melbourne in July. The Transport Safety Bureau found evidence that cleaning mops may have contributed to the coupling coming undone. The crew returned to Los Angeles and landed safely, with Qantas conducting fleet-wide inspections and implementing changes to its cleaning procedures. Airbus is also working on a solution.

site_title: China looks to build first luxury cruise ship with Carnival
summary: China is partnering with Carnival Corp and Italian shipyard Fincantieri SpA to build its first luxury cruise ship. The venture aims to capitalize on China's growing domestic tourism industry, which is expected to reach 4.5 million passengers by 2020. China State Shipbuilding Corporation (CSSC) will provide the shipbuilding expertise, while Carnival will contribute ship design and expertise. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to support China's struggling shipbuilding industry, which has been hit by a global shipping slump. The joint venture also aims to form a domestic cruise company.

site_title: Toyota recalls 1.67m Toyota, Lexus cars for three separate defects
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has recalled 1.67 million vehicles globally to address three separate defects, including a faulty brake master cylinder that may hinder brake performance. The affected vehicles include Toyota Crown, Noah, Auris, and more than a dozen Lexus models. Toyota stated it was not aware of any crashes, injuries, or deaths resulting from the defects. The recall is part of a series of actions by the world's largest carmaker to address safety concerns.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp said on Wednesday it would recall a total 1.67 million vehicles globally to address three separate defects including a faulty brake master cylinder that could hinder the brake's performance - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by consumer sentiment, energy stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by stronger consumer sentiment and gains in mining and financial stocks. The three 'Big Four' banks, Westpac and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, increased 0.4% and 1.1%, respectively. Energy shares were weighed down, tempering broader gains.

site_title: Hotel Properties in joint venture to buy former Royal Mail Delivery Offices in London for £111m
summary: Hotel Properties has formed a 70:30 joint venture with Anchorage View Pte Ltd to buy a freehold property in Paddington, London, for £111m. The JV will pay £11.1m upfront and the remaining £99.9m in December 2014. The property, formerly Royal Mail Delivery Offices, has redevelopment potential and will be assessed for residential and retail re-development. A further £20m planning overage payment will be paid to Royal Mail Group when planning permission is granted, following the completion of the Crossrail project in 2018.

site_title: Q3 GDP performance uneven across sectors
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 1.2% in Q3 2014, driven by a manufacturing sector rebound, but services and construction sectors showed weakness. The manufacturing sector grew 1.2% after a 15.1% contraction in Q2, while the services sector expanded 1.3% but at a slower pace than the previous quarter. The construction sector contracted 2.7% for the second consecutive quarter. Year-on-year growth was 2.4%, below forecasts. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects growth to be uneven across sectors, with benefits from the US recovery and mild global IT growth offset by structural headwinds in the core eurozone and Japan.

site_title: China inflation slows to 1.6% in September: government
summary: China's inflation rate slowed to 1.6% in September, the lowest in nearly five years, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This fell short of analyst forecasts and the government's 3.5% annual target. The producer price index also decreased 1.8% year-on-year, indicating rising deflationary pressures. This slowdown in inflation may weigh on growth and signal a need for policymakers to address economic concerns.

site_title: South Korea unemployment rate unchanged in Sept
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.5% in September, with young people still facing difficulties in the job market. The rate for those aged 15-29 rose to 8.5%, up from 8.4% in August. Job cuts were reported in agriculture and fisheries, while retail and health sectors created fewer jobs. This year's data was drawn after the Chuseok holidays, which typically see temporary job creation and loss.

site_title: Small stock 'quakes' are healthy, says BlackRock official
summary: BlackRock's Jeff Shen stated that small stock corrections, including those caused by lower oil prices, are healthy. He likened these corrections to "small quakes" that help prevent a larger, more devastating earthquake. This analogy suggests that the asset manager views minor market fluctuations as a necessary and beneficial part of the market's overall health.

site_title: Broker's Take: Buy SGX, target price S$8 a share: Jefferies
summary: JEfferies has upgraded Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) to a "buy" rating, targeting a price of S$8 a share due to expected growth in derivatives volume. The research house attributes this growth to the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, which can fuel SGX's ChinaA50 futures. At press time, SGX traded around S$6.86 a share.

site_title: Triyards acquires two facilities in Singapore and Vietnam for A$23.3m
summary: Triyards Holdings acquired Strategic Marine (S) in Singapore and Strategic Marine (V) in Vietnam for A$23.3 million. The acquisition includes two facilities, one in Pioneer, Singapore, and another in Dong Xuyen Industry Park, Vietnam. The deal is expected to provide increased fabrication capacities and access to the target companies' clientele base, enabling Triyards to achieve economies of scale and scope. The consideration was funded by Triyards' issuance of new shares and internal cash resources.

site_title: Dollar steadies, euro slides after data surprises
summary: The euro declined by a whole cent to US$1.2640, reaching an 11-month low against the yen, due to unexpectedly sharp declines in industrial output and investor morale. The eurozone's industrial output and German investor sentiment indicator fell below forecasts, exacerbating economic concerns. The dollar steadied against the euro while rising against the Swiss franc, solidifying its position as a safe-haven currency. The decline in the euro was attributed to growing worries about growth and the eurozone's economic recovery, with traders considering the dollar as a more attractive option.

site_title: Vard Holdings warns of 'marginally negative Ebitda' in Q3
summary: Vard Holdings reported that it is likely to report "marginally negative Ebitda" for its third quarter ended Sept 30, 2014, due to slower-than-expected improvements in throughput and productivity at its new Vard Promar shipyard in Brazil. The company attributed additional costs for vessels built at a third-party yard. Despite these challenges, the company expects no impact on delivery schedules.

site_title: Median size of new sales continues to shrink in H1
summary: The median size of new private apartments and condos sold by developers in Singapore has shrunk to 743 sq ft in the first half of 2014, down 10% from last year, due to developers' strategy of building smaller units to address affordability issues. In contrast, the median size of resale units has remained constant at around 1,200 sq ft since 2007. This is attributed to the higher proportion of smaller units in the resale market and the better selection of larger units in completed projects.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points to 1796.21. The trading volume reached 18.93 million lots worth RM9.26 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 66.

site_title: Seoul: Shares choppy as growth woes check sentiment; won edges down
summary: South Korean shares ended flat, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gaining 0.03% to 1,929.88 points. The market reacted mutedly to the Bank of Korea's rate cut, as investors remain cautious about the global economy's growth. Foreign investors sold South Korean equities for the 9th straight session, netting 110.3 billion won (US$103.49 million). Traditional defensive plays, such as consumer staples, outperformed the broader market, while airline shares rallied on lower jet fuel costs. The won edged lower against the dollar, amid a risk-off mood.

site_title: South Korea cuts interest rate for second time in three months
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, cut interest rates for the second time in three months, lowering the benchmark rate to 2.0% to boost the economy. The rate cut aims to counter weakening demand at home and abroad, following a similar cut in August. The move also follows a 41 trillion won stimulus package unveiled in July to prevent a recession. Analysts expect a downward revision of the country's 2014 growth forecast, citing lingering global economic concerns and volatility in the domestic financial markets.

site_title: Asia: Stocks edgy on lingering growth anxiety, China inflation slows
summary: Asian stocks rose cautiously on Wednesday, driven by benign inflation data in China and a decline in euro zone economic concerns. China's consumer inflation eased to 1.6% in September, while South Korea's central bank cut interest rates for the second time in three months. However, global growth fears persisted, with the dollar steadying after disappointing data out of Germany and Britain. The euro zone's economic woes, including a decline in German business confidence and reduced growth forecasts, continued to weigh on markets, with US Treasuries and German Bunds rallying this week.

site_title: Ireland unveils post-austerity budget, ends tax loophole
summary: Ireland unveiled its first non-austerity budget since its economic crisis, marking the end of budget austerity. The budget includes income tax cuts amounting to 458 million euros, offset by new water charges that will raise 300 million euros. The government forecasts strong GDP growth this year of 4.7% and plans to reduce the deficit to 2.7% of GDP next year. The budget also tightens corporate tax rules, abolishing the Double Irish tax loophole, and includes measures to tackle waiting lists for social housing.

site_title: Microsoft's Skype launches video messaging app
summary: Microsoft's Skype has launched a new video messaging app called Skype Qik, allowing users to send short videos up to 42 seconds long. The app is designed to help users stay "connected between calls" and takes features from Twitter's Vine and Snapchat. Messages on Qik disappear in two weeks, while Snapchats are gone after being viewed. The new service aims to help Microsoft compete in the growing mobile messaging space.

site_title: Airlines need tougher rules to stop battery fires, says ICAO advisory group
summary: An ICAO advisory group recommends tightening restrictions on bulk shipments of lithium batteries via commercial airplanes to reduce the risk of battery fires, which can lead to loss of control of an airplane. The group suggests reassessing fire detection systems and limiting battery shipments in cargo compartments with better fire-suppression ability. The recommendations are non-binding, requiring ICAO action to take effect, a process that could take years. This comes after a 2010 incident where a lithium battery fire caused a cargo plane crash in Dubai, resulting in two fatalities.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.04 points to 3,201.44. Volume was 30.8 million shares worth S$41.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 53.

site_title: Apple, Facebook will pay for female employees to freeze their eggs
summary: Apple and Facebook will cover the costs of egg freezing for female employees, with Apple paying up to $20,000 and Facebook reportedly offering the benefit without medical necessity. The move aims to support women in balancing work and family life. The companies' benefits include extended parental leave and flexible family-planning perks, sparking debate on creating a more balanced culture.

site_title: India says it has tamed food prices as inflation slides
summary: India's new government claims to have controlled rising food prices, a key issue in the country, following better-than-expected inflation data. Annual wholesale inflation slowed to a five-year low of 2.38%, while consumer price inflation fell to a three-year low of 6.46% in September. The finance minister attributed the improvement to lower food prices, but analysts warn that this trend may wear off soon. The central bank aims to achieve a low and stable inflation rate of six% by January 2016.

images.alt_text: Annual wholesale inflation slowed to a five-year low of 2.38 per cent last month, the commerce ministry said, helped by lower food prices - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.49%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.49% higher on Wednesday, snapping a five-day losing streak. The Nikkei 225 index rose 73.24 points to 15,009.75, driven by the dollar's uptick against the yen and solid US corporate earnings. The market is considered oversold, due for a modest rebound. The dollar was at 107.25 yen, up from 107.13 yen in New York Tuesday afternoon.

site_title: Britain issues first yuan bond outside China
summary: Britain has issued the first yuan-denominated sovereign bond outside China, a £300 million (US$480 million) 3-year bond with a 2.7% yield. The bond was arranged by Bank of China, HSBC, and Standard Chartered, and will be used to finance Britain's foreign currency reserves. This move aims to boost links with China, bolster London's market for yuan, and underline the city's status as a global financial hub. The UK government hopes the bond will attract more investment to its shores and support economic ties with China.

site_title: After selling unit to Glencore, Italian firm on comeback trail
summary: Italian family-owned firm Pacorini is making a comeback after selling its metals business to Glencore three years ago. Pacorini Global Systems (PGS) is hiring two former executives, Mario Casciano and Daniel Saez, to rebuild its metals operations. The company aims to offer trucking and logistics services in LME and off-exchange sheds, focusing on ports and in-house services. This move comes as the LME considers tougher regulations to curb year-long queues and the sector faces challenges from a copper financing scandal in China.

site_title: Asian investors need to keep eurozone enthusiasm in check
summary: Asian investors should exercise caution on eurozone stocks and maintain a negative stance on the euro against the US dollar as the European Central Bank (ECB) implements monetary easing. Despite the ECB's asset-purchasing program, the economic backdrop remains uncertain, and the effectiveness of the measures is far from assured. Eurozone growth stalled in the second quarter, and the policy's impact may be complicated by diverse government requirements and differing motivations.

site_title: Gulfstream unveils two new business jets
summary: Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation unveiled two new business jets, the G500 and G600, which optimize speed and offer spacious cabins. The aircraft feature advanced flight decks and can fly at high speeds, including a record 1102 km/h from New York to Geneva. Orders are in line from Flexjet and Qatar Airways, demonstrating strong demand for the new models.

images.alt_text: Flexjet signed an order Tuesday for up to 50 Gulfstream aircraft, including the existing G450 as well as the new G500 and G650 - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Brazil bets on flip-flops, Olympic mascot for sales of 1b reals
summary: Rio de Janeiro Olympics organisers are targeting 1 billion reals (S$533 million) in merchandise sales, with licensing deals for 12,000 games-related products, exceeding previous Olympics. The sales will be driven by flip-flops, a yet-to-be-announced mascot, and products aimed at children. The Rio 2016 organising committee has completed 65 licensing agreements, with 90% of sales targeting the domestic market. The identity of the mascot will be announced next month, and organisers believe it will be a best-seller, with a potential cartoon series in the works.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher on solid earnings
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Tuesday, reversing a three-day slump, as analysts believed the market was oversold in the short run. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 5.88 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 2.96% and 13.52%, respectively. Solid corporate earnings from banks like Citigroup and Wells Fargo contributed to the gains, while energy stocks were hurt by a decline in oil prices. Airline stocks, however, rallied as investors sought safety amid global growth concerns.

site_title: Ascott opens three new serviced residences in Hangzhou, Hamburg and Jakarta
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has opened three new properties: Citadines Intime City Hangzhou in China, Ascott Hamburg in Germany, and Ascott Jakarta in Indonesia. The 104-unit Citadines in Hangzhou is the 35th property in China, near major business districts and attractions. Ascott has also secured a management contract for its second Dubai property, set to open in 2017. This expansion marks Ascott's presence in new international markets, strengthening its global serviced residence network.

site_title: South Korea import prices fall for 25th straight mth, BOK rate cut seen
summary: South Korea's import prices dropped 8.8% in September from a year ago, marking the 25th consecutive month of declines. The fall was attributed to a 10.5% plunge in crude oil prices and a 5% rise in the won's strength against the dollar. This data precedes the Bank of Korea's monetary policy meeting, where a rate cut is expected for the second time in three months to re-energize the weak economy. Actual inflation remains outside the central bank's target band, and domestic demand is still slow to indicate a firm recovery.

images.alt_text: Import prices fell 8.8 per cent in September in annual terms, the Bank of Korea said, continuing their longest falling streak on record, although the fall was a little slower than in August, when prices fell 9.9 per cent - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Intel gives rosy fourth-quarter revenue forecast as PCs recover
summary: Intel Corp has given a rosy fourth-quarter revenue forecast, citing a recovering PC industry and a healthy supply chain ahead of the holiday season. The company expects revenue of $14.7 billion, above analyst expectations. Demand for personal computers has stabilized, driven by companies replacing older laptops. Intel's shares have risen 24% in 2014, making it the top performer in the Dow Jones industrial average. However, the company's gross margins are expected to slip to 64% in the current quarter.

site_title: Singapore's CEOs largely ignore benefits of becoming more 'social'
summary: Singaporean CEOs largely ignore the benefits of social media presence, with only one CEO on Twitter and no other social media activity reported. Despite being active social media users, the country's citizens, CEOs are missing an opportunity to engage with their target audience. Research shows that CEOs' reputation is crucial for a company's enterprise value and that active social media engagement is linked to higher reputational status and trust among stakeholders.

site_title: Singapore to supply LNG to ships by 2020: minister
summary: Singapore plans to supply liquefied natural gas (LNG) to ships by 2020, aiming to reduce emissions and capitalize on its position as the world's largest bunkering port. The city state will start a pilot program in 2017 to fund up to $2 million per vessel for six LNG-fueled vessels. This move follows a global trend to shift away from oil to gas.

site_title: Ebola infection rate could reach 10,000 a week, WHO says ahead of UN crisis talks
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) predicts the Ebola infection rate could reach 10,000 cases per week by mid-December, with a mortality rate of 70% in West Africa. The latest death toll is 4,447, from 8,914 recorded cases of infection. The UN is holding crisis talks on the epidemic, and international efforts are being intensified to contain it, including measures to screen passengers at airports and provide medical support.

site_title: Longest A$ bond shows belief in budget amid deficit
summary: Australian investors are showing confidence in the government's efforts to repair the nation's finances with the sale of its longest bond, a 2037 note. The sale comes after Bank of America Merrill Lynch warned of a possible deficit target miss and despite falling commodity prices, which will hurt government efforts to reduce the deficit. Strong demand for the bond is expected to show investor confidence in the government's ability to manage the economy's transition after the end of a record mining investment boom.

site_title: Hong Kong tensions rise as police use pepper spray on protesters to clear road
summary: Tensions in Hong Kong escalated as police used pepper spray to clear a major road blocked by pro-democracy protesters, who have been demanding universal suffrage. The clashes, the worst in over a week, occurred after protesters stormed into a tunnel on Lung Wo Road, halting traffic and chanting for democracy. The protesters, who have been camped out in the Admiralty district for two weeks, have been met with resistance from police, who have used pepper spray and batons to disperse the crowds. The clashes have fueled frustration and drained public support, with China ruling Hong Kong under a "one country, two systems" formula.

site_title: European companies paying price for Ukraine crisis
summary: European companies are facing significant financial losses due to the Ukraine crisis, with EU direct investments in Russia totaling $215 billion. The EU has imposed sanctions, which Russia has retaliated against, affecting 600 European companies. Germany is the most affected, with exports to Russia declining 14% in August. European taxpayers may face $64.5 billion in damages this year, and a further $50 billion in 2015. The EU's business interests in Russia are being "sacrificed" by both European and Russian authorities, according to Philippe Pegorier, chairman of the Association of European Business.

site_title: Investors shifting focus in emerging markets
summary: Investors are shifting focus to emerging markets that benefit from a stronger US economy, such as Singapore, Taiwan, and Thailand, which are likely to see growth from manufacturing exports to the US. In contrast, commodity exporters like Russia, Chile, and South Africa are expected to fare less well due to their dependence on China. The falling cost of oil is also expected to improve balance sheets and drive down production costs for manufacturing industries, benefiting countries like India and Indonesia. However, investors must also consider regional economic cycles and avoid over-reliance on weaker developed markets in Europe or Japan.

site_title: Seven in 10 new private condos sold in H1 at under S$1.25 m
summary: A study by CBRE found that 71.7% of new private condo sales in Singapore's first half of 2014 were priced below S$1.25 million, higher than 63.6% in the previous year. This trend has remained stable since 2007, with 52-67% of buyers being HDB occupiers, often upgrading to private homes for owner occupation or downsizing. The TDSR framework has limited liquidity, making it harder for HDB upgraders to buy private properties.

site_title: Euro ministers 'not amused' by Greek plan to cut aid line
summary: Euro ministers expressed skepticism about Greece's plan to exit its rescue program early, citing concerns about the economic implications. Austrian Finance Minister Hans Joerg Schelling stated that the plan is being watched with "certain skepticism and concern." This comes as a clash between Greek political priorities and European economic preferences.

site_title: Sizing up Pimco, after Bill Gross
summary: The Pimco Total Return bond fund, managed by William H Gross, has been a popular choice in 401(k) accounts since its inception in 1987. However, the fund's recent events have raised concerns among retirement savers. Gross's abrupt resignation has created uncertainty, and the fund's performance may be affected. As a result, investors are advised to exercise caution when managing their retirement accounts. The article does not provide a clear conclusion, but it highlights the potential risks and challenges facing the Pimco Total Return bond fund.

site_title: Getting to grips with the era of 'the new mediocre'
summary: Finance ministers and central bankers at the IMF and World Bank meetings in Washington were concerned about rising interest rates due to escalating financial market risks, despite a fragile global economy. IMF managing director Christine Lagarde stated that there is "too much financial risk-taking and not enough economic risk-taking". This poses a challenge to maintaining economic recovery and risk-averse behavior. The pressure to raise interest rates threatens to disrupt already wobbly economic conditions.

site_title: Planned Reit changes seen positive overall
summary: Credit agencies Moody's and Fitch have deemed Singapore's proposed Reit reforms largely positive, but with risks. The reforms increase the development limit to 25% of total asset value, potentially increasing rental yields and improving financial performance. However, Moody's views the proposal as "marginally credit negative," while Fitch notes it may increase earnings volatility and encourage unrated Reits to borrow more, posing risks to the sector. The reforms also introduce a single-tier leverage limit of 45% for all Reits.

site_title: Mid- to large caps still up on year despite recent woes
summary: Singapore stocks, including mid- and large-cap, have experienced recent struggles with negative returns over the past month, but remain positive compared to a year ago. The Straits Times Index (STI) offered a -4.2% return, while the FTSE ST Mid-Cap index returned -4.4% and the FTSE ST Small-Cap index returned -6.1%. However, the STI is still up 4.3% over the past year, and mid-cap stocks have shown resilience with a 6% return. Experts attribute recent weakness to institutional funds shifting out of the region and sector-specific pressures.

site_title: Luxury car dealers unleash promotional blitz
summary: Singapore luxury car dealers are offering various freebies to attract potential buyers, with Borneo Motors' Lexus offers being particularly impressive. However, not all customers are swayed by these sales tactics, with some viewing them as gimmicks. The promotional blitz is part of a larger effort by dealers to stay competitive in the market, but the effectiveness of these strategies remains to be seen.

site_title: Christie's sells £47m of artwork in London
summary: Christie's sold £46.9 million of postwar and contemporary art in London, with a Gerhard Richter painting, "Netz," selling for £5.5 million to a private US collector after failing to find a buyer at an estimated £10 million. The sale took place at the start of Frieze week in London.

site_title: Support list grows as more step forward
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 5th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2014 from October 27 to 31, with 76 companies signing the Statement of Support for excellence in corporate governance. Key supporters include the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, Singapore Exchange, and several major corporations such as Frasers Commercial Trust, OKP Holdings, SingTel, ST Engineering, and Yongnam Holdings, who emphasize the importance of good corporate governance in enhancing shareholder value and building trust with stakeholders.

site_title: Valuetronics hit by earnings worries?
summary: Valuetronics Holdings' stock price plummeted 15.8% to 32 Singapore cents on Tuesday, following a "sell" report by Maybank Kim Eng, which cited uncertainty over the company's future earnings due to its largest customer's decision to split its lighting business. Analysts also noted that premium LED lighting brands are being undercut by cheaper Chinese products, potentially impacting Valuetronics' revenue and gross profit. The report contradicts other current "buy" recommendations from other analysts, sparking concerns about the influence of one report on the stock's performance.

site_title: Sembmarine's US$696m deal seen as timely
summary: Sembmarine, a Singapore-based rigbuilder, has secured a US$696 million deal to convert a shuttle tanker into a floating, production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel for OOGTK Libra in Brazil. The project, valued at 50,000 barrels of oil per day and four million cubic metres of natural gas per day, is set for delivery in third-quarter 2016 and could boost the company's stock price. The deal comes as Sembmarine's stock has been taking a beating due to low oil prices, doubts over the timely delivery of a drillship, and sluggish contract wins.

site_title: Aussie banks shrug off warnings on mortgages
summary: Australia's major banks are dismissing central bank warnings of regulatory steps to curb lending to property investors, despite a record-high 40-60% of residential loans going to investors. The Reserve Bank of Australia is concerned that speculation could lead to a housing price correction, but banks argue that investor borrowers are of higher quality and that their lending practices are conservative. Despite potential regulation, banks expect business to remain unaffected, citing the attractiveness of the investor market and the lack of supply in the housing market.

images.alt_text: 'The investor market is pretty attractive... there is very low activity from first-time home buyers,' said Tony Bice, managing director at Mortgage Choices.

site_title: German investor confidence drops on possible recession
summary: German investor confidence plummeted to minus 3.6 in October, the worst level in nearly two years, according to the ZEW Center for European Economic Research. The decline is attributed to geopolitical tensions, weak economic development in the eurozone, and disappointing data on business confidence. The European Central Bank's efforts to stimulate the economy through low interest rates and asset purchases may not be enough to counteract the economic slowdown. Economists predict a technical recession in Germany, with some forecasting a quantitative-easing program similar to those used by the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: SRX flash estimate shows uptick in condo resale in Sept
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home resale market showed an uptick in September, with 468 homes transacted, a 15.3% increase from August and 13.3% year on year. Median transaction over X-value (TOX) improved to negative S$2,000, marking the best showing since September 2013. However, the overall resale price index decreased 0.3% month on month and 4.6% year on year. The rental market also softened, with a 14% decrease in leasing volumes and a 5.3% year-on-year decline in rental index.

site_title: Top Glove's shares fall 1.4% on weak Q4 results
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest rubber glove maker, reported weaker fourth-quarter results due to higher natural gas prices, with earnings declining 5.2% and revenue falling 1.7%. The company's net profit for the full year declined 8.3% to RM180.1 million. Despite a 17% drop in latex prices and an 8% drop in nitrile latex prices, rising utility costs and intense competition outweighed any benefits, leading to a 1.4% drop in shares.

site_title: India's Sept wholesale inflation falls near 5-year low
summary: India's wholesale price inflation eased to a near 5-year low of 2.38% in September, driven by moderation in food and fuel prices. The rate is the slowest pace since October 2009. Consumer price inflation, also tracked by the central bank, dropped to 6.46% in September, its lowest since January 2012. Despite a favorable base effect and low food prices, economists caution that the real picture of inflation will emerge after November and that the Reserve Bank of India may not cut interest rates soon due to concerns about price shocks.

site_title: Hard sciences back in favour with VCs
summary: Venture capitalists are shifting their focus to hard sciences, engineering, and clean-tech startups, investing $1.24 billion in industrial and energy startups in the first half of 2014, a 125% increase from the previous year. Investments in biotechnology startups also rose 26% to $2.93 billion. These investments are driven by a desire to address the world's difficult problems and capitalize on the success of social media and mobile apps. Companies like Vestaron, Transatomic Power, and Helion Energy are receiving funding from Silicon Valley VCs to develop innovative technologies, such as eco-friendly pesticides, nuclear fusion, and clean energy solutions.

site_title: T-Mobile, Iliad deal unravels
summary: T-Mobile US has successfully deflected a third takeover bid, with Iliad SA scrapping its offer to buy a majority stake in the company. Despite the pressure, T-Mobile CEO John Legere remains confident, citing the company's recent growth and strong subscriber numbers. In the first half of the year, T-Mobile added 2.68 million monthly subscribers, making it the fastest-growing US wireless carrier. Analysts praise the company's strategy, with some predicting the stock could reach $34 and surpassing Sprint in total subscribers by the end of the year.

site_title: CDL leads the pack in large-scale use of prefab tech
summary: CDL, a Singaporean developer, has become the first in Asia to use prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) in a large-scale residential project. The 3,300-module executive condominium (EC) on Canberra Drive is expected to increase construction productivity by 40% and save 55,000 man days compared to conventional methods.
