Lawmakers agree to implement measures to help gambling addicts, with companies like Las Vegas Sands Corp vying for licenses to operate casinos in Japan.

site_title: Shares of Malaysia's CIMB fall 2% after announcing merger with smaller lenders
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd shares fell 2% after announcing a merger with smaller domestic lenders RHB Capital Bhd and Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB). CIMB will own 70% of the merged entity, while RHB shareholders will own 30%. The deal, expected to be completed in mid-2015, will form the country's biggest banking group and a mega Islamic bank.

site_title: EU sets rules to aid securitisation revival
summary: The European Commission has published new rules to encourage securitisation of assets, aiming to boost the European economy. The rules, part of the EU's capital markets union project, will facilitate the securitisation of car and consumer loans, small business loans, and other assets. This move is intended to reduce banks' reliance on traditional funding sources and promote market-based funding for fledgling companies. The goal is to strengthen banks' resilience and keep insurers solvent.

images.alt_text: The European Commission published new rules on Friday to encourage more securitisation of assets such as car and consumer loans and small business loans as part of a drive to channel more funds into the flagging European economy. - BLOOMBERG

site_title: Symantec to split into security and storage software companies
summary: Symantec Corp will split into two publicly traded companies, one selling security software and the other providing data management services. The move is expected to reverse the company's $13.5 billion acquisition of Veritas Software a decade ago and focus on faster-growing businesses. The security business generated $4.2 billion in revenue in fiscal 2014, while the data management business generated $2.5 billion. The split is expected to be completed by the end of December 2015, with the new data management business distributing shares tax-free to existing Symantec shareholders.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Reits, Yongnam, Tiger Air
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes to improve corporate governance of Reits and align fees with unit holders' interests. Analysts view the proposals as positive, potentially reducing fees and increasing transparency. Yongnam Holdings secures S$76.6 million in sub-contracts for MRT Line and Hong Kong projects. Tiger Airways sub-leases 12 aircraft to IndiGo, making a one-off accounting provision of S$93 million amid overcapacity in the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 1.20%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.20% lower on Friday amid heightened global growth concerns, following a 1.97% decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and a 2.07% drop in the S&P 500. Weak economic data from Germany contributed to the sell-off. The Nikkei 225 index lost 186.05 points to 15,292.88.

site_title: Philippine August exports slowest in three months
summary: The Philippines reported its slowest August exports in three months, with total exports reaching $40.75 billion, a 9.2% increase from the same period last year. Electronics and semiconductors drove the growth, with a 10% increase, while the government aims for a 6.5-7.5% GDP growth this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.67 points to 1822.91. Volume reached 143.1 million lots worth RM71.1 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 460 to 37, indicating a bearish market trend.

site_title: DBS joins World Bank's Global Infrastructure Facility as advisory partner
summary: DBS Bank has joined the World Bank's Global Infrastructure Facility (GIF) as an advisory partner, aiming to catalyze and mobilize private-sector investment in emerging markets' infrastructure projects. As an advisory partner, DBS will advise on project preparation, financial structuring, and risk instrument design. The GIF, launched in Washington, seeks to address the lack of a steady pipeline of bankable projects in emerging markets, with the World Bank estimating an additional $1 trillion in annual investment needed through 2020 to meet growing infrastructure demands.

site_title: Trade, rights on agenda as China's Li visits Germany
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang met German Chancellor Angela Merkel, signing 30 cooperation and investment deals worth over $2.5 billion. The talks focused on bolstering trade and investment links, but came amid growing concerns over human rights and business rules in China. Merkel criticized China's life jail term for a leading ethnic Uighur activist and expressed support for free speech in Hong Kong, where protests are ongoing. China is seeking to deepen its strategic partnership with Germany, but investor concerns remain over Beijing's anti-monopoly investigations and rule of law.

site_title: Google wins bid on which court to fight Rockstar over patents
summary: Google will fight Rockstar Consortium in a California court over patents, after the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ordered proceedings stayed in Texas due to overlapping cases. Google initially filed a lawsuit in Texas, but Rockstar countered with a California lawsuit, prompting the appeals court to rule that the issue should be decided first in California. The court cited substantial similarity in the infringement and invalidity issues across all suits, with Rockstar paying $4.5 billion for thousands of patents from Nortel Network Corp.

site_title: US SEC needs new standards for investing in private deals: panel
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) Investor Advisory Committee recommends revisiting 1980s-era rules governing private stock deals, suggesting a new approach to defining "accredited investors" based on financial sophistication rather than income and net worth thresholds. The current standards, which require a net worth of $1 million or annual income of $200,000, are seen as arbitrary and may still put people at risk. The SEC will consider the proposal, which aims to improve investor protection and financial literacy.

site_title: HK pushes back crisis talks with protesters
summary: The Hong Kong government suspended formal talks with pro-democracy protesters after protesters called for more demonstrations, citing the occupation as "uncooperative". The protests, now in their second week, have dwindled to hundreds, but leaders remain committed to their cause, demanding free elections and the resignation of the current Chief Executive. The government has stepped up its criticism of the traffic snarls, and protesters have vowed to continue their civil disobedience unless their demands are met.

site_title: BOJ minutes: some members worry about market volatility
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers expressed concerns about potential market volatility due to diverging views on global economies and monetary policies. Minutes from the September meeting showed that the economy is likely to continue recovering moderately as labor markets and wages improve. Inflation is expected to accelerate in the second half of the fiscal year as the output gap improves.

site_title: MH17 victim found with oxygen mask: Dutch FM
summary: A victim of the Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash, which killed 298 people, was found wearing an oxygen mask, raising questions about whether some passengers knew their plane was doomed. The discovery was made by Dutch prosecutors, who are investigating how the mask ended up around the victim's neck. The investigation has not revealed any conclusive results, and the crash site remains inaccessible due to ongoing fighting. The Dutch government regrets the timing of the announcement, which was made before victims' families were informed by prosecutors.

site_title: Stock option volumes soar for biotechs with Ebola drugs
summary: Stock option volumes have surged for biotech companies working on Ebola treatments, with Tekmira Pharmaceuticals and Chimerix seeing significant increases. Investors are betting on the companies' potential to find a cure, driving up trading activity in their stock options. Trading volumes have soared, with Tekmira options volume nearly eight times the combined options trading volume in the stock for the first seven months of the year. The surge in trading activity reflects investors' optimism about the companies' prospects, despite concerns about the spread of the disease.

site_title: Gorbachev hospitalised, 'determined to fight for life'
summary: Former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, 83, has been hospitalized in Russia due to deteriorating health, citing a "moderate" condition. Gorbachev, who served as Soviet leader from 1985, is determined to fight for his life. He has been hospitalized before, in June 2013, for a general check-up, and is also diabetic. Gorbachev's health issues come as he continues to criticize Russian President Vladimir Putin and advocate for reforms.

site_title: Mobile wallet adoption years away: eMarketer
summary: US mobile wallet adoption is expected to rise, but consumers won't quickly abandon cash or credit cards. eMarketer forecasts $3.5 billion in smartphone purchases this year, jumping 150% to $8.5 billion in 2015, and $27.47 billion by 2016. Apple's introduction of Apple Pay is expected to boost awareness, but widespread adoption remains years away. Merchants' incorporation of mobile payment systems into checkout processes will play a crucial role in winning over consumers.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble fends off pressure to spend more
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble denied Germany was falling into recession, contradicting IMF pressure to increase spending to revive the eurozone economy. Schaeuble instead called for Italy and France to implement structural reforms and warned against further monetary policy easing, citing "moral hazard." He acknowledged Germany needed to prioritize investment, but rejected the idea of increasing spending, stating "you can't always spend other people's money in a monetary union." Schaeuble also downplayed fears of a German recession, citing geopolitical risks and the impact of eurozone woes on Germany's export-oriented economy.

site_title: US: Wall Street sells off on growth concerns; volatility picks up
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the S&P 500 posting its largest percentage decline in six months, as concerns over the global economy and corporate earnings took hold. Weak data from Germany and comments from a Fed official fueled market jitters, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 1.97% and the S&P 500 losing 2.07%. Energy shares were particularly hard hit, with crude oil prices reaching their lowest level since December 2012. The market's volatility surged, with the CBOE Volatility Index jumping over 24% to its highest level since early February.

site_title: Ford says Sept China auto sales dipped 0.2% y-o-y
summary: Ford Motor Co reported a 0.2% year-over-year decline in September China auto sales, with 95,875 vehicles sold. This follows a 9% increase in August and a 25% rise in July. For the first nine months of the year, Ford's sales totaled 813,412 vehicles, up 26% from the same period last year.

site_title: Swiss banking secrecy set to end in 2018
summary: Switzerland's banking secrecy is set to end in 2018 as the government launches talks with other nations on the automatic exchange of account details. This move comes after years of pressure from the US and EU to crack down on tax cheats who stash cash abroad. Switzerland has agreed to introduce the statutory basis for the automatic exchange of information in a timely manner, with the first exchange of information possible in 2018, subject to parliamentary approval. The country has lagged behind 40 nations that have already adopted new international standards, but aims to introduce the new system to defend the overall principle of privacy.

site_title: GIC leads US$150m investment in mobile payments startup Square
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC led a US$150 million venture-capital round in Square, a mobile payments startup, valuing the company at US$6 billion. This investment, alongside those from Goldman Sachs and Rizvi Traverse Management, brings total funding to over US$590 million since 2009. GIC sees Square as a key player in accelerating mobile payment adoption among small and medium businesses, despite the company's recent struggles to turn a profit.

site_title: Australia's volatile jobs numbers cloud visibility for central bank, investors
summary: Australia's volatile jobs numbers have made it challenging for the central bank and investors to gauge the impact of record-low interest rates on the economy. The number of employed people fell by 29,700 in September, after rising 32,100 in August, due to "unusual volatility" in key labour figures. This lack of clarity complicates the central bank's policy-making, particularly in guiding the economy toward domestically-driven growth. Analysts warn that the uncertainty will make it harder for the Reserve Bank of Australia to adjust interest rates, which has been at 2.5% since last year.

site_title: Ports tighten rules to curb spread of Ebola
summary: Brazillian ports, along with Argentina and the US, have tightened port entry procedures for ships from West Africa in an effort to control the spread of the Ebola virus. The move comes as the virus has killed over 3,400 people in Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Liberia, raising concerns for trade, airline, and tourism industries. This measure aims to minimize the risk of Ebola transmission and protect global seaborne activity.

site_title: Genting S'pore fights to stay above S$1.10 levels
summary: Genting Singapore's stock price rose 2.5 cents, or 2.3%, to S$1.115 after dipping below S$1.10 for the third time in recent weeks following its post-quarterly results decline. The stock has been trading above S$1.10 levels for the past week, with increased trading activity. Analyst UOB-Kay Hian upgraded the stock to "buy" and maintained a target price of S$1.32, citing limited downside risk. Genting Singapore is seen as a potential front-runner for a Japanese integrated resort project if a casino bill is passed.

site_title: Visceral lens' eye view
summary: Tan Ngiap Heng, a 48-year-old Singaporean, holds a PhD in engineering but has never worked as an engineer. Instead, he pursued a career in photography, particularly dance photography, after a year at a contemporary dance school in London. His recent exhibition, "Body of Work," at the ION Art Gallery features dance and portrait photography series, including long-exposure shots with LED lights. The exhibition also includes a three-screen video installation, "Stealing Breath, Stopping Time," which explores the physical reactions of the artist's body to dance performances.

site_title: The hedge fund king
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, is considered the "king of hedge funds" after his firm became the world's largest, with a staff of 1,500 and assets under management exceeding $150 billion. Dalio, 65, has a net worth of $15.2 billion and has been a successful investor since 1994 when the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation (GIC) recruited him as an external fund manager. His unconventional approach to investing and corporate culture has contributed to Bridgewater's success, with a client base including top sovereign wealth funds and institutional investors.

site_title: Anatomy of a failed marriage
summary: The film "Gone Girl" is a dark and devious look at the breakdown of a marriage, directed by David Fincher. Based on Gillian Flynn's novel, the movie follows the story of Nick and Amy Dunne, whose seemingly perfect marriage turns out to be a facade. After Amy's disappearance, Nick becomes the prime suspect, and as the investigation unfolds, the couple's twisted and sinister relationship is revealed. With no clear heroes or villains, the film is a psychological thriller that explores the complexities of marriage and the media's role in shaping public opinion.

site_title: Ebola fears spread as Spanish nurse worsens, British man tested
summary: A Spanish nurse's worsening condition amid the Ebola outbreak has raised global fears of the disease spreading. A British man who died in Macedonia is being tested for the virus, and US lawmakers are demanding travel bans on citizens of Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. The US and Britain have announced airline passenger screenings for fever and Ebola symptoms. The calls for travel bans come after the first US Ebola death and increased global concerns.

site_title: Zynga revamps hit 'Words With Friends' game
summary: Zynga revamped its hit mobile game "Words With Friends" to regain its footing in the mobile age, releasing a new version with solo play offline and a dictionary for learning words. The game, which has become the top free game of all time at Apple's App Store, has 55 million matches happening at any time. The move comes as Zynga's new CEO Don Mattrick tries to revive the company, which has seen reported losses widen to $62.5 million in the second quarter and revenues drop to $153 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat on global growth concerns, China tariff
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.7% on Friday due to concerns over global economic growth and China's decision to levy import tariffs on coal, affecting the competitiveness of Australian miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 89.3 points to 5,207.4, its biggest one-day percentage drop since February, reaching eight-month lows.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Barclays to pay US$20m to settle Libor suit
summary: Barclays has agreed to pay $20 million to settle a US lawsuit over manipulation of the London interbank offered rate (Libor) between 2005 and 2010. The payment also allows the plaintiffs to pursue claims against other banks. The settlement aims to encourage other defendants to settle, with Barclays providing information to help identify new defendants. This is the first US antitrust litigation settlement over Libor-linked investments.

site_title: MAS moves to strengthen Singapore's Reit sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released a consultation paper to strengthen the country's real estate investment trust (Reit) market. The proposals aim to improve corporate governance and align fees with unitholders' interests. Key changes include increasing independence for Reits from their sponsors, regulating performance fees, and implementing stricter rules on acquisition and divestment fees. The move is seen as a response to long-running issues in the Reit sector, including unfair fees and excessive asset purchases. The consultation paper is expected to improve the Reit market's transparency and fairness.

site_title: Amazon.com to open first physical store: report
summary: Amazon plans to open its first physical store in New York, located across from the Empire State Building, ahead of the year-end holiday season. The store will serve as a warehouse for quick deliveries, returns, and exchanges, rather than a browsing space. This move aims to provide a tangible link to customers and enhance the online shopping experience. The store's opening marks a significant expansion of Amazon's retail presence and reflects the company's efforts to bridge the gap between online and offline shopping.

site_title: Over 200 Marina One units sold, mostly to bulk buyers
summary: Over 200 units of Marina One Residences have been sold, mostly to bulk buyers, with a sales rate of over 85% for multi-unit purchasers. The 242 units released include 1 and 2-bedroom apartments priced from S$1,960 to S$3,100 psf. The developer has received an overwhelming response, exceeding its initial target of 150-200 units. The public launch for the remaining units is set to begin on Saturday.

site_title: Aligning tax and business
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is implementing a major overhaul of international tax laws to combat tax avoidance, known as the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project. Multinational corporations with cross-border operations must reassess their tax practices to prepare for the changes. The OECD's 15 BEPS Actions, including country-by-country reporting and transfer pricing rules, aim to close tax loopholes and align profit allocation with business operations. Companies are advised to review their tax models, engage with tax functions, and document value creation to comply with the new regulations.

site_title: Renewed push to give EM nations more IMF power
summary: A renewed push by Asian and emerging-market nations to gain more power at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is on track, with a "lame duck" US Congress session potentially approving reforms in November. The reforms, agreed upon in 2010, would give China, India, and other BRIC members more influence at the Fund, potentially moving them into the top 10 effective shareholders or quota holders. Passage of the enabling resolution would also allow for a doubling of IMF quotas and financial resources to take effect.

images.alt_text: A GROUP of Asian and other "dynamic" emerging-market (EM) nations may finally be within sight of achieving more say in the Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) after being forced to wait several years for a promised bigger place at the table - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Reset, change manpower mindset
summary: A Singaporean business leader urges the government to adopt a more focused approach to its manpower policy, prioritizing jobs that Singaporeans want rather than trying to attract them to jobs they don't want. The current "one size fits all" approach is seen as fueling wage inflation. The leader also advocates for a Fair Consideration Framework that allows for judicious use of global talent, and an end to age discrimination, ensuring equal pay and treatment for all working Singaporeans regardless of age.

site_title: Tiger sub-leases 12 jets to IndiGo, makes S$93m provision
summary: Budget airline Tiger Airways sub-leases 12 aircraft to Indian carrier IndiGo as it seeks to reduce excess capacity amid market overcapacity. The sub-lease arrangement will lower related leasing costs and bring down cash flow burden by about S$162 million. Tiger will make a one-off accounting provision of S$93 million and review various funding options, including a potential rights issue, to strengthen its balance sheet. The sub-leased planes will be delivered to IndiGo over six months, with seven expected to be integrated into Tiger's fleet upon return.

site_title: Disruptive forces on horizon for Singapore digital banking
summary: Singapore's traditional banks face disruption from emerging digital banks and non-bank players, despite being regulated. Innovations in mobile payments and social lending are on the horizon, with online lenders offering better rates and faster response times. However, traditional banks highlight the importance of regulation to prevent overborrowing. DBS and OCBC have been engaging with younger users through social media, while UOB is exploring Twitter integration. Regulators are expected to catch up with non-bank players, and Singapore banks are working to improve data analytics and customer service to stay competitive.

site_title: Coming out of the darkroom
summary: Gwen Lee, co-founder and director of the Singapore International Photo Festival, has been instrumental in transforming the photography landscape in Singapore. Since co-founding the festival in 2008 and Singapore's first contemporary photography gallery, 2902 Gallery, Lee has promoted and sold photography in Singapore, helping local photographers gain recognition and sales. The festival has grown, attracting over 800 works by 105 photographers from 35 countries, and has gained traction, with visitor numbers reaching 60,000 in 2012. Despite limited government funding, the festival remains a ground-up effort, with Lee and her team securing sponsorships and collaborations with major art museums to provide venues and exhibition spaces.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) has drifted down to S$0.50 after posting worse-than-expected Q2 FY14 earnings. However, soy prices appear to be bottoming and plantation owners may benefit from the absence of export taxes on CPO. OCBC Investment Research downgrades FY14 CPO price assumption to US$760/ton, reducing revenue and earnings estimates by 3%. The research firm upgrades its valuation call to "hold".

site_title: It's a cloudy setting for banks' data crawl
summary: Banks are struggling to adopt cloud computing due to security concerns, limiting the potential benefits of storing and retrieving data in the cloud. Despite this, some digital banks, such as Fidor Bank, are successfully using cloud-based services for global payments and digital rights management. To address security issues, banks are exploring alternative methods, such as processing payments without client data. Retaining customer loyalty remains a priority as banks balance digital and physical platforms.

site_title: Castaway on a private island
summary: Three luxury eco-resorts in the Asia-Pacific region have opened, offering a luxurious twist to island living while prioritizing environmental sustainability and community involvement. The Brando in French Polynesia features a deep seawater air-conditioning system and supports marine wildlife conservation. Nihiwatu in Indonesia has a bio-fuel produced from coconuts and a 90% local staff ratio, with profits going to a community-based foundation. Song Saa Private Island in Cambodia has a marine reserve and supports the local population through livelihood projects and environmental education.

site_title: Sime offers £1.07b for London-listed PNG firm
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby launched a £1.07 billion takeover offer for PNG's New Britain Palm Oil Ltd (NBPOL), a 85% premium viewed as pricey by some. The conglomerate defended the offer as a rare opportunity to expand geographically and upstream. The deal, conditional on 51% acceptance, will see Sime delist NBPOL from the London Stock Exchange and re-list it on Bursa Malaysia or Singapore Exchange. NBPOL's state-owned government has given its support, and independent directors have recommended accepting the offer.

images.alt_text: Mr Bakke said there was no reason for Kulim not to take up the offer as Sime had fulfilled all tender conditions while the PNG government intends to keep its 18 per cent stake in NBPOL.

site_title: SRX: HDB Sept resale prices down again
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.5% in September, marking the 8th consecutive month of declines, according to flash estimates from the Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX). Despite the price drops, resale transaction volumes increased 10.7% from August. Consultants attribute the increase in volumes to buyers returning to the market after the Hungry Ghost Festival and the weak buying interest. Resale rental prices also declined, with overall rents down 2.5% from last year. Experts predict a 5-8% fall in resale HDB prices for the whole year.

site_title: GIC and Bridgewater: A 20-year friendship
summary: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation (GIC) and Bridgewater Associates, a global investment firm, have formed a 20-year friendship despite being external fund managers. The unlikely partnership was established in 1994, when GIC hired Bridgewater, then a small and untested firm, as one of its external managers. Over the years, the two organizations have learned from each other, with GIC gaining valuable insights and Bridgewater benefiting from GIC's resources. The relationship is characterized by mutual consideration, open debate, and a focus on doing the right thing, with both parties achieving high returns and a strong working relationship.

site_title: Time for Globalscepticism?
summary: The article questions the effectiveness of globalization in achieving economic prosperity and peaceful coexistence, citing the Gaza Strip and Middle East as examples of its failure. It argues that the "Political Man" has overpowered the "Economic Man," leading to sectarian and tribal conflicts rather than open markets. The article also notes that globalization has awakened insecurities among citizens facing economic and social inequalities, leading to nationalist and xenophobic movements. Despite this, the author concludes that globalization is here to stay, but policymakers must reassess the myths surrounding its success and adopt a more nuanced approach, recognizing different policy responses for various countries and societies.

site_title: Industrial property likely to stay mixed in Q4
summary: Singapore's industrial property market is expected to remain mixed in Q4 due to persistent downside risks, including global economic uncertainties and a traditional year-end lull. Replacement anchor sub-tenants will struggle to find space, leading to stronger bargaining power and potential rent and yield pressure for third-party facility providers. Rents for business parks and high-spec buildings are expected to hold steady, while prime conventional industrial segment rents may ease marginally due to supply pressures.

site_title: Cyber security threat is a business, not just IT, risk
summary: A global study by PwC found that there were 117,339 cyber attacks per day worldwide in 2013, with an estimated 42.8 million attacks in 2013. This number is expected to increase as cyber threats become more coordinated and planned. The Singapore government has taken steps to combat cybercrime, but experts believe that enterprises need to improve their preparedness, including implementing intrusion detection systems and changing their approach to cyber security. Failure to do so can disrupt business operations and damage a company's reputation.

site_title: Easing of mortgage rules in China lifts demand for homes
summary: China's mortgage rules have been relaxed, easing demand for homes and stabilizing the property market. The central bank's policy change allows second-home buyers to enjoy the same 30% downpayment ratio as first-time buyers and lower interest rates, boosting potential home buyers' confidence. This has led to a surge in home sales, with over 20 transactions brokered in a week, according to real estate agents. The market sentiment is improving, with some cities reporting record-high sales, but experts predict that house prices will continue to fall in the near future.

site_title: An invitation to all foodies
summary: The article highlights the best food halls in the world, offering a range of gourmet and artisanal options. These food halls, such as Peck in Milan and Eliseevsky in Moscow, are not only culinary destinations but also tourist attractions. They feature a variety of prepared and ready-to-make food items, allowing visitors to indulge in their favorite dishes. The article does not provide specific details on the food halls, instead focusing on their unique offerings and historical significance.

site_title: Private collector parts with Indian miniatures
summary: Jamshed K Fozdar, an 88-year-old American citizen, is selling his collection of 35 Indian miniature paintings at an exhibition in Singapore. The paintings, which average A4 size, are 200-300 years old and depict historical and legendary aspects of Indian culture. Fozdar, a collector for over 50 years, is selling the collection due to his mortality and to allow others to appreciate these unique, naturally made artworks. Prices range from S$3,500 to S$12,000, reflecting the rarity and value of the vegetable-dyed paintings and natural elements used.

site_title: Rail and bridge subcontracts worth S$76.6m for Yongnam Holdings
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured three subcontracts worth S$76.6m for work on the Thomson-East Coast MRT Line in Singapore and a project in Hong Kong. The subcontracts include supplying, installing, and dismantling steel struts and pipe pile cofferdam systems. The deals are expected to be completed in 48 months and are expected to have a favourable impact on the group's financial performance. Yongnam has a strong track record in developing Singapore's MRT infrastructure since the 1980s.

site_title: Debate over Reit governance not over yet
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed changes to strengthen governance in Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) and Reit managers, aiming to mitigate the "agency problem" where managers may prioritize their own interests over those of investors. The proposals include restrictions on Reit managers' fees, increased board independence, and improved alignment of interests between managers and unitholders. While MAS has stopped short of taking a stand on whether Reits should be internally or externally managed, industry players believe that internal management structures may eventually become more prevalent in Singapore.

site_title: Sartorial storytelling
summary: Shentonista.sg, a Singapore-based street style blog, has been chronicling the sartorial habits of common people in the business district for six years. Founded by Darren Lee, the site initially featured interview-based content and has evolved to showcase stylish individuals in the area. Lee's approach focuses on the person behind the outfit, offering a unique perspective on fashion choices. Despite the rise of social media, Lee believes that street style blogs will continue to thrive, as they provide a platform for showcasing individuality and style. The site aims to put Singapore on the global map by highlighting the country's fashion-conscious citizens.

images.alt_text: From left: Lesley Chee, 23, Cheng Shu Yar, 27 and Darren Lee, 34 of Uniform.com.sg, the trio who work on street fashion blog Shentonista that Darren started.

site_title: Sharp drop in German, French exports casts pall on eurozone
summary: A sharp drop in exports from Germany and France has cast a pall on the eurozone, with Germany's trade surplus shrinking to 17.5 billion euros and France's trade deficit rising to 5.8 billion euros in August. German exports contracted by 5.8% and French exports by 1.3%, with exports to countries outside Europe slumping by 4.7%. Analysts attribute the weakness to the Ukraine crisis, but some predict a short-term slowdown. The German economy contracted in the second quarter, and a renewed drop in the third quarter could put the country in recession, sparking concerns about the eurozone's economic stability.

site_title: Turnaround in US fuels rate hike debates
summary: The US economy is experiencing a strong boom, with record-high household wealth, a 4.2% GDP growth rate, and a 5.9% jobless rate in September. Despite concerns about potential rate hikes, analysts believe the economy will continue to grow, particularly during the holiday shopping season. The Federal Reserve is expected to debate rate hikes, with hawks arguing for a stronger economy and doves warning about the risk of deflation. Fed Chair Janet Yellen is seen as dovish, and her position on "considerable time" is closely watched for signs of a potential rate hike.

images.alt_text: Orders for durable goods expanded by the most on record in July, reflecting the rise in US household wealth, which hit a new high in the second quarter.

site_title: Asian deal boom points to more buys
summary: Asian real estate dealmaking has reached a record $34 billion last quarter, surpassing the global financial crisis. Key deals include a Hyundai-led group's $10 billion purchase in Seoul's Gangnam district and Frasers Centrepoint's $3 billion bid for Australand Property Group. This boom is expected to continue, with more firms, such as CapitaRetail China and Saizen, being targeted as potential acquisition targets. The surge in dealmaking suggests a strong appetite for Asian property investments, driven by economic growth and increasing demand for real estate assets.

site_title: Weak housing market in China blights the other sectors as well
summary: China's housing market slowdown is likely affecting other sectors, including imports, investment, and retail sales, which may have reached multi-month or multi-year lows in September. This raises concerns about the country's economic growth, with fading momentum worldwide contributing to the slowdown. Policymakers are under pressure to address the issue, as the sagging housing market increasingly weighs on the economy. The slowdown is expected to continue, with Citigroup predicting a 1,150 target for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: A slow day in a Hefei market in Anhui province in September reflects the slow-down in retail sales in China. It has raised questions on whether policy makers should do more to jump-start the economy.

site_title: More than meets the eye
summary: The 4th Singapore International Photography Festival features various exhibitions, film screenings, and workshops at multiple venues, with most exhibitions free and some requiring a S$50 festival pass for talks and screenings. Notable exhibitions include "Still Moving" at SAM At 8Q, showcasing works from the Deutsche Bank collection and featuring renowned photographers like Andreas Gursky and Gerhard Richter, and "4th Open Call Showcase" at the National Museum of Singapore, featuring 47 photographers from 23 countries. The festival also includes exhibitions at the ArtScience Museum.

site_title: China auteur tests the limits
summary: Mainland Chinese filmmaker Lou Ye continues to push boundaries with his gritty and realistic films, despite facing censorship and bans in his homeland. His breakthrough film, Suzhou River (2000), will be screened at the Perspectives Film Festival in Singapore, which explores themes of displacement. Lou has faced controversy and restrictions for his work, including a two-year ban after screening Suzhou River without approval. However, his recent films have received critical acclaim and nominations, including Blind Massage, which is up for several Golden Horse awards.

site_title: One dead, a dozen hurt in grenade blast in Kuala Lumpur
summary: A grenade blast in Kuala Lumpur's Bukit Bintang neighborhood killed one person and injured a dozen others, including a parking attendant who died later. The incident is suspected to be related to a gangland turf battle. Police found an unexploded grenade at the scene and believe the motive is being investigated. Authorities have ruled out terrorist involvement, but a gangland feud is suspected. Such incidents are rare in Muslim-majority Malaysia, which has seen a rise in crime and public concern.

images.alt_text: A MAN was killed and a dozen other people wounded in Kuala Lumpur early on Thursday when a hand grenade exploded in a tourist section of Malaysia's capital city, in an incident police suspect to be related to a gangland turf battle - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Clampdown likely on banks' 'excessive' risk-model variation
summary: Global regulators are set to implement stricter measures to prevent banks from understating credit risk, as a report by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision reveals "excessive" variability in models used to assess credit risk and measure capital needs. The report proposes introducing a non-risk-based leverage ratio and floors or benchmarks, requiring banks to publish their capital requirements based on simpler, non-model based approaches. This aims to improve transparency and constrain the degrees of freedom banks have when using their models, following studies that found unexplained differences in risk weightings for identical assets.

site_title: Analysts upbeat on S'pore banks ahead of results
summary: Analysts have expressed optimism about Singapore banks ahead of their results announcements, with HSBC upgrading OCBC Bank to "overweight" and raising its target price to S$13, and Jefferies maintaining its "buy" call on DBS Group Holdings while lifting its target price to S$21. The upgrades are attributed to clearer earnings outlooks for OCBC and diversified business segments for DBS. The research community is generally positive about the Singapore lenders, with DBS having 24 "buys" and four "holds" and OCBC having 14 "buys" and nine "holds".

site_title: Da Vinci building in Upper Bukit Timah sold for S$58m
summary: Sim Lian Holdings has acquired the Da Vinci building at 191 Upper Bukit Timah Road in Singapore for S$58 million. The building, which has a land area of 21,415 sq ft and a gross floor area of nearly 30,000 sq ft, will be leased out after the seller vacates the property. The sale was brokered by ERA Legends Division, a member of Prime Group. Managing director Ken Kuik plans to redevelop the combined land with the adjacent Sim Lian Holdings' headquarters building, potentially creating a larger commercial complex.

site_title: BuildTech Asia to focus on latest technologies, innovations
summary: BuildTech Asia 2014, a trade show for the built environment sector, will focus on the latest technologies and innovations to enhance productivity amidst a tightening labour supply in large Asian markets. The event, held from Oct 14-16, will feature over 200 exhibiting brands showcasing the latest products and services in building information modelling, construction IT, prefabricated systems, and smart materials. Industry professionals and foreign visitors are expected to attend, with conferences on facilities management and sustainability also being held.

site_title: Crude imports to US Midwest hit new high
summary: US crude imports to the Midwest surged to a record 2.53 million barrels a day in the week ending Oct 3, driven by anticipation of a new pipeline linking the region to Cushing, Oklahoma. Deliveries from Canada, mainly through the Midwest, reached 3 million barrels a day for the first time. The pipeline's opening is expected to increase oil access to the Chicago area and reduce the need for urgent shipments, helping to narrow the discount for Canadian heavy crude.

site_title: New Zealand CPI components to include pet ownership
summary: New Zealand's consumer price index (CPI) will include pet ownership costs starting from the third quarter, with additions including kitten and dog purchases, pet food, and accessories. The index will also include breakfast drinks and women's dresses, while removing squash club memberships, tennis rackets, and car alarms due to declining expenditure. The country's CPI rose 1.6% in the second quarter, expected to slow to 1.3% in the third quarter. Statistics New Zealand is adjusting the CPI weight and using retail transaction data to measure price changes for consumer electronics.

site_title: Sa Sa's HK retail sales drop 1% due to Occupy Central protests
summary: Sa Sa International Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-based skincare retailer, reported a 1% drop in retail sales during China's Golden Week holiday due to civil unrest in its home market. This contrasts with an 11% rise in sales the previous year. The company attributed the decline to reduced shopping activity during the protests.

site_title: Tech firms lead ranking of brands
summary: The 2014 Interbrand Best Global Brands report ranks technology firms as the top brands, with Apple taking the lead for a second year, valued at $118.9 billion. Google is the No 2 brand, valued at $107.4 billion, while Microsoft and Samsung also feature in the top 10. The technology category is the most valuable, with a total value of $493.2 billion, and Facebook, a technology brand, saw the highest percentage increase in value, 86%. However, concerns over data security and the use of behavioral data for marketing purposes may impact consumer confidence in these brands.

site_title: S'pore will join fight against climate change, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the country's commitment to addressing climate change, despite potential impacts on its energy and chemicals sector. The government will work with companies to develop the industry sustainably and support international efforts to mitigate climate change. Singapore has grown its petrochemical industry sustainably and will continue to support its growth, while also addressing environmental concerns through initiatives like co-generation plants.

site_title: Drawing out dualities in molten metal
summary: French artist Val Goutard, based in Bangkok, creates sculptures that highlight the duality of bronze, a weighty yet fragile metal. Her goal is to represent human sensitivity on a monumental scale, evoking emotions without being overshadowed by size. Goutard, a former marketing professional, achieved her full-time passion in just two years after dedicating two years to pursuing her art. Her work showcases the balance of dualities, bringing a sense of balance and human sensitivity to monumental scales.

site_title: Modi to states: capitalise on foreign investment boom
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged states to capitalize on a foreign investment boom worth $100 billion, following diplomatic interactions with Japan, China, and the US. The central government will support states in facilitating investment and boosting economic growth. States with business-friendly policies are expected to attract the largest portions of international investment. Modi's government has launched a "Make in India" campaign to turn the country into a manufacturing hub and implement business-friendly policies, aiming to improve living standards in emerging markets.

site_title: Hub for surface engineering firms opens
summary: Singapore has opened a S$59 million JTC Surface Engineering Hub @ Tanjong Kling, a centralized facility for the surface-engineering industry. The hub, built using precast and prefabrication technology, features a centralized wastewater treatment plant and offers support services like testing and certification, chemical solution supplies, and laboratories. The facility aims to promote land optimization, collaborative synergies, and knowledge sharing among surface-engineering companies and their complementary businesses, creating jobs and boosting industries in the value chain.

site_title: Small-car COE premium rises; big-car demand flat
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) bidding exercise saw small-car demand strengthen, with Category A prices rising from S$1,880 to S$63,880. In contrast, big-car demand remained flat. Category C, for goods vehicles, jumped S$7,500 to S$57,389, and Category D, for motorcycles, rose S$296 to S$4,800. These results indicate a shift in consumer preference towards smaller vehicles in the Singaporean market.

site_title: The plot thickens with new Secretary of State
summary: Madam Secretary, a new White House TV drama, premiered on Sony Channel, starring Tea Leoni as Elisabeth McCord, an ex-CIA-analyst-turned-professor who becomes the new Secretary of State after the plane carrying the previous Secretary goes down. The show, created by Barbara Hall, balances intrigue, entertainment, and originality, with Leoni bringing charisma to the title role. While the pilot episode has some over-patriotic moments, it sets up the show for future episodes with a curve ball that adds to the series' potential, earning a "B" rating.

site_title: Price cuts no quick cure for Tesco's ills
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest grocer, is struggling to regain market share due to a price war with discounters Aldi and Lidl. The company's new boss, Dave Lewis, plans to cut costs and offer cheaper prices to win back customers, but analysts say it will take years to make an impact. Tesco's UK trading margin is expected to fall to 2.5% in 2014-15, down from 5.03% in 2013-14. The company's shares have fallen £4 billion in value due to an accounting scandal and declining sales. Tesco's strategy must address its economic model and become more competitive to regain its market position.

site_title: London most attractive city for business: survey
summary: London has been ranked as the most attractive city for business and innovation, surpassing New York, Paris, and Tokyo according to the Mori Memorial Foundation's Global Power City Index. The survey considers factors such as economy, research, cultural interaction, and liveability. London has held the top spot since 2008, while Singapore remains in fifth place. The ranking aims to identify challenges for Tokyo to become a more attractive city.

site_title: Chronicler of Punk
summary: Sheila Rock, an art student, captured iconic punk images on Kings Road in 1970s London, becoming a chronicler of the punk movement. Her photographs, now on display at the Substation Gallery, showcase punk icons like The Sex Pistols and The Clash. Rock's work, taken between 1976 and 1979, remains fresh and influential, offering a glimpse into the cultural revolution of the time. The exhibit, Punk+, highlights Rock's unique perspective and skill as a photographer, providing a lasting visual record of the punk era.

site_title: Taking to the water
summary: New travel options are emerging, offering diverse experiences on the water. Smaller cruise lines are exploring new destinations, such as New Guinea and the South Pacific, while larger companies are launching river cruises in South-east Asia and beyond. Luxury travel companies like Paul Gauguin Cruises and Belmond offer exclusive itineraries, and traditional Bugis schooners and tall ships are also available for charter. River expedition companies like Pandaw River Expeditions and Aqua Mekong are offering luxury river cruises in Vietnam and Cambodia, featuring sophisticated designs and gourmet dining.

site_title: Greenback weakens on Fed's cautious language
summary: The US dollar weakened to a three-week low against the yen on Thursday after minutes of the Federal Reserve's last meeting showed policymakers were cautious about raising interest rates. Investors cut favorable bets, pushing out expectations for a rate rise until around September 2015, leading to a 0.5% decline in the dollar's value against the yen. The dollar index also fell to its lowest level in two weeks, while the euro rose to its highest level in two weeks, gaining nearly three cents against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: THE US dollar fell to a three-week low against the yen on Thursday as investors cut favourable bets after minutes of the Federal Reserve's last meeting prompted many to push out expectations for the likely timing of an interest rate rise - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Opposition steps up pressure to undermine incoming Jokowi govt
summary: Indonesia's opposition, led by Prabowo Subianto, is intensifying pressure on the incoming government of President-elect Joko Widodo, threatening his reform agenda and tenure. The opposition seized leadership positions in the Lower House and secured power to appoint local leaders, and Aburizal Bakrie, a billionaire tycoon, has proposed amending the Constitution to limit presidential elections. The opposition's strategy is seen as a bold assault on the new administration, with some reports suggesting plans to impeach Jokowi soon after his inauguration. However, Jokowi's massive popularity and the opposition's internal divisions may hinder their efforts.

site_title: City Buzz
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

In Singapore, chef Asai Masashi from Japanese yakitori bar Bincho is collaborating with Spanish tapas bar Moosehead's Manel Valero for a culinary exchange. The two chefs will serve re-interpretations of each other's dishes, such as Bincho's charcoal oven-cooked pig ears and Moosehead's tsukune. Meanwhile, Matthew Bourne's all-male Swan Lake production is making its Esplanade debut, while a group show exhibition "Countershadows" explores themes of camouflage and concealment. The Kings & Queen of Comedy Asia 2014 returns with US comedians and Singaporean stars, and Archifest 2014 showcases architecture and design.

site_title: Asean needs deeper financial integration
summary: A Moody's report states that Asean's fragmented financial markets limit regional expansion for companies, citing low cross-border acquisitions and high domestic funding costs. Despite the Asean Economic Community (AEC) initiative, which aims for deeper financial integration by 2015, progress is slow due to disparities in domestic regulation and corporate governance. The report suggests that companies in Singapore and Malaysia dominate cross-border acquisitions, while Thailand's richest man Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi has been expanding his business through acquisitions.

site_title: S-E Asia boosts efforts to lure skilled citizens back home
summary: Malaysia is boosting efforts to attract skilled citizens back home, with many opting to return due to improved job opportunities and quality of life. Former Singaporean expat Kwee Keong Lim, who returned to Kuala Lumpur in 2012, credits the country's investments in industries like oil and gas for his decision. Other key news includes Vietnam's surprise reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and Citigroup's mid-2026 target for the global equity index.

site_title: S Africa's mining stocks hit by strikes, dwindling deposits
summary: South African mining stocks have plummeted to a four-year low due to extended labour strikes, dwindling deposits, and regulatory uncertainty. The country's richest mineral deposits, worth $3.3 trillion, have failed to satisfy investors, with stocks trading at a premium multiple compared to global peers. Mining companies such as Anglo American, BHP Billiton, and AngloGold Ashanti are selling or spinning off assets, citing the challenging operating environment and declining real values of their companies listed on the JSE. The decline is attributed to a "lost decade" of industry performance from 2004 to 2014.

site_title: Wholesale inventories up more than expected
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.7% in August, exceeding expectations, indicating the economy may have grown more than expected in the third quarter. Jobless claims fell to 287,000, the lowest level in eight years, signaling employers are holding onto workers as the economy improves. Sales at wholesalers fell 0.7%, but the four-week average for jobless claims decreased to 287,750, the lowest since 2006. The decline in jobless claims and steady pace of job creation suggest stronger gains in hiring and wages, boosting the US economy.

site_title: CIMB-RHB-MBSB to form Asean powerhouse
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group, RHB Capital, and MBSB have agreed to merge in a deal valued at RM72.5 billion, creating a financial powerhouse with over S$240 billion in assets. The merged entity will include a mega Islamic bank formed by the merger of CIMB Islamic and MBSB's Islamic units. RHB Capital will acquire CIMB, contrary to expectations, and will own 30% of the merged entity. The deal, expected to be completed by mid-2025, will see CIMB shareholders own 70% and RHB shareholders own 30%.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, dropping 81.50 points in the Dow Jones Industrial Average to 16,912.72, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declining. Weak German economic data, a 5.8% drop in exports, heightened concerns about a slowdown in Europe and Asia. Despite improved US economic data, traders are worried about the global economy's growth, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Rabble-rouser who wants to be a model citizen
summary: Glen Matlock, founding member of the influential punk rock band The Sex Pistols, has redefined his image as a "model citizen" after decades of rebellious behavior. Despite his band's brief tenure and chaotic history, Matlock has continued to play music, tour, and reinvent himself. He now aspires to be recognized for his songwriting skills, rather than his association with The Sex Pistols. Matlock, 58, has a wry sense of humor and a desire to leave a lasting legacy beyond his punk rock days.

site_title: Cyber-security incidents rise 48% to 42.8m this year
summary: Cyber-security incidents have risen 48% globally to 42.8 million this year, with the estimated average annual loss from cyber incidents globally increasing to US$2.7 million, a 34% increase over 2013. Company insiders are the most cited culprits of cyber crime, with current employees, service providers, and contractors being the primary causes of incidents. The survey also found that Asia Pacific is a leader in implementing strategic processes and safeguards for information security, with 75.5% of respondents having a chief information security officer.

site_title: Govt asks UK companies to appoint more women to their boards
summary: The British government has requested major UK companies to appoint more women to their boards, citing that only 22.8% of directors are currently female, despite a 10% increase from three years ago. The government's recommendations aim to improve gender equality in the boardroom.

site_title: Fed minutes spur bargain hunting
summary: The US Federal Reserve released its September meeting minutes, signaling a dovish stance to the market. This move helped rescue Singapore stocks from a five-month low, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.01% and ending a three-day losing streak. Trading activity was moderate, with 1.2 billion shares changing hands and a respectable S$1.1 billion in value. The mixed trading activity may indicate that the market is not fully listening to the Fed's signals, which could have implications for future market movements.

images.alt_text: DOVISH minutes released overnight from the US Federal Reserve's September meeting gave bargain hunters the signal that they needed to rescue Singapore stocks on Thursday from a five-month low - ST PHOTO: STEFEN CHOW

site_title: Singapore: Shares up 32.54 points to end the day
summary: Singapore shares rose on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 32.54 points to close at 3,259.25. The benchmark index saw 1.19 billion shares traded worth S$1.05 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 236 to 184.

site_title: Temasek to buy US$82m stake in India's Devyani
summary: Temasek Holdings has agreed to invest US$82 million in Devyani International, the operator of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Costa Coffee chains in India, through a combination of buying a stake and a direct purchase. The deal, valued at S$20.8 million, marks the Singapore state investor's entry into the Indian restaurant market. This investment is part of a growing trend of private equity funds pouring into the Indian market, with US$4.6 billion invested so far this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 5.41 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 5.41 points to 1,829.73. The index saw a trading volume of 1.81 billion lots, valued at RM1.85 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 609 to 229.

site_title: One good Turn deserves a revival
summary: Singapore playwright-director Chong Tze Chien's revival of the 2011 play "Turn By Turn We Turn" is a poignant allegory depicting a traditional hand-puppet troupe's struggles against China's changing politics from the 1920s to the present day. Chong's mastery of poetic storytelling and minimalist set design brings the troupe's fortunes to life, questioning the relevance of the arts in the face of strict authority. The play, now sold out, is part of The Finger Players' 15th-anniversary celebrations, running until Sunday at the Drama Centre Black Box.

site_title: US regulator approves Maersk's vessel sharing pact with MSC
summary: Maersk Line and Mediterranean Shipping Co (MSC) have won US approval for a vessel sharing pact, known as the 2M alliance, which will see 185 ships pooled on European, transatlantic, and transpacific services, saving Maersk $350m annually. The approval comes after a larger alliance proposal was rejected in June due to competition concerns in China. The two carriers still need to win over European and Chinese regulators for the pact, which would give them a 35% market share on key trade routes.

site_title: Apple,Google brands worth more than US$100b each
summary: Apple and Google have become the first two brands to surpass a $100 billion valuation, according to Interbrand's 2014 ranking. Apple rose 21% to $118.9 billion, while Google increased 15% to $107.43 billion. This marks the first time two brands have reached this milestone since the ranking began in 1974. Interbrand considers brand value based on financial performance, consumer influence, and market strength. The ranking also features a new entrant, Huawei, which ranked 94th, and notable movers include Facebook, Audi, and Amazon.

site_title: World Bank launches public-private infrastructure plan
summary: The World Bank launched the Global Infrastructure Facility, a public-private partnership initiative to attract long-term investors to meet the developing world's $1 trillion infrastructure needs over six years. The initiative aims to structure projects to attract pension funds and insurance companies. Banking groups like Citibank and HSBC, and governments from Australia and Japan, have already expressed interest in the project, which aims to address the lack of bankable projects and commercially viable infrastructure investments.

site_title: Tiger Airways to sublease excess planes, mulls rights issue
summary: Tiger Airways, a Singapore-based airline, has agreed to sublease 12 surplus aircraft to Indian budget airline IndiGo as part of a plan to reduce capacity and trim costs. The airline will make a one-off accounting provision of about S$93 million related to the aircraft. This move aims to cut the group's cash flow burden by about S$162 million over the sublease periods. Tiger Airways is also considering a rights issue as part of its efforts to address the over capacity situation in the industry.

site_title: Maersk, MSC ship-sharing pact gets US clearance
summary: Maersk and MSC Mediterranean Shipping Co have secured US clearance for their vessel-sharing pact, allowing them to pool 185 ships on European, trans-Atlantic, and trans-Pacific routes starting in January. The alliance is expected to save Maersk Line $350 million annually, but has raised concerns in China about potential collusion and anti-competitive behavior. Exporters and cargo owners in Europe and Asia have expressed worries, with the China Shippers' Association warning it would monitor the alliance and take action if it harms consumers' interests.

site_title: Patrick Modiano of France wins Nobel Literature Prize
summary: Patrick Modiano, a French novelist, has been awarded the Nobel Literature Prize for his "art of memory" in capturing the lives of ordinary people during Germany's occupation of France from 1940 to 1944. Modiano's work explores themes of memory, identity, and seeking, with his writing style described as a modern-day Marcel Proust. A 69-year-old celebrated writer, Modiano has won several awards, including the Goncourt Prize, and has written extensively about his childhood and the dark period in French history that shaped his work.

site_title: HK calls off talks with student activists
summary: Hong Kong's talks with student activists have been called off, dealing a blow to attempts to defuse the political crisis. The government blamed the students' demands for universal suffrage, which it said was not in accordance with the city's Basic Law. The decision comes as the government investigates a $6.4 million business payout to leader Leung Chun-ying, and democratic lawmakers threaten to veto major decisions to paralyze government operations. The students' next move is unclear, with protests dwindling to a few hundred people.

site_title: CFM confirms trials of new jet engine
summary: CFM International, a joint venture between General Electric and Safran, has confirmed the start of flight trials for its next-generation LEAP engine. The engine is set to power Boeing's 737 MAX aircraft and Airbus's A320neo. CFM aims to secure safety certification in 2015. The LEAP engine is being developed for various aircraft, including Comac's Chinese-made plane. This development marks a significant step forward for CFM and its partners, with the potential to secure a major order for the LEAP engine in the coming years.

site_title: BoE keeps interest rate at 0.50%
summary: The Bank of England maintained its main interest rate at a record-low level of 0.50% and kept the cash stimulus at $608 billion. This decision comes as Britain experiences low inflation and steady economic recovery. The decision was made by the central bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee during its monthly meeting on October 8. The minutes of the meeting will be published on October 22.

site_title: UK watchdog wants comparison sites for payday lenders
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) proposes introducing price comparison websites for payday lenders to ensure a price cap imposed by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) does not become the default rate. Payday lenders, such as Wonga, would be required to provide product details on comparison websites to stimulate price competition. The proposal aims to protect consumers in a market where many currently do not shop around due to unclear information on borrowing costs. Lenders have until the end of the year to respond to the CMA's proposal.

site_title: HK leader under pressure to explain Australian windfall
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, is facing a "huge integrity problem" after receiving large payments from an Australian company while in office. The payments, totaling HK$50 million (US$6.5 million), were kept secret despite Chinese President Xi Jinping's anti-graft crackdown. Opposition lawmakers have called for Leung to explain himself, citing a lack of transparency and undermining public trust. The revelation comes as Leung faces mass pro-democracy protests and a crisis of governance, with approval ratings at an all-time low.

site_title: Gloom over eurozone as top think tanks slash German growth outlook
summary: Top think tanks in the eurozone have slashed their forecasts for German growth, predicting 1.3% growth in 2014 and 1.2% in 2015. The institutes urge the German government to boost public spending to kick-start the economy, citing a need to abandon austerity measures and increase investment in the public sector. The downgrade follows warnings from the IMF and OECD about a loss of momentum in the eurozone recovery, with the German economy stagnating due to weak domestic and foreign demand.

site_title: Thailand's 2014 GDP growth seen at 1.7%: ministry official
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 1.7% this year, slower than the Finance Ministry's previous estimate of 2.0%. The country's exports and investment have not yet recovered, according to Permanent Secretary Rungson Sriworasat. The ministry is set to release a new forecast later this month.

site_title: World food prices dip to 4-year low in Sept
summary: World food prices have dropped to their lowest level in 4 years, averaging 191.5 points in September, according to the UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation. This decline was led by a sharp decrease in dairy and sugar prices. The FAO raised its forecast for global cereal production in 2014 to 2.523 billion tonnes, a new record, and predicted world wheat output to reach 718.5 million tonnes.

site_title: MAS proposes changes to strengthen Reit market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed changes to strengthen the Reit market, aiming to enhance transparency and corporate governance. The proposals include: a statutory duty to prioritize investor interests, stronger independent board members, and increased disclosure requirements. Leverage limits will also be increased, allowing Reits to access more financing options. The consultation paper is available on the MAS website, with comments due by November 10, 2014.

site_title: Small-car COE premium higher
summary: The certificate of entitlement (COE) premium for small cars in Singapore rose in the first October bidding exercise, with Category A increasing to S$63,880 and Category B rising to S$72,180. In contrast, Category E, the open category, decreased to S$72,003. The premiums for big cars, goods vehicles, and motorcycles also saw slight increases. The price hikes are attributed to increased demand and a limited supply of available COE quotas.

site_title: IMF: Eurozone faces 'serious risk' of new recession
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that the eurozone faces a "serious risk" of a new recession if action is not taken to prevent it. IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that while the zone is not heading towards a recession, inaction could lead to one. This warning comes amid economic concerns in the region, but no specific measures were announced to address the issue.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate edges up to 6.1%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 6.1% in September, the highest since July 2003, with 29,700 jobs lost and 51,300 part-time positions cut. The Bureau of Statistics revised down previous months' figures amid uncertainty over data calculation, citing a lack of seasonality in July, August, and September. Economists expect revisions next month, and the Reserve Bank of Australia may rely on forward labour market indicators while the statistics bureau addresses its issues.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on Wall St cues, hopes of more China support measures
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.2% to 23,534.53 points on Thursday, driven by global market gains and expectations of lower interest rates from the Federal Reserve. China's Premier Li Keqiang announced plans for major investment projects in information networks, water conservancy, and environment protection. Key gainers included Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group and HSBC Holdings, while China's Tianhe chemicals Group plummeted 39.4% after a stock research's allegations of cooking its books.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1% supported by banks, Wall Street
summary: Australian shares jumped 1.1% on Thursday, driven by financials and rebounding from 8-month lows. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 55.4 points to 5,296.7, its largest one-day gain since August 12. The US Federal Reserve's indication that it won't raise rates for a "considerable time" supported the rally. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.4%.

site_title: The Super-Tuscans
summary: The "Super-Tuscans" are a group of Italian wines that emerged in the 1970s due to strict naming laws. These wines, made from non-traditional grape blends, were initially unable to be labeled as Chianti under Italy's Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC) regulations. Marchese Piero Antinori led the charge with Tignanello, a blend of Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon, and subsequent wines like Sassicaia and Cepparello. The success of these wines encouraged other growers to follow suit, leading to a new era in Italian winemaking.

site_title: Malaysia's Kesas plans RM735m sukuk programme
summary: Malaysia's Kesas Sdn Bhd plans to raise up to RM735 million through an Islamic bond programme, using the funds to redeem debt, capital expenditure, and working capital. The sukuk programme was rated AA2 or stable by RAM Ratings and comes after Kesas revised toll rates and extended its concession.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 18.26 points to 3,244.97. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data release. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 24, with a total of 25.9 million shares traded worth S$36.6 million.

site_title: 1 dead, 13 hurt in KL grenade blast: police
summary: A grenade blast in Kuala Lumpur's tourist area left one dead and 13 injured, including foreigners. The blast occurred outside a pub in the Bukit Bintang area, and police suspect a hand grenade was used. An unexploded grenade was also found at the scene. A motive is unclear, but a gangland feud is suspected. The incident is rare in Muslim-majority Malaysia, where security concerns have been growing due to potential militant violence and extremist views from the Islamic State group.

site_title: Audi sells fewer cars than Mercedes
summary: Audi sold fewer cars than Mercedes-Benz for the first time this year, with 159,950 vehicles delivered in September, a 6.4% increase. Mercedes-Benz sold 162,746 models, a 14% gain, benefiting from new models and strong demand in China. Audi's sales lead over Mercedes-Benz has shrunk to 103,494 cars after nine months. Despite this, Audi aims to boost full-year sales to above 1.7 million vehicles, while Mercedes-Benz targets 1.46 million cars. The two luxury automakers are vying for the global luxury-sales crown.

site_title: China angered after FBI head says Chinese hacking costs billions
summary: China accused the US of faking facts after FBI Director James Comey stated that Chinese hacking likely costs the US economy billions of dollars annually. China denies wrongdoing, calling the US' claims "unjustified fabrication of facts." China has suspended a working group on cyber issues and demands the US cease its large-scale internet attacks. Many in China view the US as hypocritical, following revelations about its own extensive spying. The US has charged five Chinese military officers with hacking into US companies, further escalating tensions between the two nations.

images.alt_text: China accused the United States on Thursday of faking facts, after the head of the FBI said that Chinese hacking likely cost the US economy billions of dollars every year - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: 117,339 cyber attacks a day globally: PwC
summary: A new study by PwC reveals that the number of reported cyber security incidents globally rose 48% to 42.8 million in 2015, equivalent to 117,339 attacks per day. The estimated average financial loss from cyber incidents increased by 34% to $2.7 million, with big losses exceeding $20 million nearly doubling. The Asia-Pacific region remains a leader in implementing information security strategies and safeguards, but a lack of investment and board-level involvement in managing cyber threats is a concern.

site_title: Singapore HDB resale prices slipped 0.5% in Sept: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices fell 0.5% in September, marking an eighth consecutive decline, according to flash estimates from SRX. This drop was attributed to price declines in three-room, four-room, and five-room flats. In contrast, executive flat prices rose 0.1%. Resale volumes increased 10.7% from August, with a 19.9% rise from last year.

images.alt_text: HOUSING and Development Board (HDB) resale prices could have fallen in an eighth consecutive month, going by flash estimates from the Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX) - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Falling German exports slash trade surplus in August
summary: Germany's trade surplus shrank in August due to a 5.8% drop in exports, the sharpest decline since January 2009. Exports fell to 92.6 billion euros, down from 98.3 billion euros in July, while imports decreased by 1.3% to 75.1 billion euros. The seasonally adjusted trade surplus narrowed to 17.5 billion euros, down from 22.2 billion euros in July. The contraction was largely due to the timing of the summer school holidays.

images.alt_text: A sharp drop in German exports caused the country's trade surplus to contract in August, but largely due to the timing of the summer school holidays, official data showed on Thursday - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Singapore industrial transactions slow in Q3, while business park rents rise
summary: Singapore's industrial transactions declined 36% quarter-on-quarter in Q3, with 203 strata-titled industrial properties sold. This is a significant drop from 672 units sold in the same period last year. Business park rents rose, drawing office occupiers, but conventional industrial space rental values stagnated. A large supply of industrial space, including 40.7 million sq ft by 2016, is expected to restrain rental growth, potentially leading to downward pressure on rents.

site_title: Small stocks, not so small impact
summary: A 2013 penny stock selloff had a significant impact on smaller Singaporean stocks, with the FTSE ST Small Cap Index experiencing its largest one-day decline in almost two years, a 4.1% drop. However, the impact may have been overstated due to limited data available for other benchmarks. The selloff also had far-reaching consequences, including rule changes, market liquidity issues, and investigations, which are still affecting the market today.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks lose early gains to close down 0.75%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.75% on October 9, 2014, despite early gains following the US Federal Reserve's September meeting minutes, which dampened expectations for an earlier interest rate hike. The benchmark Nikkei fell 117.05 points to 15,478.93, while the Topix index slipped 1.10% to 1,260.78. The stronger yen was cited as a contributing factor to the decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound as Wall Street rallies on Fed minutes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% on Thursday, rebounding from 9-month lows, after the US Federal Reserve indicated it would not raise interest rates for a "considerable time." The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 66.8 points to 5,308.1, driven by gains in financials, including Westpac Banking Corp and Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Despite a decline in iron ore prices and a rise in bond yields, the market showed resilience, with the materials sector leading gains.

site_title: Italy's Renzi faces confidence vote over labour reform
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi faces a confidence vote on labour reform, with the vote expected to pass despite opposition from hard-line labour unions. The proposed changes aim to simplify firing procedures and boost job creation, but details remain unclear. A successful vote would bolster Renzi's EU credentials and aid his push for economic reforms, including an expansionary 2015 budget to stimulate the stagnant economy.

site_title: Australia employment slips in Sept, but data in doubt
summary: Australia's employment data for September showed a net 29,700 jobs lost, with full-time jobs rising 21,600 and part-time jobs falling. However, the figures are disputed due to the Australian Bureau of Statistics' decision to report raw, unadjusted data instead of seasonal adjustments, which were previously restated. The unemployment rate ticked up to 6.1% from 6.0%. Analysts and financial markets are skeptical of the data, citing leading indicators of labor demand suggesting future employment growth.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime increases stake in Subtech Saudi Arabia to 95%
summary: Mermaid Maritime has increased its stake in Subtech Saudi Arabia to 95% by acquiring General Technology & Systems Co Ltd. The acquisition, made through a wholly owned subsidiary, costs US$250,000 for 25% shares. This move aims to capitalize on Saudi Aramco's planned investment increase, fueling spending in Saudi Arabian offshore facilities. Mermaid Subsea Services, the new entity, will operate in Saudi Arabia and is the key subsea service provider to Saudi Aramco, with CEO Chalermchai Mahagitsiri expecting to capitalize on the increased offshore spending.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after dovish Fed minutes
