This reassurance comes as the Bank of Korea faces scrutiny over its monetary policy decisions.

site_title: S Korea central bank sees little impact on economy from low inflation
summary: South Korea's central bank stated that low inflation has a limited negative impact on the economy, primarily due to good crop harvests and stable global commodity prices. The Bank of Korea reported that annual inflation has stood at 1% levels since July 2012, below the central bank's target band of 2.5-3.5%. Despite this, the economy is expected to recover, with forecasted growth rates of 3.8% this year and 4.0% in 2015, according to the central bank's report to parliament.

site_title: Bezos to integrate WaPost app in new Kindle: report
summary: Jeff Bezos plans to integrate The Washington Post app into Amazon's new Kindle tablets, with the app pre-installed on 8.9-inch Kindle devices for free. Other versions will be available for Apple and Android devices for a fee. The move, part of "Project Rainbow," aims to expand digital readership for the US daily. Bezos recently appointed Fred Ryan as publisher and CEO, and the Post has been adding staff in recent months to adapt to declining print circulation and advertising. The updated Kindles are set to be launched later this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares lose 1% ahead of RBA meeting
summary: Australian shares fell 1.1% to eight-month lows on Tuesday, weighed down by weakness on Wall Street and anticipation of a Reserve Bank of Australia policy meeting. Key bank stocks including Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corp dropped 1.4% and 1.3%, respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 56 points to 5,236.9, marking its first decline in three sessions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.59 points to 1846.57 on Tuesday, with 138 gainers outnumbering 53 losers. The market saw a trading volume of 34.46 million lots worth RM22.49 million.

site_title: Petronas threatens 15-year delay of Canada LNG plant if no tax deal
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy company Petronas threatens to delay its planned $11 billion liquefied natural gas plant in Canada by up to 15 years unless it reaches a favorable tax deal by the end of October. The economics of the project are deemed marginal, and without a favorable tax arrangement, Petronas may shelve the project for a decade or more. This could benefit other companies, as less competition would increase the sense of urgency to get other deals done, according to chief energy economist Peter Tertzakian.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.31%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.31% lower on Tuesday, following Wall Street's drop and the dollar's decline against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 49.78 points to 15,841.17 yen, amid investor caution ahead of third-quarter earnings reports. A stronger yen negatively impacts Japanese exports and erodes profits. The dollar was at 108.90 yen, up from 108.75 yen in New York, but down from 109.52 yen in Tokyo earlier Monday.

site_title: Rio Tinto says it rejected Glencore merger bid
summary: Rio Tinto rejected Glencore's potential merger bid in July 2014, citing that a combination would not be in the best interests of shareholders. The board unanimously decided against the deal after consulting with financial and legal advisers. Glencore had approached Rio shareholder Chinalco about a possible deal, but no further contact was made. Rio Tinto's shares rose 4.48% following the news, with the company's chairman stating that the firm has made significant progress in refocusing and strengthening its business, and is poised to increase free cash flow and returns to shareholders.

site_title: Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop names new CEO, plans e-commerce push
summary: Goop, the lifestyle blog and online shopping site founded by Gwyneth Paltrow in 2008, has named Lisa Gersh as its new CEO. Gersh will spearhead an e-commerce expansion, including the launch of Goop-branded apparel and partnerships with fashion designers like Stella McCartney. The site will focus on being a US-based site that ships globally for the next 18 months before expanding into its own label, beauty, and home products. Gersh, previously CEO of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, aims to build the business to match its existing brand, taking a step-by-step approach.

site_title: Detroit not 'where we need to be,' but can rebuild after bankruptcy: mayor
summary: Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan expressed caution over the city's recovery from bankruptcy, stating it will take years to reach 10% of its pre-bankruptcy state. He supported the plan for adjusting $18 billion in debt but raised concerns over the $325 million loan from Barclays Capital and the city's ability to afford spending requirements. The plan projects $200 million in annual revenue sharing from Michigan, but Duggan noted potential risks, including reduced state funding and increased competition from new casinos.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q3 profit likely down 60% on year
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 59.7% drop in operating profit for the July-September period, reaching 4.1 trillion won (US$3.8 billion), as earnings from its smartphone division likely declined. This marks the company's fourth consecutive quarter of declining operating profit. Third-quarter sales are also expected to have fallen 20.5% to 47 trillion won, lower than the mean forecast of 50.9 trillion won. The guidance is lower than the mean estimate of 43 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

site_title: Facebook closes US$19b buy of WhatsApp
summary: Facebook has completed its US$19 billion acquisition of WhatsApp, appointing co-founder Jan Koum to the social network's board of directors. Koum will remain chief of WhatsApp as part of the deal. The acquisition aims to connect more people worldwide and create value for WhatsApp users. The deal marks a significant expansion of Facebook's presence in the messaging market.

site_title: HK financial industry shrugs off pro-democracy protests
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark index rose 1.1% on Monday, its biggest daily gain in over a month, as pro-democracy activists scaled down protests. Some banks reopened branches, and the Hong Kong dollar gained 0.06%. Despite the protests, the city's financial industry has been relatively unaffected, with banks and brokerages continuing to operate normally. The World Bank warned of a potential impact on Hong Kong's economy, but noted limited spillover to the broader Chinese economy.

site_title: NZ business confidence slips to 2-year low in Q3 - survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence has fallen to a two-year low in the third quarter, according to a private think tank. A net 19% of firms surveyed expect general business conditions to improve, the lowest since September 2012. Rising cost pressures and inflation concerns are cited as reasons for the decline. The New Zealand Institute of Economic Research expects interest rates to continue increasing from early next year.

site_title: New Argentina central bank chief wants more private bank lending
summary: Argentina's new central bank chief, Alejandro Vanoli, urged private financial institutions to increase lending to jumpstart the country's stagnant economy. Vanoli, who took over the position after Juan Carlos Fabrega's resignation, wants to control inflation, which is around 40% per year. He emphasized the need to comply with foreign exchange policies and deepen credit-oriented policies to increase production and investment. The central bank is introducing a floor for interest rates on small deposits to encourage saving in pesos.

site_title: Japan nuclear restart to hit oil usage hardest: survey
summary: Japan's nuclear power restart, expected to begin in early 2015, is expected to significantly reduce oil usage, with utilities slashing oil consumption and shutting ageing oil-fired plants. The move will punish oil imports the most, as oil is Japan's most expensive fuel and the plants are costly to maintain. In the fiscal year ended March 31, Japan's big utilities burned 18% less oil, mostly opting for cheaper coal, after oil for power use hit a 16-year high the previous year.

site_title: Cyber-crime against the US costing billions: FBI chief
summary: The FBI's director, James Comey, stated that China is waging an aggressive cyber-war against the US, costing American businesses billions of dollars annually. China tops the list of countries seeking to pilfer US secrets, with almost every major US company targeted. Annual losses from cyber-attacks are "impossible to count," but measured in "billions." A historic case against China's People's Liberation Army unit for hacking US companies for trade secrets has been prosecuted, resulting in job losses in the US.

site_title: Japan's Aso plays down South Korean president's concerns over weak yen
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso downplayed concerns over the weak yen's impact on South Korean exporters, saying President Park Geun-hye's comments were not a cause for worry. The yen has weakened to a six-year low, affecting South Korean industries that compete with Japanese peers in key export markets. Aso stated that the president's remarks were "various" and not worth worrying about, as the yen's weakness was already a concern. The yen traded at around 108.78 versus the dollar, pulling back from last week's six-year low.

site_title: Investors burned by index overshoot on CDS rebirth
summary: Hedge funds suffered significant losses after the launch of new credit default swap (CDS) indices, which saw the iTraxx Sub Financials index widen by 58bp to 145bp and the iTraxx Crossover index shoot 86bp wider to 332bp. The introduction of the new contracts, designed to compensate protection holders more effectively for losses sustained on restructured sovereign and financial bonds, caught hedge funds off guard, resulting in significant losses. The unexpected negative skew on the iTraxx Crossover and Main indices further exacerbated the losses.

site_title: Britain's financial services firms back on growth path
summary: Britain's financial services firms are experiencing growth, with business volumes rising at their fastest rate since 2007 and 60% of firms reporting greater profits. The sector is expected to continue its upward trend, with competition being a major concern for companies. New jobs are being created, with 3,470 positions added in London in September, mostly in compliance and regulatory functions. Experts believe the sector is moving into a new phase of recovery, with firms focusing on competing for new customers and business.

site_title: GIC takes full ownership of Italian mall
summary: GIC, a Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, is acquiring the remaining half stake of the RomaEst Shopping Centre in Italy, gaining full ownership of the mall. The deal, valued at 400 million euros, was initially acquired by GIC and ING Real Estate in 2008. The acquisition demonstrates GIC's confidence in Italy's long-term prospects and its ability to add value to the centre through asset management. RomaEst, one of Italy's largest shopping centres, comprises a mall, hypermarket, and cinema, with a gross lettable area of 102,000 sq m.

site_title: Indonesia's new leader, facing growth hurdles, may focus on cutting red-tape
summary: Indonesia's new president-elect, Joko Widodo, may focus on cutting bureaucratic red tape to boost the country's struggling economy. With a new parliament and limited powers, Widodo aims to simplify business regulations and resolve land disputes to attract investors. He has pledged to cut through the red tape that stifles growth and has proposed a one-stop service for issuing permits. Analysts expect supply-side reforms to improve the investment climate, but short-term growth challenges are expected due to high interest rates and limited fiscal stimulus options.

images.alt_text: Soon after he became governor of Indonesia's traffic-clogged capital in 2012, Joko Widodo came up with a creative approach to an impasse blocking completion of a ring-road around Jakarta for almost a decade. - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: US: Wall Street falls in choppy day; traders wary before earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 17.78 points, or 0.1%, to 16,991.91. The S&P 500 lost 3.08 points, or 0.16%, to 1,964.82, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 20.82 points, or 0.47%, to 4,454.80. Traders are cautious ahead of earnings season, citing a strong US dollar and weak European economy. Key stocks, including Hewlett-Packard and CareFusion, saw gains, while others, such as GT Advanced Technologies and Micron, fell.

site_title: Turner to slash 10 per cent of jobs, including at CNN
summary: Turner Broadcasting is slashing 10% of its workforce, including approximately 300 jobs at CNN, as part of a cost-cutting plan to refocus the media group. The company will eliminate 1,475 positions from 14,000 full-time posts worldwide. The move is part of Turner's "Turner 2020" plan, which aims to prioritize investment in programming, monetization, and innovation. The company will also add 150 new positions in areas of investment and growth, with buyouts and layoffs being used to achieve the job reductions.

site_title: Macau casino revenue falls most in 5 years
summary: Macau casino revenue plummeted 12% to 25.6 billion patacas in September, the largest drop in five years, due to President Xi Jinping's crackdown on graft and high-stakes gamblers. The decline is attributed to decreased spending by high-rollers, with protests in Hong Kong potentially deterring mainland Chinese tourists. The Cotai Strip, a major hub for casino companies, saw lower foot traffic and table game minimums. Analysts expect further decline in revenue, with some predicting a weak gaming market for the rest of the year.

site_title: E-applications for Lake Life EC project cross 1,200
summary: More than 1,200 e-applications have been received for Lake Life, a 546-unit executive condominium (EC) project in Singapore, with e-applications closing on Oct 12. The project's indicative average pricing is around S$880- S$890 per square foot. Firm pricing will be released on Nov 5, and bookings will begin on Nov 8. The developers attribute the strong response to the project's location in the Jurong Lake District and "active living" lifestyle pitch.

site_title: Hong Kong activists agree to talks as protests shrink
summary: Hong Kong protest leaders agreed to talks with the government as protests dwindled, with many demonstrators leaving the streets after a warning from leader Leung Chun-ying to end the sit-in. The main site in Admiralty had several hundred remaining protesters, while similar numbers were in Mongkok. The talks aim to resolve the pro-democracy movement, which began as a mass rally but shrunk in size. The outcome is uncertain, but the decision marks a shift towards dialogue, following weeks of growing pressure to end the protests.

site_title: Keppel Land, Philips team up to save energy
summary: Keppel Land, a Singaporean prime office developer and landlord, has partnered with Royal Philips to implement a zero capital expenditure scheme to reduce energy consumption at its office buildings. Philips will replace conventional office lamps with energy-efficient LED lighting, with Keppel Land sharing the estimated 60% cost savings with Philips for the next three years. The scheme aims to encourage tenants to adopt green practices and obtain Green Mark certifications, with expected annual savings of up to S$400,000.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard split aims to sharpen focus
summary: Hewlett-Packard is set to split into two companies, one focused on personal computers and printers, and the other on software and enterprise services. The split, expected to be completed by the end of 2015, aims to generate long-term value for shareholders and provide each new company with the independence and flexibility needed to adapt to market dynamics. The move follows a trend of sector companies splitting to focus on specific markets, with HP citing the need to adapt to the shift away from traditional personal computers to mobile devices.

site_title: Dollar pauses after last week's surge
summary: The US dollar retreated against major currencies on Monday after a strong September jobs report boosted the dollar last week. The euro, supported by a US$1.25 level, resisted a decline despite poor eurozone data, including a 5.7% drop in German factory orders. Analysts predict the euro's gains could be short-lived due to deteriorating economic conditions in the region, potentially prompting the ECB to take action.

site_title: German factory orders plunge 5.7% in August
summary: German factory orders fell 5.7% in August, the largest decline since 2009, indicating a poor growth outlook for Europe's largest economy. This drop was more severe than economists' predictions of a 2.5% decline. The decline was attributed to deteriorating confidence, geopolitical risks, and a slowing Chinese economy. Euro area inflation remained low at 0.3%, and the European Central Bank maintained interest rates at record lows, signaling support for the economy. A "modest economic expansion" in the second half is still expected, despite ongoing risks.

site_title: Bangkok Airways seeks as much as 14b baht in IPO
summary: Bangkok Airways plans to raise up to 14 billion baht (S$548 million) in its initial public offering (IPO) by selling 520 million shares at 23-27 baht apiece. The airline aims to use the funds to expand its fleet and renovate airport facilities. The IPO is part of Thailand's third-biggest IPO this year, following a 26.2 billion baht IPO by Thai Hotel Investment in May.

site_title: Maersk banks on industry's new giants
summary: The world's largest container shipping company, Maersk, has introduced the Triple-E, a massive container ship that can carry over 18,000 containers, nearly 3.5 times the capacity of older ships. The Mary Maersk, one of the Triple-Es, has gained a following and is now sailing between Europe and Asia, carrying various goods. However, the industry's overreaching ambitions and excessive capacity have led to a decline in demand and profits, with many carriers struggling to make money. Experts warn that only large companies like Maersk or niche players will survive the current market downturn.

site_title: Tax transparency in Corporate Australia
summary: A report by the Tax Justice Network claims that Singapore Telecommunications (SingTel) and other top 200 Australian companies have avoided paying over A$80 billion in taxes between 2004 and 2013. The report, timed to coincide with the Liberal-National government's stalled tax-raising bills, accuses the government of Prime Minister Tony Abbott of dereliction in collecting taxes from big corporations. However, the report's methodology has been criticized, and the issue of tax avoidance is a complex one, with companies using available laws to reduce their tax burden.

site_title: US must allow crude exports to sustain its oil boom
summary: The US oil boom, driven by fracking and horizontal drilling, has increased oil production from 5 million barrels a day in 2008 to 8.3 million barrels a day in 2014, with potential to reach 9.6 million barrels a day by 2019. However, the current ban on exporting crude oil hinders the boom's sustainability, as producers face lower prices due to inadequate refining capacity and transportation issues. Lifting the ban would promote continued exploration and benefit the US economy, but public perception of the policy as an "unjustified giveaway" to industry hinders its implementation.

site_title: A$ slide would dent S'pore firms' profits
summary: The Australian dollar has slid to a 5-year low against the Singapore dollar, with analysts predicting it will trade below S$1.10 in the next year. This has led to concerns about the impact on Singapore companies with operations in Australia, such as telco giant SingTel and property developers. A weakening Australian dollar can affect earnings, share prices, and balance sheets, particularly for companies with significant revenue from Australia. Analysts expect the Australian dollar to continue to weaken, with some predicting it could drop to S$1.06 in 12 months.

site_title: Online firms lead Asian office space leasing
summary: Social media and e-commerce firms led office leasing activity in Asia, taking up 21% of new space in the second quarter, surpassing financial companies. Internet companies such as LinkedIn, Amazon, and Facebook leased over 1.1 million square feet, driving the growth. The trend is attributed to Asia's rapid e-commerce growth, with China's online retail sales expected to hit $1.5 trillion this year, according to Cushman & Wakefield.

site_title: Chinese firm buys Hilton's Waldorf Astoria for US$1.95b
summary: Chinese insurance company Anbang Insurance Group has acquired Hilton's Waldorf Astoria New York for US$1.95 billion. The landmark hotel, a New York City landmark since 1993, will be restored to its historic grandeur and managed by Hilton for the next 100 years. Anbang will also allow Hilton to operate other Waldorf Astoria hotels worldwide. The sale will help Hilton use the proceeds to acquire additional US hotel assets.

site_title: Debt, signs of drought squeeze Thai economy
summary: Thailand's economy faces significant challenges due to record-high household debt, a severe water shortage, and weak demand for key exports. The country's growth is predicted to be 1.5% this year, with rice farmers, many of whom supported the ousted government, being particularly affected by debt and water scarcity. The junta's control over the economy is being tested, with the central bank warning of a potential drought that could exacerbate the water shortage, affecting the poorer segment of the population.

site_title: Has a brain drain started at CapitaLand?
summary: CapitaLand's CEO Lim Beng Chee has resigned, followed by Sharon Lim's resignation as CEO of CapitaMalls Malaysia Reit Management. The company's privatisation of CapitaMalls Asia has been met with criticism, and some staff may be leaving the group due to uncertainty about its direction. The loss of income from the sale of Australand Property Group and potential changes in leadership could exacerbate the brain drain. Former CapitaLand CEO Liew Mun Leong is expected to become chairman of a new entity, potentially attracting former CapitaLand staff.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: New benchmark contracts for US$17t credit swap mkt
summary: A new benchmark contract for the US$17 trillion credit swap market has been introduced, addressing flaws that prevented some bondholders from being fully compensated for losses. The overhaul increases the cost of insuring junior bank bonds and sovereign debt, with new contracts offering investors greater protection. The changes were prompted by Greece's debt restructuring in 2012 and the Dutch government's seizure of bonds in 2013, and expand the list of events triggering payouts to include bail-ins. The updates aim to provide more comprehensive protection for investors in the global credit derivatives market.

site_title: Board diversity: Policy should weigh benefits and costs
summary: A Singaporean article discusses the importance of diversity in corporate boards, highlighting the benefits and costs of increasing boardroom diversity. While research shows that diverse teams can provide a greater depth of thought and experience, they can also lead to fault lines and decreased cooperation among team members. To effectively harness the benefits of diversity, boards should consider the contingencies that influence the extent of benefits, such as geographic diversification and industry-specific needs. Developing a diversity policy that weighs benefits and costs is crucial for creating value for stakeholders.

site_title: M&A plans at 3-year high: survey
summary: Corporate executives are planning acquisitions at a 3-year high, with 40% anticipating deals in the next 12 months, according to a survey by EY. The global economy's stabilization is boosting dealmaking, with total takeover values rising 29% to $887 billion in the third quarter. Executives are optimistic about M&A, citing greater certainty in strategic planning, despite monitoring geopolitical events. This growth in confidence is attributed to improving corporate earnings and the economic recovery in the US and UK.

site_title: US$ poses triple threat to American firms' profits
summary: The US dollar's recent surge is posing a triple threat to American companies' profits, driving up costs of doing business overseas, suppressing non-US sales, and signaling weak international demand. The dollar has gained 8% against six major currencies since June, with companies in the S&P 500 deriving almost half of their revenue from international markets. This is expected to lead to disappointment for companies that fail to meet expectations, particularly those with significant overseas sales.

site_title: Japan condo builder taps bond market after 20 years
summary: Japanese condo builder Haseko Corp is returning to the bond market for the first time in 20 years, selling up to 30 billion yen of notes. The company, which defaulted on debt in 1999, has seen its shares and cash reserves recover significantly. The bond offering comes as Japan's real estate market experiences a boom, with the average cost of an apartment in Tokyo reaching a 22-year high. This is a sign of the bond market expanding, with investors taking advantage of low borrowing costs and a favorable market environment.

site_title: Jimmy Choo London IPO values firm at US$1.1b
summary: Jimmy Choo London, a luxury shoe company, is set to join the main stock market with a value of up to US$1.1 billion. The initial price range for its IPO is 140-180 pence per share, with an aim to list 25% of the company, valued at £546-702 million. The funds raised will be used to expand, particularly in Asia. The company plans to open 10-15 new shops annually until 2016. BOA Merrill Lynch is lead managing the listing, with HSBC as joint bookrunner.

site_title: Good jobs numbers: So what?
summary: The US Labor Department reported a 5.9% unemployment rate, the lowest in over six years, with 248,000 new jobs added in the last month. The rate is the first time below 6% since July 2008. The Federal Reserve expects the rate to drop to 5.5% next year, indicating a positive trend in the American economy.

images.alt_text: What numbers say: Some of the drop in unemployment suggested fewer Americans are looking for jobs or are working in part-time jobs.

site_title: Understanding the principles of nudging
summary: A new unit has launched in the advertising industry specializing in "Behaviour Change" or Behavioural Economics, a science and business that aims to study and apply principles to nudge people into making specific choices. Governments have also assigned Behavioural Insights teams, or "Nudge Squads," to encourage citizens to make better choices. These teams use established principles of nudging, such as creating tangible value, loss aversion, and the cost of zero, to drive behavioral change. The goal is to change people's actions more than their minds, and to add value to businesses through more effective strategies.

site_title: BOJ to stand pat on policy, warn of weak factory output
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its massive monetary stimulus and offer a bleaker view on factory output, citing signs that Japan's economy may have entered a mild recession following a sales tax hike. The central bank is sticking to its forecast of a moderate recovery and a 2% inflation target next year without additional monetary stimulus. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is likely to maintain optimism, but some board members may press for a bleaker view on the economy.

site_title: HK ETF bulls unfazed by political unrest
summary: Investors in Hong Kong-listed ETFs remain optimistic about the market despite the city's biggest political unrest since the 1960s. Over $200 million has been added to the six largest ETFs since September 28, as investors continue to bet on a rebound. The Hang Seng Index fell 2.6% last week, but short-sellers cut their bets by an average 16% as the market adjusted to the protests. Analysts say investors are staying loyal to the equity market, expecting a long-term positive impact on the Chinese economy.

site_title: Small city routes lucrative for India airlines
summary: India's domestic aviation market is experiencing rapid growth, with passenger numbers expected to increase by over 75% in the next six years. This growth is driven by higher disposable incomes and urbanization, particularly in smaller cities like Patna, where passenger numbers have risen nearly 17% annually since 2009. As a result, airlines are shifting focus to smaller regional routes, which are now more profitable than big city routes. New airlines are emerging to cater to regional demand, but industry analysts warn that increased competition could lead to lower fares and reduced yields.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard to split into 2 listed companies
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) plans to split into two listed companies, separating its computer and printer businesses from its corporate hardware and services operations. The split is expected to occur next year through a tax-free transaction, with shareholders owning a stake in both businesses. The move comes as HP adapts to the shift towards mobile and online computing. The company's shares rose 5.1% in premarket trading following the announcement.

site_title: Water management: Need for right mindset
summary: The world faces a collective water crisis due to poor water management and governance. Companies recognize water as a limited resource and are working to improve its availability, quality, and sustainability. However, traditional approaches to water management need to change to address the complexities of resource constraints, conflicts, and emerging trends like population growth, urbanization, and industrialization. A new "can-do" mindset is required to implement business-unusual solutions, and determined political will, public pressure, and coordination among sectors are necessary to solve the world's water problems.

site_title: Goldman says not so fast while BlackRock sees earlier Fed rate hike
summary: Goldman Sachs' chief economist Jan Hatzius says the Federal Reserve should not raise borrowing costs until the third quarter of next year due to labour market slack. However, BlackRock's chief investment officer Rick Rieder believes the Fed will hike interest rates sooner, citing a strong economy. The conflicting views highlight Fed Chair Janet Yellen's dilemma over when to raise rates amid uneven growth.

site_title: Jakarta stocks retreat as Jokowi is thwarted
summary: Indonesian stocks plummeted 3.7% as investors lost faith in President-elect Joko Widodo's ability to revive the country's economy, amid a political stalemate in Parliament. The Jakarta Composite Index has dropped to a 7.6% potential decline in October, with foreign funds pulling $344 million from the shares. The durability of the Red-White coalition, which backs losing presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto, threatens Jokowi's ability to implement key policies, including cutting fuel subsidies and reducing bureaucracy.

site_title: Safety tops the food chain at Indoguna
summary: Indoguna, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, has won two consecutive Enterprise 50 awards for its commitment to serving the best to its customers. The company, which has undergone significant transformation since 1993, now offers a wide range of products, including seafood, cheese, and boutique wine. With a staff strength of nearly 180, Indoguna has established itself as a leader in the industry, with its strong devotion to quality and customer satisfaction.

site_title: Resale volumes of private condos plunge
summary: Resale volumes of private condominiums in Singapore have plummeted to levels last seen during the Global Financial Crisis, with total resales standing at 1,314 units in the second quarter, accounting for 31.9% of all private non-landed residential transactions. Districts 18 and 27 in the east and north showed resilience, while Districts 7 and 19 experienced significant falls in resale volumes. The decline is attributed to cooling measures, including the buyer's stamp duty and loan restrictions, which have affected the Core Central Region market segment.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard says to split in two
summary: Hewlett-Packard Co announced plans to split into two companies, separating its computer and printer businesses from its corporate hardware and services operations. The split, expected to occur next year, will result in two separate listed companies: HP Inc, led by Dion Weisler, and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, led by Meg Whitman. The move aims to adapt to the shift towards mobile computing and capitalize on faster-growing businesses.

site_title: German bank sees euro going down 4% by end-2015
summary: A German bank, Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg (LBBW), predicts the euro will drop 4% to US$1.20 by the end of 2015, surpassing the consensus forecast of a 4% drop to US$1.23. LBBW attributes its bearish view to the eurozone's precarious economic state, which may prompt the European Central Bank (ECB) to adopt quantitative easing (QE) measures as early as November.

site_title: The Third Way's second chance
summary: The Third Way, a centrist ideology that combines social-democratic values with modern liberal economics, is experiencing a resurgence in popularity. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and French Prime Minister Manuel Valls are among those seeking to implement policies that balance fiscal austerity with investments in jobs and skills. The concept, popularized by Tony Blair and Bill Clinton in the early 2000s, has been successful in countries such as Germany, Sweden, and Chile, and is now being revisited by centre-left politicians worldwide. Key to its success are policy pragmatism, fiscal realism, modern welfarism, and progressive liberalism.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.16%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.16% on Monday, driven by upbeat US jobs data and a stronger dollar against the yen, which boosted Japanese exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index gained 182.30 points to 15,890.95 and the Topix index climbed 1.08% to 1,296.40.

site_title: World Bank issues alert on debt servicing, property prices
summary: The World Bank has issued an alert on debt servicing and property prices in the East Asia Pacific region, warning of potential problems due to monetary tightening and increased financial volatility. Rising interest rates could create debt service challenges for some countries, and historically, monetary policy normalization has been correlated with declines in housing prices. The global economy is expected to recover at an uneven pace, with growth projected at 2.6% in 2014 and 3.3% in 2015-17. However, uncertainties remain, particularly in high-income economies, and the outlook for the region is clouded with uncertainty.

site_title: DBS completes purchase of Societe Generale's private banking business in Asia
summary: DBS Bank has completed the acquisition of Societe Generale's Asian private banking business in Singapore and Hong Kong, as well as selected parts of its trust business. The acquisition significantly increases DBS' wealth management business, boosting its high net worth assets under management to S$88 billion. DBS Private Bank and Societe Generale Private Banking Asia will collaborate, offering clients access to each other's services in different regions. Most SGPB Asia employees will join DBS, strengthening the bank's wealth management talent pool.

site_title: British car sales at highest for decade: trade data
summary: British new car sales rose 5.6% in September to 425,861 vehicles, the highest level for the month since 2004, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. The strong performance was attributed to increased confidence in the UK economy and a wide range of fuel-efficient new cars. SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes stated that demand has been boosted by consumers' attraction to new cars. This marks the highest September sales for a decade, solidifying the UK new car market's robustness.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.09% on Monday, driven by a strong US jobs report, to close at 23,315.04 on the Hang Seng Index. The benchmark index gained 250.48 points on turnover of HK$72.57 billion. A pro-democracy protest in the city thinned out, allowing trading to resume. The Shanghai market was closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares squander early gains to edge lower on profit-taking; won falls
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.39% to 1,968.39 points, reversing early gains, as offshore investors sold holdings due to a weak won. The won fell to a six-month low against the dollar, which hit a multi-year high amid upbeat US economic data.

images.alt_text: - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Gradual home price slide a plus for banks: Moody's
summary: Singapore banks face reduced pressure on asset quality due to the gradual decline in private home prices, according to Moody's. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's Q3 2014 flash estimate showed a 0.6% quarter-on-quarter drop in the private residential property price index. Moody's expects asset quality to remain robust despite stable economic growth and low unemployment. Regulatory measures, such as the total debt-service ratio cap, have contributed to a smaller increase in housing loans, with year-over-year growth in 2014 being the lowest in almost five years.

site_title: South Korean president says weaker yen could hurt exporters
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye warned that a weaker yen could negatively impact Korean exporters' profitability, citing increased uncertainty about the global economy. The yen's weakness affects South Korea's big industries competing with Japanese rivals in key export markets. Park rarely comments on currency movements, making her statement noteworthy.

site_title: London beats NY as most popular place to work: poll
summary: London has been ranked as the most popular city to work in, according to a survey of over 200,000 people from 189 countries. The city surpassed New York and Paris, with nearly one in six respondents wanting to move to London for employment. The study found that almost two-thirds of jobseekers are willing to move abroad, but only 44% of people in Britain want to move overseas for work. The survey, conducted by The Boston Consulting Group and totaljobs.com, is the largest study on worker mobility.

site_title: London home prices start cooling amid construction boom
summary: London home prices are cooling amid a construction boom, but steep falls are unlikely due to ongoing interest from overseas buyers. Homebuilding in central London doubled in two years, driven by record-low interest rates and demand from foreign buyers. Prices have fallen month-on-month for the first time in two years, with expectations for growth falling at the fastest pace since the financial crisis. Despite this, many developers remain optimistic, citing growing employment and limited housing supply, which will keep values close to record highs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks notch best day in a month as protests scale down
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark index posted its biggest daily gain in over a month, rising 1.1% to 23,315.04 points, as protests scaled down and upbeat US jobs data provided relief on the global economy outlook. Pro-democracy activists allowed civil servants to pass through barricades, and some banks reopened branches closed during the protests. Macau casinos rallied, with Sands China and Galaxy Entertainment Group gaining 7.1% and 6.6% respectively, as investors bet on a technical rebound in the oversold sector.

site_title: DBS completes buying SocGen's Asian private banking business
summary: DBS Bank has completed its acquisition of Societe Generale's Asian private banking business in Singapore and Hong Kong, expanding its wealth management business to S$129 billion in assets under management. The acquisition significantly increases DBS' position as a leading wealth manager in Asia, complementing its existing private bank units. DBS' high net worth assets under management now stand at S$88 billion.

site_title: Human trafficking a US$7b business along main routes: UN
summary: The UN estimates that human traffickers earn US$7 billion annually from smuggling routes between Africa and Europe, and between Latin and North America. Thousands of migrants die in search of a better life, with 40,000 estimated deaths since 2000. The International Organisation for Migration reported 3,000 deaths in 2014, including 500 migrants who drowned in a shipwreck off the Mediterranean coast. The UN calls for closer international cooperation to combat smuggling networks, citing "terrible tragedies" and the need for joint efforts to prevent traffickers from staying ahead of law enforcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit by struggling iron ore prices
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, down 25.3 points or 0.5% at 5,292.90, due to struggling iron ore prices and foreign investors trimming exposure. The S&P/ASX 200 index hovered near a 7 1/2-month low.

site_title: Hilton to sell NY's Waldorf Astoria hotel to Chinese insurer
summary: Hilton Worldwide is selling the Waldorf Astoria New York hotel to Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group Co Ltd for $1.95 billion. The sale, completed after a 100-year management agreement, marks a significant milestone for Hilton's luxury brand, Waldorf Astoria Hotels & Resorts.

site_title: Struggling Euro Disney announces 1b euro crisis plan
summary: Euro Disney, which operates Disneyland Paris, has announced a one-billion-euro crisis plan to overcome a sharp decline in visitor numbers and spending. The plan includes a cash infusion of 420 million euros and debt conversion into equity. The company blames the economic environment in Europe for its problems, citing a six-per-cent drop in visitors and a 16-per-cent increase in net losses. The plan aims to improve the company's financial health and enable continued investments in the resort, with a projected cash position improvement of around 250 million euros.

site_title: Oil prices slip on increased supply, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices have slipped to multi-year lows due to increased global supply and a strong US dollar. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell to $89.69, while Brent North Sea crude eased to $91.95, a two-year low. Analysts predict further losses, citing a build-up in supplies and a stronger dollar, which makes dollar-priced commodities more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies. Supply surges in the US, Russia, Libya, and Kurdistan, while Saudi Arabia continues to cut prices to defend its market share.

site_title: E-applications for Lake Life EC in Jurong cross 1,200
summary: More than 1,200 e-applications have been received for Lake Life EC in Jurong, exceeding initial expectations. E-applications close on October 12, with firm pricing to be released on November 5 and bookings starting on November 8. The current indicative average pricing is around S$880-890 per square foot.

site_title: US: Stocks rise following corporate deals
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, driven by large corporate deal announcements and ahead of third-quarter earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.46% to 17,087.79, while the S&P 500 rose 0.46% to 1,976.86, and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.40% to 4,493.49. The gains followed a strong start to the week, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: MARKETS DIGEST
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 24.53 points to 3,253.24 on Friday, with the STI futures also increasing by 24.00 points. Other markets, including the SIMSCI and Forex, also saw gains. Prime rates in Singapore and Britain were 5.35% and 0.50%, respectively, while US interest rates remained at 3.25%. China's employment aid measures were announced amid trade tensions, and US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly. Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year.

site_title: German industrial orders slump in August
summary: Germany's industrial orders declined 5.7% in August, a sharp drop from July's 4.9% increase. Domestic orders fell 2.0% and export orders dropped 8.4% compared to the previous month. Orders from the eurozone and outside the eurozone also decreased, with the latter dropping 9.9%. The decline was partly due to the timing of summer holidays and a surge in big-ticket orders in July.

site_title: Malaysian markets closed on Monday
summary: Malaysian financial markets were closed on Monday due to a public holiday. No specific news or market updates were reported in the article.

site_title: Germany can play its part in foreign missions despite equipment problems: defence minister
summary: German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen stated that despite equipment problems, Germany can still play a significant role in foreign military missions. She acknowledged 140 risks and problems related to defence projects, but emphasized the need for Germany to rectify issues rather than abandoning its commitment to international missions. Von der Leyen expressed confidence in the country's deployment capability and denied any plans to overstretch its armed forces. She also considered reviving a high-altitude reconnaissance drone project, the Euro Hawk.

site_title: 51 firms so far in Sias's excellence initiative
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 5th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2014 from October 27 to 31, with 51 companies committing to uphold high standards of governance to enhance shareholder value. The initiative, supported by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority and the Singapore Exchange, aims to promote good corporate governance standards in the country's financial markets. Key companies, including China Aviation Oil, DBS Bank, and Koh Brothers Group, have expressed their commitment to upholding high standards of corporate governance to create value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Those Were the Days, Not Simple or All Sweet
summary: Norman Lear, creator of iconic sitcoms like "All in the Family" and "The Jeffersons," has written a memoir that delves into his life, including his experiences as a Depression-era kid, World War II veteran, and pioneering television producer. Lear shares behind-the-scenes stories of his shows, including disputes with CBS executives and his father's influence on his work. He reflects on the legacy of his shows, which tackled sensitive topics like racism and sexism, and how they continue to influence contemporary television. Lear's memoir, "Even This I Get to Experience," is set to release on October 14.

site_title: Seoul: Shares shed gains on profit-taking; won sharply lower
summary: South Korean shares reversed early gains to drift lower on Monday, driven by offshore investors' profit-taking amid recent currency volatility. The KOSPI fell 0.08% to 1,974.52 points. Foreign investors sold 72.5 billion won of shares, while analysts see the KOSPI nearing the end of its short-term down cycle. Automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motor rose, while chipmaker SK Hynix fell after Samsung Electronics' investment announcement. The won fell to a 6-month low, 1,069.6 to the dollar, amid stellar US employment data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on Monday as a strong US jobs report was offset by concerns over a pro-democracy demonstration. The Hang Seng Index dropped 10.77 points to 23,053.79. The US jobs data was seen as a positive for the market, but the uncertainty surrounding the Hong Kong protests weighed on investor sentiment.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide, miners hit by iron ore prices
summary: Australia's shares slid on Monday due to losses in mining companies, primarily hit by struggling iron ore prices. Top miner BHP Billiton plummeted to a 14-month low after cutting costs and boosting production capacity, raising concerns about downward pressure on iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 21.51 points to 5,296.70, with local trading thin due to a public holiday. Foreign investors trimmed exposure to Australian stocks, citing lingering worries about growth in China and a weaker domestic currency.

site_title: Singapore markets closed on Monday
summary: Singapore's financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday. No key events or stock movements were reported in the article.

site_title: Global banks join hands to set up one-stop bond shop: WSJ
summary: A group of 12 global banks, including BNP Paribas, Credit Suisse, and Goldman Sachs, are collaborating on a "Neptune" initiative to create a one-stop bond shop for corporate bond buyers and sellers. The project aims to improve liquidity in the market, which has been affected by new regulations and capital requirements following the financial crisis. The banks will pay 30,000 pounds each for the first phase of consultancy work. The move is part of efforts to make corporate-bond trading more efficient, addressing concerns over a disparity between trading volumes in new and old bonds.

site_title: Samsung to invest US$14.7b in S Korea chip facility
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest US$14.7 billion in a new semiconductor production facility in South Korea, with construction set to begin in 2025 and completion expected by 2017. The facility, to be built in Pyeongtaek, could produce memory chips or logic chips, but Samsung has not yet finalized its product plans.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge shows broad slowdown in Sept:TDMI
summary: Australia's TD Securities-Melbourne Institute's monthly measure of consumer prices showed inflation at its slowest in almost a year in September, with a 0.1% increase, following a flat August. The annual pace of inflation slowed to 2.2%, near the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. The RBA is expected to keep interest rates at 2.5% at its October meeting. A broad slowdown in goods and services costs and a muted rise in underlying inflation suggest that a high reading in the second quarter was an aberration.

site_title: Soft landing for Singapore housing market is credit positive for local banks: Moody's
summary: Moody's reports a gradual decline in Singapore's private home price index for the third quarter, a credit positive for local banks. This easing of the property market relieves pressure on bank asset quality. The agency notes that regulatory measures, including the total debt-service ratio cap, have contributed to a smaller increase in housing loans. Moody's expects the asset quality of housing loans to remain robust, with stable economic growth and low unemployment. This is despite a few isolated cases of problem home loans, mainly affecting United Overseas Bank.

site_title: Australia job advertisements hit 19-mth high in Sept: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements reached a 19-month high in September, increasing 0.9% to 137,087 per week on average, according to a survey by Australia and New Zealand Banking Group. This marks the fourth consecutive month of growth, indicating a gradual recovery in labor demand. The increase was 1.6% higher than August and 7.9% higher than the same period last year.

site_title: Next phase of underwater MH370 search begins
summary: The Australian agency leading the MH370 search, the ATSB, announced the next phase of the underwater search began Monday. The Malaysian-contracted vessel GO Phoenix, equipped with experts and equipment, resumed operations in the southern Indian Ocean, where the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 239 people onboard disappeared on March 8, 2014.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.11%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.11% higher on Monday, driven by a strong US jobs report that boosted the dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 173.63 points to 15,882.28. This followed a 1.24% gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Friday. The US economy added 248,000 jobs in September, according to the Labor Department.

site_title: Singapore's GIC to buy rest of Italian shopping centre
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) has agreed to purchase the remaining 50% stake in Italy's RomaEst Shopping Centre from CBRE Global Investors for an undisclosed sum. RomaEst, located near Rome, features a 208-unit mall, hypermarket, and cinema, with international and national brands as tenants. The transaction will make GIC the sole owner of the shopping centre.

site_title: Small city routes hold big potential for India airlines
summary: India's smaller cities are experiencing rapid growth in air travel, with passenger numbers from these cities rising nearly 17% annually since 2009. The airport in Patna, one of the country's poorest states, has seen a doubling of passengers and daily flights in the last four years due to increasing demand from smaller regions. The government is considering building a new airport to alleviate congestion, while the country's domestic aviation market is expected to grow by over 75% in the next six years, driven by higher disposable incomes and urbanization.

site_title: Growth back on the agenda for UK financial firms: industry survey
summary: UK financial firms are showing signs of growth, with business volumes rising at their fastest rate since 2007 and 60% of firms reporting increased profits. The sector is expected to continue growing, with competition being a major concern. Job creation is also on the rise, with 3,470 new jobs created in London in September, largely in compliance and regulatory functions. Investment banking fees have risen 13% to $68.8 billion, driven by increased M&A and equity capital market activity.

site_title: New Zealand house price growth slows in September
summary: New Zealand's house price growth slowed for a ninth consecutive month in September, with the residential property index rising 6.4% in the year to Sept 30, compared to 6.9% in September. This represents a 16.2% increase above the market's previous peak in late 2007. Auckland led national gains, with the country's biggest city experiencing significant growth.

images.alt_text: Growth in New Zealand's house prices slowed for a ninth consecutive month in September, although there were signs the sector is becoming more active, the government property valuer said on MondayM - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: US journalist with Ebola to arrive in Nebraska Monday
summary: A US journalist, Ashoka Mukpo, contracted Ebola in Liberia and is set to arrive at the Nebraska Medical Center on Monday for treatment. He is the fourth American to contract the virus and had worked on humanitarian projects in Liberia. The hospital has a 40+ member team ready to handle the patient, who is expected to experience severe symptoms. The US military has announced plans to increase troops deployed to Liberia to 4,000 to help combat the outbreak, which has infected over 7,000 people and killed about half of them.

site_title: British house prices forecast to dip in 2015
summary: British property prices are forecast to dip 0.8% in 2015, following a 7.8% growth in 2014, the strongest since 2007. The Centre for Economics and Business Research attributes this to a correction after the market got ahead of itself, with tougher mortgage requirements and higher deposit demands expected to dampen the market. Prices are expected to increase 2.6% in 2016 and 3% in the following years.

site_title: World Bank trims China, East Asia 2014-2016 growth forecasts
summary: The World Bank trimmed its growth forecasts for developing East Asia and China, expecting 6.9% growth in 2014 and 2015, down from 7.1% previously. China's growth is seen slowing due to policy measures, while Indonesia faces capital-flight risks. The bank also reduced its 2016 forecast for the region to 6.8% from 7.1%. The slowdown is attributed to a gradual recovery in high-income economies, with regional exports and growth benefiting from this trend.

site_title: New kings of the road: Big motorbike makers rev up in South-east Asia
summary: Motorcycle manufacturers, including Honda, Yamaha, Ducati, Kawasaki, and KTM, are shifting their focus to the growing market of big-bike riders in South-east Asia. The region, home to 600 million people, is seeing an increase in demand for larger motorcycles, with sales of bikes with bigger engine capacities outpacing smaller models in countries like Malaysia and Vietnam. Harley-Davidson plans to enter the market with its Street 750 model, while companies like Ducati and KTM are already producing and selling larger motorcycles in the region. This shift is driven by rising incomes and a growing middle class in South-east Asia.

site_title: Abenomics: Roadmap to corporate reform
summary: Japan's Abenomics reforms aim to shift the economy from a vicious circle of deflation to a virtuous circle of growth. The government has emphasized corporate sector reforms, including greater capital efficiency, improvements in stewardship, and corporate governance. Recent developments suggest investors may be too pessimistic, with progress on reforms potentially rekindling interest in Japanese equities. The introduction of the Japan Revitalisation Strategy and the Ito Review has emphasized the importance of corporate sector reforms, and the Government Pension Investment Fund's shift to equities and adoption of the Stewardship code could lead to increased investment and growth.

site_title: China cyber-crime costing US billions: FBI chief
summary: China is waging an aggressive cyber-war against the US, costing American businesses billions of dollars annually, according to FBI Director James Comey. China tops the list of countries seeking to pilfer secrets from US firms, with almost every major company targeted. Comey stated that annual losses from cyber-attacks launched from China are "impossible to count" but measured in "billions." This comes after a historic case of five Chinese military personnel indicted for hacking US companies for trade secrets, which outraged China. The FBI chief refused to disclose the top list of countries targeting the US.

site_title: How it all started going wrong for Tesco
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, has faced a major crisis after a £250 million error in its first-half profits, resulting in a £4 billion drop in market value and the suspension of four senior executives. The company's chairman, Richard Broadbent, attributed the mistake to an "unnoticed" issue, while former employees and analysts questioned an aggressive culture that may have prevented staff from warning of the problem. The scandal has raised doubts over Tesco's management and financial oversight, with lawmakers and regulators launching investigations into the matter.

site_title: Norway likely to maintain Yara stake post-merger
summary: Norway is likely to maintain its stake in Yara International ASA after a merger with CF Industries Holdings Inc, despite potential financial costs. The Norwegian state owns about a third of Yara's shares and has a sovereign wealth fund worth $850 billion. If a merger occurs, Norway would have to pay an estimated $4.4 billion to keep its 34% stake, but the government says it's "extremely unlikely" to reduce its stake. The Conservative and Progress parties, which form the minority government, favor keeping minority control to ensure Yara stays based in Oslo.

site_title: Loyal depositors shore up Bank Asya
summary: Loyal depositors of Bank Asya, a Turkish Islamic lender, are raising funds to support the bank amid a power struggle between President Tayyip Erdogan and cleric Fethullah Gulen. Despite reporting a drop in profits and deposits, CEO Ahmet Beyaz claims the bank has a strong capital structure and will survive. The central bank has allowed Bank Asya to access its reserves, but Erdogan has denied any effort to undermine the bank. Pro-government newspapers have portrayed Bank Asya as a failing bank being propped up by Gulen's supporters, prompting the bank to file a lawsuit against regulators.

site_title: Team Juncker put to party politics test
summary: European Commission president-elect Jean-Claude Juncker's nominees face a party politics test as lawmakers consider their suitability. The European Parliament recalled Britain's Jonathan Hill for a second hearing on his fitness to lead the banking and financial services portfolio. Despite concerns, Juncker's nominees are expected to survive the power struggle, with lawmakers likely to pass judgment this week. The outcome will determine the European Commission's leadership.

site_title: More demand for computer memory could lift Micron shares 50%: Barron's
summary: Micron Technology Inc shares could rise 50% due to increased demand for computer memory, driven by businesses replacing Windows XP operating systems and increasing need for "big data" applications. This could lift shares from $34 to over $50, despite a potential price-earnings discount to the semiconductor group. Industry consolidation has reduced the number of DRAM makers to three, leading to increased supply discipline and steadier cash flows.

site_title: France, Germany throw spanner in Draghi's works
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's plan to buy asset-backed securities (ABS) to bolster inflation is facing opposition from Germany and France, two euro-area linchpin economies. Bank of France governor Christian Noyer and Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann have expressed concerns about the plan's design, citing exclusion of national central banks and excessive risk exposure. The opposition suggests Draghi's willingness to deliver a full-throated response to the economy's challenges is in question, potentially undermining investor confidence.

site_title: Pound in biggest weekly drop in 15 months
summary: The pound experienced its largest weekly drop in 15 months, falling to US$1.5960, as UK economic recovery signs faded. This decline was attributed to comments from Bank of England policymaker Ben Broadbent, who stated that the recovery may not warrant higher interest rates. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index gained for a seventh week, while the euro dropped to a two-year low after the European Central Bank kept interest rates at a record low. The US jobless rate fell to a six-year low, further fueling the dollar's rise.

site_title: British resort town may elect anti-EU candidate
summary: Clacton-On-Sea, a British coastal resort town, is set to make history by voting the anti-EU UK Independence Party into parliament for the first time. The by-election comes ahead of 2015 polls and is seen as a potential bridgehead for the party. Local resident Joe, 78, plans to vote UKIP, citing a desire for change. The town has struggled with high unemployment and is the second most-aged town in the country. The by-election could propel Clacton to national prominence, marking a significant shift in British politics.

site_title: Xinjiang unrest takes heavy toll on tourism
summary: Tourism in Xinjiang, a remote region in China's western region, has plummeted for the first time in 20 years due to a series of violent attacks and terrorist incidents. The region, known for its exotic landscapes and ethnic minority groups, has seen a significant drop in visitors, with domestic tourism down 7% and foreign tourism down 1%. The Xinjiang Regional Tourism Bureau attributes the downturn to "influences from recent terrorist attacks". Local businesses are struggling, with hotel workers reporting lower earnings and occupancy rates. Authorities have issued travel cards to tourists visiting with tour groups to boost tourism.

site_title: Putin turns deaf ear to economic alarm
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is ignoring dire warnings from senior officials about the country's economic crisis, despite warnings of an "explosive situation" created by inflation and economic growth expected to be less than 1%. Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev and Sberbank CEO Herman Gref have sounded the alarm, comparing the current state to the Soviet Union's downfall, but their opinions seem to be falling on deaf ears. The IMF has described Russia's economic outlook as "bleak," with massive capital flight and a plummeting ruble, and experts warn of irreparable consequences for the country.

site_title: Global airline IPOs still need tailwind to fly
summary: Global airline initial public offerings (IPOs) have struggled, with only three out of 15 since 2010 trading above their offer price as of October 3. The industry's overall returns remain 2.2% below the cost of capital, according to the International Air Transport Association. Low-cost carriers like Spirit Airlines have performed better, while budget airlines like Tiger Airways have underperformed. Hong Kong Airlines, Virgin America, and Bangkok Airways are among those waiting to list, but face a challenging market with value destruction being the industry's trend. A strong tailwind is needed for successful IPOs.

site_title: China's central bank vows to maintain credit growth
summary: China's central bank stated it will maintain adequate liquidity and reasonable credit growth using various monetary tools. The People's Bank of China also vowed to implement a prudent monetary policy and push forward with interest rate and yuan exchange rate reforms. Despite economic growth momentum faltering, the bank noted that China's growth remains within a reasonable range, aiming to meet its 2014 target of 7.5% economic growth.

site_title: UK stamp dealer gears up for new investors
summary: Stanley Gibbons, the 158-year-old UK-based stamp trading specialist, has taken on six new investors in Singapore with an average portfolio size of £40,000, despite growing interest from the wealthy in alternative investments like stamps. Managing director Keith Heddle plans to open a retail shopfront in Singapore next year and has been building links with the wealth management sector. The company is diversifying beyond stamps, dealing in coins, military medals, and other collectibles, with non-stamp-related activities contributing over a fifth of revenue.

site_title: Flood of junk bond issues worries investors
summary: Global investors are growing wary of low-yielding emerging and European lower-grade corporate "junk" bonds as a flood of new issues hits the market, leading to a decline in prices and a rise in average yields. The first three quarters of 2014 saw $397 billion of emerging market bonds issued, with Chinese banks contributing $100 billion of Asian deals. This has exceeded high-yield, junk bond issues in the US and Europe, causing concerns among investors.

site_title: And soon, a 'buy' button on your social network
summary: Facebook and Twitter are introducing "buy" buttons on their sites, allowing users to make purchases directly from social networks. This move is expected to boost social commerce, which is projected to hit $15 billion by 2015. However, marketers will need a targeted strategy to encourage users to click the "buy" button, as a recent survey found only 5% of Americans have made a purchase on a social media site, but 20% would consider doing so. Concerns about security, privacy, and seamless buying processes will need to be addressed to achieve significant adoption.

site_title: Hamilton wins chaotic Japanese Grand Prix
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the chaotic Japanese Grand Prix, edging out teammate Nico Rosberg in a wet and rain-hit event. However, the victory was overshadowed by a serious crash involving Frenchman Jules Bianchi, who was rushed to hospital with a head injury after a shunt. Bianchi underwent emergency surgery and his condition will be reassessed after 24 hours.

site_title: Plant-based vaccine makers take on big boys
summary: Two companies, Medicago and Caliber Biotherapeutics, are developing plant-based vaccines for influenza, potentially faster and cheaper than traditional methods using chicken eggs. They could produce 50 million doses in weeks, compared to six months, and could be ready for a pandemic. The US government has invested $400 million in start-up funding for biodefense and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) has awarded multi-million-dollar grants to the companies. This technology could threaten the dominance of large pharmaceutical companies in the $3 billion global market for influenza vaccines.

site_title: Irish city nervous about EC probe of Apple
summary: The European Commission is investigating Apple's tax deal with Ireland, potentially amounting to illegal state aid. If found to be illegal, the deal could result in huge economic damage for the Irish city of Cork, where Apple's European headquarters is located. The city's mayor fears the outcome could have significant economic repercussions. Apple has been based in Cork since 1980, and the investigation raises concerns about the company's local tax arrangements.

site_title: Abe neutral on further hike in sales tax: minister
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe remains neutral on raising the national sales tax, Economy Minister Akira Amari said. Abe faces a decision by year's end on whether to double the tax rate over 18 months to curb Japan's runaway government debt. The decision could impact his "Abenomics" strategy to reflate the economy. Abe will scrutinize various data before making a decision, amid concerns about the strength of the country's economic recovery and the risks to investors' confidence.

images.alt_text: HOLDING BACK: Hit by the April tax hike, the economy shrank by a worse-than-expected annualised rate of 7.1 per cent in the second quarter.

site_title: US economy thrives while others struggle
summary: The US economy continues to thrive, with unemployment dropping to a six-year low of 5.9% in September and payrolls rising by 248,000. US factories also experienced their strongest quarter in over three years, while exports reached a record in August. This positive trend contrasts with other countries, such as Vietnam, which was surprised by a potential US tariff increase, and the UK, whose economy shrunk for the second consecutive month. The global economy remains troubled, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and Malaysia seizing assets from a high-profile individual.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard plans to split into two companies: WSJ report
summary: Hewlett-Packard plans to split into two companies: one focused on corporate hardware and services, and another on computer and printer businesses. The division will be made through a tax-free distribution of shares to stockholders next year. This move aims to make HP more agile and capitalize on faster-growing businesses, as investors and analysts have long called for a break-up of the company to focus on more profitable operations. The split will see current CEO Meg Whitman lead the new enterprise company, while Dion Weisler will head the PC and printer company.

images.alt_text: Hewlett-Packard plans to split into two companies, separating its computer and printer businesses from its corporate hardware and services operations, the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: New crop of subprime bonds under scrutiny
summary: Investors are buying a new crop of subprime car loan-backed bonds, despite concerns over lack of transparency and potential for fraud. Ratings companies are awarding top grades to the securities, with yields 0.44 percentage points higher than benchmark rates. The US Justice Department is investigating underwriting and disclosure practices, while the SEC has reduced the amount of information demanded for private deals. Critics say the lack of transparency puts investors at risk, similar to the 2008 housing market crisis that fueled $250 billion losses.

site_title: MARKETS
summary: Global markets declined on the week, with the HSTI index falling 38.97 to 3,253.24. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also dropped, with the Dow falling 103.46 to 17,009.69 and the S&P 500 falling 14.95 to 1,967.90. In forex, the US dollar strengthened against the Singapore dollar and euro, trading at 1.273 and 1.264 respectively. Prime rates in Singapore and Hong Kong remained stable, while Indonesia's rate increased to 14.875. China's shares surged on unverified reports of a sector revival.

site_title: Are we occupied by HK situation?
summary: The Singapore stock market appears unresponsive to recent global events, including the Hong Kong protests and US interest rate hikes. Despite the Hang Seng's potential rebound, investors remain cautious due to the market's low volume and volatility. The lack of confidence in equities is further exacerbated by earnings concerns, with Credit Suisse warning that Asian markets are leading in terms of earnings downgrades. Analysts also note that the third year of a president's term is typically a good year for stocks, but the Fed's liquidity injections may negate this trend.

site_title: US jobs data may still boost markets this week
summary: The US job market showed signs of continued growth, with 250,000 new jobs added in September and the unemployment rate dropping to 5.9%. However, concerns remain over the participation rate, which fell, and the potential impact of automation on the workforce. The start of the third quarter earnings season may reveal whether the economic recovery is sustainable. Analysts expect companies to report 6.4% earnings growth, and the recent drop in oil prices could boost consumer spending. The stock market may continue to rally, but investors will closely watch management commentary for signs of the impact of the stronger US dollar on sales and profit margins.

images.alt_text: ALUMINIUM STRIKES BACK: Slabs of aluminium sit on the production floor of Alcoa's Davenport Works facility in Riverdale, Iowa. Analysts say that the glut in the material is finally clearing up, making Alcoa more significant again.

site_title: Rebound in buying, selling stays down
summary: Singapore Exchange filings from Sept 29 to Oct 3 show buying rebounding while selling among directors remained low. 16 companies recorded 26 purchases worth S$10.2 million, while one firm recorded a disposal worth S$0.20 million. Insider buys were made in Cogent Holdings, Captii Ltd, MTQ Corporation, Best World International, and ITE Electric. Notable buys include CEO Anton Syazi Ahmad Sebi's 20,000 Captii Ltd shares and CEO Kuah Boon Wee's 71,000 MTQ Corporation shares.

site_title: DiCaprio ends talks for role of Steve Jobs: sources
summary: Leonardo DiCaprio has ended talks to star as Steve Jobs in the Sony Corp movie based on Walter Isaacson's biography of the Apple Inc. founder. DiCaprio plans to take a break from acting after completing his current project, The Revenant, scheduled for release in 2015.

site_title: J-Trust stands firm behind LCD purchase (Amended)
summary: Japanese financial giant J-Trust Group has acquired a 29.5% stake in Singapore-listed hospitality group LCD Global Investment, sparking concerns among minority shareholders. J-Trust's president and CEO, Nobuyoshi Fujisawa, believes LCD will flourish under its ownership, leveraging J-Trust's resources and networks. Fujisawa sees LCD as J-Trust's primary platform for property and property-related business across Asia, with plans to finance LCD's expansion through loans and credit guarantees. The acquisition is part of J-Trust's expansion into the non-bank financial space in North-east Asia, with ambitions to grow its property footprint in Japan and across Asia.

images.alt_text: JAPAN'S J-Trust Group's acquisition of Singapore listed hospitality group LCD Global Investment has caused consternation among some of the latter's minority shareholders - ST PHOTO: JENSEN LIM

site_title: US Navy to deploy armed, robotic patrol boats
summary: The US Navy plans to deploy armed, robotic patrol boats with no sailors on board to escort and defend warships in sensitive sea lanes. The technology, adapted from NASA's Mars rovers, was demonstrated in August with 13 robotic patrol craft escorting a ship along the James River in Virginia. The unmanned boats can be outfitted with non-lethal equipment and 50-calibre machine guns, and can fire on an enemy ship if ordered to do so by a sailor. The US military sees the innovation as saving sailors' lives and strengthening its edge, but sceptics have raised concerns about the dangers of armed robots in warfare.

site_title: Poland - symbol of regional stability, resolve
summary: Poland, a key European nation, has maintained solid growth rates and attracted significant new investment, making it a symbol of regional stability and resolve. Since the 2008 financial crisis, Poland's GDP has grown by 25%, with exports increasing from $53 billion to $203 billion. The country's low corporate and household debt, combined with EU aid, has contributed to its prosperity. However, economists warn that Poland needs to invest in education and technology, and encourage new industries and homegrown brands to maintain its progress and competitiveness.

site_title: Interest in new, small cars on the rise
summary: Interest in new, small cars has been rising in Singapore, with some showrooms experiencing a doubling of traffic as owners of aging vehicles shop around for COE Category A models. However, actual sales have not increased significantly, as buyers wait for COE premiums to soften. Many prospective buyers are holding out until the next COE quota announcement in mid-October, expecting prices to decrease. This trend is evident across various brands, with some dealerships reporting a 25% increase in browsing activity, while others, such as Volkswagen and Toyota, have seen no change.

images.alt_text: INTEREST in new cars has been rising steadily in the past month and it is being shown mainly by someone with a small, old car - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Most prices slide as US dollar races higher
summary: Commodity prices declined last week due to a stronger US dollar, abundant supplies, and weak demand. Brent oil fell to two-year lows, gold reached its lowest level this year, and cocoa slid on profit-taking from recent highs linked to Ebola fears. The decline was also influenced by investors' concerns over market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, particularly after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada.

images.alt_text: COMMODITY prices mostly sank last week as the dollar soared on strong US payrolls data, while many markets were also weighed down by abundant supplies and weak demand - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Russian light oil shows up in California
summary: Russian light oil, specifically Sokol, has arrived in California for the first time in six years due to oversupplied markets and slowing demand in Asia. The crude, prized for its high yield of jet fuel and kerosene, was shipped to Tesoro Corp refineries from Korea, bypassing the US West Coast. The US has not imposed sanctions on flows of Russian crude, and the global glut of light oil has depressed prices in Asia, leading to increased competition for supplies.

site_title: WHO in the dock over Ebola crisis
