summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, with aid workers and UN officials blaming a lack of leadership and coordination. The WHO initially played down the outbreak and did not provide adequate support, despite being asked by the affected countries for help. The organization's budget cuts and lack of preparedness have been cited as contributing factors to the crisis. WHO officials have defended their actions, stating that the organization's role is to advise and support countries, not to run clinics.

site_title: Schwab to offer free robo-broker for newbies
summary: Charles Schwab is set to launch a free automated investing service, targeting novice investors, in the coming weeks. The service, developed in-house, will offer features such as portfolio rebalancing and tax-loss harvesting, and is expected to be free, positioning Schwab as the first conventional brokerage with its own robo-broker offering. This move aims to attract young investors and potentially replace affluent but ageing Baby Boomers, who are the bulk of Schwab's client base.

site_title: Taking Heart
summary: A fully sponsored arts programme for pre-schoolers in low-income families in Singapore's west has been launched. The programme, run by The Rice Company, is funded by The Business Times Budding Artist Fund. Wong San's Group will donate 1% of its kids' meal sales at The Playhouse to the fund over two years. The programme aims to introduce young children to the arts, promoting cultural development and accessibility.

site_title: Airbus insider trading trial goes to higher court
summary: An Airbus insider trading trial involving seven current and former executives, as well as two former shareholders, was suspended after lawyers sought dismissal on human rights grounds. The trial was halted pending a higher French court's ruling on the procedure's constitutionality. The case dates back to 2006 and concerns allegations cleared by the French stock market regulator.

site_title: UK stamp dealer gears up for new investors (u)
summary: Stanley Gibbons, the 158-year-old UK-listed stamp trading specialist, has taken on six new investors with an average portfolio size of £40,000 since opening its Singapore office in April. Managing director Keith Heddle is optimistic about the market, citing the growing wealth in Singapore and the potential for stamps to gain value over time. The company plans to open a retail shopfront in Singapore by the end of next year and is launching an online marketplace. Non-stamp-related activities now contribute over a fifth of revenue, with the company diversifying into coins, military medals, and other collectibles.

site_title: S'pore among leaders in regional digital marketing
summary: Singapore ranks among the top leaders in regional digital marketing, according to the third annual Apac Digital Marketing Performance Dashboard survey. The survey found that Singapore, Australia, and India are pulling ahead with strong executive support and digital champions, while Korea, China, and Hong Kong struggle with executive support and skill shortages. Despite this, Singapore's leadership teams are the most receptive to piloting and testing new digital channels and programmes, and marketers are encouraged to set the digital agenda and educate stakeholders on its benefits and value.

site_title: Taiwan's health minister quits over 'gutter oil' scandal
summary: Taiwan's health minister, Chiu Wen-ta, has resigned amid a food safety scandal involving "gutter oil" products. Hundreds of tonnes of tainted oil were removed from sale after investigators discovered the oil was mixed with regular lard and distributed to clients. Yeh Wen-hsiang, chairman of Chang Guann Co., was indicted on 235 counts of fraud and food safety violations for selling the tainted oil. This is the second food safety scandal in Taiwan in less than a year, following a previous case involving adulterated olive oil.

site_title: Singapore bags IP search and examine authority
summary: Singapore has been accorded an important role in the international patent search and examination process by the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), with the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) appointed as an International Searching Authority (ISA) and International Preliminary Examining Authority (IPEA). This appointment is effective from early 2015 and recognizes IPOS as a global authority in intellectual property services. The move is expected to support innovative companies in Singapore by providing easier access to regional markets and strengthening the country's position as an IP hub in Asia.

site_title: Thailand may retake spot as world's top rice exporter
summary: Thailand is poised to regain its position as the world's top rice exporter after ending a controversial subsidy scheme that drove up global prices and damaged the kingdom's market share. Shipments of cheap rice resumed after the end of the subsidy, which had helped former premier Yingluck Shinawatra win rural votes in 2011. Thailand sold 7 million tonnes of rice from January to September, and experts predict the kingdom will sell 10 million tonnes by the end of the year, potentially edging out India in 2014.

site_title: Investors find shelter in ETFs after leaving Pimco
summary: Investors are flocking to exchange-traded funds (ETFs) as a safe-haven option after leaving troubled investment firm Pimco. EP Wealth Advisors, which had invested in Pimco's Total Return Fund for over a decade, moved its $130 million to BlackRock's iShares Core US Aggregate Bond ETF, citing the need for liquidity and time to search for a new manager. The move led to a record trading volume of $791 million for the ETF, highlighting the importance of ETFs for active investors during market turmoil.

site_title: US-EU pact will not include public services
summary: The US and EU have agreed not to include public services privatization in their proposed trade pact, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). This decision was made to address concerns about generalized deregulation, particularly in the agriculture sector and consumer protection. The agreement aims to boost economic growth and create jobs, but a long and difficult path lies ahead to reach a deal. US chief trade negotiator Dan Mullaney stated that the US will not include such provisions, while EU chief negotiator Ignacio Garcia Bercero emphasized that the environment, health, and data privacy will be protected.

site_title: HK protesters allow access to govt offices
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong allowed access to the government headquarters on Sunday, clearing the site ahead of a Monday deadline. The Hong Kong Federation of Students (HKFS) will appoint marshals to provide safe passage for government employees, ensuring no heckling or harassment. The move comes after the government warned workers not to attend the headquarters, amid escalating tensions and calls for a peaceful resolution. Thousands of protesters remained at the main protest site, with dozens still present at the chief executive's office, as talks between student leaders and the government continue.

site_title: US judge orders Argentina to stop servicing exchange bonds locally
summary: A US judge ordered Argentina to stop servicing exchange bonds locally due to its attempts to evade orders in a dispute with hedge funds over debt the country defaulted on in 2002. The judge held Argentina in contempt, stating its local payments were "illegal." This move plunged Argentina into its second default in 12 years, affecting its economy.

site_title: Beware toll of cross-border anti-graft laws
summary: Singapore corporations expanding overseas must be cautious of anti-graft laws, as they can be exposed to liability even with tenuous associations. The UK's Bribery Act and the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) can catch companies with a UK representative office or transactions in the UK, even if unrelated to their UK business. Implementing organisation-wide policies, systems, and controls to prevent and detect corrupt activities is crucial to mitigate liability. Companies must also be aware of the guidance released by UK authorities and the US authorities' resource guide to avoid prosecution.

site_title: Come home to rustic Spanish fare
summary: Terry's Singapore, a new Spanish restaurant in the Les Amis group, has opened its doors at Shaw Centre. The restaurant, named after Juan Carlos de Terry, is known for its classic Spanish cooking. While the menu offers a range of dishes, including pan con tomate, piquillo peppers, and Spanish omelette, some flavors are lacking, and dishes like the octopus and squid ink paella need refinement. However, the gambas and clams are cooked from scratch, and the crispy suckling pig is a standout. With some time to sharpen its cooking, Terry's Singapore has the potential to become a reliable and trustworthy option for Spanish cuisine in Singapore.

site_title: TRANSPORT STOCKS
summary: Stock markets for transport companies saw fluctuations globally. In Singapore, Cosco Corp rose 0.01 to 0.68, while Ezra Holdings fell 0.01 to 0.96. In Kuala Lumpur, Keppel Corp dropped 0.04 to 10.40, and Sembcorp Industries gained 0.08 to 5.14. In Bangkok, Precious Ship rose 0.10 to 23.00, and in Hong Kong, Oilco remained unchanged at 43.00. In the Philippines, Aboitiz Equity surged 0.20 to 53.15, and in Taiwan, Evergreen Marine rose 0.05 to 18.05.

site_title: A storm is brewing in financial markets
summary: A storm is brewing in financial markets as investors worry about a potential dry-up of liquidity, triggered by the US Federal Reserve's halt in bond buying later this month. The euro/dollar rate is expected to fall further, potentially leading to a repricing of already historically expensive assets. Central banks' ability to maintain liquidity may be limited, and investors fear a sharp reversal of the current accommodative monetary policies, which could lead to increased volatility and a pullback from riskier assets.

site_title: GIC among buyers of 3 UK airports: report
summary: A group including Spanish infrastructure firm Ferrovial, Singapore sovereign fund GIC, and Australian bank Macquarie is set to buy three UK airports - Aberdeen, Glasgow, and Southampton - from Heathrow Airport Holdings (HAH) for £1 billion. The deal could be announced in days and would leave HAH with just Heathrow, allowing it to focus on a planned third runway. GIC's involvement is being finalized, but its name may not be publicly disclosed.

site_title: Facebook steps up battle on 'fake likes'
summary: Facebook has stepped up its efforts to combat "fake likes" by obtaining nearly $2 billion in legal judgments against spammers who promise to deliver likes to its members. The social network has implemented various techniques, including algorithms and machine learning, to detect suspicious spikes in likes. Facebook also limits likes per account to make spammers' operations less efficient and has contributed its spam-fighting technology to the academic community. The goal is to preserve authenticity on the platform of over 1 billion members.

site_title: Comfortable future ahead
summary: Comfort Design, a Singapore-based furniture wholesaler, has transformed into a one-stop shop specializing in creating comfort for customers. The company, founded by Bob Chew, offers a wide range of products and customization options, catering to clients including NTUC Food Fare, DBS Bank, and Minor Food Group. With a focus on user comfort, Comfort Design incorporates ergonomic features and warranties into its products. The company's success can be attributed to its strong relationships with clients and employees, as well as its commitment to quality control and after-sales service. Comfort Design is expanding into the residential market, solidifying its position as a leading furniture provider in Singapore.

site_title: Chinese premier to attend Europe summit, sign Russia rail deal
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang will attend the Asia-Europe Meeting summit in Milan, Italy, from Oct 9-16, and visit Germany to sign energy and high-speed rail deals with Russia. The trip comes as China seeks to capitalize on Russia's diplomatic showdown with Europe over Ukraine. Li will sign over 30 agreements on finance, energy, and rail cooperation with Russia, amid close economic and diplomatic ties between the two countries. This marks the second trip by Li to Europe this year, following a March visit to Germany.

site_title: Police arrest triad gang members in Hong Kong clashes
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 19 people, including at least 8 with suspected triad links, following clashes between protesters and authorities. Violence left 12 people injured, including 6 police, and several women reported being sexually assaulted. Police denied collaborating with triads, claiming the arrests were made in response to the protests. The clashes marked a turning point in the pro-democracy protests, which had previously been peaceful, sparking speculation that authorities may have orchestrated the violence to discredit protesters.

site_title: MTP rule - a move in the right direction
summary: Singapore's introduction of a 20-cent minimum trading price (MTP) for stocks aims to enhance the quality of Mainboard-listed companies and weed out underperforming firms. The rule will create a more robust trading environment, raise market liquidity, and reduce volatility. Companies with low trading prices can raise their MTP through share consolidation or share buybacks, while those that fail to meet the requirement will be delisted. The 12-month transition period allows firms to prepare for the change, and the SGX has waived consolidation fees until 2017. The move is expected to benefit retail investors and improve the overall quality of the securities market.

images.alt_text: Lim Soon Hock, Managing Director, PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

site_title: Formula One: Vettel quitting Red Bull team
summary: Sebastian Vettel, the four-time defending Formula One world champion, announced he will quit Red Bull at the end of the current season. Vettel, 27, won all his world titles with Red Bull in a four-year spell of dominance. He will be replaced by 20-year-old Russian Daniil Kvyat, who debuted this season with Red Bull's junior team Toro Rosso.

site_title: Employers divided over re-hiring perks
summary: Business chambers in Singapore have mixed views on the government's plan to introduce incentives to encourage companies to hire older workers. While some, like the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, argue that hiring based on talent is more effective, others, such as the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry, believe the government should help employers reduce costs associated with accommodating senior workers. Industry players emphasize the importance of both employers and employees being willing and able to work beyond the age of 65.

site_title: Feminism's place in fashion
summary: The 2015 spring fashion season raised concerns about feminism and respect in the industry. Designers such as Hermès, Calvin Klein, and Celine favored non-body-conscious silhouettes and non-ornamented styles, while others like Saint Laurent focused on gritty, youthful aesthetics. Karl Lagerfeld's Chanel show featured models carrying placards with feminist slogans, but the message was unclear. The season's emphasis on comfort, luxury, and emotional appeal was seen as a reflection of the industry's focus on pleasing customers rather than elevating fashion forward. The meaning of a "feminist aesthetic" in fashion remains undefined.

site_title: No Internet, S'poreans sure to cry: study
summary: A study by Tata Communications found that 78% of Singaporeans experience negative emotions when without Internet access, ranking high on FOMO. The nation has a high reliance on the Internet, with 43% of respondents using it for over 6 hours daily, second only to India. Despite this, 1 in 4 Singaporeans do not understand where the Internet resides. The study also found that Singaporeans believe the Internet's most beneficial impact is connecting people globally, but differ from respondents in the US and Europe in their vision of the Internet's future inspirational opportunities.

site_title: Apple plans iPad event on Oct 16: report
summary: Apple plans an October 16 event to update its iPad line, which will also feature next-generation software for Macintosh computers. The event will take place at Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, California, a day before the company begins selling its new iPhones in China. This move comes as Apple seeks to expand its presence in the Chinese market, which is its second-largest revenue source after the US. The event follows the successful launch of Apple's large-screen iPhones, including the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus.

site_title: PM: No further sharp curbs on foreign workers
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that no further drastic measures will be taken to curb foreign workers, citing recent manpower numbers that have eased to a sustainable level. This decision comes after years of tightened policies affecting companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Lee emphasized the need to balance "heart" and "head" in population policy, allowing for moderate and sustainable inflows while considering the comfort level of the population and the impact on the economy.

site_title: China aims to sooth transport bottlenecks by 2020
summary: China aims to alleviate transport bottlenecks by 2020, tackling issues like excessive road tolls and poor connectivity. Despite billions invested in infrastructure, logistics costs remain high, accounting for 18% of GDP. The central government outlines a plan to modernize the logistics industry, addressing a fractured market and lack of modern warehousing. The goal is to improve the flow of goods and reduce costs, aiming to catch up with developed countries.

site_title: GM halts delivery of new pickups over faulty air-bags
summary: General Motors has halted deliveries of the 2015 Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon pickup trucks due to a faulty airbag safety system. The company is contacting affected customers to bring their vehicles in for repairs as soon as possible. This is the latest issue for GM, which has recalled nearly 650,000 vehicles for various problems. The company described the airbag issue as a "fast-moving problem" and is urging customers to take action promptly.

site_title: City, non-city condo price gap narrows
summary: The median price gap between resale private condos in city central and city fringes/suburbs has narrowed since 2011, falling to S$461 psf in the second quarter of 2024. The Core Central Region (CCR) and Rest of Central Region (RCR) gap decreased from S$610 psf to S$461 psf, while the city and Outside Central Region (OCR) gap fell from S$870 psf to S$712 psf. Successive cooling measures have contributed to the narrowing gap, indicating a shift in the market.

site_title: UEL to dispose of listed engineering unit for S$230m
summary: UNITED Engineers Ltd (UEL) has agreed to sell its listed engineering unit, UE E&C, to a private equity firm for S$1.25 per share. The deal, subject to terms, is part of UEL's strategy of divestments. The offeror will make a voluntary conditional offer to acquire all UE E&C shares at S$1.25 a share. The sale is expected to generate S$230m for UEL and UES Holdings.

site_title: US: Strong jobs report helps stocks cut weekly losses
summary: US stocks closed the week with losses for a second week, despite a strong jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.60%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.75% and 0.81%, respectively. The September jobs report showed the US economy added 248,000 jobs, bolstering confidence in the economic recovery, but analysts expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates steady due to a weaker economic outlook in China and other factors.

site_title: Facebook may have plans to track your health
summary: Facebook is exploring creating online support communities for users with various ailments and developing preventative care applications to improve lifestyles. The company has been holding meetings with medical industry experts and setting up a research and development unit to test new health apps. This move comes after the success of its "organ-donor status initiative" in 2012, which led to a 21-fold increase in online organ donor registrations. However, concerns over privacy and the lack of targeted advertising may hinder the company's plans.

site_title: Microsoft says Samsung owes US$6.9m in unpaid interest
summary: Microsoft is suing Samsung Electronics for $6.9 million in unpaid interest on royalty payments for smartphone patents. The dispute began after Microsoft announced the purchase of Nokia's handset business in 2013, leading Samsung to initially refuse a payment. However, Samsung eventually paid the late fee without interest. Microsoft is seeking to rule that it did not breach its 2011 agreement with Samsung and is seeking the interest on over $1 billion in delayed payments.

site_title: Shareholders sue Lloyd's Bank, directors for HBOS takeover
summary: Lloyds Bank shareholders have launched a UK class action lawsuit against the bank and former directors, alleging they were misled about the value of Halifax Bank of Scotland (HBOS) before its acquisition in 2008. The shareholders claim HBOS was "effectively worthless" at £5.9 billion, leading to multi-billion pound losses. The lawsuit, which began with 220 signatories, aims to build a case against former Lloyds chairman Victor Blank, CEO Eric Daniels, and other directors for breaching their fiduciary duties.

site_title: Yahoo wants to invest in Snapchat: report
summary: Yahoo is reportedly considering investing in Snapchat, a mobile messaging startup valued at $10 billion. This comes after Yahoo's investment in Alibaba has paid back the initial $1 billion investment. Snapchat, created in 2011, allows users to send text and photo messages that disappear seconds after viewing. The company has rejected a $3 billion buyout offer from Facebook and has been courted by other investors. This move is part of Yahoo's efforts to re-invent itself as an online venue for premium content, following the loss of its internet search service to Google.

site_title: Indonesia radicals in violent protest against new Jakarta governor
summary: Indonesian riot police fired tear gas during clashes with hundreds of Islamic hardliners protesting against the city's incoming Christian Chinese governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama. The Islamic Defenders Front demanded he be prevented from taking office due to his ethnicity and religion. 20 FPI protestors were arrested, and 16 police officers were injured in the clashes. Purnama was in South Korea attending the Asian Games closing ceremony. The FPI, known for violent protests, has targeted Purnama due to his ethnically Chinese background and has succeeded in cancelling events deemed "un-Islamic" in the past.

site_title: World Bank staff press Kim over selective bonuses
summary: The World Bank's staff association has called for a meeting with President Jim Yong Kim due to a "climate of fear and confusion" over bonuses granted to select top officials, citing "major frustration" over cost-cutting measures and insufficient budgets. The association, representing 10,000 staff, requested a town-hall meeting with Kim to address staff concerns and confusion over the bank's restructuring efforts, which include a $5 billion annual expenditure cut. President Kim's bonuses, including a $94,000 bonus for CFO Bertrand Badre, have been a point of contention.

site_title: Cambodian monks rally over casino
summary: Approximately 100 Cambodian Buddhist monks marched in Phnom Penh on Friday to protest the Ministry of Cults and Religion's alleged leasing of the Buddhist Institute's land to a nearby NagaWorld hotel and casino. The protesters called for the Ministry to stop the lease or demolish the complex. Hundreds of anti-riot police were deployed to maintain order, but there were no reported clashes. The monks' demands remain unresolved, with the situation continuing to unfold.

site_title: Talented Turbo
summary: The Porsche Cayenne Turbo has undergone a mid-life makeover, featuring a refreshed design, increased power, and enhanced equipment. The 4.8-litre V8 biturbo engine now produces 520 hp, accelerating from 0-100 km/h in 4.5 seconds. The SUV also features improved air suspension, a new Sport Chrono package with a Sport Plus mode, and a keyless ignition system. With its powerful engine, precise handling, and advanced features, the Cayenne Turbo is a versatile and impressive vehicle.

site_title: Malaysian housing project stresses jobs, food to tackle slums
summary: IRIS Corp Bhd, a Malaysian housing project, aims to alleviate slum poverty by providing jobs, food, and shelter. A pilot scheme built a four-storey, 32-apartment building for $1.5 million, offering a faster alternative to demolishing one-storey shacks. The project's managing director, Tan Say Jim, suggests this approach can free up city space for economic activities. IRIS has built three rural villages and plans 15 more, with African nations interested in the concept, which has seen fewer than 1 in 20 families decline the opportunity.

images.alt_text: URBAN OUTREACH: A ramshackle structure (above) in Kampung Tanah Jawa in Segambut, near Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia's IRIS Corp Bhd has transformed land in Pahang, Malaysia, into a four-storey building with 32 apartments for the country's slum-dwellers.

site_title: Youyue secures nod to move into sustainable energy business
summary: Youyue International Limited has secured shareholders' approval to move into the sustainable energy business. The company will acquire Harbin Prom-lite Energy Saving Technology Co Ltd, specializing in energy conservation services and sustainable developments. This move is seen as a strategic expansion for Youyue, with the group aiming to capitalize on the growing demand for sustainable energy solutions. The acquisition is expected to bring significant benefits to the company's bottom line.

site_title: PM: No further sharp curbs on foreign workers
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee reassured foreign workers that no further sharp curbs will be imposed, easing concerns for SMEs affected by the foreign workforce. RAS and SMTA presidents welcomed the move, citing the need to maintain productivity and avoid exacerbating the situation. Lee emphasized the importance of balancing being "hard-hearted" with being "good-hearted" and understanding the past to create a brighter future for Singapore.

site_title: BOJ chief says weaker yen is good for Japan
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's aggressive monetary-easing strategy, stating that a weaker yen is good for the economy. The yen has plummeted to a six-year low against the US dollar, but Kuroda believes it won't pose a major problem. He also reaffirmed the BOJ's 2% annual inflation target, achievable in around two years, despite concerns from critics and economists. Kuroda's comments come as Japan's economy faces challenges, including eroding real incomes and friction with Asian competitors.

site_title: Absolute power a double-edged sword
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has become the country's most powerful leader since Deng Xiaoping, with significant centralization of power. Despite facing constraints on executive power, Xi's leadership bears comparison to pre-revolutionary China, raising concerns about the "bad emperor" syndrome. Xi's anti-corruption drive has netted high-profile figures, but the concentration of power in one person's hands means his personal qualities and abilities have profound implications for the nation. Xi's rule enjoys widespread popular support, but the potential for the "bad emperor" syndrome remains, particularly as he faces his biggest test in the Occupy Central protests in Hong Kong, where he must balance his power with democratic ideals.

site_title: Tuan Sing soars to five-year high
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings' shares hit a five-year high, rising 6.7% to S$0.475, after announcing the pricing of its S$80 million 4.5% notes due 2019. The notes will be issued at 100% of their principal amount, with a fixed interest rate of 4.5% per annum. This issuance is expected to be used for financing investments and general working capital. The move follows a significant increase in the company's shareholdings by Koh Wee Meng, chairman and CEO of the Fragrance Group, who raised his stake from 4.46% to 5.02%.

site_title: Political infighting breaks out over reviews for European Commission members
summary: The European Parliament clashed with candidates for Jean-Claude Juncker's executive team, including Pierre Moscovici, Jonathan Hill, and Miguel Arias Canete, over their responses to written questions and testimonies. The parliament delayed a vote on approving Canete due to concerns over a potential conflict of interest. The battle threatens to force Juncker to reshuffle his team, which could hinder the EU's focus on economic issues just as it's meant to be a key platform. The European Parliament has the power to reject or modify the team's composition.

site_title: September jobless rate falls to 6-year low of 5.9%
summary: The US jobless rate fell to a six-year low of 5.9% in September, with 248,000 new jobs added, exceeding projections. Average hourly earnings remained stagnant. The trade deficit narrowed to its lowest level in seven months, with a record US$198.5 billion in exports. The stronger-than-expected hiring growth is expected to sustain faster economic growth, with the underemployment rate decreasing to 11.8%.

site_title: Up to 100 years of rent-free land lures 7 S'pore food firms to Korea
summary: Seven Singaporean food firms have agreed to set up factories in Foodpolis, South Korea, in exchange for 100 years of rent-free land. The initiative, backed by the Korean government, aims to attract investors to the region. The companies will also receive other perks, such as tax breaks and subsidies, for establishing their factories. This move is seen as a significant step towards strengthening economic ties between Singapore and Korea. The agreement was reached following an invitation to set up factories in Foodpolis.

site_title: Bank regulators urged to be more flexible
summary: Bank regulators are being urged to be more flexible in setting rules for the world's largest banks, particularly regarding capital requirements. The G-20 is set to issue a draft rule in November, which many major banks believe needs to be tailored to each institution. The proposed rule would double the capital cushion banks are required to hold, but leaders are pushing for more flexibility to accommodate individual bank needs.

site_title: New beginnings for OCBC Wing Hang
summary: OCBC Wing Hang, a Hong Kong bank, has officially rebranded as OCBC Wing Hang, marking a new beginning for the 77-year-old bank. The new name and logo, featuring OCBC Bank's signature Chinese sailing vessel symbol, have been unveiled and are now reflected across all 80 branches in Hong Kong and Macau. The rebranding aims to enhance customer experience and reflect the bank's integration with OCBC Bank.

site_title: Specially for you
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Customized gifts are now available for expectant parents and kids. Amutha Saravanan offers "belly pots" made from clay and glazes, which can be used as functional dishes and bowls. Jayl Chen creates unique plates and mugs with illustrations that cater to personal preferences. ABC Me Books offers personalized children's books, teaching the alphabet and promoting letter and name recognition. Happy Hands Project provides custom calligraphy and lettering services for weddings and special occasions, using a range of techniques and materials. These businesses aim to create lasting memories and personalized products for families.

site_title: SMEs 'modestly upbeat for next 6 months'
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are modestly optimistic about their prospects for Q4 2014 to early 2015, with business services and construction SMEs being the most positive. The SME Index, measuring the sentiments of 3,000 SME owners and managers, shows a score of 55.5 points, indicating a positive outlook for the next six months. The sectors of business services and construction/engineering are the most optimistic, with business expansion expectations and capital investment plans rising.

site_title: First package of bus routes up for tender
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has put the first package of bus routes up for tender, comprising 26 services, to be implemented from the second half of 2016. Both local and foreign operators may bid for the right to operate the services under the Government Contracting Model (GCM). The tender move is seen as cautious by some observers, who express concerns about the potential for overpayment and taxpayer dissatisfaction. The tender process is expected to attract bids from several overseas and local operators.

site_title: IMF: Open up labour markets or face mediocre growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that the global economy may be stuck in a "new mediocre" growth path due to high debt and unemployment unless policymakers implement reforms. The eurozone, particularly, is at risk of low growth, high unemployment, and low inflation. The IMF is likely to downgrade its global economic forecasts, citing a disappointing recovery and mounting risks. Christine Lagarde called for bold policies and reforms to bolster growth, but efforts to secure action in the eurozone have been hindered by Germany's reluctance to stimulate.

site_title: Team SunMoon in a galaxy of its own
summary: Team SunMoon has won the BT Corporate Golf League for the third consecutive year, beating 20 teams in six rounds of competition over three months. The team's captain, Gary Loh, attributes their success to sticking to their plan, and they will likely return as a social team next year. Audi quattro topped the Category A table, while Team SPH Sultans of Swing and Tat Hong's The Crane Boomers finished second in the Open Category. The league's organizers praised the event's mix of competitiveness, networking, and fun, and sponsors expressed their appreciation for the opportunity to network with business leaders.

site_title: wine& dinewith BTWeekend
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore hotels are offering various promotions and dining experiences. Marina Mandarin Singapore offers a "Experience Singapore Package" with complimentary buffet breakfast and river cruise tickets. Conrad Centennial Singapore features a "Lunch On The Go" menu and a "Weekend Afternoon High Tea" with oysters and chocolate. Swissôtel The Stamford's Equinox Restaurant offers a semi-buffet lunch and high tea, while Mandarin Orchard Singapore's Triple Three features an international Japanese-inspired buffet. Pan Pacific Orchard Singapore's 10 at Claymore offers a crustacean celebration with unlimited seafood and desserts. Serenity Spanish Restaurant in Ngee Ann City and Graffiti Sky Bar in Carlton City Hotel also offer unique dining experiences.

site_title: Swimming through garbage in the world's oceans
summary: A swimmer, who is the UN Patron of the Oceans, spent four weeks swimming in the world's oceans, including the Mediterranean, Adriatic, and Red Seas. The swim highlighted the dire state of marine ecosystems due to overfishing, pollution, and habitat destruction. The swimmer observed severe depletion of marine life, including sharks, whales, and dolphins, as well as massive amounts of plastic waste and non-native species. The swimmer argues that protecting marine ecosystems through marine protected areas is crucial for recovery and that it's essential for humans to take responsibility for the health of the oceans.

site_title: HK protests, Wall St fall add to market woes
summary: Pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong led to a significant decline in the Hang Seng Index, with the index falling 39 points or 1.2% for the week. The protests also impacted Singapore's Straits Times Index, which fell for the first four days of the week before rebounding on Friday. The decline in Hong Kong's manufacturing PMI and concerns over Beijing's reaction to the protests have added to market worries. The US stock market also experienced volatility, with large plunges on Wall Street, although the reasons for the weakness were unclear.

site_title: Eurozone business growth hits 2014 low in September
summary: Eurozone business growth reached its lowest point in 2014 in September, with new orders at a near-one-year low, according to surveys. Firms cut prices at a faster rate, indicating difficulty in increasing inflation due to weak demand and a stagnating economy. This challenges the European Central Bank's efforts to bring inflation back up.

site_title: The lingering legacy of Pimco's co-founder
summary: Pimco, a leading bond giant, is continuing to implement the investment thesis of its late co-founder, Bill Gross, despite his departure. The "new neutral" approach, which suggests a stagnating global economy will keep interest rates low, remains a guiding principle for the company. However, investors have withdrawn an estimated $23.5 billion from Pimco's flagship fund, the Total Return Fund, in September, the largest outflow in the fund's history. Pimco's new management team, led by Daniel Ivascyn, is doubling down on Gross's economic mantra, but progress in regaining investor trust has been slow, with performance continuing to trail its peers.

images.alt_text: DOMINEERING MANNER: Bill Gross, who would have been forced out had he not left last Friday, had called his insight the 'new neutral'.

site_title: Tokyo reassures small firms on weak yen
summary: Japan's government has pledged assistance to small companies hurt by the country's weakening yen, urging large businesses and exporters to pass on rising input costs to smaller enterprises. The move aims to kindle sustained inflation in the economy, which has been marred by two decades of stagnation. The yen has fallen to its lowest against the US dollar since 2008, sparking concerns about the impact on purchasing power and export earnings.

site_title: Trafigura raises US$1.73b credit facilities
summary: Trafigura, a commodity trader, has raised US$1.73 billion in credit facilities from Asian banks, exceeding its initial target of US$1.3 billion. The oversubscribed syndicated facilities demonstrate strong backing from the banking community.

site_title: RadioShack reaches US$590m refinancing deal
summary: RadioShack has secured a $590 million refinancing deal led by Standard General LP, allowing the electronics chain to access more cash and flexibility ahead of the holiday season. The deal refines $535 million of loans and provides room for RadioShack to close underperforming stores, reducing cash burn. The agreement is part of RadioShack's efforts to improve liquidity, with Standard General holding a significant stake in the company.

site_title: Tokio Marine seeking more M&A targets in N America
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc, Japan's largest insurer by market capitalization, is seeking more acquisition targets in North America, following a history of aggressive overseas expansion. CEO Tsuyoshi Nagano said the company has a list of 10-20 potential targets globally and is prepared to spend billions on acquisitions. Premiums from non-Japanese businesses are expected to reach $12.9 billion this financial year, accounting for 36% of total earnings. Nagano aims to achieve a return on equity of at least 8% over the next three years, driven by overseas operations.

images.alt_text: Mr Nagano (above) says the company always keeps a list of 10-20 potential acquisition targets globally and keeps close tabs on them.

site_title: Not-so-golden week looms for retailers
summary: Pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong are disrupting the city's shopping season during Golden Week, a crucial time for retailers. Demonstrators are occupying shopping areas, shutting stores, and testing the patience of Chinese tourists who account for 75% of the city's visitors. The protests have led to a decline in sales of jewelry, watches, and other valuable gifts, with some companies expecting a 30% drop in revenue during Golden Week. The demonstrations have also prompted China's tourism board to cease approving new tour groups to Hong Kong.

site_title: Simple requirements
summary: A Chia family in Sembawang, Singapore, has built a unique three-storey semi-detached home with only two bedrooms, prioritizing communal space over individual rooms. The design consultant, Kelvin Lim, created a home with large empty spaces for the family to gather, including an outdoor sitting area, dining space, and a ledge that runs through the middle of the house, connecting the bedrooms and other spaces. The family uses the ledge as a bridge to spend time together or have individual activities, while also featuring a gym, outdoor sitting area, and a bookshelf for Mrs. Chia's personal items. The home's design emphasizes simplicity and comfort, allowing the family to relax and enjoy quality time together.

site_title: Strong growth in SGX derivatives & commodities business in September
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported strong growth in its derivatives and commodities business in September, with average daily value traded in derivatives increasing 18% year-over-year to S$1.3 billion. Total value traded in securities declined 34% to S$21 billion, while 10.6 million contracts were traded, up 13% from August. The exchange also saw record volumes in its Asiaclear commodities clearing service, with a 78% increase in total contracts traded and a 56% jump in rubber futures contracts.

site_title: Knee injury forces Serena to withdraw from China Open
summary: Serena Williams withdraws from the China Open due to a left knee injury, forcing her to miss the US$5.4 million tournament ahead of her quarter-final match. The world No. 1 is uncertain if her participation in the WTA Finals in Singapore will be affected, pending an MRI scan. Williams had been seeking to retain her year-end number one ranking and was also a strong contender to win the WTA Finals, which she has won four times.

site_title: Big diamond finds harder to pull off
summary: Diamond explorers have largely given up searching for the gem due to the significant financial investment with minimal results. Since 2000, over $7 billion has been spent, with no major finds, leading to a 50% drop in exploration investment since 2007. Producers, including BHP Billiton, have shifted their focus, and the diamond industry's prospects appear bleak.

site_title: The new 'new Tiong Bahru'
summary: Tiong Bahru, a Singaporean neighborhood, is undergoing a transformation from a sleepy estate to a trendy cafe cluster. New businesses, including boutique stores, record shops, and restaurants, have opened in the area, catering to a younger demographic. Decades-old businesses have also revamped themselves to suit the times. Despite concerns over the impact on the area's heritage, many residents welcome the changes, citing the importance of evolution and the preservation of architecture through government conservation efforts. The neighborhood now boasts a diverse range of establishments, from heritage bistro The Tiong Bahru Club to independent record store Curated Records, offering a unique blend of local culture and international influences.

site_title: Tuan Sing to raise S$80m in note issuance, counter hits 5-year high
summary: TUAN Sing Holdings' counter surged 6.7% to S$0.475 on Friday, a five-year high, ahead of its S$80 million 4.5% note issuance. The notes will be issued at 100% of principal, with fixed interest and semi-annual payments. DBS Bank and HSBC are joint lead managers and bookrunners. The net proceeds will be used for financing investments and working capital.

site_title: U.S. jobless rate falls to six-year low in September
summary: The US jobless rate fell to a six-year low of 5.9% in September, with non-farm payrolls rising by 248,000, exceeding analyst expectations. This strong hiring data could bolster bets on a Federal Reserve rate hike in mid-2015 or earlier, as the labor market continues to improve. The economy is expected to expand at a 3% annual rate in the third quarter, well above the two-year average.

site_title: The sky's the limit for Huationg's cranes
summary: Huationg, a Singapore-based logistics provider, is upgrading its business model to boost its reputation as a world-class logistics provider. The company, founded in the 1980s, has expanded its services to include machinery rental, heavy-lifting project management, and crane operations. With a focus on efficiency, flexibility, and safety, Huationg has attracted clients from diverse sectors, including construction and shipping. The company is also prioritizing human capital, offering attractive remuneration packages and in-house training programs to ensure a skilled workforce. Huationg's expansion plans include entering new markets and increasing its presence in Myanmar, where it established its first subsidiary in 2012.

site_title: Smoother operator
summary: The Peugeot 5008 has undergone a facelift, featuring new headlights, a grille, and a 3D Peugeot lion badge. The interior now boasts a new head-up display and a centre monitor displaying GPS navigation and a reverse camera. The automated manual gearbox has been reprogrammed for smoother gear shifts, but still experiences torque interruption. The vehicle's strong turbodiesel engine and fluid transmission make for an engaging drive, despite some limitations in mid-corner shifting. The updated model is priced at S$144,900.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Two brokerages, Credit Suisse and UOB Kay Hian, have initiated coverage on energy companies KrisEnergy and Triyards Holdings. KrisEnergy is rated "outperform" with a target price of S$0.93, driven by its 94% production CAGR and potential to reach 20,000 boe/d in 2016. Triyards Holdings is rated "buy" with a target price of S$1.10, driven by its strong liftboat business and growing demand in Asia. Both companies have attractive valuation and growth potential, with KrisEnergy boasting a 17% upside potential and Triyards Holdings trading at a cheap 5.4x PE.

site_title: CAO eyes more acquisitions
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) aims to double its 2012 gross profits by 2020 by acquiring more assets in China and Europe, with a focus on synergistic investments in jet fuel and oil products. The company's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, stated that investments so far are insufficient to meet the target, and new acquisitions will help secure supply, optimize logistics, and boost demand. CAO's existing assets, including a stake in Shanghai Pudong International Airport's jet fuel supplier and a pipeline supplying Beijing Airport, will be leveraged to drive growth.

site_title: US cuts Indonesian debt in return for US$12m wildlife protection
summary: The US has agreed to reduce Indonesia's debt in exchange for approximately $12 million for wildlife conservation programs on Sumatra island. This deal, brokered by Conservation International, aims to protect endangered species and habitats. Similar agreements were made in 2009, where Indonesia pledged $30 million for forest conservation. The US government contributed most of the debt swap funds, while Conservation International also provided some. The deal benefits critical ecosystems in Sumatra and increases conservation efforts for species like Sumatran rhinos and tigers.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 3.14 points higher
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 3.14 points to 1,840.82. A total of 1.70 billion lots worth RM1.50 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 408 to 367.

site_title: Giving heart bypass a miss
summary: Doctors are now successfully treating 100% blocked heart arteries using minimally invasive techniques, achieving high success rates of over 90% with low complication rates. This is possible due to advancements in equipment and techniques, allowing highly experienced specialists to open blocked heart arteries with high accuracy. The procedure, known as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), has become a viable alternative to open heart bypass graft surgery, which has limitations and higher risks. Patients should consult with a heart specialist to make an informed decision about the best treatment option for their specific condition.

images.alt_text: IN GOOD HANDS: Highly experienced heart specialists are able to achieve a success rate of close to 90 per cent during the first attempt at opening a CTO and this is achieved with a low complication rate.

site_title: (Update)Clashes as backlash builds against Hong Kong protesters
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong clashed with groups opposed to their campaign, leading to barricades being dismantled in two busy shopping districts. The clashes followed days of anti-government demonstrations, with protesters demanding fully free elections. China has expressed concern, while the US, Europe, and Japan have also spoken out. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying refused to resign, instead appointing his deputy to meet with a prominent students' group. Talks have yet to start, with mistrust growing that Leung is trying to buy time.

site_title: Heathrow set to sell regional airports to GIC, Ferrovial group: Sky
summary: Heathrow Airport Holdings is set to sell three regional airports, Aberdeen, Glasgow, and Southampton, to a group including Ferrovial, Singapore's GIC, and Australian bank Macquarie for 1 billion pounds. The sale would leave Heathrow as the sole airport under HAH, allowing the company to focus on its plan to build a third runway. The deal, which could be announced in days, is a result of HAH's efforts to conclude a transaction by the end of 2014 and comes after Ferrovial made an 800 million pound offer in February.

site_title: Bentley joins ultra-luxury fast lane
summary: Bentley, a 95-year-old British luxury car brand, has launched the Mulsanne Speed, its fastest ultra-luxury saloon, at the Paris auto show. The $411,000 model boasts an 8-cylinder engine, reaching 100km/h in 4.9 seconds and a top speed of 305kph. To boost sales, Bentley aims to double its deliveries of high-end cars by 2018, targeting 133,000 vehicles. This diversification into luxury SUVs in 2016 is crucial to capturing a growing market, with the super-rich prioritizing performance and brand loyalty over traditional loyalty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.64% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended 0.64% higher on Friday, reversing morning losses, ahead of talks with pro-democracy protestors who have shut down parts of the financial hub. The Hang Seng Index rose 147.49 points to 23,080.47 on $12.41 billion in turnover, despite being down for the week. The index was closed on Wednesday and Thursday for public holidays.

site_title: HK student leaders call off talks with govt
summary: Hong Kong student leaders have called off talks with the government, citing violent clashes between pro-Beijing supporters and protesters. The clashes, which included attacks on Occupy camps, were seen as orchestrated by paid thugs from "triad" gangs. The students had been seeking free elections in Hong Kong, but the government had promised talks in an attempt to end the protests. The decision to call off talks follows widespread allegations of violence and sexual assault during the clashes, with the US, Europe, and Japan expressing concern over the situation.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end the day higher
summary: Singapore shares rose 24.53 points to close at 3,253.24 on Friday, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Straits Times Index saw 1.11 billion shares worth S$910 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 245 to 166.

site_title: Chinese borrowers go for S$ bonds
summary: Chinese borrowers are tapping the Singapore market with record-breaking offerings, with S$1.7 billion in local currency-denominated notes sold this year, more than double 2013 sales. Private investors in Singapore took almost all of the S$380 million of local dollar-denominated notes sold by mainland Chinese companies excluding banks last month, citing cheaper rates. This surge is attributed to the island's affluent population, which requires S$1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: EU clears Facebook's US$19b buyout of WhatsApp
summary: The European Union's executive arm, the European Commission, has cleared Facebook's $19 billion buyout of WhatsApp, despite opposition from telecom companies. The commission stated that Facebook and WhatsApp are not close competitors and that consumers will continue to have a wide array of choices. The decision was made after reviewing the deal and concluding that it would not hamper competition in the dynamic and growing market. The commission found that the transaction would not raise competition concerns, despite concerns over access to user data and unfair competition advantages.

site_title: Macau dealers stage walk out
summary: Hundreds of Macau casino workers, including up to 300 dealers, walked off the job to demand higher wages and better benefits. The strike, led by the Forefront of Macau Gaming labor union, follows labor unrest in the region. MGM China Holdings Ltd declined to comment on the strike. The move is part of a wave of labor unrest affecting casino operators in Macau, which is facing shrinking revenues.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe declined, with banks and healthcare sectors dragging, amid US-EU tariff tensions. The US stock market edged down from records due to tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Air France may revise strike cost higher: source
summary: Air France may revise the cost of its two-week pilots strike to 400 million euros (S$641 million) due to losses from cancelled bookings, according to a source. The company initially estimated the strike cost at 300 million euros. Air France plans to announce a revised estimate of losses on October 8. The strike occurred before the company targeted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) of 2.2-2.3 billion euros for 2014.

site_title: S'pore jets off into high-end products
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector remains a significant contributor to its economy, with precision engineering playing a key role. The country's industry stays ahead with high-performance parts for Boeing aircraft, such as landing gear components. Despite rising competition from China, Singapore's model of shifting to niche, high-value-added sectors is seen as a success. The government has invested heavily in research and development, and the country's high-wage jobs and skilled workforce have attracted global companies. Singapore's economy is expected to continue to thrive, with the manufacturing sector accounting for around 20% of the economy.

site_title: First bus package up for tender
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has put the first bus package under the Government Contracting Model (GCM) up for tender. The package includes 26 bus routes, originating from three interchanges and terminating at five, with buses to be operated from a new Bulim Bus Depot. Local and foreign operators can bid for the contract, with the progressive implementation of the services starting from the second half of 2016.

site_title: Trafigura gets new US$1.73 bln credit from Asian banks
summary: Trafigura, a commodity trader, successfully raised US$1.73 billion credit facilities from Asian banks, exceeding the initial US$1.3 billion target. The facilities include a 364-day revolving credit, a three-year term loan, and a one-year CNH denominated tranche. The new credit lines were well-supported by the banking community and were oversubscribed, demonstrating strong investor confidence in the company.

site_title: Blockade lifted at Indonesia copper mine
summary: A two-day blockade at Indonesia's Grasberg copper mine, operated by Freeport-McMoRan Inc, has ended after a meeting with workers on safety concerns. The mine's operations remain suspended until Tuesday as the government investigates the deaths of four workers on Saturday. A spokesperson for the company did not provide details on when operations might resume.

site_title: Sept euro zone business grew at the slowest rate
summary: The euro zone business grew at the slowest rate this year in September, with new orders and prices falling, according to surveys. The Markit Composite Purchasing Managers' Index fell to a 10-month low of 52.0, indicating stagnant growth. This weak demand and falling prices may pressure the European Central Bank to broaden its asset purchases, including government debt. The euro zone's economy stagnated in the second quarter, and inflation remains at a five-year low of 0.3%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.16% lower as protests drag on
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.16% on Friday, marking the third consecutive day of losses amid ongoing pro-democracy protests that have closed parts of the city. The Hang Seng Index dropped 265.83 points to 22,667.15. The protests, which began in September, show no signs of ending, and investors are concerned about the impact on the city's economy. The decline in Hong Kong shares follows a two-day public holiday, and traders are watching US-EU trade talks for further market movements.

site_title: Australia: Shares reverse losses to end higher on week, banks rally
summary: Australian shares reversed early losses to finish 0.4% higher on Friday, ending a five-week losing streak. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,318.20, driven by a late-session rally in banks and high-yielding stocks ahead of US jobs data. This week's gain was the first since June, snapping the losing streak.

images.alt_text: - REUTERS

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 5.56 points to 3,223.15. Volume was 39.4 million shares worth S$42.3 million. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating loss compared to H1. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Defiant HK protesters clash with police despite talks offer
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong clashed with police outside government offices on Friday, despite an offer for talks. Over 100 protesters remained at the scene, skeptical of the talks with Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying. The clashes follow five days of protests that have brought parts of the city to a standstill. China described the protesters as "doomed to fail." The talks aim to defuse escalating tensions, but the protesters' demands for Leung's resignation remain unchanged.

site_title: Government to cut its central London buildings by 80%
summary: The UK government plans to cut its central London buildings by 80% and move over half of its London civil servants to cheaper areas by 2020. This is part of a plan to reduce costs, foster economic growth, and save billions for taxpayers. Currently, 72 government buildings have been vacated, and the goal is to reduce the total number of buildings in London to 23. This move is expected to save taxpayers billions of pounds by 2030. The policy will also lead to the sale or lease of existing central London locations, freeing up space for housing and businesses.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises on Fast Retailing's strong sales; HK unrest caps upside
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by Fast Retailing's strong sales, but gains were limited by Hong Kong unrest. The Nikkei index ended at 15,708.65, with the broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gaining 0.2%. Investors awaited the US jobs data release, which curbed risk appetite.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.38 points to 1838.06. Volume reached 27.97 million lots worth RM8.56 million, with 77 gainers and 68 losers.

site_title: Singapore questions foreigners over Hong Kong vigil
summary: Singapore police have questioned several foreign nationals over their participation in a candlelit vigil in support of Hong Kong pro-democracy protests. The vigil, which drew over 100 people, was held at Singapore's Speakers' Corner, a free-speech zone, despite only Singapore citizens and permanent residents being allowed to participate. The police stated that the foreigners were being investigated for offences under the Public Order Act, with no arrests made. The police emphasized that foreigners must abide by Singapore's laws and not conduct activities that can disturb public order.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Land, Swiber Holdings, Sitra Holdings
summary: Keppel Land begins construction on 37 storeys of offices and serviced apartments in Ho Chi Minh City's Saigon Centre Phase Two. Swiber Holdings sees its stake in Vallianz Holdings diluted due to increased share capital, with brokers downgrading the stock due to slow order flow and thin margins. Sitra Holdings' share price surges 36% after a bullish report estimated the company's stake in a Singapore industrial property to be worth more than initially thought, potentially delivering a valuation surplus.

site_title: Facebook tightens reins on research at social network
summary: Facebook has tightened its research methods following an outcry over a secret study on how posts affect moods. The social network has introduced a new framework to review proposed research projects and clarify how studies should be handled. A panel of senior personnel will scrutinize research to ensure it falls within acceptable guidelines. Facebook has also made research practices part of its employee training program. The move comes after a study was criticized for manipulating users' emotions without their explicit consent.

site_title: Marubeni to focus on trading naphtha, LNG from crude
summary: Japanese trading house Marubeni Corp is refocusing its energy trading on naphtha and liquefied natural gas (LNG), shifting away from crude due to low margins and competition. The company is pulling back on crude and fuel oil trading, instead concentrating on naphtha and LNG, and will continue to supply gasoline and kerosene to Japanese customers. Marubeni aims to become a niche market player in the energy trading business, citing tighter regulation and increased prominence of large international trading firms. The company's energy trading department will remain intact despite staff cuts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.27%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.27% lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 41.51 points to 15,620.48, amid dollar weakness against the yen and anticipation of US payroll data. The dollar has backed off from a 110 yen barrier, making Japanese exports more expensive abroad. A strong yen erodes profits when repatriated. US payrolls data will be crucial, with a strong labor report potentially pushing the dollar back up.

site_title: SMEs forecast modest growth outlook for next 6 Months
summary: Singaporean SMEs are modestly optimistic about their business prospects for the next six months, with a 1.1% increase in the Singapore Business Federation (SBF)-DP Information Group (DP) SME Index to 55.5 points. The business services and construction/engineering sectors are the most confident, driven by strong outlooks and government initiatives to improve productivity. However, commerce/trading, manufacturing, and transport/storage SMEs are reporting lower revenue expectations due to softening global demand. Overall turnover expectations increased to 5.71 points, with business services SMEs projecting more projects and expansion in the next two quarters.

site_title: Aldermore listing to raise S$154m
summary: British bank Aldermore plans to list on the stock market this month, raising about S$154 million. The bank has set a price range of 217-265 pence per share, implying a market capitalisation of US$1.29 billion. Aldermore focuses on lending to small and medium-sized businesses and homeowners, and the listing is expected to take place around October 17.

site_title: China Sept official services PMI falls to 8-month low
summary: China's services sector growth eased to an 8-month low in September, with the official PMI falling to 54.0 from 54.4 in August. This marks the first time new orders have shrunk for at least a year, indicating weakness in the world's second-largest economy. The data suggests China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip, protests hit Hong Kong
summary: Asian markets slipped on Friday, with Hong Kong falling 1.10% as pro-democracy protests continued for a sixth day, despite the city's chief executive offering to talk to protest leaders. The Hang Seng Index closed for holidays, with major banks HSBC and Standard Chartered losing 1.9% and 2.8%, respectively. The euro rose against the yen and US dollar after the European Central Bank refrained from unveiling new measures to combat deflation.

site_title: Up to 100 possibly exposed to US Ebola patient; four isolated
summary: A US Ebola patient, identified as Thomas Eric Duncan, a Liberian national, has been diagnosed with the deadly virus after traveling to Texas from Liberia via Brussels and Washington. Up to 100 people, including four individuals in a Dallas apartment, have been potentially exposed to the virus, with no reported symptoms. Health officials are conducting thorough contact tracing and providing care to those who may have been infected. The US healthcare system is well-prepared to contain the outbreak, with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) working to track those who may have had contact with Duncan and develop a treatment for the virus.

site_title: Bad car loans pile up in Thailand as consumers bear more debt
summary: Thailand's auto lenders have repossessed three times as many cars as last year, with defaults soaring in a flatlining economy. Household debt has risen to over 80% of the country's total output, making it difficult for consumers to spend their way out of stagnation. Small and medium-sized banks are most exposed, with non-performing loans increasing to a four-year high of 2.45% in the second quarter. This has hurt earnings growth of car loan providers, leading some analysts to cut their forecasts.

site_title: Hong Kong student protesters agree to government talks
summary: Hong Kong student protesters agreed to meet with the government to discuss demands for universal suffrage, following a midnight deadline to stand down. The Hong Kong Federation of Students (HKFS) vowed to continue occupying the streets until their goal is achieved, criticizing Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying for his decision to use tear gas on peaceful demonstrators. The HKFS sees Leung's resignation as "a matter of time," and will continue the protest movement until genuine universal suffrage is achieved.

site_title: China Investment, Avic end talks to buy Avolon
summary: China Investment Corp (CIC) and Avic Capital Co Ltd have ended talks to acquire Avolon Holdings Ltd, a Dublin-based aircraft leasing company, making an initial public offering (IPO) the most likely option for its private equity owners. The deal was valued between $4 billion and $5 billion, but failed to materialize. Avolon, backed by private equity firms and Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, had registered for an IPO in the US and is working with major banks on the deal.

site_title: Hong Kong protests 'doomed to fail': China party paper
summary: China's official Communist party newspaper has stated that Hong Kong protests are "doomed to fail" and will not make concessions to pro-democracy protesters. The protesters' demands for unfettered elections are deemed "neither legal nor reasonable." China's National People's Congress had previously ruled that candidates for Hong Kong elections would be selected by a committee, a move protesters see as "fake democracy." The protesters have agreed to hold talks with the government, but vowed to continue their occupation if their demands are not met.

site_title: Origins rewrite fails to draw blood
summary: The movie "Dracula Untold" tells the origin story of Vlad the Impaler, a 15th-century prince who makes a Faustian pact with a vampire to save his kingdom from invading Turks. Despite initial reluctance, Vlad accepts the pact and gains superhuman strength, immortality, and supernatural powers. However, the film fails to draw suspense or excitement, toning down the horror elements and following a predictable plot. The movie holds little surprise and lacks bite, despite its attempt to retell the Dracula legend.

site_title: Google threatened with lawsuit over leaked celebrity photos: NY Post
summary: Google is threatened with a lawsuit over leaked celebrity photos posted online by hackers, according to an attorney representing about a dozen female celebrities. Lawyer Martin Singer claims Google is profiting from the victimization of women and could be liable for over $100 million in damages. Singer says Google is aware that the images are hacked, stolen, and private, and that the company is violating victims' privacy rights and basic human decency.

site_title: Emaar Properties mulls listing hotels unit
summary: Emaar Properties, Dubai's largest listed developer, may take its hotels unit public after the successful listing of its malls and retail subsidiary, Emaar Malls Group. The company's chairman, Mohamed Alabbar, did not provide a specific timeline for the hotels unit's listing, but expressed intention to move forward as soon as possible. This comes after the successful initial public offer of Emaar Malls Group, which raised US$1.6 billion and saw its stock jump 13% after listing.

site_title: JPMorgan says addresses of 76 million households exposed
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. reported a cyber attack that exposed the addresses of 76 million households and 7 million small businesses. The company stated that account information, such as account numbers and passwords, was not compromised. JPMorgan initially denied the breach but later confirmed it after a New York Times report. The attack is one of the largest on record, affecting 83 million customers. The company does not believe account information needs to be changed, and no unusual customer fraud has been reported.

site_title: RBS hires Goldman Sachs to seek buyers for Coutts International: FT
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland has hired Goldman Sachs to find a buyer for Coutts International, a private bank with Queen Elizabeth II as a client, due to financial struggles. RBS intends to retain its UK operations and sell the entire entity, but may allow a buyer to use Coutts' IT system. Coutts International was established in 1692 and is headquartered in Switzerland.

site_title: Caring and sharing
summary: Companies such as City Developments Limited, Shook Lin & Bok LLP, Brocade, and Resorts World Sentosa have expressed their support for the Children for Children initiative, which aims to bring joy to less privileged children in Singapore. The companies are participating in the event to promote equality and opportunities for underprivileged children, with some believing that every child deserves a chance to enjoy Children's Day and pursue their dreams. The initiative encourages children volunteers to make a difference in the lives of their peers and fosters a spirit of caring and sharing.

site_title: FAA to release draft rules on drones soon
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has received nearly a dozen new applications to allow commercial use of drones, bringing the total to 57 exemption applications. The agency plans to publish draft rules to allow broader use by the end of the year. This comes after the approval of six exemptions for film and TV production companies last week, leaving 51 pending. The increase in applications is up from 40 pending when exemptions were approved last week.

site_title: US eases arms embargo against Vietnam for maritime security
summary: The US has partially lifted its 40-year-old arms embargo on Vietnam to improve maritime security, allowing for the future transfer of defense articles. The decision follows some progress by Vietnam on human rights issues, including the release of 11 political prisoners. However, sales of specific weapons will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Next chief of Sias being prepped for role
summary: David Gerald, CEO of the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (Sias), is preparing to step down within the next 3-5 years. He has identified at least three potential successors, who will be vetted through various roles, including meeting investors, resolving issues, and demonstrating media savvy. Gerald emphasizes the importance of a successor who can effectively represent the interests of retail investors and is willing to roll up their sleeves to address concerns.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Universal Studios Singapore's Halloween Horror Nights 4 kicks off on Oct 3, featuring a 3D horror house, haunted houses, and scare zones. The event runs for 13 nights and offers various ticket options. Other events include the Liquid Architecture exhibition, da:ns festival 2014's Swan Lake, and "Something Very Far Away" at the Esplanade Recital Studio. Local artist Yukinori Yanagi's art exhibition "Money/Flower" is also on display at the Michael Janssen gallery until Oct 9. Various ticket prices and details are available online for these events.

site_title: Carriers, Kenya govt oppose Mombasa cargo tax
summary: Kenya's government and carriers oppose a proposed tax on cargo at Mombasa port, citing concerns it will increase import prices and reduce competitiveness. The local authority had proposed the tax to generate revenue, but officials say it could undermine recent customs reforms that have improved efficiency and reduced costs. The government aims to maintain Mombasa's position as a key trade hub in the region.

site_title: Working on more ways to boost ties
summary: Korean Ambassador to Singapore Suh Chung-ha has highlighted significant progress in promoting bilateral ties between the two countries. Key developments include the opening of a MedTech Development Centre in Biopolis, joint research and development projects, and the establishment of the Korea IT Cooperation Centre. Accumulated Korean investments in Singapore reached US$6.13 billion as of June 2014. Korean construction companies have also won tenders for several Singapore projects. People-to-people exchanges have increased, with 13.3% more Singapore visitors to Korea in 2013 compared to 2012. The two countries will also host the Asean-Korea Commemorative Summit in Busan in December, with Singapore playing a key role in elevating their strategic partnership.

site_title: US: Wall St ends flat, small caps rebound in volatile day
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday, rebounding from a 1% drop earlier in the session, with energy stocks leading the recovery. The S&P 500 closed with a 0.01 point gain, its smallest since April 2013, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.02%. Small-cap stocks also reversed direction, with the Russell 2000 up 1%. The day's volatility was driven by concerns over economic growth and rich valuations, but investors temporarily set aside worries ahead of the September jobs report.

site_title: Tripping the light fantastic
summary: The Singapore International Photography Festival has opened at various museums, showcasing the diverse and complex world of contemporary photography. The festival features a triple-bill at SAM at 8Q, "Still Moving: A Triple Bill On The Image," with works by prominent photographers such as Andreas Gursky, Hiroshi Sugimoto, and Gerhard Richter. The exhibition includes photography and video works from South-east Asia, the Deutsche Bank Collection, and the Yokohama Museum of Art, exploring various styles, strategies, and conceits. The festival runs from October 3 to November 30, with free admission for Singaporeans and permanent residents.

site_title: Rex unit secures deal from national oil firm
summary: Rex International Holdings' Switzerland-based unit, Rexonic AG, has secured a US$10 million contract with a national oil company, valued at 30-380% increase in onshore and offshore oil production. The contract, expected to contribute to the group's earnings for the current financial year, was secured through a wholly owned unit and will start at the end of this year. Rexonic's ultrasonic well stimulation technology will be used on certain wells owned by the client, a "reputed and large" NOC, following months of hard work by the management team.

site_title: Seoul: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Seoul's financial markets are closed on Friday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, in other markets, stocks in Europe and the US edged down, despite reaching record highs earlier in the week. The focus is on US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff threats. In Asia, Singapore stocks have had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and traders are cautiously optimistic despite new Trump threats.

site_title: US plunge sends STI to 4-month low
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted to a four-month low of 3,228.71, shedding 1.08% for its fourth consecutive loss. US stocks tumbled 1.3-1.6% on Wednesday, partly due to weak construction and manufacturing data, which may indicate the US Federal Reserve's tightening monetary policy. Market liquidity remains weak, with low interest and activity in Singapore stocks.

site_title: M'sian petrol, diesel prices up by 9-10%
summary: Malaysia's government raised petrol and diesel prices by 9-10% to meet its budget deficit target of 3.5% of GDP by 2014's end. The move is part of Prime Minister Najib Razak's pledge of fiscal reform, despite low oil prices. The price hikes are expected to cause a one-off inflation spike, potentially curbing consumer spending and business activity.
